X-Originating-IP: [66.128.224.196]

From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 01 Nov 2004 07:51:25 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F74Oc0Ne0PaLI90002c3ed@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 01 Nov 2004 15:52:24.0859 (UTC) FILETIME=[C7ED3EB0:01C4C02A]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RR: Weekend Review...

Good lord - what a weekend.

Started off by rolling down with Mr. Jonas R to Bam's company Halloween 
Party @ Suede where we both spun (alongside Mr.Redstickman, Bam & Nick 
Nyquil, etc.). It was really funny jamming nuskool & tech-funk to a rack of 
little hip-hop loving folks. No less than 10 times I was asked if I had any 
hip-hop. Um, obviously NOT?!!? Whatever - still had a ton of fun and got a 
nice alcoholic buzz on.

Good friends of mine from the DC area who moved to Seattle flew down Friday 
night so's we could all go to Otherworld on Saturday for what turned out to 
be an epic party.

On to the Otherworld...we rolled in @ 10, and other than the delay in 
getting the party going - the party went off like gangbusters. The place was 
packed well into the 5am hour. Music was absolutely off the heezy.

Highlights:
Finally getting to see Shazbot in action...dude, you RIPPED up that hallway. 
Had people grooving all night long, and the beats were on point. I was mad 
impressed, as were my people - and we all thank you for the cd's! (I still 
want a list of vinyl you played there!!!)

El Juan - good lord. I thought I was pretty much over D&B till hearing this 
guy, but he delivered one of the best sets I have heard in AGES! I don't 
know how this guy is not just HUGE by now. My mission is to get him booked 
out east where the junglist massive (as it were) is still huge...

Sutekh, Praxxis & Minor Minor - I'm putting em altogether since they played 
one after another, and dropped some of the sickest techno I have ever 
witnessed. Hard-hitting, but totally danceable - none of that sparse, cold 
crap here - all bass rumbling, pounding techno beats. I would pay good money 
to see any of these DJ's again - especially Sutekh & Minor Minor who just 
devastated the joint. SIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIICKNESS!!!

Azeem & Zeph - These guys sound REALLY polished at this point. Some of the 
best hip-hop I have ever heard live. I'm glad the Otherworld crew are really 
supporting this cat, cuz he is destined to blow up sooner or later, and I 
want to be able to catch him as many times as I can in a setting like the OW 
warehouse while I still can. EXCELLENT!

The OW residents - what can I say? They created a rockin' atmosphere, played 
great music, and once again proved what a crew can accomplish when they bust 
their asses. My hat's off once again...

It was nice to meet/see people from SFR too: Li, Terry, Tyler, Osby, Ryan, 
etc. W00t!

Anyhoo - back to work with me....thanks again everyone!!!

Marc(O)
*THWAP!*//Substructure//Mario Bros.
DC/MD/VA/CA
deep.funky.techy.tribal.progressive.nuskool.beats&bass
AIM:  OPKing138

_________________________________________________________________

get there! http://lifeevents.msn.com/category.aspx?cid=Retirement

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: Weekend (OtherWorld) Review...

quoth Van Mundegaarde:
> Highlights:
> Finally getting to see Shazbot in action...dude, you RIPPED up that
> hallway. Had people grooving all night long, and the beats were on
> point. I was mad impressed, as were my people - and we all thank you
> for the cd's!  (I still want a list of vinyl you played there!!!)

Thanks Marco, it was nice meeting you. Thank to you everyone that packed
the hallway over the course of my 2 and a half hour set--even if I
couldn't see you, I know you were there! And thank you, once again, to
the Otherworld for throwing such a kick-ass Halloween party. They will
surely be missed.

Here's my playlist for the night. The superb UK quirk-house label
U-Freqs definitely wins the award for the most Halloween-appropriate
tracks. :)

Horror Inc. - The Sentinel [Revolver]
Le Grande Boofont - Bulbous [U-Freqs]
DHS - House of God [DHS Remix]
Reinhard Voigt - Protekt [Kompakt Extra]
Justin Maxwell - Garrulous [Palette]
John Tejada & Arian Leviste - Psycho Happiness [Palette]
John Spring - Do You Like That? [Sub Static]
Big Hair - If I Was a Psycho Killer... [U-Freqs]
Big Hair - Wha' Appen??? [U-Freqs]
I-f - Playstation #2 [Viewlexx]
Carl Craig - Tres Demented [Planet E]
John Shananigans - Charlie's on the Dancefloor [Cynosure]
Jacob London - Escape From Horror House [U-Freqs]
Brian Aneurysm - Succubus [Sub Static]
Ricardo vs. Jay - Cactus Love [Contexterrior]
Akufen - FORCEPT1:FR:01:V1 [Concept]
Mike Shannon - Shogun [Pacific Technics]
Horror Inc. - I Plead Guilty [Perlon]
Omni A.M. & Casey Hogan - In Time of Flying [Euphoria]
Guido Schneider - Moved [Poker Flat]
Circulation - Grey (Nathan Larsen's Doric Reply) [Hooj]
Gideon & Rob H. - Seduction [LHB]
Joel Mull - Dish [Truesoul]
2 Dollar Egg - #5 Lebt [Nummer]
2 Dollar Egg - Graphit [Klang]
Kero - Motorcity Mold [Bpitch Control]
Mike Shannon - Suspiction [Logistic]
Dandy Jack & The Latin Flava - Ein File FÃ¼r Derrick [Perlon]
Stereofuse - Hot Slot [Salo]
False - .wav Pool [Plus 8]
Chris Udo - The Next Stop (Barcode Remix) [Oblong]
Spektrum - Freakbox (Richie Hawtin's Uncontrolled Edit) [Playhouse]
L'usine - Push [Ghostly International]
Justin Maxwell - Bebop Cola [Palette]

Much love,

Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV12daQYrVjYK000130cd@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 01 Nov 2004 20:03:00.0640 (UTC) FILETIME=[C9F35A00:01C4C04D]

Subject: [sfraves] OtherWorld :: RIP :: Pictures

------=_NextPart_000_0025_01C4C00A.BE241C20
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Pictures :: http://www.sninesix.com/otherworld_halloween04/

OtherWorld just keeps outdoing itself. So much thought and effort into =
the decorations and setup. 4 rooms of sound and such a diverse lineup. I =
heard it all genre wise. I can't say I really heard anything bad either. =
Doing sound for a room that was 90% live PA was interesting. Thanks to =
one of the performers things went a lot better. It's nice when everyone =
playing works together to sort out their problems. Carrying 4 stacks of =
sound to the overflow space upstairs is not something I want to do =
again. Hell, we have to go their tonight and tear it all down and load =
up the van again. Ugh. I have to say that over all the party was a blast =
and it felt like it went forever. It was a chill night for me. No =
climbing walls. No trying to get into the power panel. I think I =
wandered so much that night that I must have walked over 5 miles. Really =
good night of techno. I'm not a big fan of it, but what I heard that =
night was all consistantly good. It was great to see so many people =
really dancing and into the party. I'd say they easily had 500 people in =
there that night. When it was the peak hour it was chaos. I love that. I =
love when all the rooms and hallways are just jammed with people. So =
much more exciting. I loved the trees with the hands reaching out in the =
main room. Those were cool. Oh and the stuffed animal hallway. That was =
funny shit. =3D)

Good to see a lot of familiar faces that night. =3D)

:: r y a n ::


------=_NextPart_000_0025_01C4C00A.BE241C20--

----- Original Message -----
From: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, November 01, 2004 12:03 PM
Subject: [sfraves] OtherWorld :: RIP :: Pictures


Pictures :: http://www.sninesix.com/otherworld_halloween04/

OtherWorld just keeps outdoing itself. So much thought and effort into the
decorations and setup. 4 rooms of sound and such a diverse lineup. I heard
it all genre wise. I can't say I really heard anything bad either. Doing
sound for a room that was 90% live PA was interesting. Thanks to one of the
performers things went a lot better. It's nice when everyone playing works
together to sort out their problems. Carrying 4 stacks of sound to the
overflow space upstairs is not something I want to do again. Hell, we have
to go their tonight and tear it all down and load up the van again. Ugh. I
have to say that over all the party was a blast and it felt like it went
forever. It was a chill night for me. No climbing walls. No trying to get
into the power panel. I think I wandered so much that night that I must have
walked over 5 miles. Really good night of techno. I'm not a big fan of it,
but what I heard that night was all consistantly good. It was great to see
so many people really dancing and into the party. I'd say they easily had
500 people in there that night. When it was the peak hour it was chaos. I
love that. I love when all the rooms and hallways are just jammed with
people. So much more exciting. I loved the trees with the hands reaching out
in the main room. Those were cool. Oh and the stuffed animal hallway. That
was funny shit. =)

Good to see a lot of familiar faces that night. =)

:: r y a n ::




---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


Massive Selector and Club Six present San Francisco with the Get Selected 
Finals: SELECTION DAY, taking place on Friday, November 3 at 9PM inside 
Club Six central headquarters.  Hiphop battle up top, house mix-off down 
low.  Finalists from the August and October Get Selected primaries have 
advanced to compete in this ultimate showdown to become San Francisco's 
next hot DJ to the clubs.  Who's going to win?  After casting your vote on 
Tuesday, rock your vote on Friday!  Here are the candidates:

The Grand Ole' Hiphop Party:
DJ Solace
G-Fresh
C-Kryt
DJ Marz

The Future Electronica Party:
DJ Steve Madera
Bernard Thomas
DJ Kevin B
Joe Encarnacion

Special guest judges/DJs:
JESSE SAUNDERS, JBoogie, and SAKE-ONE

PRICE: free b4 11pm,
$5 after
TIME: 10pm-4am
MUSIC: Hip-Hop, Soul, Dancehall, & House

ATTENTION DJS!!!  We are looking for more competitors to try and topple the 
champs in this mix-off.  Winners of this competition will earn a chance to 
spin at Club Six's New Year's Eve bash (draws 1000 deep each year!), a Club 
Six DJ residency in 2005, free vinyl, gift certificates, and top-notch 
audio equipment.  If you are interested in competing, come to the open 
auditions at Club Six on Wednesday, November 3 at 7PM sharp!  For more 
info, email 
<mailto:whowantstobeadj@clubsix1.com>whowantstobeadj@clubsix1.com .  WE 
WANT YOU!




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Homeland Security Agents Visit Toy Store

--=====================_13046920==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Homeland Security Agents Visit Toy Store


Oct 28, 5:20 PM (ET)

ST. HELENS, Ore. (AP) - So far as she knows, Pufferbelly Toys owner 
Stephanie Cox hasn't been passing any state secrets to sinister foreign 
governments, or violating obscure clauses in the Patriot Act.

So she was taken aback by a mysterious phone call from the U.S. Department 
of Homeland Security to her small store in this quiet Columbia River town 
just north of Portland.

"I was shaking in my shoes," Cox said of the September phone call. "My 
first thought was the government can shut your business down on a whim, in 
my opinion. If I'm closed even for a day that would cause undue stress."

When the two agents arrived at the store, the lead agent asked Cox whether 
she carried a toy called the Magic Cube, which he said was an illegal copy 
of the Rubik's Cube, one of the most popular toys of all time.

He told her to remove the Magic Cube from her shelves, and he watched to 
make sure she complied.

After the agents left, Cox called the manufacturer of the Magic Cube, the 
Toysmith Group, which is based in Auburn, Wash. A representative told her 
that Rubik's Cube patent had expired, and the Magic Cube did not infringe 
on the rival toy's trademark.

Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement, said 
agents went to Pufferbelly based on a trademark infringement complaint 
filed in the agency's intellectual property rights center in Washington, D.C.

"One of the things that our agency's responsible for doing is protecting 
the integrity of the economy and our nation's financial systems and 
obviously trademark infringement does have significant economic 
implications," she said.

Six weeks after her brush with Homeland Security, Cox told The Oregonian 
she is still bewildered by the experience.

"Aren't there any terrorists out there?" she said.

---

Information from: The Oregonian



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Conversations with voters

	These snippets of conversations with voters from an activist urging 
people to "end the war in Iraq" while passing out fliers for 
Libertarian presidential candidate Michael Badnarik:

A lady said: "I'm with you. I'm voting for Kerry."
Me: "Kerry will expand the war."
Lady: "Kerry will end the war."
Me: "That's not what he said."
Lady: "Do you believe everything you hear?"

	Vote for my candidate because he's lying. What can one say to a 
response like that?

Another voter said: "Who's this guy?"
Me: "He's Michael Badnarik."
Voter: "I don't know who he is."
Me: "Well, read about him here."
Voter: "It's very hard to change."

	Yes, we've noticed. That's what we're here to help with.   8)   Vote 
Libertarian and win a free country!

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] bsp - new mix by apot - aberration - hard trance/dark nrg

--0-1726935666-1099422201=:16586
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

hello... i recently recorded a new mix on september 19, 2004 and wanted to share it with everyone on the list... it's a blend of some of my favorite classics and some pretty new releases from the past year; one of my best works so far... it's hard trance/dark nrg, 15 tracks, and runs 75:30 long...
 
aberration
mixed by apot
hard trance/dark nrg
abysmal frequencies 2004
email: djapot@yahoo.com
web: http://www.djapot.com/
 
01 - o.g.r. - daydreamer [tidy white]
02 - bulldozer - going ballistic [project five]
03 - rubec - concentration [hard trax]
04 - nick sentience - freedom [nukleuz]
05 - paul glazby - you won't last [frantic]
06 - tomo & tuffcub - ace [nukleuz]
07 - fatboy slim - the rockafeller skank (unknown remix) [fat records]
08 - stimulant djs - scream & shout (guyver remix) [stimulant records]
09 - project mayhem - take hold (james lawson & justin bourne remix) [short circuit]
10 - barely legal - the future (colin barratt remix) [synapse]
11 - the edison factor - the curse of voodoo ray [nukleuz]
12 - dmf - palpitation [recharge]
13 - ali wilson & matt smallwood - just listen [vicious circle]
14 - lab-4 - pump it [fragile]
15 - lab-4 - 4th floor [tidy]
 
graphic design by miss du franco
mastered by tim moriarty - dj delphis (skills, f-8/reverb)
recorded live using two technics 1200 turntables and a vestax mixer
 
this mix is available for dowload on my website at
http://www.djapot.com/mixes/mixes.html
(right-click on the link below the cover image and select *save target as...*)
or through the direct link:
http://www.djapot.com/mixes/apot%20-%20aberration/apot%20-%20aberration.mp3
 
comments, feedback, and reviews are always appreciated... if you would like a hard copy, please contact me privately... thanx for your interest and support, hope you enjoy...
 
 
cheers,
 
apot.

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:

"i am so mad."
"why, ig?"
"everytime i try to write to you, the arrow is moving
around on my screen all by itself."
"that happens sometimes. done with your candy?"
"for now.  i need more. i am writing to supa to place
my holiday order."
"sounds good. get some sausages too."
"okay. is there anything else i can do for you?"
"no, that is it for now. do you want to keep having a
conversation."
"not really. let's just  talk later. okay?"
"okay. bye." :)

it's almost 8 in the morning, the day after the election, and it ain't over 
yet!  CNN shows Bush with 254 electoral votes and Kerry 252. 

Something seems fishy. The turnout was 7 million more than last time, and a 
larger turnout normally skews the results more toward the Demos. Earlier in the 
day, according to CNN commentators, Republicans seemed depressed that Bush 
seemed headed toward defeat. Exit polls indicated that Kerry would win handily, 
almost a landslide. 

Through it all, Bush wore a smirk -- just like he did in the last election, 
when somehow he "knew" he would win Florida. 

It feels like his friends at Diebold were tweaking the results so he would 
just barely win the key states. After all, the head of Diebold promised him a 
victory, didn't he? That's what someone told me. 

To me it's just inconceivable that Kerry could do worse than Gore. With 
Bush's terrible performance in office, with much more of a buzz about Kerry than 
there was with Gore, with Michael Moore and Al Franken and everyone else 
pointing out Bush's failures ... how could Bush possibly win?  

Do we want to live in a country where the majority of the people would vote 
for someone like that? It's really depressing. I'm so disappointed in the 
people of this country. 

Who wants to start an SF Raves "cell" in Vancouver?  ;)   (getting out my ski 
jacket)

--part1_1dc.2f1c2605.2eba5963_boundary--

SOBs, the need to seek re-election, is now gone; leaving them not the 
slightest reason NOT to grind the people of this country under their 
heel.  Look for expanded and extended versions of the, PATRIOT act, 
rave act, DMCA, TIPS, Carnivore, etc.  Look for protest to be outlawed, 
except for their "free speech zones".  Look for media that disagrees to 
be marginalized by the FCC, and forced off the air, as with Howard 
Stern's departure to satellite radio.

I wonder how long he'll wait before he reinstates the draft?

I've been saying this for days... and while it may seem ridiculous,
it's all very possible in theory.

I was thinking to myself last night while I sat at the laundrymat,
glued to the TV. If we assume that 50% of Californians are democratic,
what percentage of those people would support the idea of California
claiming independence?

We generate 1/3 of the nation's money. We could easily operate as an
independent country. We have the most fertile lands, the most
open-minded citizens, the best technology.

The other option is organizing a militia (liberals with firearms
unite!) and just starting a civil war. But I think Bush would like
that too much.

I'm nominating myself for President of California!

The revolution will not be televised, so get out there on the streets.

Over 30 communities are demonstrating tomorrow no matter the outcome of 
today for an end to the war and to build a real democracy! way to go! check 
out www.beyondvoting.org

Also check out No Stolen Elections: www.nov3.us and This Time We're 
Watching www.ttww.org !!

Lots of stuff happening in cities and towns everywhere--it will surely be a 
very interesting next 24 hours! And apparently demonstrations in the UK and 
Baghdad too?!

From: info@beyondvoting.org
Date: Tue Nov 2, 2004  2:39:05 PM America/New_York
To: undisclosed-recipients: ;
Subject: Networking & Conference Call Tonight 9:30EST

Networking & Conference Call Tonight 9:30EST

The Beyond Voting campaign is thrilled to announce that no matter who wins
the presidential election, there will be mobilizations in the name of
justice and democracy occurring in over 30 cities nationwide!  Your city is
listed as one of these on our website [BeyondVoting.org] and you are listed
as one of the contacts.  If any of our information is incorrect, please let
us know.

The Beyond Voting campaign is coordinated through a decentralized 
grassroots network of
local organizations organizing around the elections, regardless of the
winner, emphasizing that we all share a powerful and clear demand:
democracy not empire.  The campaign supports local organizing through
shared resources and networking ­ which we would like you to take part in!

The following are some immediate ways you can participate:


TUESDAY CONFERENCE CALL
On Tuesday, November 02, Beyond Voting will be hosting a conference call for
us all to check-in.  The call will be a quick 45 minute go-around of actions
in different places, updates, and discussion.  There won't be any heavy
decision making: just sharing, exchanging, and feeling connected.  Start
Time: 9:30p.m. Eastern Std Time (6:30PST).  Dial-in Number: 1-805-620-4000
(Ventura, CA)  Participant Access Code: 20041103


TEXT MESSAGE ALERTS
The Michigan IMC will be sending text message alerts with vital information.
  To sign up, visit:
http://voip.radicaldesigns.org/subscribe.php?organization_ID=6


NETWORKING LISTSERVE
Currently around 14 of us from different cities are using an email listserve
to network and share resources.  If you would like to be added to this
listserve, respond to this email and you will be added.


MEDIA CONTACTS
Already we have had contact from many media sources asking for local
contacts.  If you would like to get your message out, please provide us
with a media contact for your event, including full name and phone number.
These will be displayed on our press releases and at BeyondVoting.org


CONTACT DATABASE
We have compiled a useful excel spreadsheet of Beyond Voting contacts that
can be sorted by city or state.  Let us know and we'll send you a copy.


STAY IN CONTACT!
Much will happen these next days and it will be important to stay connected
and show the scope of people power in our nation.  Make sure to keep in
contact by sending up reports of how your events worked out.  Photos and
video would be especially helpful ­ a section of BeyondVoting.org will be
set up for reports from actions nationwide.


TALKING POINTS
Below you'll find some talking points courtesy of the smartMeme strategy &
training project that will be handy to have ready for reporters and
skeptics.  We have a larger lists of messaging we can send.

_________________________________________________________________

November 3: Beyond Voting Core Messages and Talking Points
Prepared  for beyondvoting.org
Nov 3 2004

Tips:
1) Be calm, and passionate. Speak from your heart and your own experience.
2) Its not about the question they ask. It's about creating a real
democracy
3) Everything is on-the-record.

Core Messages

       We're here to defend the rights of everyone to vote and participate in
democracy--to have their vote counted and to have real choices and real
power to make the decisions that affect our world and our lives.

       Voting is just the first step, and today is just the beginning!
There is
so much more to Democracy than voting on Nov 2­that's why we're going
beyond voting on Nov 3 to demonstrate what real democracy looks like.

       Some of the most important issues facing our country and our lives 
are not
being addressed by the 2 candidates, and we are taking to the streets to
demand real social change in America:

       Nov 2 we went to the polls Nov 3 we are going to the streets. We stand
united on the day after the election for peace, democracy and global
justice, and united against an empire agenda of aggression abroad and
repression at home.



What is "Beyond Voting"?
Beyond Voting is a decentralized grassroots effort to demonstrate what real
democracy looks like in cities and towns all over the country the day after
the election. Today there are over 30 groups around the country doing what
we are doing here today­gathering together as neighbors and working
together for change beyond Nov 2, because getting rid of Bush is just the
beginning of the fight to take our democracy back.

Because the crisis of our democracy didn't start yesterday and it won't end
tomorrow. Beyond Voting is part of the history of grassroots struggle, for
suffrage, for civil rights, for the environment­the history of people
working together at the grassroots level to make democracy happen.


Isn't it undemocratic to be protesting the outcome of an election?
We're demonstrating for a real democracy.  There's more to democracy than
just a once a year choice between 2 rich white guys who have many of the
same opinions.  We're also highlighting the deep flaws in our electoral
process ­ from Big Money donors buying the candidates, to rampant voter
disenfranchisement.  Democracy is more than voting at the ballot box, it is
mobilizing in our communities to have control over the decisions that effect
our lives: our jobs, health care, education, are all under attack by the
Empire agenda of the Bush Administration and we're in the streets to say --
Democracy not empire!

How do you respond when people accuse you of being sore losers?
The real losers today are those who were intimidated and disenfranchised at
the pollsthe 45 million who go without healthcarethe 1000 families who
have lost a loved one in Iraqthe 100,000 Iraqi families who have lost
loved ones in this brutal war

What is the definition of a stolen election?
This election was stolen from millions of black and Latino voters who are
disenfranchised by the system. Lets not forget whose land we are standing
on­this country was stolen in 1492! So when we talk about stolen elections,
let's be clear, that the majority of people don't vote, and millions can't
vote­that this system has historically denied women, African American, and
politically marginalized communities a voice in the process

Isn't America a republic, not a democracy?
America is a country with a dark past of genocide of native peoples, slavery
and the vast majority of people (except rich white men) being denied the
right to vote.  200 years of grassroots movements struggling for justice
have given women, African Americans and others the vote.  However we are
still seeing efforts to prevent people voting and to give them still have
massive disenfranchisement of people trapped in America's growing prison
system. The mobilizations around the country on Nov 3 are part of this
ongoing effort to make America a real democracy by building grassroots
movements for democracy, peace and justice.



====================
Doyle Canning
doyle@smartmeme.com
802.860.1155--office
802.999.7502--mobile
====================
19 Church St. Suite 07
Burlington, VT 05401 USA

strategy & training resources, values based communication tools, and "meme" 
campaigning....
visit online: http://www.smartmeme.com

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

heh.. well while i was traveling around the world for
the better part of this last year, after revealing that
i was in fact american (to which the general response
was that i was one of the most unamerican americans
they had met--thanks!), eventually everyone asked what
i thought of bush and the (then) upcoming elections..

to which my response was, should bush win in november i
am moving out of the country... most people would laugh
and say, well there is no way that he would win again,
right? (i think the world gives americans as a group
too much credit, thinking that we would be smart enough
to realize what a douche bag bush is) i had to point
out that i came from a part of the country that
generally speaking is more educated and progressive
than middle america... and unfortunately a lot of
americans are ignorant and dont take the time to look
for unbiased media and news, therefore they just lap up
the bullshit bush propaganda and take it for honest to
god truth.. 

well, i suppose that if nothing else, bush has made an
honest woman out of me ;) though i cant say that i was
going to stick around even if he had lost.. 

love and hugs and kisses,
tina

http://moonchyld1.livejournal.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed

At 01:01 PM 11/3/2004, goofrider wrote:
>OMG That's fucking hilarious!!!!
>
>
>On Wed, 3 Nov 2004 13:00:04 -0800 (PST), Delia <velouria83@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > *shivers*
> >http://letsriot.com/stuff/new_map.jpg



I spent all my free time the last couple of months talking to people in 
"Jesusland."  Deliberately placed myself on lists where Republican and 
other points of view were well represented.  I believed that talking with 
folks who believed the same things I do would be unproductive and wasteful.

I learned quickly that I had to divest myself of the elitism about religion 
that defines the "United States of Canada" or whatever you want to call our 
haven of secularism.  You can blame the Brits for unloading the Puritans on 
us, but fact is their beliefs rule the middle of the country and they rule us.

I thought I would be talking about politics, the problems in Iraq, and 
economic philosophy.  Nope.  Aside from a pervasive fear that these people 
in Jesusland shared of Arab heathens storming their white picket fences -- 
and that fear was palpable -- all we talked about was the Bible.

Now I was trained in prep school by Jesuits and so am well prepared to talk 
Jesus.  I've studied the New Testament in Latin and Greek and am still 
good, I discovered, at doing biblical exegesis.  The only inroads I made 
with these people was by staying on one important message:  Jesus' core 
message was love and compassion.  Actually, though I'm not a Christian 
these days, I'm in agreement with this message and can talk about it with 
passion because love and compassion are core beliefs of mine.

I discovered many Christians who were anguishing about the 100,000 civilian 
deaths in Iraq;  who were conflicted on the issue of war and violence;  and 
were open to my peace and love deal.

Problem with many liberals is that we approach these Christians, many of 
whom are intelligent and very strong believers in Christ's teachings, with 
arrogance:  that is, your beliefs are trash;  we atheists or whatever, are 
cooler than thou;  and you're stupid for believing in this superstitious 
trash.

Any political inroads in Jesusland must be accompanied by creative, and I 
believe, proper use of the New Testament.

Finally, anything can happen in the next four years.  When Nixon was 
elected for a second term I was in despair, as I am now.  But....Watergate 
came along.  This war in Iraq is going south fast as is the economy in the 
long run under the monkey who spends and cuts taxes.  There will be a 
battle on the right on these very issues and there will be hell to pay 
whoever won this election.  Believe in serendipity, 'cause it rules the 
universe.

And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his hubris in going down hard 
before the end of his term, and I intend to do everything I can to 
facilitate this.

Leave the country.  Fuck no.  It's MY country too and I'm not one to be 
defeated.  "Hasta la victoria siempre!"

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_10537231==.ALT--

>> white picket fences -- 
>> and that fear was palpable -- all we talked about
>> was the Bible.
>>
>> Now I was trained in prep school by Jesuits and so
>> am well prepared to talk
>> Jesus.  I've studied the New Testament in Latin and
>> Greek and am still
>> good, I discovered, at doing biblical exegesis.  The
>> only inroads I made
>> with these people was by staying on one important
>> message:  Jesus' core
>> message was love and compassion.  Actually, though
>> I'm not a Christian
>> these days, I'm in agreement with this message and
>> can talk about it with
>> passion because love and compassion are core beliefs
>> of mine.
>>
>> I discovered many Christians who were anguishing
>> about the 100,000 civilian
>> deaths in Iraq;  who were conflicted on the issue of
>> war and violence;  and
>> were open to my peace and love deal.
>>
>> Problem with many liberals is that we approach these
>> Christians, many of
>> whom are intelligent and very strong believers in
>> Christ's teachings, with
>> arrogance:  that is, your beliefs are trash;  we
>> atheists or whatever, are
>> cooler than thou;  and you're stupid for believing
>> in this superstitious
>> trash.
>>
>> Any political inroads in Jesusland must be
>> accompanied by creative, and I
>> believe, proper use of the New Testament.
>>
>> Finally, anything can happen in the next four years.
>>  When Nixon was
>> elected for a second term I was in despair, as I am
>> now.  But....Watergate
>> came along.  This war in Iraq is going south fast as
>> is the economy in the
>> long run under the monkey who spends and cuts taxes.
>>  There will be a
>> battle on the right on these very issues and there
>> will be hell to pay
>> whoever won this election.  Believe in serendipity,
>> 'cause it rules the
>> universe.
>>
>> And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his
>> hubris in going down hard
>> before the end of his term, and I intend to do
>> everything I can to
>> facilitate this.
>>
>> Leave the country.  Fuck no.  It's MY country too
>> and I'm not one to be
>> defeated.  "Hasta la victoria siempre!"
>>
>> Love,
>>
>> Apollo
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>>
>> House Music 101:
>>
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>>
>>
>> "The government, which was designed for the people,
>> has got into the hands
>> of the bosses and their employers, the special
>> interests.  An invisible
>> empire has been set up above the forms of
>> democracy."
>> -Woodrow Wilson
>>
>> "There are times when you have to obey a call which
>> is the highest of all,
>> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such
>> obedience may cost many a
>> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends,
>> from family, from the
>> state to which you may belong, from all that you
>> have held as dear as life
>> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>>   - Gandhi
>>
>> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic
>> organization are ahead of the
>> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that
>> will gradually become
>> visible."
>> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>>
>>
>>

Subject: [sfraves] CANABASS was So Dope lastnight

OK... perfect like ummm... ok, not vent, oh oh oh,..
release from my after class activity!!  Oh Yeah!!  OK..
I do like totally have 2 say that LoL.. I was like
totally expecting 2 go 2 like the "old" location of
Bench and Bar.. but OK.. this was a NEW Bench And Bar..
Oh My Gosh man.. Love IT!!  So Dope!!  LoL...I was
hella bein' nostalgic when like Miki, Ryan, Aryck, & I
all met up @ Mad Hatter back in the day @ the old
location... LoL...

OK... DJs of the night.. when i 1st got there, Happy
was finishing up his set... nice nice nice.. Loved it! 
Lewt went on next.. ok ok ok .. I dunno.. I wasn't
really attentive during most all sets... like every1
who spun that night were Dope alota good tunes.. hard,
raga, I didn't really hear any dub lastnight... Kaela,
Cubehead, DOS... they were all Dope!!!

But OK.. yeah.. Megatron's like 1 of my closest homie &
ofcourse I'll say taht I did Love his set
aloooooooot!!!  LoL... Even the bartender did also! I
guess he started out kinda dubby.. can't really
remember.. but like after a while of his set.. it all
of a sudden went HARD DNB & I was like Heeeeeeeeeello
2Day... I ran 2 the florr again & had 2 Groovy where i
kinda remeained the rest of his set!!  It was So
Dope!!!  I mean... LoL.. I Loved all the vocal Jungle
he dropped & it was just like ummm... Jump Up Hard Shit
that he spin all throughout the rest of his set that I
LOVED!!!  Wow!!  LoL.. seriously.. I only recognized 1
Mega tune like during his whole set & Wow... he did
spin like all these new tracks I don't remember him
spinning like last time i heard him spin Jungle!!  & I
swear I thought i heard Mega talkin' in a Jamacian
accent when he 1st got 2 the club!!!  Oh My Goodness,
Ya Mon! LMAO

It was a good night mos def!!  Alota people did show
up!!  Oh My Goodness man.. So dope!!!  Had the best
time hangin' w/ every1!!  I do see this blowingup &
well.. people have no reason 2 complain there ain't
shit happening in the East Bay 'cause now there is! 
Granted Jungle doesn't tickle every1's fancy, but
man... So Dope.. I really had the mondo best time of
the week thus far...  with how Groovy things went
lastnight... I do see this event takin' off lik mondo
soon!!  YAY!!

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 59311 invoked from network); 4 Nov 2004 00:30:36 -0000
Message-ID: <20041104003032.33849.qmail@web51705.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 2004 16:30:32 -0800 (PST)
From: matthew johnson <mpj_bay@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20041104001924.64334.qmail@web21523.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: History of mixtapes in the rave scene

I do not have a link to anything written about this
but I started going out way before this music was
mainstream, i.e. the first time I heard house/acid
house/techno whatever first played in a public place
was back in '94 on Height. 

In my underground career, mixed tapes seem to appear
in the 80's. Mostly DJ's just making tapes for thier
friends and clubs recording to hand out free or to
sell as party memories. These tapes got duped and
given to friends of friends. Not sure the exact year
but in the late 80's early 90's DJ's were selling
tapes for a number of reasons. 
1. to learn new records
2. to make money to buy more records
3. to get thier name out
4. give to friend
5. demo's for gigs. 

I am sure this goes back to the disco days some how
but I just missed that era.

Hope this helps. Someone correct me if I'm wrong. 
Maybe I should write an article on this. Let me know
if you need more specific info and I will find it for
you.

=)
Matt

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr new map of us

quoth Apollo:
> Problem with many liberals is that we approach these Christians, many
> of whom are intelligent and very strong believers in Christ's
> teachings, with arrogance:  that is, your beliefs are trash;  we
> atheists or whatever, are cooler than thou;  and you're stupid for
> believing in this superstitious trash.
> 
> Any political inroads in Jesusland must be accompanied by creative,
> and I believe, proper use of the New Testament.

That's what sucks though! Rather than using facts, logic and reason, we
have to relate every issue to a book written thousands of years ago.
Religion exists everywhere on this planet, but it seems that only in
America (and ironically, the fundamentalist Middle East) are the
majority of people simply unwilling to frame any issue outside the
context of their faith.

I only wish I had the opportunity to explain to a Christian
fundamentalist how my disbelief in God is only *confirmed* by the 4
years running up to last night's election: seriously, what God would
allow somebody like George Bush to become president in the first place,
let alone get re-elected after what he's done thus far? I think anyone
who interprets the Bible literally should take a good, hard look at all
of Bush's policies (and the actions of the Republicans that support
him), then re-evaluate their support for a man that wages endless
immoral war, cuts social programs for poor Americans while indebting
future generations with huge tax breaks for the rich, and ravages the
environment at the behest of the energy industry.

I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as far
as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's fucking
depressing.

> Finally, anything can happen in the next four years.  When Nixon was
> elected for a second term I was in despair, as I am now.
> But....Watergate came along.  This war in Iraq is going south fast as
> is the economy in the long run under the monkey who spends and cuts
> taxes.  There will be a battle on the right on these very issues and
> there will be hell to pay whoever won this election.  Believe in
> serendipity, 'cause it rules the universe.

I find even serendipity hard to believe in these days. Bush is the
Teflon President; every single one of his mistakes and misdeeds has been
deflected, then more often than not dishonestly projected onto his
opponents and critics. The Republicans, rather than losing seats in
Congress as a result of their bitter partisanship and rancor, gained a
larger majority. Corporate America get richer every day, at the expense
of our middle and lower classes, the environment, and Iraqi citizens.
The media continues to prefer pitting pundits against each other and
calling it "news" instead of reporting the facts against either side.
Karma's going to be a serious BITCH if it ever gets back to these
people.

> And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his hubris in going down
> hard before the end of his term, and I intend to do everything I can
> to facilitate this.

Me too. I also started visiting conservative blogs a couple of weeks ago
in an attempt to talk to sense into the people that think George Bush is
a "compassionate conservative", or some other such bullshit. I don't
think it's about relating to religion. Most of the time, I've found
reasonable people who are willing to have civil discussions as long as
you show some respect for them. That's what's missing in politics today,
and my hope is that Bush may yet live up to his promise of being a
"uniter" in his second term.

Unfortunately I think the President will point to this election as a
mandate to enact even more radical policies that will divide the
American electorate even further, if that's possible. We can look
forward to more misguided national education reforms; the privatization
of major public services, including Social Security; renewed attacks on
the civil rights of gays; the continued illegal imprisonment and torture
of both American citizens and foreign nationals; the further dismantling
of important regulatory agencies like the EPA, FDA, HHS, and the Labor
Department; and more tax cuts for the wealthy at the expense of our
nation's poor.

As much as I'd like to say that none of these things affects me, I
can't. And to any potential voters that sat out this year because you
couldn't decide or just don't care, I implore you: educate yourself.
Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. Learn the
facts about the issues that affect your everyday life and those of your
fellow citizens. Register to vote, and cast your ballot based on those
issues. Voting is what makes our democracy work, and as long as you sit
on the sidelines, your country will continue to elect people without
your interests in mind. Bottom line: you can't complain if you don't
inform yourself and vote your conscience.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

You wanna hear something really sad that happened to me this week? My 
brother and I, arguably the more "left" of the family, got IM's from my 
neice (who is a mere 14) - who was absloutely TERRIFIED because people were 
voting for John Kerry. She was under the impression that if Kerry won, we'd 
all be in concentration camps under the thumb of militant Muslim warlords in 
the next couple of years. Basically, the rhetoric of fear that Bush's 
"America" is cramming down our throats on a consistant basis is starting 
take hold even in the least likely of places. Both my brother and I were 
sickened by this, and heartbroken that our neice (who is otherwise quite 
intelligent) had been bamboozled by this crap. Bush is doing damage in 
places I never thought he could get to. I swear - there has GOT to be SOME 
way of impeaching this asshat before he pulls a "Rome" on our asses and my 
neices fears are realized....

I know - not exactly on topic, but it seems to fit in with todays events.

> quoth Apollo:
>> Problem with many liberals is that we approach these Christians, many
>> of whom are intelligent and very strong believers in Christ's
>> teachings, with arrogance:  that is, your beliefs are trash;  we
>> atheists or whatever, are cooler than thou;  and you're stupid for
>> believing in this superstitious trash.
>>
>> Any political inroads in Jesusland must be accompanied by creative,
>> and I believe, proper use of the New Testament.
>
> That's what sucks though! Rather than using facts, logic and reason, we
> have to relate every issue to a book written thousands of years ago.
> Religion exists everywhere on this planet, but it seems that only in
> America (and ironically, the fundamentalist Middle East) are the
> majority of people simply unwilling to frame any issue outside the
> context of their faith.
>
> I only wish I had the opportunity to explain to a Christian
> fundamentalist how my disbelief in God is only *confirmed* by the 4
> years running up to last night's election: seriously, what God would
> allow somebody like George Bush to become president in the first place,
> let alone get re-elected after what he's done thus far? I think anyone
> who interprets the Bible literally should take a good, hard look at all
> of Bush's policies (and the actions of the Republicans that support
> him), then re-evaluate their support for a man that wages endless
> immoral war, cuts social programs for poor Americans while indebting
> future generations with huge tax breaks for the rich, and ravages the
> environment at the behest of the energy industry.
>
> I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
> ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
> it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
> Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as far
> as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's fucking
> depressing.
>
>> Finally, anything can happen in the next four years.  When Nixon was
>> elected for a second term I was in despair, as I am now.
>> But....Watergate came along.  This war in Iraq is going south fast as
>> is the economy in the long run under the monkey who spends and cuts
>> taxes.  There will be a battle on the right on these very issues and
>> there will be hell to pay whoever won this election.  Believe in
>> serendipity, 'cause it rules the universe.
>
> I find even serendipity hard to believe in these days. Bush is the
> Teflon President; every single one of his mistakes and misdeeds has been
> deflected, then more often than not dishonestly projected onto his
> opponents and critics. The Republicans, rather than losing seats in
> Congress as a result of their bitter partisanship and rancor, gained a
> larger majority. Corporate America get richer every day, at the expense
> of our middle and lower classes, the environment, and Iraqi citizens.
> The media continues to prefer pitting pundits against each other and
> calling it "news" instead of reporting the facts against either side.
> Karma's going to be a serious BITCH if it ever gets back to these
> people.
>
>> And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his hubris in going down
>> hard before the end of his term, and I intend to do everything I can
>> to facilitate this.
>
> Me too. I also started visiting conservative blogs a couple of weeks ago
> in an attempt to talk to sense into the people that think George Bush is
> a "compassionate conservative", or some other such bullshit. I don't
> think it's about relating to religion. Most of the time, I've found
> reasonable people who are willing to have civil discussions as long as
> you show some respect for them. That's what's missing in politics today,
> and my hope is that Bush may yet live up to his promise of being a
> "uniter" in his second term.
>
> Unfortunately I think the President will point to this election as a
> mandate to enact even more radical policies that will divide the
> American electorate even further, if that's possible. We can look
> forward to more misguided national education reforms; the privatization
> of major public services, including Social Security; renewed attacks on
> the civil rights of gays; the continued illegal imprisonment and torture
> of both American citizens and foreign nationals; the further dismantling
> of important regulatory agencies like the EPA, FDA, HHS, and the Labor
> Department; and more tax cuts for the wealthy at the expense of our
> nation's poor.
>
> As much as I'd like to say that none of these things affects me, I
> can't. And to any potential voters that sat out this year because you
> couldn't decide or just don't care, I implore you: educate yourself.
> Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. Learn the
> facts about the issues that affect your everyday life and those of your
> fellow citizens. Register to vote, and cast your ballot based on those
> issues. Voting is what makes our democracy work, and as long as you sit
> on the sidelines, your country will continue to elect people without
> your interests in mind. Bottom line: you can't complain if you don't
> inform yourself and vote your conscience.
>
> Cheers,

At 05:06 PM 11/3/2004, shawn allen wrote:
>quoth Apollo:
> > Problem with many liberals is that we approach these Christians, many
> > of whom are intelligent and very strong believers in Christ's
> > teachings, with arrogance:  that is, your beliefs are trash;  we
> > atheists or whatever, are cooler than thou;  and you're stupid for
> > believing in this superstitious trash.
> >
> > Any political inroads in Jesusland must be accompanied by creative,
> > and I believe, proper use of the New Testament.
>
>That's what sucks though! Rather than using facts, logic and reason, we
>have to relate every issue to a book written thousands of years ago.
>Religion exists everywhere on this planet, but it seems that only in
>America (and ironically, the fundamentalist Middle East) are the
>majority of people simply unwilling to frame any issue outside the
>context of their faith.

When people are afraid they often turn to religion, or booze, or 
both:)  Seriously, good political strategy arises from reality, not some 
dreamscape.  It has been said that Liberals can understand everything but 
the people who don't understand them.  I believe that's true and, again, is 
the result of a lack of true compassion.



>I only wish I had the opportunity to explain to a Christian
>fundamentalist how my disbelief in God is only *confirmed* by the 4
>years running up to last night's election: seriously, what God would
>allow somebody like George Bush to become president in the first place,
>let alone get re-elected after what he's done thus far? I think anyone
>who interprets the Bible literally should take a good, hard look at all
>of Bush's policies (and the actions of the Republicans that support
>him), then re-evaluate their support for a man that wages endless
>immoral war, cuts social programs for poor Americans while indebting
>future generations with huge tax breaks for the rich, and ravages the
>environment at the behest of the energy industry.

That was my strategy and it seemed to work on a limited scale (ie, within 
my own outreach experiences).  Put simply, what does the gospel say about 
war, greed and violence.  Bit more complex than that, though.  Take for 
example the phrase:  "....you shall have dominion over the earth."  Many 
conservatives believe this to mean we can screw the environment as much as 
we like.  However, a more correct translation reads:  "...you shall have 
stewardship over the earth."   Thus, one must protect the environment as 
any good steward would.  This was one discussion I had, and I had to go to 
heavy scholarship to deal with this.  Even those who read the New Testament 
literally are going to have trouble reconciling, say, the sermon on the 
mount with the actions of a "Christian" empire flattening the rest of the 
world for it's own benefit.


>I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
>ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
>it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
>Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as far
>as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's fucking
>depressing.

The whole issue was handled ineptly from the beginning.  The term 
"marriage" should never have been used.  Were I to have created a political 
platform for establishing the legal and other effects of marriage I would 
have called them civil unions, and moved to create legislation that would 
have focused on the needs of straights, as well as, incidentally, gays and 
bisexuals as in the EU.  Most folks these days, I understand, don't have 
marriages but, rather, civil agreements.  Marriage here has massive 
religious connotations.  "Family values" and the rest of it.  A shrewd 
politician understands this and works with it.   Now 'tis a bit late for that.


> > Finally, anything can happen in the next four years.  When Nixon was
> > elected for a second term I was in despair, as I am now.
> > But....Watergate came along.  This war in Iraq is going south fast as
> > is the economy in the long run under the monkey who spends and cuts
> > taxes.  There will be a battle on the right on these very issues and
> > there will be hell to pay whoever won this election.  Believe in
> > serendipity, 'cause it rules the universe.
>
>I find even serendipity hard to believe in these days. Bush is the
>Teflon President; every single one of his mistakes and misdeeds has been
>deflected, then more often than not dishonestly projected onto his
>opponents and critics. The Republicans, rather than losing seats in
>Congress as a result of their bitter partisanship and rancor, gained a
>larger majority. Corporate America get richer every day, at the expense
>of our middle and lower classes, the environment, and Iraqi citizens.
>The media continues to prefer pitting pundits against each other and
>calling it "news" instead of reporting the facts against either side.
>Karma's going to be a serious BITCH if it ever gets back to these
>people.

Things do happen, Shawn.  I feel events in Iraq are going to worsen and 
terrorism will continue to flourish under Bush.  His economic policies are 
under fire from both traditional conservatives (the American Conservative 
endorsed Kerry btw) and the neoliberals.  All gonna' collapse, and it may 
well be a very good thing that a Democrat isn't captain of this currently 
sinking ship.


> > And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his hubris in going down
> > hard before the end of his term, and I intend to do everything I can
> > to facilitate this.
>
>Me too. I also started visiting conservative blogs a couple of weeks ago
>in an attempt to talk to sense into the people that think George Bush is
>a "compassionate conservative", or some other such bullshit. I don't
>think it's about relating to religion. Most of the time, I've found
>reasonable people who are willing to have civil discussions as long as
>you show some respect for them. That's what's missing in politics today,
>and my hope is that Bush may yet live up to his promise of being a
>"uniter" in his second term.

Ain't no way.  He is a divider and that's just fine.  What mandate does he 
really have?  60% of the electorate voted this time...big deal for 
America.  What the hell do the other 40% think?  And of that 60%, a bit 
over 30% voted for Bush.  That's what we call a landslide here.  A 
"mandate."  The youth vote was a fiction.  Same percentage voted this time 
as in 2000.  Shame.  Here in CA we had about a 50% turnout, lower than 
expected.

What needs to happen is some outreach to the 40% who don't vote, and 
putting some fire under the kids who are just to cynical to get off their 
asses and participate.  I think a draft will take care of the latter:)

Basically, and I see it all around me, folks would prefer to live in denial 
-- some consensus reality.  Well, everything isn't going to be just fine, 
as Bush says, and I guess it will take some great pain all the way around 
to get through the bullshit we surround ourselves with.  That pain is 
coming.  We elected it, and those who were too busy to vote deserve what 
they get, as do those who have succumbed to their fears.  The longer you 
delay dealing with painful reality the worse things become.  Anyone who has 
lived more than twenty years knows that.


>Unfortunately I think the President will point to this election as a
>mandate to enact even more radical policies that will divide the
>American electorate even further, if that's possible. We can look
>forward to more misguided national education reforms; the privatization
>of major public services, including Social Security; renewed attacks on
>the civil rights of gays; the continued illegal imprisonment and torture
>of both American citizens and foreign nationals; the further dismantling
>of important regulatory agencies like the EPA, FDA, HHS, and the Labor
>Department; and more tax cuts for the wealthy at the expense of our
>nation's poor.

Pain.  Maybe the people in Ohio need a bit more before the wake up?:)


>As much as I'd like to say that none of these things affects me, I
>can't. And to any potential voters that sat out this year because you
>couldn't decide or just don't care, I implore you: educate yourself.
>Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. Learn the
>facts about the issues that affect your everyday life and those of your
>fellow citizens. Register to vote, and cast your ballot based on those
>issues. Voting is what makes our democracy work, and as long as you sit
>on the sidelines, your country will continue to elect people without
>your interests in mind. Bottom line: you can't complain if you don't
>inform yourself and vote your conscience.

In closing, I must say I thought Kerry was the worst choice the democrats 
could have made.  If they really wanted to go for the security mom vote, 
etc., they should have chosen Wesley Clark -- good Democratic, decisive, 
and well capable of dealing with military needs.  Me, I supported Dennis J. 
Kucinich in the beginning.  Kerry is a universe away from Kucinich.  Kerry 
on foreign policy, the war in Iraq, and terrorism mirrors the same "kill 
'em before they kill us" philosophy as Bush.  The Democratic party, to my 
mind, has rendered itself meaningless and without beliefs other than 
imitating the other side to win.  What have you now?  Two parties with 
increasingly similar political philosophies.  No dialectic.  The end of 
democracy as we know it.  Something must change here, or we are lost.

Further, the treatment of third party candidates in this election was 
disgraceful.  Both the Democrats and Republicans are owned by the 
corporations these days and those who really rule the country don't want a 
Nader, Green, or Kucinich ruining this sweet deal.  So we have what we have.

There are, however, winds of change out there and much of that is now 
coursing through DSL lines round the country and world.  There will be 
revolutionary change in the next few years, and it will come from the 70% 
of the American population who didn't vote for Bush.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr new map of us

There are very few seculars who would treat normal, average Christians
indiscriminately. We stypicaly jump all over right-wing Christian
fundamentalists with arrogance because they treat other people with
arrogance with the first place.

The fundamental issue being that a rational secular is naturally
incompatible with a religous zealot. You can't use rationale on these
people because they rely on blind faith.

And to a greater extend, I believe the the average American tends to
hinge on religions more so than many other western cultures because
America is a young country without a clear sense of roots. The
Britishs, Frenchs, Germans, etc., all have centuries of history and
tradtions to protect and honor. Amerian traditions, on the on other
hand, only consist of the concept of freedom and Christianity. Oh and
maybe Thanksgiving and Halloween

And when American pop culture became the global pop culture, .it
stopped being an identifying element for Americans. It pushes the
fundamentalists to hinge tighter onto their religions. This is
particular telling in the fact that while most of western europe has
written religions out of their legislations, Americans are trying to
write them back into it, in the name of protecting traditions.

I think things would be quite different with these people if America
had a few more hundreds years of history and  non-religous traditions.

Personally, I think the better angle to reach the
irrational-but-non-fundy Christian types would be via religious
freedom.

The fundies, obviously, are a lost cause.

Liberals need to understand that many liberals are Christians too, and
it's OK to apply personal faiths in campaigns. Kerry didn't ever
attempt to appear to be a religious person. There was a time when
religion wasn't a partisan issue. We need to take our half of the
Christian card back from the fundies.


> >I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
> >ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
> >it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
> >Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as far
> >as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's fucking
> >depressing.
> 
> The whole issue was handled ineptly from the beginning.  The term
> "marriage" should never have been used.  Were I to have created a political
> platform for establishing the legal and other effects of marriage I would
> have called them civil unions, and moved to create legislation that would
> have focused on the needs of straights, as well as, incidentally, gays and
> bisexuals as in the EU.  Most folks these days, I understand, don't have
> marriages but, rather, civil agreements.  Marriage here has massive
> religious connotations.  "Family values" and the rest of it.  A shrewd
> politician understands this and works with it.   Now 'tis a bit late for that.

> 
> 

The whole gay marriage thing is very simple: the average American
feels that their tradtions are being threatened. Those of us who live
in urban areas don't think twice about gay people because we know gay
people are normal people. But the average mid-western/sothern folks
typically never met a normal gay person in their life.

They feel particularily threatened because in the pastfew  years gays
have made inroads in mainstream entertainment: shows like Will &
Grace, Queer Eye, Queer As Folks, etc. Frankly I think they're hurting
us because they perpetuate stereotypes.

As much as I hate MTV, I thank the Real World for changing young
Americans attitude towards gays. I can't tell you how many teenagers I
talked to who said that their first ever exposure to a normal gay
person is from watching Real World.

Bush and his neocon friends are tearing the Republican party apart.
Those people are squeezing the moderate Republicans to a corner.
There'll be some dramatic changes in the near future, and it'll come
from within the Republican party. It's time for Democrats and
Republican reformists to unite and work hard.

> > > And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his hubris in going down
> > > hard before the end of his term, and I intend to do everything I can
> > > to facilitate this.
> >


Iraq is all Bush's responsibilty now. If he fucks up, he's gonna go
down in history as the loser. It's only a matter of time.

Not to mention there are a tons of scandals waiting to be exposed. Why
is Bush's Enron connections being buried? His Saudi connections? What
if he's found neglience of the facts that lead to 9/11? What if we
find the smoking gun that prove conclusively that he **knew** there's
no WMD from the get-go and lied about it?

This administration has defered a lot of questions. Now we have
another 4 years to grill them.




> 
> Ain't no way.  He is a divider and that's just fine.  What mandate does he
> really have?  60% of the electorate voted this time...big deal for
> America.  What the hell do the other 40% think?  And of that 60%, a bit
> over 30% voted for Bush.  That's what we call a landslide here.  A
> "mandate."  The youth vote was a fiction.  Same percentage voted this time
> as in 2000.  Shame.  Here in CA we had about a 50% turnout, lower than
> expected.
> 

Those who don't vote because they don't believe in the system. Because
they think it doesn't matter. And you know damn well they're right.
Presidential elections doesn't matter 99% of the time if you don't
live in a swing state.

Change doesn't come about by casting a single vote in a presidential
election, electing a president means noting if there isn't a channel
for the people to ether candidate once he's elected. We need to change
the system. We need to make the government accountable, we need to
make the media got back to their job to channel public opinions to the
leaders. And we're gonna change the system via untraditional means.

I'd use Creative Commons as an example. We all know damn well that the
copyright laws as they stand only benefit the labels and publishers
and media megacorps, and there's very little the customers and the
artists can do to challenge that. So here comes Creative Commons, it
attempts to create a new media culture that encourage creativity reuse
and respect fair uses, without changing the interpretation of existing
copyright laws (in fact, it relies on existing copyright laws to
function).

The same thing goes for the hippie/anti-war/civil rights movement. It
brought a mass of social and legistrative changes in our system by
actrively pursuing them outside of the system.

Like I always say, if we can't beat somone in a game where they make
all the rules, then beat them with a new game where **we** make all
the rules. Foxnews did just that.



> What needs to happen is some outreach to the 40% who don't vote, and
> putting some fire under the kids who are just to cynical to get off their
> asses and participate.  I think a draft will take care of the latter:)
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

> >Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. Learn the

> >on the sidelines, your country will continue to elect people without
> >your interests in mind. Bottom line: you can't complain if you don't
> >inform yourself and vote your conscience.
> 

No, we need to stop lying to ourselves that a vote is gonna make a
difference. Getting our ass out there to vote b/w a dolch and a turd
then sit on our ass for fourstraight years isn't gonna change
ANYTHING.

We need to find a way to energize the people to do things b/w
elections: monitor our government, voice our opinions, bring about
social changes, help the less fortunate, etc.




> In closing, I must say I thought Kerry was the worst choice the democrats
> could have made.  If they really wanted to go for the security mom vote,

Yeah I think Wesley Clark would have been a much better choice. A much

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: History of mixtapes in the rave scene

Any more?

Anyone know of disco era DJs circulating mix tapes? 
Lots of people made mix tapes in the seventies (I was
there) but I haven't been able to confirm that early
club DJs used them.

Regards,

Peter

--- matthew johnson <mpj_bay@yahoo.com> wrote:

> I do not have a link to anything written about this
> but I started going out way before this music was
> mainstream, i.e. the first time I heard house/acid
> house/techno whatever first played in a public place
> was back in '94 on Height. 
> 
> In my underground career, mixed tapes seem to appear
> in the 80's. Mostly DJ's just making tapes for thier
> friends and clubs recording to hand out free or to
> sell as party memories. These tapes got duped and
> given to friends of friends. Not sure the exact year
> but in the late 80's early 90's DJ's were selling
> tapes for a number of reasons. 
> 1. to learn new records
> 2. to make money to buy more records
> 3. to get thier name out
> 4. give to friend
> 5. demo's for gigs. 
> 
> I am sure this goes back to the disco days some how
> but I just missed that era.
> 
> Hope this helps. Someone correct me if I'm wrong. 
> Maybe I should write an article on this. Let me know
> if you need more specific info and I will find it
> for
> you.
> 
> =)
> Matt

At 11:00 PM 11/3/2004, Peter Rothman wrote:
>Exactly the sort of story I'm looking for...
>
>Any more?
>
>Anyone know of disco era DJs circulating mix tapes?
>Lots of people made mix tapes in the seventies (I was
>there) but I haven't been able to confirm that early
>club DJs used them.
>
>Regards,
>
>Peter


Yes, Peter, I have some information for you on this.  Lots of reel to reel 
recordings made in the seventies and passed about.  Larry Levin made one 
for me when I was an erotic dancer:)  Lots of Bobby V's tapes from the Troc 
in the seventies have now been burned onto CDs, and I understand Barry 
Lederer in NYC and others are doing the same with other early disco 
sets.  I personally have two complete Troc parties on CD.

Not focused on this now, but if you'll remind me tomorrow I'll see what I 
more I can dig up.  I do mention this several times in House Music 101.

Love,

Apollo


>--- matthew johnson <mpj_bay@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> > I do not have a link to anything written about this
> > but I started going out way before this music was
> > mainstream, i.e. the first time I heard house/acid
> > house/techno whatever first played in a public place
> > was back in '94 on Height.
> >
> > In my underground career, mixed tapes seem to appear
> > in the 80's. Mostly DJ's just making tapes for thier
> > friends and clubs recording to hand out free or to
> > sell as party memories. These tapes got duped and
> > given to friends of friends. Not sure the exact year
> > but in the late 80's early 90's DJ's were selling
> > tapes for a number of reasons.
> > 1. to learn new records
> > 2. to make money to buy more records
> > 3. to get thier name out
> > 4. give to friend
> > 5. demo's for gigs.
> >
> > I am sure this goes back to the disco days some how
> > but I just missed that era.
> >
> > Hope this helps. Someone correct me if I'm wrong.
> > Maybe I should write an article on this. Let me know
> > if you need more specific info and I will find it
> > for
> > you.
> >
> > =)
> > Matt

MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-ID: <20041104003800.N57902@taz3.hyperreal.org>
