Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: History of mixtapes in the rave scene

--0-235802269-1099557445=:57902
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
Content-ID: <20041104003800.N57902@taz3.hyperreal.org>

There are many references to influences of mixtapes in the rave scene from=
=20
conducting this search, while none specifically give a diatribe on just=20
this influence, there are some worthwhile links:

http://www.google.com/search?q=3Dthe+influence+of+mix+tapes+in+the+rave+sce=
ne&btnG=3DSearch&hl=3Den&lr=3D

It might be interesting to conduct research, search opinions and=20
experiences and write an article specific to this "scene".

This may not be exactly what you are looking for, but there are some good=
=20
reads here on how mixtapes influenced the Hip Hop scene, which in many=20
ways also influenced electronic music.

Here are a few references of the history of mixtapes=20
in another genre of music, known for its historical use of mixtapes:

Hip/Hop:

http://www.lavozdeanza.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/01/4185ca0d9cbf5
http://www.submunition.com/mtype/archives/culture_society/history_of_mixtap=
es.html
http://www.mtv.com/bands/m/mixtape/news_feature_021003/index8.jhtml
http://www.tymelyne.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3D619

History of Mixtapes:

http://www.digressmagazine.com/1mixtape.html
http://www.sfbg.com/37/41/art_music_mix.html

Impact: Sample Law
http://rap.about.com/b/a/2003_10_08.htm
and:
http://www.superswell.com/samplelaw/samplelaw03.html

"...Back in the day, I remember that there weren't many radio stations=20
playing hip-hop. MTV was concerned with Dire Straits. The only way a lot=20
of us were exposed to new artists was by buying mix tapes. If any of you=20
live in a normal urban area, you know that mix tapes still sell as well=20
today as they ever did. Mix tapes, in my opinion, are what carry on the=20
original traditions of dub. Turntablists are hip-hop purists. They are=20
doing exactly what Kool Herc did. Maybe a little differently, but mixing=20
records on two turntables and mixer is as primal an element to hip-hop as=
=20
the beats themselves. Most mix tapes, of course, are banned by copyright.=
=20
We all know that there are at least two kinds of DJs in the world.=20
Category A are radio disc jockeys and people who play CDs at weddings and=
=20
bar mitzvahs. Category B is anyone with two 1200s and something between=20
them. The Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) has been very=20
vague about mix tapes that fall into Category B, what I like to call,=20
"transformative" compilation. Here is a snippet from a recent RIAA press=20
release:

"DJs are not exempt from copyright laws. When radio and nightclub disc=20
jockeys compile a CD or cassette of tracks from a number of unrelated=20
albums to use in their work, each song must be authorized -- even if the=20
CD is made by a legitimate CD manufacturer.

"The law is simple: Duplicating copyrighted sound recordings for=20
professional disc jockey purposes without the authorization of the sound=20
recording copyright owner is a violation of federal and/or state copyright=
=20
law. This includes copying all or some of a sound recording to analog or=20
digital tape, CD-R, mini-disc or a computer disk/hard drive. Violators=20
could be civilly liable for statutory damages of up to $100,000 per=20
infringed sound recording, in addition to costs and the copyright owner=92s=
=20
attorney fees. Criminal liabilities include up to five years imprisonment=
=20
and/or a fine of up to $250,000.

"The RIAA=92s continuing enforcement efforts focus on the manufacture and=
=20
distribution of illegal compilations throughout the DJ community,=20
including businesses that allege to be authorized but are not. The RIAA=20
also addresses flagrant copyright infringement by DJs who create and=20
manufacture multi-disk compilations of top hits without obtaining=20
appropriate licenses from the copyright holders." [RIAA]

After reading this, one would assume that they're targeting people who=20
manufacture "Top Hits" CDs, what's "hot" that week and so on. But with the=
=20
threat of five years in jail and a fine of up to $250,000, how badly do we=
=20
want to find out..."

Anti Mix Tape Influence:
http://www.snarl.org/texts/features/mixtapes.htm

TO add to these reasons:

> > 1. to learn new records
> > 2. to make money to buy more records
> > 3. to get thier name out
> > 4. give to friend
> > 5. demo's for gigs.

6. To provide a cheap medium to distribute music, given the constraints of=
=20
recording formats and cost of distribution in the early 70's, 80's, 90's=20
as mixing and recording formats changed from analog to digital.

7. To interpret, alter, influence, perfect, expand and better the mixing=20
techniques of many djs.

8. To sample, dub, and alter the art of mixing music with various sound=20
inputs.

9. To distribute the latest tracks on a tight budget. (See #6)

10. To give artists, producers, promoters, listeners another way to=20
communicate their musical style.

11. To distribute tracks that may or may not have had another means=20
of distribution due to copyright restraints or those which are/are=20
not an offiical release, commercial release or promotional release.

12. To provide a gauge for how well a certain track might be played on the=
=20
radio, in clubs, purchased in stores, played by other djs, or how an=20
audience might respond w/ demand versus supply.

13. To provide a medium for experimental or custom music releases.

14. To give listeners the option have portable music, the option to listen=
=20
to their favorite artists on the "go".

15. Mixtapes break new artists, help the music industry discover unsigned=
=20
talent, and increases music industry sales as a street promotional tool.

See mixing basics for other influences:

http://www.humbuckermusic.com/aug1820basmi.html

Hope this helps...

<3

Karina
--=20

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************

--- Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:

> There are many references to influences of mixtapes
> in the rave scene from 
> conducting this search, while none specifically give
> a diatribe on just 
> this influence, there are some worthwhile links:
> 
>
http://www.google.com/search?q=the+influence+of+mix+tapes+in+the+rave+scene&btnG=Search&hl=en&lr=
> 
> It might be interesting to conduct research, search
> opinions and 
> experiences and write an article specific to this
> "scene".
> 
> This may not be exactly what you are looking for,
> but there are some good 
> reads here on how mixtapes influenced the Hip Hop
> scene, which in many 
> ways also influenced electronic music.

> Here are a few references of the history of mixtapes
> 
> in another genre of music, known for its historical
> use of mixtapes:
> 
> Hip/Hop:
> 
>
http://www.lavozdeanza.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/01/4185ca0d9cbf5
>
http://www.submunition.com/mtype/archives/culture_society/history_of_mixtapes.html
>
http://www.mtv.com/bands/m/mixtape/news_feature_021003/index8.jhtml
> http://www.tymelyne.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=619
> 
> History of Mixtapes:
> 
> http://www.digressmagazine.com/1mixtape.html
> http://www.sfbg.com/37/41/art_music_mix.html
> 
> Impact: Sample Law
> http://rap.about.com/b/a/2003_10_08.htm
> and:
> http://www.superswell.com/samplelaw/samplelaw03.html
> 
> "...Back in the day, I remember that there weren't
> many radio stations 
> playing hip-hop. MTV was concerned with Dire
> Straits. The only way a lot 
> of us were exposed to new artists was by buying mix
> tapes. If any of you 
> live in a normal urban area, you know that mix tapes
> still sell as well 
> today as they ever did. Mix tapes, in my opinion,
> are what carry on the 
> original traditions of dub. Turntablists are hip-hop
> purists. They are 
> doing exactly what Kool Herc did. Maybe a little
> differently, but mixing 
> records on two turntables and mixer is as primal an
> element to hip-hop as 
> the beats themselves. Most mix tapes, of course, are
> banned by copyright. 
> We all know that there are at least two kinds of DJs
> in the world. 
> Category A are radio disc jockeys and people who
> play CDs at weddings and 
> bar mitzvahs. Category B is anyone with two 1200s
> and something between 
> them. The Recording Industry Association of America
> (RIAA) has been very 
> vague about mix tapes that fall into Category B,
> what I like to call, 
> "transformative" compilation. Here is a snippet from
> a recent RIAA press 
> release:
> 
> "DJs are not exempt from copyright laws. When radio
> and nightclub disc 
> jockeys compile a CD or cassette of tracks from a
> number of unrelated 
> albums to use in their work, each song must be
> authorized -- even if the 
> CD is made by a legitimate CD manufacturer.
> 
> "The law is simple: Duplicating copyrighted sound
> recordings for 
> professional disc jockey purposes without the
> authorization of the sound 
> recording copyright owner is a violation of federal
> and/or state copyright 
> law. This includes copying all or some of a sound
> recording to analog or 
> digital tape, CD-R, mini-disc or a computer
> disk/hard drive. Violators 
> could be civilly liable for statutory damages of up
> to $100,000 per 
> infringed sound recording, in addition to costs and
> the copyright owners 
> attorney fees. Criminal liabilities include up to
> five years imprisonment 
> and/or a fine of up to $250,000.
> 
> "The RIAAs continuing enforcement efforts focus on
> the manufacture and 
> distribution of illegal compilations throughout the
> DJ community, 
> including businesses that allege to be authorized
> but are not. The RIAA 
> also addresses flagrant copyright infringement by
> DJs who create and 
> manufacture multi-disk compilations of top hits
> without obtaining 
> appropriate licenses from the copyright holders."
> [RIAA]
> 
> After reading this, one would assume that they're
> targeting people who 
> manufacture "Top Hits" CDs, what's "hot" that week
> and so on. But with the 
> threat of five years in jail and a fine of up to
> $250,000, how badly do we 
> want to find out..."
> 
> Anti Mix Tape Influence:
> http://www.snarl.org/texts/features/mixtapes.htm
> 
> TO add to these reasons:
> 
> > > 1. to learn new records
> > > 2. to make money to buy more records
> > > 3. to get thier name out
> > > 4. give to friend
> > > 5. demo's for gigs.
> 
> 6. To provide a cheap medium to distribute music,
> given the constraints of 
> recording formats and cost of distribution in the
> early 70's, 80's, 90's 
> as mixing and recording formats changed from analog
> to digital.
> 
> 7. To interpret, alter, influence, perfect, expand
> and better the mixing 
> techniques of many djs.
> 
> 8. To sample, dub, and alter the art of mixing music
> with various sound 
> inputs.
> 
> 9. To distribute the latest tracks on a tight
> budget. (See #6)
> 
> 10. To give artists, producers, promoters, listeners
> another way to 
> communicate their musical style.
> 
> 11. To distribute tracks that may or may not have
> had another means 
> of distribution due to copyright restraints or those
> which are/are 
> not an offiical release, commercial release or
> promotional release.
> 
> 12. To provide a gauge for how well a certain track
> might be played on the 
> radio, in clubs, purchased in stores, played by
> other djs, or how an 
> audience might respond w/ demand versus supply.
> 
> 13. To provide a medium for experimental or custom
> music releases.
> 
> 14. To give listeners the option have portable
> music, the option to listen 
> to their favorite artists on the "go".
> 
> 15. Mixtapes break new artists, help the music
> industry discover unsigned 
> talent, and increases music industry sales as a
> street promotional tool.
> 
> See mixing basics for other influences:
> 
> http://www.humbuckermusic.com/aug1820basmi.html
> 
> Hope this helps...
> 
> <3
> 
> Karina
> -- 
>
**************************************************************
>
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps
> not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another
> life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus --
> *******************************************
>
**************************************************************
>

>my best works so far... it's hard trance/dark nrg,
>15 tracks, and runs 
>75:30 long...
> 
>aberration
>mixed by apot
>hard trance/dark nrg
>abysmal frequencies 2004

>05 - paul glazby - you won't last [frantic]
>06 - tomo & tuffcub - ace [nukleuz]
>07 - fatboy slim - the rockafeller skank (unknown
>remix) [fat records]
>08 - stimulant djs - scream & shout (guyver remix)
[stimulant records]
>09 - project mayhem - take hold (james lawson &
>justin bourne remix) [short circuit]

[synapse]

[nukleuz]
>12 - dmf - palpitation [recharge]
>13 - ali wilson & matt smallwood - just listen
[vicious circle]
>14 - lab-4 - pump it [fragile]
>15 - lab-4 - 4th floor [tidy]
>

f-8/reverb)

Subject: [sfraves] bsp:  bam plays 1015, grooverider in the main room

a tiny little BSP that i'm opening the VIP room at 1015 this friday.  
breakthru is hosting all breaks upstairs and Grooverider is headlining the 
main room.

this is my first time playing at 1015 and while the place has gone through 
it's share of ups and downs...i'm still pretty excited since it was the club 
that got me into the electronic dance music scene (or whatever you call 
this) in the bay area.  oh, how many long long long nights and mornings were 
spent there...

free before 10:30 and i play from 10:30-11:30.  how perfect.  ;)  i'll be 
warming things up with a little funk and groove break action.

$10 presales online at 1015.com.  or $5 off at the door with flyer.

Received: (qmail 80581 invoked from network); 4 Nov 2004 21:28:20 -0000
Message-ID: <20041104212817.20699.qmail@web54702.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 2004 13:28:17 -0800 (PST)
From: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) (nrr) Subversive Soundz presents author Derrick Jensen at AK Press

so, this is way, way off the rave topic, but i don't
post too often, and we've been talkin' politics, so
here goes...

Derrick Jensen is one of my favorite non-fiction
authors, and I'm really excited to have him speaking
here in the Bay Area.  He's able to skillfully
interweave stories of our relationship to the natural
world, prisons and racism, people's resistance, and
the continuing occupation of North America plus much
more.  While Subversive Soundz generally does musical
events, we do branch out.  

(and hopefully this will be done in time for me to
catch jeff samuel at the rx gallery afterwards.)

Details below:

AK Press and Subversive Soundz present:

Author Derrick Jensen 
on  Dismantling Civilization

Saturday, November 6th
7pm
AK Press

Derrick Jensen is the author of books A Language Older
than Words, The Culture of Make Believe, Listening to
the Land, Walking on Water: Reading, Writing and
Revolution, and most recently, Strangely Like War: The
Global Assault on Forests and Welcome to the Machine:
Science, Surveillance and the Culture of Control. 

>From Derrick Jensen: "We are members of the most
destructive culture ever to exist. Our assault on the
natural world, on indigenous and other cultures, on
women, on children, on all of us through the
possibility of nuclear suicide and other means--all
these are unprecedented in their magnitude and
ferocity.  So began my first book, Listening to the
Land . Why do we act as we do? What are sane and
effective responses to outrageously destructive
behavior? What will it take for us to stop the horrors
that characterize our way of being? My work and life
revolve around these questions."

Jensen is a writer increasingly recognized as a major
new voice of cultural dissent. A Language Older Than
Words has become an underground best seller on college
campuses and The Culture of Make Believe was one of
two finalists for the 2003 J. Anthony Lukas Book
Prize, which cited it as "a passionate and provocative
meditation on the nexus of racism, genocide,
environmental destruction and corporate malfeasance,
where civilization meets its discontents." 

"A typical Jensen event is multidimensional and feels
a bit like traveling beneath the earth among tree
roots, as they twist their way into soil, rock, river
beds and accompany fish, insects, discarded tires,
cellophane wrappers, animal minds, history, and human
instinct on a strange and interlocking journey." 

Event includes special guest Agent Apple of the Biotic
Baking Brigade.

$5-10 sliding scale donation, no one turned away for
lack of funds. A benefit for Break the Chains prisoner
support (www.breakthechains.net).

AK Press is located at 674-A 23rd. Street, Oakland, CA
between MLK and San Pablo - near 19th St. BART and
West Grand Exit of 80/980. 

Wheelchair accessible.

For more info contact: AK Press at 510.208.1700,
akpress@akpress.org, www.akpress.org, or
subversivesoundz@yahoo.com

also see www.derrickjensen.org

www.yahoo.com

> appear

> thier

> > given to friends of friends. Not sure the exact
> year

> > tapes for a number of reasons.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  DIRTY w/ Autobots and Subscience DnB Room - Nov 12th

NOTE:  Just as a little incentive to all you breaks lovers out there, Evil 
Breaks has
agreed to do a special 2 for $10 deal to anyone registered on SFBreaks.org .
SFBreaks.org will be sending out an email a week before the show to get 
people on
the special list.  The list is limited only to the first 30 pairs, so make 
sure you
are signed up and ready.

www.SFBreaks.org


Evil Breaks presents: DIRTY
Friday November 12th, 2004
Jelly's (295 China Basin Wy @ pier 50)
9pm - 3am
$7 before 11pm / $10 after

The Autobots in their first ever west coast appearance. With a special 
outside DnB
room hosted by the Subscience crew with live fire dancers, free cd's, vinyl,
stickers and more.....

The Autobots (Broke/Skuff/TCR/Passenger/Botchit) - UK

The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez. Before the start of the 
Autobots
project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom has 
produced over
40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been promoting dance 
events
since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly new to the breaks scene, 
they
have had releases on almost every major breaks label, they've toured all 
around the
world, and their tracks can be found in the boxes of quite a few of the 
biggest
names in the business. Don't miss them on their first ever west coast 
appearance.

Evil Breaks room:

Ripple (Subscience)
B-Smarter (www.Sparxx.us/Equalize Ent/Virus Breaks) - Seattle, WA
Aaron Jae vs Athena (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks/the Nubotz)
Bam vs Influence (Evil Breaks/in Tha Mix)

Subscience DnB room:

Method One (Method-One.com)
Arson (Urban Drums/www.594Apparel.net)
The Hitmen (Subscience)
Doubleday (Swatchdog Recordings)

Located at Jellys (295 China Basin Wy) this event will be going strong from 
9pm - 3am.
$7 before 11pm and $10 after that.

more info: www.EvilBreaks.com

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Never Die-Bold...

VERY interesting piece.  My heart tells me something
is VERY wrong....like someone stole my candy dammit!

c h r i s

---------------------

Never Say Die-bold: So You Dont Think the Bush
Campaign Stole This Election? Think Again 

By Jackson Thoreau 
opEdNews.com 

If youre looking for one word to sum up the way the
Bush-Cheney campaign stole another election Tuesday
besides obvious ones like cheated, try this one:
Diebold.

An election judge where I voted Tuesday in a heavily
Democratic precinct in Maryland knows what that means
and wasnt adverse to sharing his opinion of the
Republican-owned company. As I was about to vote with
the electronic system, I asked this judge if they had
a way to check peoples votes through a paper backup.


The official said no, and then in a low voice so no
one else would hear, added, And that really makes us
nervous, with Diebold as the owner of that system.


Goodbye, hanging chads. Hello, computer fraud that
leaves no trace, no chads hanging. 
  
Diebold Inc. of North Canton, Ohio, supplied scores of
machines and counted millions of votes Tuesday, while
reportedly discarding many votes for Democrat John
Kerry, according to British investigative reporter
Gregory Palast. Walden ODell, chief executive of
Diebold and a top fundraiser for the Bush campaign,
wrote in a fund-raising letter last year that he was
committed to helping Ohio deliver its electoral votes
to the president next year.


That he did.


Software errors involving the system can change
results, computer scientists say. Since the majority
of touch screens in the United States do not produce
paper records, the machines could alter ballots
without anyone noticing. 
  
What has most concerned scientists are problems that
are not observable, so the fact that no major problems
were observed says nothing about the system, David
Jefferson, a computer scientist at Lawrence Livermore
National Laboratory in California, told the Associated
Press. The fact that we had a relatively smooth
election yesterday does not change at all the
vulnerability these systems have to fraud or bugs. 
  
Some 8.2 percent of touch-screen votes in senatorial
elections between 1998 and 2000 were lost, according
to an MIT/CalTech study. That was more than any other
system except lever machines, which lost 9.5 percent
of votes. 
  
Bev Harris, author of Black Box Voting and the
BlackBoxVoting.com web site, has documented numerous
cases of electronic disasters. One occurred in Volusia
County, Fla., in 2000 in which county election
officials hand recounted more than 184,000 paper
ballots used to feed the computerized system, after
the central ballot-counting computer showed a
Socialist Party candidate receiving more than 9,000
votes and Al Gore getting minus 19,000. Another 4,000
votes were received for Bush that should not have been
there. 
  
Election officials eventually tallied Gore beating
Bush by 97,063 votes to 82,214. But the wrong numbers
had already been sent to the media, which were used by
FOX and other networks to erroneously call the
election for Bush and swing the public relations part
of the recount battle in his favor. 
  
On Tuesday, Election Protection, a program of People
for the American Way, had more than 15,000 calls to
its hotline about ballot problems, voter intimidation
and other
situations.


The Institute for Public Accuracy also outlined
various problems. Susan Truitt, co-founder of the
Citizens Alliance for Secure Elections, was quoted on
its site saying that seven counties in Ohio had
electronic voting machines without paper trails, and
scientific exit polls showed Kerry with the lead. But
verifying votes was impossible, she said. 
  
A recount without a paper trail is meaningless; you
just get a regurgitation of the data, Truitt said. A
poll worker told me [Wednesday] morning that there
were no tapes of the results posted on some machines;
on other machines the posted count was zero, which
obviously shouldnt be the case. 
  
Other problems include Ohios version of Katherine
Harris 
  
There were many other problems in Ohio. Like in
Florida, the Ohio secretary of state, Ken Blackwell,
made decisions on what could be counted and other
important matters even as he shilled for Bush as a
co-chair of his campaign. This raised serious
conflict-of-interest concerns, said Ohio state Senator
Teresa Fedor. 
  
There is a pattern of voter suppression; thats why I
called for Blackwells resignation more than a month
ago, she said. Blackwell, while claiming to run an
unbiased elections process, was also the co-chair of
the Bush-Cheney campaign in Ohio. Additionally, he was
the spokesperson for the anti-business, anti-family
constitutional
amendment Issue 1, and a failed initiative to repeal
a crucial sales-tax revenue source for the state.
Blackwell learned his moves from the Katherine Harris
playbook of Florida 2000, and we wont stand for it.


The Ohio tally also included a version of the Florida
butterfly ballot, said Bob Fitrakis, an attorney with
Election Protection. The absentee ballots were
misleading in Franklin County, he said. Kerry was
the third line down, but you had to punch number four
to vote for him. Bush was getting both his votes as
well as Kerrys.


There were also far fewer machines in the inner-city
districts than in the suburbs, Fitrakis said. I
documented at least a dozen people leaving because the
lines were so long in African-American areas, he
said. Blackwell did a great deal of suppressing
before the election - like attempting to refuse to
process voter registration forms. 
  
I heard a report that one Ohio voter had to wait in
line 15 hours to vote. In one of the busiest precincts
in Columbus, Blackwell only supplied it with three
voting
machines. How many people gave up and did not vote
there?

Dirty tricks by Republicans on the rise 
  
A few days before the 2004 election, the Washington
Post published an article detailing increasing dirty
tricks, mostly by Republicans. 
  
In Lake County, Ohio, some people received a memo on
bogus Board of Elections letterhead informing voters
who registered through Democratic and NACCP drives
that they could not vote.

In Leon County, students at Florida State and Florida
A&M universities who signed petitions to legalize
medical marijuana or impose stiffer penalties for
child molesters unknowingly had their party
registration switched to Republican and their
addresses
changed. The latter would affect their ability to vote
since they would not be registered at the proper site.
The media traced the source to a group hired by the
Florida Republican Party. 
  
In Allegheny County, Pa., fliers on a bogus county
letterhead were handed out and mailed, saying that
due to immense voter turnout expected on Tuesday,
the election had been extended. Republicans should
vote Tuesday, while Democrats should vote on Wednesday
 the wrong day.


In some Milwaukee black neighborhoods, a flier warned
people that they could not vote in that election if
they had already voted in another election that year.
If you
violate any of these laws, you can get ten years in
prison and your children will get taken away from
you, the flier said.

In Charleston County, S.C., a fake letter supposedly
from the NAACP threatens
voters who have outstanding parking tickets or have
failed to pay child support with arrest. A similar
flier was distributed in Baltimore in 2002. 
  
Such tricks are not new. There are famous examples
like the 1971 break-in of Democratic National
Committee headquarters by Nixon. There are also many
lesser known examples. In 2002, Ron Kirk, a former
Dallas mayor who ran as a Democrat for U.S. Senate,
reported a bogus automated phone message dialed to
voters in Austin and other cities. The message asked
voters to support Kirk because he supported same-sex
marriages and gay adoptions. Kirk said he didnt
support either issue and blamed more Republican
pre-election dirty tricks. His Republican opponent,
John Cornyn, denied being behind the false phone bank.

  
U.S. has a long history of rigged elections 
  
The U.S., of course, is no stranger to rigged
elections, even well before Tuesdays and the one in
2000. A famous case was the controversial way that the
late President Lyndon B. Johnson won a U.S. Senate
seat in 1948 in Texas on his way to the White House
that reportedly involved votes from dead people. What
some overlook in this case was how LBJ had lost an
election in a similar disputed fashion seven years
before. 
  
Another lesser known case involved the 1984 landslide
presidential election of the late Republican Ronald
Reagan. In Dallas, where both Bush and Cheney lived at
one time, there were 217 ballots cast in a precinct
that had zero registered voters. That would not affect
the election, but it demonstrates that fraud has
existed for a long time. 
  
As early as 1986, Michael Shamos, a Pennsylvania
computer scientist, testified during a Texas hearing
that the computer hardware and software used to
tabulate voters ballots could easily be manipulated. 
  
Computers can be manipulated remotely, by wire or
radio, or by direct physical input, Shamos said. The
memories on which these computers operate can easily
fit into a shirt pocket and can be substituted in
seconds. The software can be set to await the receipt
of a special card, whose presence will cause all the
election counters to be altered. This card could be
dropped into the ballot box by any confederate. The
possibilities for this type of tampering are endless,
and virtually no detection is possible once tabulation
has been completed....Even if the software is not
altered, there is no reason to believe that it is
correct. Many tests performed on such programs have
revealed faulty logic and wildly incorrect results. 
  
Suzan Kesim, then-vice president of a security
consulting firm in South Bend, Ind., also testified in
1986 that many of the computer auditing procedures
used by the banking industry that have been tried and
true could easily be modified or used as they are for
auditing elections....Fraud possibilities include
hidden programs.  
  
Texas even had its own voter purge almost two decades
before Florida attempted to strike some 60,000 voters
from the rolls with false accusations of felony
convictions. In 1982, lists were provided to Texas
election officials that made mostly false accusations
of felony convictions against voters. The accused
included public officials who successfully sued for
slander. The state also hired armed officers at
minority voter precincts and posted signs warning
voters against casting illegal ballots. Charles
Knutson pointed out in a Democrats.com report that the
Texas purge probably involved Bush mastermind Karl
Rove, who worked for then-Texas Republican Gov. Bill
Clements in 1982.  
  
Another odd case involved a West Texas county where
the systems optical scanners misread ballots and at
first reported landslide wins for two Republican
commissioners in 2002. But the next day, after alert
poll workers became suspicious of the wide margins of
supposed victory, they discovered a defective computer
chip in the scanner system. After two hand recounts
and another count with a replacement scanner chip,
officials announced that Democrats Jerry House and
Chloanne Lindsey actually won by wide margins. 
  
It was hard to believe that that type of mistake had
happened, Robbie Floyd, one of the Republicans who
lost, said in one press report. 
  
So could Kerry have been ripped off by a defective
computer chip in Ohio and Florida, where scientific
exit polls indicated Kerry wins? We will never know
since, unlike the Texas machines in 2002, the Diebold
machines in Ohio and Florida have no paper trail. 
  
How convenient. 
  
Popular vote fixed? 
  
With all the former and current Republicans supporting
Kerry  even a long-time Texas Republican friend of
mine voted for a Democrat for the first time for
president on Tuesday  its hard to believe that Bush
got about 3.5 million more votes than Kerry and 8
million more than he received in 2000. 
  
There cant be that many new devil worshippers or
Christian fundamentalists. 
  
A larger turnout  Tuesdays 60 percent turnout was
the largest since 1968  has favored Democrats in the
past. But about 6 million of those votes have not been
counted. 
  
Some said that exit polls were accurate in states that
had paper trails, but not in ones without the paper
trails for e-voting. 
  
Even though Kerry conceded, groups like the
International Labor Communications Association refused
to follow suit. The group is waging a campaign to
count all the votes in Ohio. 

Kerrys concession was really strange and
disappointing. Would Howard Dean have conceded so fast
to Bush? Gore fought Bush harder than Kerry. I dont
get it since Kerry even had Bruce Springsteen play No
Retreat, No Surrender at a campaign appearance and
used that song during other events. John Edwards also
pledged to make sure votes were counted. Then they
surrendered without putting up a fight in the overtime
phase. That was most disappointing, more so than
Gores concession in 2000. 
  
Did Skull and Bones members blackmail Kerry into
conceding without a real fight?


Perhaps Kerry simply foresaw the inevitable result,
but he still could have seen the counting of
provisional ballots through to the end. It would have
raised some more awareness about the problems with
Diebold and possibility of vote tampering. It would
have shown Bush-Cheney that Democrats werent backing
down, especially with so many questions about vote
reliability and reports of Republican voter
suppression and dirty tricks. 
  
But Kerry called for unity with the Evil Empire. Why
is it that Democrats are always trying to call for
unity and compromise with Republicanazis? As Carolyn
Kay with MakeThemAccountable.com said, we have to
completely remake the Democratic Party. We have to
learn from right wingers to take a licking and come
back kicking. It is absolutely essential that as soon
as possible we pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off,
and start working to take over the Democratic Party.
It has lost its moorings, and because of that it is
losing elections, over and over and over again. 
  
Sure, the deck was stacked against Kerry. Perhaps the
last week of bad news for Bush, the Washington
Redskins loss, the exit polls, and other omens that
seemed to spell a Kerry victory were mere ploys by
Rove to make his side work harder and our side slack
off a bit. 
  
One thing I know: We have to keep fighting these
cheating thieves, not try to make peace with them. And
I hope many people on our side wont move away 
though I realize moving out of the country is the
ultimate protest and I understand that choice. We all
have to figure out what is the best path to take for
ourselves. 
  
As for me, Im staying in the belly of the beast, in
the shadow of the Evil Empire, to continue to sucker
punch it in its bloated, bullshit-filled gut. Starting
now, just as many conservatives boycotted France for
its correct stance against the Iraqi invasion, Im
boycotting the state of Texas, where I lived for 40
years before moving to friendlier and more progressive
confines last year. Bush got his political start in
Texas, where the Republicanazis imposed a
redistricting scheme that made that far-right state
even more Republican. Every statewide official is a
Republican there. The Texas Republican Party platform
reads like a nazi playbook, even calling for getting
out of the UN, abolishing numerous federal agencies,
making homosexuality a crime and teaching the Bible in
public schools. 
  
Enough is enough. Fuck Texas and the horses that Bush
and Cheney rode in on. 
  
And fuck Diebold, too. 
  
As for you, Sen. Kerry, I appreciate your hard work,
your intelligence, your dedication to this campaign,
although I was disappointed by your finish. But, with
all due respect, you know where you can stick your
call for unity.. 

Jackson Thoreau is a Washington, D.C.-area
journalist/writer. The latest book to which he
contributed, Big Bush Lies, was published by RiverWood
Books of Ashland, Ore., and is available at bookstores
across the country. He can be contacted at
jacksonthor@yahoo.com or jacksonthor@juno.com.   
Read more of Jackson's writing at Jackson Thoreau
Article Archive 
  
Taken From
http://www.opednews.com/thoreau_110404_diebold.htm

From sfraves-return-116878-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Nov 05 02:01:48 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-116878-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 38115 invoked from network); 5 Nov 2004 02:01:46 -0000
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 2004 18:05:17 -0800
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <20041104010616.GX475@hubble>
Message-Id: <23E61C62-2ECF-11D9-9D52-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr new map of us

On Wednesday, November 3, 2004, at 05:06  PM, shawn allen wrote:

> quoth Apollo:
>> Problem with many liberals is that we approach these Christians, many
>> of whom are intelligent and very strong believers in Christ's
>> teachings, with arrogance:  that is, your beliefs are trash;  we
>> atheists or whatever, are cooler than thou;  and you're stupid for
>> believing in this superstitious trash.
>>
>> Any political inroads in Jesusland must be accompanied by creative,
>> and I believe, proper use of the New Testament.
>
> That's what sucks though! Rather than using facts, logic and reason, we
> have to relate every issue to a book written thousands of years ago.
> Religion exists everywhere on this planet, but it seems that only in
> America (and ironically, the fundamentalist Middle East) are the
> majority of people simply unwilling to frame any issue outside the
> context of their faith.

	I haven't found that most conservatives base their politics primarily 
on religion. Certainly for many of them it informs their beliefs on 
hot-button issues like homosexuality, but look at the prominent 
conservative or conservative-leaning news sources in the U.S. -- most 
have more of a secular focus. For example, Rush Limbaugh, Insight 
Magazine, Weekly Standard, Fox News, the Wall Street Journal, National 
Review, WorldNetDaily.com, Townhall.com, American Spectator. Even the 
Washington Times, owned by right-wing religious figure Rev. Sun Myung 
Moon, doesn't have much of a religious focus. Thinking of 
religion-based news sources, only Pat Robertson's 700 Club comes 
readily to mind.

> I only wish I had the opportunity to explain to a Christian
> fundamentalist how my disbelief in God is only *confirmed* by the 4
> years running up to last night's election: seriously, what God would
> allow somebody like George Bush to become president in the first place,
> let alone get re-elected after what he's done thus far?

	If you look at history, or even just what's going on in the world 
today, George Bush hardly even shows up on the chart of causes of human 
misery and suffering. First you've got to figure out why a benevolent 
God would allow people in power like Joseph Stalin, Mao Tse-Tsung, Pol 
Pot, Robert Mugabe, and Kim Il Sung.

>  I think anyone
> who interprets the Bible literally should take a good, hard look at all
> of Bush's policies (and the actions of the Republicans that support
> him), then re-evaluate their support for a man that wages endless
> immoral war, cuts social programs for poor Americans while indebting
> future generations with huge tax breaks for the rich, and ravages the
> environment at the behest of the energy industry.
>
> I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
> ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
> it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
> Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as far
> as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's fucking
> depressing.

	Conservatives (and libertarians) feel the same way about legal gun 
ownership, which actually *reduces* violence. Why would anyone want to 
ban it? Living in the Bay Area you may not know much about the gun 
culture, but even if you set aside hunting -- which I have a personal 
problem with as an animal rights advocate -- millions of Americans 
enjoy the recreational use and/or collecting of firearms. Yet thousands 
of gun control laws have been passed in the U.S., and most are still on 
the books. Even though the Constitution clearly protects the right to 
keep and bear arms, politicians are allowed to get away with treating 
it like toilet paper. That's fucking depressing too.

	For many on the right, guns are a *very* big deal. Maybe even a bigger 
deal than religion. Many conservatives are afraid of a police state too 
-- but while you worry about John Ashcroft rounding up the Arabs, or 
throwing you in jail for drugs, they worry about politicians like Ted 
Kennedy and Hilary Clinton sending people to take away their guns and 
their kids and EPA or UN bureaucrats kicking them off their land. They 
see the mainstream media, Hollywood, and the educational establishment 
as actively hostile to their culture, and they generally don't see 
government, corporations, or unions standing up for them either. So 
they are more into self-reliance -- knowing how to shoot back if 
somebody comes after them. When leftists talk about more gun control, 
they directly threaten this self-reliance and what conservatives view 
as their last-ditch means of preventing a police state.

	Fortunately, I think the tide on guns is turning. The Democrats are 
starting to realize that there is much less political benefit in being 
against guns than they thought there was. Kerry made pains this year to 
be photographed in hunting gear, to talk about how he believed in RKBA, 
how he'd been hunting since he was a boy, etc. Unfortunately for him, 
he lacked credibility, because he'd been casting anti-gun votes in the 
Senate for the past 30 years and never disassociated himself from those 
votes or explained how he'd changed his mind. When an organization in 
West Virginia gave him a gun as a gift during a visit to that state, it 
turned out that he would have been committing a crime to bring that gun 
across state lines back to Massachusetts because of a law he himself 
had helped pass!

	Ultimately, if the real police state does arrive, we cultural liberals 
better start learning how to shoot too. If the Iraqi insurgents can 
successfully fight an urban war against the might of the U.S. military 
and government, we can do it on our own turf too if push comes to shove.

>> Finally, anything can happen in the next four years.  When Nixon was
>> elected for a second term I was in despair, as I am now.
>> But....Watergate came along.  This war in Iraq is going south fast as
>> is the economy in the long run under the monkey who spends and cuts
>> taxes.  There will be a battle on the right on these very issues and
>> there will be hell to pay whoever won this election.  Believe in
>> serendipity, 'cause it rules the universe.
>
> I find even serendipity hard to believe in these days. Bush is the
> Teflon President; every single one of his mistakes and misdeeds has 
> been
> deflected, then more often than not dishonestly projected onto his
> opponents and critics. The Republicans, rather than losing seats in
> Congress as a result of their bitter partisanship and rancor, gained a
> larger majority. Corporate America get richer every day, at the expense
> of our middle and lower classes, the environment, and Iraqi citizens.
> The media continues to prefer pitting pundits against each other and
> calling it "news" instead of reporting the facts against either side.
> Karma's going to be a serious BITCH if it ever gets back to these
> people.

	The way I look at it, Bush has done much more wrong than right. But 
the main opposition (Kerry and the Democrats) failed to focus on the 
worst of it -- the growing police state in America. In a national 
scientific poll taken earlier this year for Libertarian presidential 
aspirant Aaron Russo (who lost the party's nomination to Michael 
Badnarik), 34% of respondents said they think the country is becoming a 
police state, and an additional 17% said they weren't sure. That's a 
majority, 51%, who either believe the U.S is turning into a police 
state, or think it might be happening. Those numbers should have been a 
wake-up call.

	I believe Kerry and the Democrats failed to focus on this because they 
themselves are complicit in it. The police state has been growing since 
well before Bush took office, under Clinton and previous presidents -- 
Bush just accelerated it. Kerry voted for the Patriot Act, and has not 
disavowed it. "Free speech zones" were in place at both the Republican 
and Democrat national conventions. Both parties conspired to shut 
alternative candidates out of the debates. Both have gone along with 
fascist security measures at the airports, increased police ability to 
violate the 4th and 6th Amendments, ramping up the "War on Drugs," 
adding yet more gun-carrying government agents, cracking down on raves, 
etc.

	The reality is that government spending grew by leaps and bounds under 
Bush and the past Republican Congress. But rather than siding with the 
majority of Americans who want smaller government, Kerry saved his 
strongest criticism of Bush's domestic policy for a *popular* policy 
that *reduced* the size of government -- Bush's tax cuts! How stupid 
was that? The reality is that the wealthiest 20% of Americans pay like 
80% of the income taxes, so of course any across-the-board cut in 
income taxes is going to "favor the wealthy." Criticizing income tax 
cuts as "favoring the wealthy" as Kerry did, is either ignorant or 
dishonest. In the case of prominent politicians who do it, I think we 
can probably rule out the "ignorant." They are familiar enough with 
where the tax money comes from to know how hard it is to have a 
substantial cut in income or other "progressive" taxes without 
"favoring the wealthy." That's why they always criticize, but never 
come up with their own alternative plans that would substantially cut 
taxes *without* "favoring the wealthy."

	If they want to help the poor directly, of course, there's plenty of 
other things they could do. Eliminate professional licensing laws that 
require people to pay an annual fee to government just to work. 
Eliminate laws that require people to pay off the government in order 
to start their own business. Cut Social Security taxes. Mandate 
reductions in union dues. Let anyone make money by using his or her 
vehicle as a taxi. Get rid of sales taxes. Make housing and health care 
affordable again by getting rid of the government regulations that have 
made them so expensive. In the case of health care, rein in the lawyers 
whose lawsuits are driving up medical insurance fees that get passed 
along to patients. Stop using parking and traffic tickets as a way to 
raise government revenue.

>> And fight on.  I will.  I think Bush in all his hubris in going down
>> hard before the end of his term, and I intend to do everything I can
>> to facilitate this.
>
> Me too. I also started visiting conservative blogs a couple of weeks 
> ago
> in an attempt to talk to sense into the people that think George Bush 
> is
> a "compassionate conservative", or some other such bullshit. I don't
> think it's about relating to religion. Most of the time, I've found
> reasonable people who are willing to have civil discussions as long as
> you show some respect for them. That's what's missing in politics 
> today,
> and my hope is that Bush may yet live up to his promise of being a
> "uniter" in his second term.
>
> Unfortunately I think the President will point to this election as a
> mandate to enact even more radical policies that will divide the
> American electorate even further, if that's possible. We can look
> forward to more misguided national education reforms; the privatization
> of major public services, including Social Security;

	We'd all be better off if we could legally invest the money paid into 
Social Security for our own retirement instead of government taking the 
money and then giving it back years later at a poor rate of return.

> renewed attacks on
> the civil rights of gays; the continued illegal imprisonment and 
> torture
> of both American citizens and foreign nationals; the further 
> dismantling
> of important regulatory agencies like the EPA, FDA, HHS, and the Labor
> Department; and more tax cuts for the wealthy at the expense of our
> nation's poor.

	These "important regulatory agencies" and their spending are 
destroying the U.S. economy. Some EPA regulations actually *hurt* the 
environment and wildlife protection, while the FDA enforces bullshit 
laws preventing people from self-medicating with marijuana and other 
drugs. Making people go to a doctor to get permission to take 
prescription drugs just makes those drugs that much more expensive and 
contributes to the lack of affordable health care for the poor.

> As much as I'd like to say that none of these things affects me, I
> can't. And to any potential voters that sat out this year because you
> couldn't decide or just don't care, I implore you: educate yourself.
> Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. Learn 
> the
> facts about the issues that affect your everyday life and those of your
> fellow citizens. Register to vote, and cast your ballot based on those
> issues. Voting is what makes our democracy work, and as long as you sit
> on the sidelines, your country will continue to elect people without
> your interests in mind. Bottom line: you can't complain if you don't
> inform yourself and vote your conscience.

	I can agree with that. But if you want a balanced picture, don't just 
listen to NPR. Listen to Rush Limbaugh as well. If you buy the 
Chronicle during the week, subscribe to the Washington Times national 
weekly edition for weekends. Don't just read Time or Newsweek magazines 
-- read Reason or Liberty. If your own news intake is ideologically 
balanced, you'll have a better perspective on what's going on with the 
rest of the country.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

     If you wanna start a revolution than the most efficiant thing to do is

From sfraves-return-116881-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Nov 05 04:52:42 2004

Date: Thu, 4 Nov 2004 20:52:36 -0800
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr new map of us

quoth Starchild:
> I haven't found that most conservatives base their politics 
> primarily on religion.

OK, I was exaggerating a bit. But it's clear that the religious right
had a huge impact in this religion, and Christian fundamentalists are,
well, fundamentally incapable of being presuaded that something is more
"moral" if it doesn't say so in the Bible.

> Certainly for many of them it informs their beliefs on hot-button
> issues like homosexuality, but look at the prominent conservative or
> conservative-leaning news sources in the U.S. -- most have more of a
> secular focus.
>
> For example, Rush Limbaugh, Insight Magazine, Weekly Standard, Fox
> News, the Wall Street Journal, National Review, WorldNetDaily.com,
> Townhall.com, American Spectator. Even the Washington Times, owned by
> right-wing religious figure Rev. Sun Myung Moon, doesn't have much of
> a religious focus. Thinking of religion-based news sources, only Pat
> Robertson's 700 Club comes readily to mind.

While the conservative establishment as a whole may not advocate
enlisting the aid of religious fundamentalists, that's exactly what
they've done. Karl Rove, hardly a religious man by anyone's standards,
clearly reached out to social conservatives for support. The President
himself is a born-again Christian, and few conservatives that I've
spoken with have voiced any distaste for his tendency to wield his faith
as political power so long as it helps him defeat the opposition. To aid
these efforts, the conservative-leaning media establishment regularly
inflates wedge issues to drum up support against social liberals among
the religious base.

> If you look at history, or even just what's going on in the world
> today, George Bush hardly even shows up on the chart of causes of
> human misery and suffering. First you've got to figure out why a
> benevolent God would allow people in power like Joseph Stalin, Mao
> Tse-Tsung, Pol Pot, Robert Mugabe, and Kim Il Sung.

Right. So... you agree then, it's unlikely there is a God? ;)

> >I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
> >ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
> >it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
> >Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as
> >far as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's
> >fucking depressing.
> 
> Conservatives (and libertarians) feel the same way about legal gun 
> ownership, which actually *reduces* violence.

I think we've had this discussion before, so I'm going to avoid it.
Needless to say I totally disagree, and I think it's disingenuous to
equate gay rights with gun ownership. One grants people the legal rights
to share property, have children, and take care of one anothers' legal
affairs; the other permits people the right to own and use lethal
weapons. I have to admit though, I've given a lot of thought to buying a
gun recently.

> For many on the right, guns are a *very* big deal. Maybe even a 
> bigger deal than religion.

So, if these people are *so* adamant about their right to own a gun
because it says they can in the Constitution, why do they feel the need
to amend the document to accomodate their religious beliefs? I really
don't think guns are as important to the fundamentalists as, so the
saying goes, "god and gays".

> They see the mainstream media, Hollywood, and the educational
> establishment as actively hostile to their culture, and they generally
> don't see government, corporations, or unions standing up for them
> either. So they are more into self-reliance -- knowing how to shoot
> back if somebody comes after them.
>
> When leftists talk about more gun control, they directly threaten this
> self-reliance and what conservatives view as their last-ditch means of
> preventing a police state.

Sure. So if these people are so into self-reliance, why do they feel the
need to impose their religious beliefs on people that they never come in
contact with? And if they don't see government or corporations standing
up for them, why the FUCK would they vote for Bush? Again, I think it's
because religion trumps everything for these people. We'll see how happy
they are when an industry unregulated fouls up the environment so much
that even their precious small towns and unmolested countryside become
so poisoned that they can no longer live there.

> Ultimately, if the real police state does arrive, we cultural liberals
> better start learning how to shoot too. If the Iraqi insurgents can
> successfully fight an urban war against the might of the U.S. military
> and government, we can do it on our own turf too if push comes to
> shove.

I learned how to shoot a .22 in summer camp, does that count? :)

> The way I look at it, Bush has done much more wrong than right. But
> the main opposition (Kerry and the Democrats) failed to focus on the
> worst of it -- the growing police state in America. [snip]
> 
> I believe Kerry and the Democrats failed to focus on this because 
> they themselves are complicit in it. [snip] Both have gone along with 
> fascist security measures at the airports, increased police ability to 
> violate the 4th and 6th Amendments, ramping up the "War on Drugs," 
> adding yet more gun-carrying government agents, cracking down on raves, 
> etc.

Agreed. Though I have to say, I trust a police state run by Democrats
only *slightly* more than Republicans. There's something extra creepy
about a Department of Justice run by a man who runs his office according
to the rules of a fundamentalist Christian sect called the "Assembly of
God". Given the choice between a religious fanatic and a power-hungry
lawyer, I'll take the lawyer, thanks. For me, nothing rings truer when
discussing American politics than the phrase "lesser of two evils".

> The reality is that government spending grew by leaps and bounds 
> under Bush and the past Republican Congress. But rather than siding with 
> the majority of Americans who want smaller government, Kerry saved his 
> strongest criticism of Bush's domestic policy for a *popular* policy 
> that *reduced* the size of government -- Bush's tax cuts! How stupid 
> was that?

Erm, not very stupid. Think about it: you're elected President at the
onset of a recession. Hundreds of thousands drop below the poverty line
during your first term. Millions lose their healthcare. Salaries of
everyone except the biggest earners fail to keep up with inflation. So
what do you do? Issue a tax cut that breaks down like this:

Salary			Average Tax Cut		Percentage of Tax Cut
< $20,000		$98					1.2%
$20-36,000		$508				6.2
$36-59,000		$791				9.6
$59-97,000		$1081				13.2
$97-205,000		$1225				11.2
$205-518,000	$2780				6.8
> $518,000		$85,002				51.8

(source: <http://www.ctj.org/html/gwb0602.htm>)

So the 2002 tax cut gave less than $100 to the poorest taxpayers over a
8-year period, and $85,000 each to the top %1. The Child Tax Credit
sunsets in 2005, but capital gains taxes don't return to 2000 levels
until 2009. I don't think that's just at all. The fact of the matter is
that the ultra-rich can get by without that money. It is our
responsibility--according to most religions, ironically enough--to help
the poorest among us through these tough times.

> The reality is that the wealthiest 20% of Americans pay like 
> 80% of the income taxes, so of course any across-the-board cut in 
> income taxes is going to "favor the wealthy."

Actually, the CBO reports that the wealthiest 20% pay about 64% of
federal taxes. The President's tax cuts have increased the burden of
middle and lower classes when they needed a tax cut the most.

> Criticizing income tax cuts as "favoring the wealthy" as Kerry did, is
> either ignorant or dishonest. In the case of prominent politicians who
> do it, I think we can probably rule out the "ignorant." They are
> familiar enough with where the tax money comes from to know how hard
> it is to have a substantial cut in income or other "progressive" taxes
> without "favoring the wealthy." That's why they always criticize, but
> never come up with their own alternative plans that would
> substantially cut taxes *without* "favoring the wealthy."

It seems pretty simple to me: make the tax brackets more progressive.
Cut taxes for the lowest wage earners, leave the middle untouched, and
increase taxes on the wealthiest. Eliminate payroll taxes, increase the
earned income tax credit, and place capital gains taxes on equal footing
with the income tax to account for all those people that simply live off
their investments and inheritances. Of course, reigning in spending on
government waste, including nuclear weapons research and "strategic"
missile defense, would help too. And don't forget those billions of
dollars doled out in no-bid contracts to corporations with close ties to
the executive branch...

> If they want to help the poor directly, of course, there's plenty of 
> other things they could do. Eliminate professional licensing laws that 
> require people to pay an annual fee to government just to work. 
> Eliminate laws that require people to pay off the government in order 
> to start their own business. Cut Social Security taxes. Mandate 
> reductions in union dues. Let anyone make money by using his or her 
> vehicle as a taxi. Get rid of sales taxes.

So where does all that revenue go? How is the government supposed to
maintain social services, fund education and medical research, keep the
military trained, or keep the roads paved? Oh yeah, that's right:
privatize everything. Give corporations control over everything that
people rely on, eliminate stable government jobs, and let the market
dictate what society needs. Great plan!

> Make housing and health care affordable again by getting rid of the
> government regulations that have made them so expensive. In the case
> of health care, rein in the lawyers whose lawsuits are driving up
> medical insurance fees that get passed along to patients.

That's such a load of bullshit. You can demonize lawyers all you want,
but do you know why medical insurance is so much more expensive? Because
the healthcare industry isn't regulated properly, and drug companies and
HMOs have been allowed to run roughshod over people without consequence.
It's fashionable to claim that medical malpractice is solely responsible
for the rising costs of healthcare, but that only accounts for 1% of the
increase. The biggest factors are the cost of prescription drugs (for
which we pay the most in the world) and the unholy alliance of
corporations and HMOs, which limits our choice--and thus, discourages
competition--in the medical insurance market.

Strangely, I haven't heard any Libertarians opposing the Republicans'
horrendous Medicare reform bill that explicity outlaws drug
re-importation from Canada and denies the system the ability to
negotiate with drug companies on a national scale.

> We'd all be better off if we could legally invest the money paid into
> Social Security for our own retirement instead of government taking
> the money and then giving it back years later at a poor rate of
> return.

But that defeats the purpose of Social Security. It's not supposed to
deliver big returns for individuals; it's supposed to deliver equal
returns for people that are incapable of saving money on their own.

> These "important regulatory agencies" and their spending are
> destroying the U.S. economy. Some EPA regulations actually *hurt* the
> environment and wildlife protection, while the FDA enforces bullshit
> laws preventing people from self-medicating with marijuana and other
> drugs. Making people go to a doctor to get permission to take
> prescription drugs just makes those drugs that much more expensive and
> contributes to the lack of affordable health care for the poor.

Then change the laws! Don't throw the baby out with the bathwater by
diluting the regulatory agencies and taking away their powers to prevent
industry from taking advantage of both American citizens and our trade
partners. The EPA used to provide defense from corporations that pollute
our air, water and land. The Labor Department used to have the power to
prevent corporations from working their employees to death (quite
literally). But Bush came into office and put former industry lobbyists
at the heads of almost every single regulatory agency, effectively
neutering their ability to regulate. And you wonder why lawsuits are
increasingly prevelant? Lawyers haven't gotten any slimier; people are
desperate for justice, and if the government won't provide it they turn
to attorneys (many of which are, admittedly, greedy--but IMO, this only
provides some balance to the greediness of corporate America).

I think if most Americans realized this, they'd be outraged. This year
the EPA eased mercury regulations while the FDA issued warnings to
concerning the levels of mercury found in fish (as a result, pregnant
women have to watch their tuna intake out of fear of poisoning their
unborn children). Regulations on the meat-packing industry have been
downgraded, increasing the likelihood of nation-wide contamination.
There are countless examples that illustrate the irresponsibility of
de-regulation in this country, the energy crisis nonwithstanding. The
Bush Administration is directly responsible for a great deal of these
mishaps, which boil down to corporate giveaways for his big campaign
donors.

> >As much as I'd like to say that none of these things affects me, I
> >can't. And to any potential voters that sat out this year because you
> >couldn't decide or just don't care, I implore you: educate yourself.
> >Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. [snip]
> 
> I can agree with that. But if you want a balanced picture, don't just
> listen to NPR. Listen to Rush Limbaugh as well.

I will do no such thing. NPR is the most objective news source I know
of. Michael Krasny dedicated an hour of Forum last month to national
third-party candidates, including Badnarik. Rush Limbaugh, on the other
hand, doesn't deserve to be on the air. He's a hateful, angry man that
parrots the Republican party's talking points and distorts the facts to
suit his ideological slant. He's just a cog in the right-wing attack
machine, and I wouldn't waste my time listening to a word he says if I
were you.

> If you buy the Chronicle during the week, subscribe to the Washington
> Times national weekly edition for weekends. Don't just read Time or
> Newsweek magazines -- read Reason or Liberty. If your own news intake
> is ideologically balanced, you'll have a better perspective on what's
> going on with the rest of the country.

I don't want ideological balance, I want objectivity. I'd rather know
the truth than try to figure it out by listening to talking heads on
either side try to skew an argument in their favor. That's what I hate
about the national news media: it's more about letting both sides duke
it out than getting to the facts of an issue.

Toodles,
--

is OK, but really NOW is not the time), take prayers out of school,
and next thing u know Christmas won't even be a national holiday.

Liberals don't have to be atheist to be secular. But that's what the
fundies are branding the liberals and it's working.



> 
> > >I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't hurt
> > >ANYONE, let alone affect ANY of the people who so strongly oppose
> > >it--can be one of the deciding factors when so much more is at stake.
> > >Yet 11 states overwhelmingly voted to ban it, and some even went as
> > >far as banning civil unions and domestic partner benefits. That's
> > >fucking depressing.
> >

> > ownership, which actually *reduces* violence.
> 
> I think we've had this discussion before, so I'm going to avoid it.
> Needless to say I totally disagree, and I think it's disingenuous to
> equate gay rights with gun ownership. One grants people the legal rights
> to share property, have children, and take care of one anothers' legal
> affairs; the other permits people the right to own and use lethal
> weapons. I have to admit though, I've given a lot of thought to buying a
> gun recently.
> 

Actually they have more in common as I think about it. They both
violate some long-held traditions (whether they're right or wrong is
not the issue). As we're on the downside of a social progression
cycle, it's not a good time to promote radical social changes.


> > For many on the right, guns are a *very* big deal. Maybe even a
> > bigger deal than religion.
> 
> So, if these people are *so* adamant about their right to own a gun
> because it says they can in the Constitution, why do they feel the need
> to amend the document to accomodate their religious beliefs? I really
> don't think guns are as important to the fundamentalists as, so the
> saying goes, "god and gays".
> 
> 

But it's not the fundies who voted for those amendments in 11 states
in a landslide. It shows that the average Christian Americans (and
even non-Christian ones) are not ready for as ridical a social change
as gay marriage. Over 60% of Americans believe gays should have equal
rights protected. They just don't think marriage is a gay right.


> > They see the mainstream media, Hollywood, and the educational
> > establishment as actively hostile to their culture, and they generally
> > don't see government, corporations, or unions standing up for them
> > either. So they are more into self-reliance -- knowing how to shoot
> > back if somebody comes after them.
> >
> > When leftists talk about more gun control, they directly threaten this
> > self-reliance and what conservatives view as their last-ditch means of
> > preventing a police state.
> 
> Sure. So if these people are so into self-reliance, why do they feel the
> need to impose their religious beliefs on people that they never come in
> contact with? And if they don't see government or corporations standing
> up for them, why the FUCK would they vote for Bush? Again, I think it's
> because religion trumps everything for these people. We'll see how happy
> they are when an industry unregulated fouls up the environment so much
> that even their precious small towns and unmolested countryside become
> so poisoned that they can no longer live there.
>

It's very convinient (and simply naive) to brand all conservatives as
religious fundies. They're not. This election is NOT even about the
religious right (no-one in the Bush Administration qualifies as a
religious fundie except John Ashcroft). It's about the convservatives
convincing middle America that their traditions are being threatened.
It's about being seen as the most powerful, most arrogant nation in
the world. The midwestern, pro-gun, non-fundie conservatives share
that view.
 

> > The way I look at it, Bush has done much more wrong than right. But
> > the main opposition (Kerry and the Democrats) failed to focus on the
> > worst of it -- the growing police state in America. [snip]

> > they themselves are complicit in it. [snip] Both have gone along with

> > adding yet more gun-carrying government agents, cracking down on raves,
> > etc.
> 
> Agreed. Though I have to say, I trust a police state run by Democrats
> only *slightly* more than Republicans. There's something extra creepy
> about a Department of Justice run by a man who runs his office according
> to the rules of a fundamentalist Christian sect called the "Assembly of
> God". Given the choice between a religious fanatic and a power-hungry
> lawyer, I'll take the lawyer, thanks. For me, nothing rings truer when
> discussing American politics than the phrase "lesser of two evils".
>

A police state is a police state. I would only turst a police state if
**I** run it.

In the post-9/11 mindset, the middle America doesn't care about having
a police state. They overwhelmingly support giving up some civil
liberty in exchange for better security. It's obviously a doomed idea,
but you can't just campaign against what they believe and think it'll
change their minds in a few months.

I think Kerry lost because he spent a big focus on the war in Iraq and
war on terror, but failed to deliver a dramatically differrent plan
for Iraq and failed to convince us that he'll do a better job to fight
terroism. He decided not to bring up his previous experiences on the
Counter-Terrorism Taskforce in his campaign (because he thinks his
experience cannot be translated into effective campaign soundbites),
which would have been a great asset for him.



> > Make housing and health care affordable again by getting rid of the
> > government regulations that have made them so expensive. In the case
> > of health care, rein in the lawyers whose lawsuits are driving up
> > medical insurance fees that get passed along to patients.
> 
> That's such a load of bullshit. You can demonize lawyers all you want,
> but do you know why medical insurance is so much more expensive? Because
> the healthcare industry isn't regulated properly, and drug companies and
> HMOs have been allowed to run roughshod over people without consequence.
> It's fashionable to claim that medical malpractice is solely responsible
> for the rising costs of healthcare, but that only accounts for 1% of the
> increase. The biggest factors are the cost of prescription drugs (for
> which we pay the most in the world) and the unholy alliance of
> corporations and HMOs, which limits our choice--and thus, discourages
> competition--in the medical insurance market.
> 
> Strangely, I haven't heard any Libertarians opposing the Republicans'
> horrendous Medicare reform bill that explicity outlaws drug
> re-importation from Canada and denies the system the ability to
> negotiate with drug companies on a national scale.
> 

That's right, they can scream about trial laywers raising medical
costs all they want but it has nexty to nothing to do with it. It all
costs down to the Republicans trying to demonize one of the biggest
groups that funds the Democratic Party: trial laywers.

Medical costs in the US is outrageous because they relationship
between insurance companies and healthcare providers and drug
companies preclude all of them from having to follolw to the rules of
free market. Hosptials and doctors can charge whatever they want
because the insurance company will just pay for it. And instead of
pressuring the providers and drug companies to lower the cost,
insurance companies either raise our premiums or cut our benefits or
downright deny to pay for our care.

We have the longest, most monopolizing patent protection for drug
companies. Prescription drugs are orders of magnitude more expensive
here than anywhere else in the world, they remain under patent
protection for the longest, and we have no options to import them from
anywhere else.




> > These "important regulatory agencies" and their spending are
> > destroying the U.S. economy. Some EPA regulations actually *hurt* the
> > environment and wildlife protection, while the FDA enforces bullshit
> > laws preventing people from self-medicating with marijuana and other
> > drugs. Making people go to a doctor to get permission to take
> > prescription drugs just makes those drugs that much more expensive and
> > contributes to the lack of affordable health care for the poor.
> 
> Then change the laws! Don't throw the baby out with the bathwater by
> diluting the regulatory agencies and taking away their powers to prevent
> industry from taking advantage of both American citizens and our trade
> partners. The EPA used to provide defense from corporations that pollute
> our air, water and land. The Labor Department used to have the power to
> prevent corporations from working their employees to death (quite
> literally). But Bush came into office and put former industry lobbyists
> at the heads of almost every single regulatory agency, effectively
> neutering their ability to regulate. And you wonder why lawsuits are
> increasingly prevelant? Lawyers haven't gotten any slimier; people are
> desperate for justice, and if the government won't provide it they turn
> to attorneys (many of which are, admittedly, greedy--but IMO, this only
> provides some balance to the greediness of corporate America).
> 

That's the scary thing. We all hate lawyers (not that all of them are
greedy, but the simple idea of paying $$ for justice is just sick),
yet we find ourselves having to look to lawyers more and more often to
protect ourselves from the government. Conservatives are supposed to
advocate small governement and minimum regulation in society and free
market. Now the neo-cons are turning their ideology towards
totaliarianism. There are many "true" conservatives who disagree with
the neocon ideology, liberals can win their hearts if they try hard
enough.

> I don't want ideological balance, I want objectivity. I'd rather know
> the truth than try to figure it out by listening to talking heads on
> either side try to skew an argument in their favor. That's what I hate
> about the national news media: it's more about letting both sides duke
> it out than getting to the facts of an issue.
> 

Being objective doesn't mean not having an opinion. You can have an
opinon and still be objective. That's my problem with normal news
outlets: they're afraid to have an opinion at all.

Being factual doesn't imply objectivity either. You can easily
manipulate opinions by omitting certain facts.

I want facts, facts that are thorough and complete (which means not
relying solely on US news sources). I want opinions as well. I want
ideological opinions from both sides . But most importantly, I want
the new outlets not be afraid to have an opinion about the talking
points from both sides.

Bible=20

	The religious right is an important part of the Republican base, =
no=20
question. This is partly because fundamentalists only recently got=20
their own viable party, the Constitution Party, while the Libertarian=20
Party has been drawing more socially tolerant folks away from the GOP=20
for over thirty years (along with attracting Democrats who get=20
economics). We may be seeing the evolution of a five-party system --=20
from the Constitution Party on the far right to the Green Party on the=20=

far left, with the Libertarian Party between the Republicans and=20
Democrats in the middle. Of course it remains to be seen where they=20
will each position themselves on the libertarian-authoritarian axis=20
(see http://www.self-gov.org ).

	As far as wielding faith in pursuit of political power, =
politicians of=20
all stripes regularly wrap themselves in the language of faith and seek=20=

support from church-goers and church leaders, whatever they may=20
personally believe. Leftists even have their own version of mixing=20
politics and Christianity, known as "liberation theology," which=20
basically uses the religion as a prop for Marxism. As far as I'm=20
concerned, bad public policy is bad public policy, period. A bad law=20
doesn't get any better just because the person who wrote it was=20
motivated by secular reasons rather than by religion.

	Now when you say "the conservative-leaning media establishment," =
I'm=20
sorry, but that's just mistaken. Even many leftists will admit that=20
most of the mainstream media in the U.S. lean to the left when compared=20=

to the beliefs of the U.S. public as a whole. This is starting to=20
change with the emergence of outlets like Fox News on the right to=20
balance CNN and CBS on the left however, and it's coming as a serious=20
shock to many people who have been long accustomed to getting their=20
news with a liberal bias and seeing it as normal.

>> If you look at history, or even just what's going on in the world

>> Tse-Tsung, Pol Pot, Robert Mugabe, and Kim Il Sung.

	I'm agnostic myself, but if god exists I think it would be quite=20=

unlike the God described in the Bible. Beyond merely tolerating the=20

of evil.

>>> I just don't understand how gay marriage--something that doesn't =
hurt

>> Conservatives (and libertarians) feel the same way about legal gun

is "armed gays don't get bashed."

	Because they hypocritically uphold the Bill of Rights when it =

think=20
perhaps yes. Bill Clinton publicly blamed gun owners for the Democrats'=20=

>> They see the mainstream media, Hollywood, and the educational

	Now that is an excellent question. I try to pose variations on =

	I think the biggest reason people voted for Bush is because they =
