>  So what do you do? Issue a tax cut that breaks down like this:
>
> Salary			Average Tax Cut		Percentage of =
Tax Cut
> < $20,000		$98					1.2%
> $20-36,000		$508				6.2
> $36-59,000		$791				9.6
> $59-97,000		$1081				13.2
> $97-205,000		$1225				11.2
> $205-518,000	$2780				6.8
>> $518,000		$85,002				51.8
>
> (source: <http://www.ctj.org/html/gwb0602.htm>)
>
> So the 2002 tax cut gave less than $100 to the poorest taxpayers over =
a
> 8-year period, and $85,000 each to the top %1. The Child Tax Credit
> sunsets in 2005, but capital gains taxes don't return to 2000 levels
> until 2009. I don't think that's just at all. The fact of the matter =
is
> that the ultra-rich can get by without that money. It is our
> responsibility--according to most religions, ironically enough--to =
help
> the poorest among us through these tough times.

	There's a chart on the effects of the Bush tax cuts from =
Citizens for=20
Tax Justice (the same group that provided the numbers you cite above)=20
at http://www.ctj.org/pdf/allbushcut.pdf which paints a rather=20
different picture. It shows that while the top 1% of earners get back a=20=

relatively large percent of their taxes under the cuts, most of the top=20=

20% of earners don't do that well, getting an average of only 7% back=20
compared to 10% and 12% for the bottom two categories of earners. It's=20=

noted that those in the higher income brackets will see greater=20
reductions in their tax bills if the cuts do not expire as scheduled,=20
but it's certainly not as lopsided as suggested by the table you=20
posted, which looks only at end dollar amounts rather than comparing=20
refunds as percentages of what a person actually paid in the first=20
place.

	If two people go to Safeway and one of them gets $20 discounted =
from=20
his purchase using the Club Card while the other only gets $5 off, you=20=

can't just look at the absolute dollar amounts and say that the person=20=

getting the $5 discount was cheated. You have to compare their original=20=

grocery bills, otherwise it's next to meaningless.

>> The reality is that the wealthiest 20% of Americans pay like
>> 80% of the income taxes, so of course any across-the-board cut in
>> income taxes is going to "favor the wealthy."
>
> Actually, the CBO reports that the wealthiest 20% pay about 64% of
> federal taxes.

	OK, let's say for the sake of argument it's 64%. That's still =
over=20
half the money being stolen from 1/5 of the people. And it's not=20
necessarily the wealthiest 1/5, just the 1/5 who earn the most. There=20
is a difference. Many wealthy people may have relatively little income,=20=

while some poor people may have a high income but a lot of expenses.=20
Others with high incomes may be reinvesting all their profits into=20
growing their businesses and creating jobs. I say instead of=20
predatorily taking more from the people who earn the most, who may or=20
may not be rich, let's adopt some of the other policies I suggested to=20=

help those on the bottom, like eliminating taxes on start-up businesses.

> The President's tax cuts have increased the burden of
> middle and lower classes when they needed a tax cut the most.

	If there were a tax cut for only the poor and middle class on =
the=20
ballot, and you had to pick either cutting their taxes or maintaining=20
the size of big government, which would you choose? I have not heard=20
any leftists proposing such a cut, but I would certainly support it if=20=

they did.

>> Criticizing income tax cuts as "favoring the wealthy" as Kerry did, =
is
>> either ignorant or dishonest. In the case of prominent politicians =
who
>> do it, I think we can probably rule out the "ignorant." They are
>> familiar enough with where the tax money comes from to know how hard
>> it is to have a substantial cut in income or other "progressive" =
taxes
>> without "favoring the wealthy." That's why they always criticize, but
>> never come up with their own alternative plans that would
>> substantially cut taxes *without* "favoring the wealthy."
>
> It seems pretty simple to me: make the tax brackets more progressive.

	You mean to make it even harder to cut taxes without "favoring =
the=20
wealthy?" That's a stroke of genius!

> Cut taxes for the lowest wage earners, leave the middle untouched, and
> increase taxes on the wealthiest.

	If you cut taxes on the lowest wage earners, the middle and top=20=

earners will already be paying a greater percentage of the tax burden=20
even if you don't increase their taxes at all.

> Eliminate payroll taxes, increase the
> earned income tax credit, and place capital gains taxes on equal=20
> footing
> with the income tax to account for all those people that simply live=20=

> off
> their investments and inheritances. Of course, reigning in spending on
> government waste, including nuclear weapons research and "strategic"
> missile defense, would help too. And don't forget those billions of
> dollars doled out in no-bid contracts to corporations with close ties=20=

> to
> the executive branch...
>
>> If they want to help the poor directly, of course, there's plenty of
>> other things they could do. Eliminate professional licensing laws =
that
>> require people to pay an annual fee to government just to work.
>> Eliminate laws that require people to pay off the government in order
>> to start their own business. Cut Social Security taxes. Mandate
>> reductions in union dues. Let anyone make money by using his or her
>> vehicle as a taxi. Get rid of sales taxes.
>
> So where does all that revenue go?

	The idea that every tax cut must be "paid for" is a media myth =
that=20
comes from a failure to understand the concept of the Laffer Curve*: =20
When tax rates are higher, more people avoid paying taxes because the=20
incentive to do so is greater, while lower tax rates result in more=20
compliance. Thus it is often possible to reduce tax rates and actually=20=

*increase* the amount of revenue being taken in by government. Not that=20=

government actually needs the money!

*More detailed explanation at=20
http://www.blonnet.com/iw/2004/01/11/stories/2004011100391100.htm

> How is the government supposed to
> maintain social services, fund education and medical research, keep =
the
> military trained, or keep the roads paved? Oh yeah, that's right:
> privatize everything.

	Social services? Show me one that government is doing a good job=20=

providing. The traditional tough-love of the Salvation Army, private=20
abortion clinics and health clinics, church soup kitchens, etc., are=20
much more effective. The money being wasted on inefficient government=20
programs should be taken away and given directly to groups like these=20
instead. With President Bush's "faith-based" initiative now forcing=20
taxpayers to fund religious-based charities, liberals may soon wish=20
they'd gotten government out of the charity business and let people=20
make their own choices while conservatives were open to such a=20
solution. There is still a window of opportunity there.

	Homeschooled kids and kids in non-government schools are getting =
a=20
better education than kids in government schools. Government school=20
teachers agree -- they send their own kids to non-government schools at=20=

a higher rate than the general population.

	The military is way over-funded. The U.S. government has a =
bigger=20
military budget than something like the next 10 top-spending countries=20=

combined.

	Pharmaceutical companies were told, "Poor people in other =
countries=20
can't afford your medicine. Sell it to them cheaper." Because most of=20
their drug sales were in the U.S., they were still able to cover the=20
millions of dollars it costs to develop a new drug due to government=20
regulations by selling full-priced drugs here, they complied. But then=20=

people started saying, "Drugs are cheaper overseas! Companies are=20
price-gouging! Americans should be able to buy prescription drugs in=20
Canada!" Medical research is largely funded by drug sales. What do you=20=

think is going to happen to medical research if companies are prevented=20=

from recouping the costs of that research by making a high profit on=20
the small percentage of drugs that are successfully brought to market?

	Government jobs are stable, I'll give you that. Compared to =
private=20
enterprise, it's difficult to fire anybody in civil service, no matter=20=

how badly they're fucking up. But I take it that your main point is=20
that you don't want to eliminate too many taxes and regulations even=20
when doing so would directly benefit poor people, because your top=20
priority is keeping big government. How you expect to maintain a=20
perpetually huge and powerful government without eventually getting a=20
police state I have no idea, but that is one of the paradoxes of=20
liberal ideology.

> Give corporations control over everything that
> people rely on, eliminate stable government jobs, and let the market
> dictate what society needs. Great plan!

	Making it easier and less expensive to do business would result =
in=20
more entrepreneurship and more competition. More competition means=20
*less* corporate control, not more. The opposite of competition is=20
monopoly; the more competition you have in an economy, the fewer=20
monopolies, and vice versa. Only when a company enjoys a monopoly can=20
it effectively exercise control. So contrary to your idea that a free=20
market would mean more corporate control, the reality is nearly the=20
opposite.

>> Make housing and health care affordable again by getting rid of the
>> government regulations that have made them so expensive. In the case
>> of health care, rein in the lawyers whose lawsuits are driving up
>> medical insurance fees that get passed along to patients.
>
> That's such a load of bullshit. You can demonize lawyers all you want,
> but do you know why medical insurance is so much more expensive?=20
> Because
> the healthcare industry isn't regulated properly, and drug companies=20=

> and
> HMOs have been allowed to run roughshod over people without=20
> consequence.

	Health care isn't regulated properly? It's become more and more=20=

regulated over the years, while costs have gone up and up. And you can=20=

bet your bottom dollar that's no coincidence. Ask a doctor who's been=20
practicing for a while how the amount of regulation and paperwork he or=20=

she has to deal with now compares to twenty or thirty years ago.

> It's fashionable to claim that medical malpractice is solely=20
> responsible
> for the rising costs of healthcare, but that only accounts for 1% of=20=

> the
> increase.

	Of course medical malpractice isn't "solely" responsible for =
rising=20
health care costs -- in a complex economy, where is one factor ever=20
"solely" responsible for increasing prices in an entire industry? But=20
realizing that the rising cost of insurance is a big factor in=20
expensive health care isn't just "fashionable" -- it's accurate.=20
According to a 2002 Department of Health and Human Services report,

"The litigation and malpractice insurance problem raids the wallet of=20
every American. Money spent on malpractice premiums (and the litigation=20=

costs that largely determine premiums) raises health care costs.=20
Doctors alone spent $6.3 billion last year to obtain coverage.=20
Hospitals and nursing homes spent additional billions of dollars.

The litigation system also imposes large indirect costs on the health=20
care system. Defensive medicine that is caused by unlimited and=20
unpredictable liability awards not only increases patients=92 risk but =
it=20
also adds costs. The leading study estimates that limiting unreasonable=20=

awards for non-economic damages could reduce health care costs by 5 -=20
9% without adversely affecting quality of care. This would save $60 -=20
108 billion in health care costs each year. These savings would lower=20
the cost of health insurance and permit an additional 2.4 - 4.3 million=20=

Americans to obtain insurance.

The costs of the runaway litigation system are paid by all Americans,=20
through higher premiums for health insurance (which reduces workers=92=20=

take home pay if the insurance is provided by an employer), higher=20
out-of-pocket payments when they obtain care, and higher taxes."

	This report describes the problem in some detail. I suggest you =
check=20
it out.

(source: http://aspe.hhs.gov/daltcp/reports/litrefm.htm )

> The biggest factors are the cost of prescription drugs (for
> which we pay the most in the world) and the unholy alliance of
> corporations and HMOs, which limits our choice--and thus, discourages
> competition--in the medical insurance market.
>
> Strangely, I haven't heard any Libertarians opposing the Republicans'
> horrendous Medicare reform bill that explicity outlaws drug
> re-importation from Canada and denies the system the ability to
> negotiate with drug companies on a national scale.

	Re-importing drugs from Canada that were made in the U.S. =
because they=20
are more expensive here is the kind of ridiculous scenario that results=20=

from government interference in the economy. If we had a free market,=20
such nonsense would not be occurring. But the system is so distorted=20
now, that if you just let people buy cheap drugs from Canada without=20
making any other changes, you'll screw the pharmaceutical industry and=20=

medical research along with it.

	As a matter of fact Libertarians have criticized the Medicare =
"reform"=20
bill (see http://www.lp.org/press/archive.php?function=3Dview&record=3D649=
=20
among others). It's not even a reform -- it's a new welfare pork plan=20
for seniors to have the government pay for their prescription drugs,=20
further putting Medicare into the red. By the time most of us on this=20
list are retirement age, the system will be long past bankrupt, and=20
we'll be left to pay off the debt.

>> We'd all be better off if we could legally invest the money paid into
>> Social Security for our own retirement instead of government taking
>> the money and then giving it back years later at a poor rate of
>> return.
>
> But that defeats the purpose of Social Security. It's not supposed to
> deliver big returns for individuals; it's supposed to deliver equal
> returns for people that are incapable of saving money on their own.

	Social Security was set up as a voluntary program during the=20
Depression for certain categories of working-class people without=20
employer retirement plans to save for their retirement. It was not=20
meant to be a mandatory socialist wealth-redistribution scheme, but=20
that is what it has turned into.

	Letting people save for their own retirement works. Chile =
established=20
an optional private Social Security system in 1981 which has worked=20
well for over 20 years:

*  Within 2 years, 90% of workers elected to join it.
*   The tax rate for the privatized system is 13%. The tax rate for the=20=

government program was 26%.
*   The average retirement and disability incomes are higher in the=20
privatized system than in the government program.
*   The privatized system has no deficit. The government program had a=20=

long term deficit equal to more than 100% of the Gross Domestic Product.
*   The government program paid benefits by taxing people who were=20
currently working.
*   The privatized system is self funded. Every 3 months, workers=20
receive a statement that informs them how much money they have saved.

(source: http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm#Private )

>> These "important regulatory agencies" and their spending are
>> destroying the U.S. economy. Some EPA regulations actually *hurt* the
>> environment and wildlife protection, while the FDA enforces bullshit
>> laws preventing people from self-medicating with marijuana and other
>> drugs. Making people go to a doctor to get permission to take
>> prescription drugs just makes those drugs that much more expensive =
and
>> contributes to the lack of affordable health care for the poor.
>
> Then change the laws! Don't throw the baby out with the bathwater by
> diluting the regulatory agencies and taking away their powers to=20
> prevent
> industry from taking advantage of both American citizens and our trade
> partners.

	In this case, the baby has shit in the bathtub. It's time to =
drain the=20
tub, clean up the mess, and start over. Regulations *preventing* U.S.=20
industry from taking advantage of trading partners? Ha! That's the rare=20=

exception, not the rule. Most trade regulations are designed to protect=20=

domestic industry at the expense of both overseas trade partners and of=20=

domestic consumers who have to pay higher prices due to the lack of=20
competition.

	Just look how difficult it's been for Mexican truck drivers to =
get=20
permission to transport goods to destinations in the U.S. Over ten=20
years after NAFTA supposedly guaranteed free trade between the two=20
countries, it took a Supreme Court decision this year to finally force=20=

the authorities to give them equal access. For an example of how these=20=

shipping restrictions affect you, avocados here cost nearly $2 each=20
when in Mexico the price is about 10 cents (see=20
http://www.hispanicvista.com/html2/120902osio.htm ).

> The EPA used to provide defense from corporations that pollute
> our air, water and land. The Labor Department used to have the power =
to
> prevent corporations from working their employees to death (quite
> literally). But Bush came into office and put former industry =
lobbyists
> at the heads of almost every single regulatory agency, effectively
> neutering their ability to regulate. And you wonder why lawsuits are
> increasingly prevelant? Lawyers haven't gotten any slimier; people are
> desperate for justice, and if the government won't provide it they =
turn
> to attorneys (many of which are, admittedly, greedy--but IMO, this =
only
> provides some balance to the greediness of corporate America).
>
> I think if most Americans realized this, they'd be outraged. This year
> the EPA eased mercury regulations while the FDA issued warnings to
> concerning the levels of mercury found in fish (as a result, pregnant
> women have to watch their tuna intake out of fear of poisoning their
> unborn children). Regulations on the meat-packing industry have been
> downgraded, increasing the likelihood of nation-wide contamination.
> There are countless examples that illustrate the irresponsibility of
> de-regulation in this country, the energy crisis nonwithstanding. The
> Bush Administration is directly responsible for a great deal of these
> mishaps, which boil down to corporate giveaways for his big campaign
> donors.

	Let's get something straight: Money belongs to the people who =
earn it,=20
not to the government. When government takes your money and then gives=20=

some of it back to you, or you find out that the cost of regulations=20
you have to obey is going down by 1% this year (instead of up by the=20
usual 5%), that's not a "giveaway," it's a partial return of stolen=20
property.

	When government subsidizes corporations -- which it does =
frequently=20
under both Republicans and Democrats, as evidenced by the fact that=20
corporate welfare recipients give heavily to both parties (see=20
http://www.opensecrets.org/industries/mems.asp ) -- that *is* a=20
giveaway, and it's wrong. But let's not confuse the two concepts.

	Before criticizing things like the EPA's easing of regulations =
on=20
mercury, there are important questions that need to be asked. For=20
instance, how much real danger is there from mercury in tuna fish? How=20=

many unborn babies have actually been poisoned? Is it proven, or is it=20=

a media scare story like crack babies? Should the government force=20
industry to spend $100 million (random hypothetical number) to make=20
tuna 100% mercury-free, if the same expenditure, channeled into worker=20=

salaries, lower prices, and shareholder returns, could have marginally=20=

improved the standard of living of all the tuna industry workers, tuna=20=

buyers, and people whose pension plans include stock in fisheries or=20
tuna-packing companies? Is this regulation worth costing many people=20
that little bit of extra income that might have enabled some of the=20
thousands or millions of people affected to afford to move to safer=20
neighborhoods, to afford better health care, better day care, to=20
upgrade to a newer, safer, less polluting car, to be able to afford to=20=

eat lunch somewhere healthier than McDonalds, etc.?

	The problem with the knee-jerk "let's regulate!" attitude is =
that it=20
rarely takes any kind of real economic cost-benefit analysis into=20
account. Regulators typically look at the immediate, intended effects=20
of their legislation, often based on faulty or incomplete science or=20
data, while failing to look at the more subtle and unintended=20
consequences of their feel-good policies.

	I strongly recommend the book "Give Me A Break!" by ABC's John =
Stossel=20
( http://www.lfb.com/index.php?deptid=3D&parentid=3D&stocknumber=3DSL8778 =
)=20
which has a lot of great material on the  topic of risks and costs, as=20=

well as on the issue of media bias and other issues.

>>> As much as I'd like to say that none of these things affects me, I
>>> can't. And to any potential voters that sat out this year because =
you
>>> couldn't decide or just don't care, I implore you: educate yourself.
>>> Listen to NPR or read a newspaper during your morning commute. =
[snip]
>>
>> I can agree with that. But if you want a balanced picture, don't just
>> listen to NPR. Listen to Rush Limbaugh as well.
>
> I will do no such thing. NPR is the most objective news source I know
> of. Michael Krasny dedicated an hour of Forum last month to national
> third-party candidates, including Badnarik.

	I like NPR, but if you take an honest look at their programming,=20=

you'll admit they lean to the left. They're not partisans like Rush=20
Limbaugh or Michael Moore, but I think there is a slight slant there.=20
And although Michael Krasny has generally been good about giving=20
airtime to political alternatives -- which as a taxpayer-funded news=20
source NPR damned well ought to be -- he also moderated a recent Jewish=20=

Community Center debate in SF between supporters of Bush and Kerry=20
which excluded alternative party candidates. I know because I happened=20=

to be in the building for a school board event happening that same=20
night, and found out about it accidentally.

> Rush Limbaugh, on the other
> hand, doesn't deserve to be on the air. He's a hateful, angry man that
> parrots the Republican party's talking points and distorts the facts =
to
> suit his ideological slant. He's just a cog in the right-wing attack
> machine, and I wouldn't waste my time listening to a word he says if I
> were you.

	If you were talking about Michael Savage, I would agree with =
you. But=20
Rush, despite his noted hypocrisy on the drug issue and a number of=20
other positions that I strongly disagree with, has a lot of good=20
insights on politics, economics, and society. I don't find him hateful=20=

or angry; he is generally good-humored, and polite to his callers. He=20
also gets points with me for choosing Walter Williams as his usual=20
substitute host -- Williams is a black man who is more libertarian than=20=

conservative.

>> If you buy the Chronicle during the week, subscribe to the Washington
>> Times national weekly edition for weekends. Don't just read Time or
>> Newsweek magazines -- read Reason or Liberty. If your own news intake
>> is ideologically balanced, you'll have a better perspective on what's
>> going on with the rest of the country.
>
> I don't want ideological balance, I want objectivity.

	Would you trust my opinion on what constitutes objectivity? How =
about=20
Rush Limbaugh's opinion? No? Then I hope you won't mind if I choose=20
ideological diversity in the news over your version of objectivity.=20
Those who want to make up their own minds based on hearing a wide=20
variety of viewpoints are advised to do the same.

> I'd rather know
> the truth than try to figure it out by listening to talking heads on
> either side try to skew an argument in their favor. That's what I hate
> about the national news media: it's more about letting both sides duke
> it out than getting to the facts of an issue.

	Well, we're pretty much the equivalent of those talking heads =
trying=20
to skew an argument in our favor here on SFRaves <grin>. But I hope=20
that my presentation has at least been somewhat fact-based and=20
informative, if admittedly partisan from a libertarian perspective.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>=

Subject: [sfraves] the bush era

What the British papers are saying....
 

Guardian Unlimited
<thewrap-list@guardianunlimited.co.uk> wrote:

    Subject: The Wrap: The Bush era
    From: Guardian Unlimited
    To: Guardian Unlimited
    Date: Thu, 4 Nov 2004 09:46:15 +0000 (UTC)

    The Wrap: The Bush era

    Jane Perrone and Mark Oliver
    04 November 2004

    Welcome to the Wrap, Guardian Unlimited's round-up
of the best of the
    day's papers.

    AND NOW FOR THE NEXT FOUR YEARS

    "We may not like it. In fact, to tell the truth,
we don't like it one
    bit ... Mr Bush has won fair (so far as we can
see) and square. He
    and his country - and the rest of the world - now
have to deal with
    it."

    Such is the sober mood of the Guardian's leader
writers in the wake of
    George Bush's victory in the US elections, matched
by the blacked-out
    front of the paper's G2 features section, which
contains just two
    words: "Oh, God". The Telegraph's leader line is
diametrically
    opposed, saying that Americans have "demonstrated
once and for all
    that no power on Earth can intimidate a free
nation... This is a
    president who can really speak for America", the
piece concludes.

    The British press - acutely aware of how out of
date they looked
    yesterday morning in this age of 24 hour news -
devote most of this
    morning's column inches to predicting what another
four years with Mr
    Bush in the White House will mean to America and
the rest of the
    world.

    Some do pause to wonder at the outcome, though.
The Mirror asks
    disdainfully: "How can 59,054,087 people be so
DUMB?" on its front
    page, promising more coverage of the "US election
disaster" inside.
    Nevertheless, that number was the highest number
of votes for any US
    presidential candidates in history, and the first
time since George
    Bush senior in 1988 that a US president has been
elected by a clear
    popular majority. ("Once it looked like an
aberration. Now it is an
    era," notes the Guardian's Jonathan Freedland).

    The Independent prints pictures of prisoners at
Guantanamo Bay and Abu
    Ghraib alongside a soldier in Iraq, oil piplines
and a smug picture
    of the new president with the words "four more
years".

    The Sun doesn't deem it necessary to cover events
in the US until page
    six, preferring instead to plaster its cover with
the news that "pop
    hunk" Will Young has been burgled. Once it does
get down to business,
    in a double-page spread headed "Double-ya!", it
comes up with a list
    of jobs for John Kerry (ignoring the fact he has a
perfectly good
    position as a US senator), including "Jimmy Hill
chin double" and
    "Scotland footie boss - they are used to losers".

    A page later and Sun commentator Richard
Littlejohn is in triumphal
    mood. "Michael Moore, Osama bin Laden, Saddam
Hussein, Jacques
    Chirac, Gerhard Schroeder, Kofi Annan, Yasser
Arafat, the BBC,
    Guardianistas, Channel 4 News, Robin Cook, Clare
Short, most of the
    parliamentary Labour party, half the Tory party,
Charlie Kennedy,
    your boy took one hell of a beating", he gloats.

    Every pundit, of course, has plenty of advice for
Mr Bush about how he
    should spend the next four years. A Times leader
urges him to use his
    powerful mandate as an "extraordinary opportunity"
to "advance an
    imaginative agenda for himself and his party",
including launching a
    new Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

    The Middle East is uppermost in the British prime
minister's mind, at
    least. Mr Blair defended his relationship with
America last night and
    said that the peace process is the single most
important challenge
    facing the world, "remarks not echoed in George
Bush's own acceptance
    speech", the Guardian notes.

    The Independent's Steve Richards posits that Mr
Blair must be keeping
    his fingers crossed that his Texan friend's
foreign policy ambitions
    do not lie elsewhere - namely, Iran. "If a newly
self-confident
    President Bush were to contemplate an attack on
another rogue state,
    Mr Blair would be placed in an impossible
position." Max Hastings in
    the Mail is worried. "Who is likely to believe any
warning about the
    threat posed by an Iranian bomb if it is signed by
George W Bush and
    his friend Tony?" he asks.

    Other writers consider the fate of the losers.
Former Democratic
    presidential candidate Gary Hart, writing in the
Independent,
    concludes that his party has "yet to convince the
majority of
    Americans that it understands the threats and
dangers, some real,
    some perceived, of the new century", while the
former Clinton adviser
    Sidney Blumenthal says that, in the aftermath of
the result, "the
    Democrats will form their ritual circular firing
squad of
    recriminations".

    Anatole Kaletsky's words in the Times may provide
some comfort for Mr
    Kerry, claiming that his loss in 2004 could set
the Republicans up
    for a disastrous four years in power, allowing
them to reunite around
    a new leader.

    That new leader, according to Gavin Esler in the
Mail, is Hillary
    Clinton. "You might like to make to make a note of
today's date. It
    is Day One of the Hillary 2008 campaign", he
writes in the Mail. It's
    widely agreed among Democrats that Mrs Clinton is
"the leading figure
    to challenge the Republicans in 2008", possibly
with the charismatic
    black senator Barack Obama as her running mate. Mr
Obama - ("the son
    of a white woman from Kansas and a former goat
herd from Kenya")
    provided "one bright spot on a night of
unremitting gloom for the
    Democrats" by securing a landslide victory in
Illinois, notes the
    Telegraph.

    But who could her opponent be? The Mirror thinks
the most likely
    candidate is former New York mayor, Rudy Giuliani.
But the Times
    thinks it will be a family affair in a piece
headlined: "Hillary v
    Jeb: the grudge match for 2008?"

    * Jonathan Freedland
   
(http://www.guardian.co.uk/uselections2004/comment/story/0,14259,1342920,00.html)
    * PM defends close ties to US
   
(http://www.guardian.co.uk/uselections2004/story/0,13918,1343072,00.html)
    * Defeat offers silver lining for Hillary Clinton
   
(http://www.guardian.co.uk/uselections2004/story/0,13918,1342907,00.html)
    * Sidney Blumenthal
   
(http://www.guardian.co.uk/uselections2004/comment/story/0,14259,1343006,00.html)
    * Mirror: Divided States
   
(http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/allnews/tm_objectid=14832114%26method=full%26siteid=50143%26headline=u%2ds%2d%2delection%2ddisaster%2dleaves%2dstates%2ddivided-name_page.html)
    * Telegraph: No power on earth can intimidate a
free nation
   
(http://www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion/main.jhtml;sessionid=KXVWDSLDLOVTPQFIQMGSM5OAVCBQWJVC?xml=/opinion/2004/11/04/dl0401.xml&sSheet=/portal/2004/11/04/ixportal.html)
    * Independent: Gary Hart
   
(http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/story.jsp?story=579265)
    * Sun: Double-ya!
   
(http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2004511727,00.html)
    * Times: Hillary v Jeb: the grudge match for 2008?
   
(http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,11069-1343862,00.html)
    * Times: Anatole Kaletsky
   
(http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,11069-1343889,00.html)
    * Mirror: Hillary is on track for Democrat 2008
triumph
   
(http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/allnews/tm_objectid=14832117%26method=full%26siteid=50143%26headline=hillary%2dis%2don%2dtrack%2dfor%2d2008%2dtriumph-name_page.htm)

    KARZAI DULY ELECTED

    With most media eyes focused on America, the news
that Hamid Karzai
    has been confirmed as Afghanistan's first elected
leader only appears
    in the papers' peripheral vision. The Guardian
leads its
    international pages with the news, stating that
Karzai's 55% majority
    win will "intensify pressure for a crackdown on
Afghanistan's
    warlord-driven drugs boom".

    "It is still not clear if Mr Karzai's nearest
rival, the Tajik leader
    and former education minister Younus Qanooni, who
won 16% of the
    vote, has accepted the result", notes the
Telegraph.

    Karzai's victory has been overshadowed by the
kidnapping of three UN
    election workers the militant group
Jaish-e-Muslimeen. Militants
    holding Annetta Flanigan, from Northern Ireland,
and two fellow
    election officials - a Filipino and a Kosovan -
extended their
    deadline until 2pm on Friday. The group is
demanding the withdrawal
    of British and American troops from Afghanistan,
and the release of
    all Muslim prisoners from Guantanamo Bay, in Cuba.

    * Karzai urged to tackle warlords after poll win
   
(http://www.guardian.co.uk/afghanistan/story/0,1284,1342713,00.html)
    * Telegraph: Karzai wins power in Afghan elections
   
(http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml;sessionid=KXVWDSLDLOVTPQFIQMGSM5OAVCBQWJVC?xml=/news/2004/11/04/wafg04.xml&sSheet=/portal/2004/11/04/ixportal.html)

    RUUD RUNS RIOT

    Man Utd striker Ruud van Nistelrooy dominates the
sports pages for
    happier reasons today after his four goals gave
his side to a 4-1 win
    over Sparta Prague in the Champions League at Old
Trafford last
    night. The Dutch striker has been attracting the
wrong kind of
    headlines recently for stamping on Arsenal's
Ashley Cole and is
    serving a domestic ban.

    Last night Sir Alex Ferguson hailed him as the
"most clinical
    finisher" in the club's history. It "scarcely"
mattered that he
    benefited from two atrocious backpasses and a
penalty for three of
    his goals, the Guardian says. The Mirror's
headline is "Anything Roo
    can do, Ruud can do better", referring to Wayne
Rooney's hat trick in
    the last European game at Old Trafford. Last
night's result "all but
    guarantees" Man Utd safe passage into the knockout
phase, the
    Guardian says.

    Liverpool also triumphed last night with an
impressive 0-1 win at
    Deportivo La Coruna and are in second place in
their Champions League
    group.

    * Four-star Van Nistelrooy runs riot
   
(http://football.guardian.co.uk/Match_Report/0,1527,1343013,00.html)
    * Andrade gives Liverpool the initiative
   
(http://football.guardian.co.uk/Match_Report/0,1527,1342985,00.html)

    COMING UP ON GUARDIAN UNLIMITED TODAY

    >>> Britain would not back American military
action against Iran, the
    foreign secretary Jack Straw said today.

    >>> House prices fell by 1.1% last month.

    >>> The Bank of England is expected to keep
interest rates at 4.75%.


    All comments and suggestions are welcome. Please
send them to
    unlimited@guardianunlimited.co.uk.

    If you have a query about your Wrap subscription,
email
    subshelp@guardian.co.uk.

    The Wrap is one of Guardian Unlimited's paid-for
services. If you were
    forwarded this email and would like to subscribe,
go to
    http://www.guardian.co.uk/wrap

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: SF Green Festival & After party this Saturday 11/06

'they' might have Jesus on their side, but we've got Nature!

come on down to the SF Green Festival this weekend, and see what the 
real revolution is cookin' up.  The Green Fest is a great opportunity 
to see what's going on in the, um, Real World, and will likely leave 
you with a feeling of hope and optimism in these otherwise dark times.

and.... saturday night, the SF Urban Alliance for Sustainability will 
be hosting the official SF Green Fest after-party and Eco-conscious 
fashion show. we're opening with a Tai Chi session at 8:00 pm, and 
going 'til 2.  details below.

Hope to see you all there!

-Philip-



UMA PRODUCTIONS, SWIRLSPACE, FUTURE KULTURE, and SATSI presents

                     :: GAVIOTAS ::

The official after party of the 2004 SF Green Festival

featuring

Music, Eco-Fashion, and SF Culture

Saturday, November 6, 2004
8pm - 2am
21 & over w/ ID

@ TerraSF
511 Harrison St / 1st

TaiChi with Patrick King 8pm-8:45

LIVE MUSIC by Rena <http://www.renamusic.com>
8:30 - 9:30

DJ LINEUP:
- SOULSALAAM (Future Juju, Hypnomadic) World Electronica
<http://www.soulsalaam.com>
- Neptune (global/breaks)
- Black (r & b, house)
- Satsi (breaks)

ECO-FASHION Showcase (10pm) featuring:
- Swirlspace Hempwear <http://www.swirlspace.com>
- Plutonium <http://www.plutoniumclothing.com>
- Earth Cloth
- Calime Bluebird
- MarFar
- xcus me

...and others

Guest appearance by Julia Butterfly Hill

Full bar, Organic Munchies, Massage/Healing

Free Bio-diesel shuttle service available from GreenFestival provided by
Incredible Adventures <http://www.incadventures.com>

$12 limited advanced tickets through the Green Festival website
<http://tickets.greenfestivals.com>
$15 at door with Green Festival ticket stub
$20 General Admission

Info site: http://www.umaproductions.com
Info line: 510.387.0817

Volunteer opportunities available, for more information please email
info@umaproductions.com

First, let's make a distinction between neocons and true conservatives.

I don't think the neocons, represented by Bush and his administration, are 
traditional conservatives.  Right now, I'd much prefer an old-line 
conservative in office.  Traditional conservatives believed in the Bill of 
Rights and the constitution and are against the Patriot Act.  Traditional 
conservatives believe in small government, not the creation of a global 
imperial presence. Traditional conservatives believe in fiscal 
responsibility, not massive spending while cutting taxes.

The American Conservative views Bush as the new Caesar is about to destroy 
the Republic and create an imperial power.  The old Romans
asked Caesar to rule as a monarch;  so did neocon Republicans.

As Justin Raimondo a contributing editor of The American Conservative wrote 
recently:

"The Republican Party has become the party not just of big government, but 
of global government. If, as seems likely, the President follows the 
neo-conservative agenda and takes his war of "liberation" beyond Iraq -- 
Syria and Iran seem to be the next targets -- the transformation of the 
Republican Party will be complete: it will become the imperial party, 
albeit not without dissent from traditional small government conservatives."

The "moral values" issue is something to be as frightened of as the 
aftermath of the burning of the Reichstag.  The imperialist Republican 
party deliberately leveraged the fear of middle Americans, much as Hitler 
created fear of the Jews, to win the election.  I was raised in middle 
America and I should know better.  Ohio, West Virginia, and Western 
Pennsylvania for example used to be bastions of the Democratic party -- 
when the Democratic party represented labor and the values of the working 
class.

Well, there still is a working class but the current liberal elite has 
ignored them, and the neocons have pretty much eviscerated the labor 
unions.  These people don't pay $5.00 for a Starbucks latte;  they don't 
anguish over whitening their teeth (lucky to have all of 'em);  they drive 
battered old cars if they are lucky to own one, not high performance German 
vehicles or Hummers;  and they don't have expensive educations (most 
haven't graduated high school).  Do they hate gays and want to take away 
womens' choice?  Not really.  But all they have is their church and 
families and the Republicans have skillfully created the fear in these 
folks that they would lose these precious things if the Democrats, the 
horrifying "liberals" who once helped their fathers and grandfathers get a 
five-day, eight hour work day, took office.  Shame on the neocons, and 
shame on the Democrats for abandoning a populist, workers' 
platform.  Perhaps we've all lived on the two coasts for too long:)

These days I'm building alliances with old conservatives, labor oriented 
progressives as well as progressive Christians for whom abortion and gay 
rights are minor issues in a world where greed and violence run 
rampant.  The Democratic party is in shambles because it abandoned its 
ideals.  Time to create something new, and a values system that's not based 
on "selfishness will save the world" economics.

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

i didn't see this posted yet, but if it has been already, my apologies ;)

jeff samuel & broker/dealer this saturday @ rx gallery!

SPECTRAL RECORD RELEASE PARTY
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

JEFF SAMUEL [DJ] - SEATTLE, WA

Jeff Samuel's foray into electronic music began in 1995 when he first
witnessed a DJ set by Detroit's Claude Young in Columbus, Ohio. He was
then introduced to that city's ele_mental collective, an inspiring core of
artists which included Ohio artists Titonton Duvante, the Archetype and
Todd Sines among others. Through their concept-oriented events which
showcased the finer points of electronic music, he became enthralled and
began to DJ in 1996. Soon after, he purchased his first synth and drum
machine.

While attending college in 1997, Jeff began exploring the possibilities of
software-based music production where he saw greater possibilities for
creativity and workflow. He encountered much scrutiny for attempting to
make techno using only a computer. Nevertheless, by 1998 he had started to
create his own completed tracks using an early version of Fruityloops (now
FL Studio). Music from his first demo was signed to the German label Lo-fi
Stereo. The "Bidooba" single was released in 1999 and featured a remix
from Kompakt's Michael Mayer. Other tracks from the same demo found their
way to minimal techno pioneer Daniel Bell, who released them on his 7th
City label in 2001.

Jeff pushed into the new millennium continuing his DJ career, releasing
more music and completing his college degree in Audio Production
simultaneously. 2002 proved to be a significant year which saw his
'Digital Self' Tektite EP remixed by Ricardo Villalobos, his abstract
material released by UK label Emoticon, and the beginning of a long
relationship with Cologne-based Trapez Recordings. He also left Ohio for
the western port city of Seattle, where he pursued a career as a Sound
Designer in the videogame industry.

Today, Jeff Samuel is a sought-after remixer with a heavy DJ and
production schedule who still finds the time to make SFX for videogames.
His records are played by a diverse range of the world's most talented
DJ's including: Richie Hawtin, Sven Vath, Ricardo Villalobos, Francois K,
Steve Bug, Akufen, Craig Richards, Mazi, Claude Young, Timo Maas, Josh
Wink, Electric Indigo, Michael Mayer and John Tejada. He is also currently
the only American DJ represented by the elusive Kompakt organization.

BROKER/DEALER [LIVE] - SAN FRANCISCO, CA

Equipped with an array of samplers, sequencers and vintage synthesizers,
San Francisco wunderkinds Broker/Dealer make catchy minimal electronic
music equally suited for the den or the dancefloor. Simultaneously
channeling the aquatic dub of Berlin's Chain Reaction label and the
genre-defining minimal techno of the Kompakt imprint, on their debut
full-length, Initial Public Offering, B/D recalls German electronic
artists like Mike Ink, not to mention Metro Area's innovative
electro-disco.

After cooling off from last years full-length record on Asphodel,
Broker/Dealer comes back with something a bit more for the dance floor on
their new 12" single on Ghostly's Spectral label. The duo will perform a
special live set in honor of the release along with celebrating the
Dealer's 30th birthday!

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Rx Gallery
132 Eddy Street @ Mason Street
San Francisco, CA 94102
http://www.rxgallery.com/
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
FREE before 10pm - $7 after / 9pm-2am / 21+

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=1666

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: party photo-sharing tool 

did i post this already? i can't remember.

flickr is a neat photo sharing website. it's really handy if you have a
digicam and either don't know html or don't have time to create webpages.
it has a tool where you can automatically click pictures you're looking at
on a website to add them.

it's still in beta and they give you additional space if you can convince
other suckas to try it, so if you're willing to be a victim, reply back
privately and i'll send you an invite. ;)

http://www.flickr.com/photos/xaotica

you can also make cool slideshows like this
http://www.flickr.com/photos/xaotica/sets/3462/show/

kim

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ~*ENCHANTER*~ THIS FRIDAY.November.5th($5/ALL AGES)(XTORT)*BSP*

It's the age old "Buffer zone" it is just an excuse for a promoter to 
politely say NO to you playing there party. Perfect example I have played 
for every major party promoter in the bay area with the exception of about 3 
or so.. so obviously if im good enough to play at a skillz,F-8,Harmony,quest 
etc.. party then im good enough to play at "Said promoters" lil event. But 
they ask for a demo anyway. I understand at that point the promter is just 
giving you lip service. For all the demo's that I have sent out I have only 
maybe got 1 booking out of it.

Or if you point them to a website that has mutiple sets of yours then they 
come up with an excuse about not having a stable internet connection etc..


Mac

Subject: Re: [sfraves] !! new.musik.from.innocentchild !!

If I cut the filter cutoff level on that synth lead it loses some of the 
grit I'm trying to keep in there. Tends to get too far into the fluffy 
range. It's actually intended to be more of something you're going to hear 
in a mitsubishi commercial or some telco's youth targeted advertising in 
sound. I want a bittersweet sound. Bubblegum pop at the core, but smacked 
around so that it becomes more somber. BT, yeah right. Maybe if I had gone 
to Berklee School of Music like I originally intended to back in the day...

http://www.sninesix.com/music/sninesix%20-%20hellifiknow.mp3 - unfinished 
breaks track
http://www.sninesix.com/music/sninesix%20-%20mdf.mp3 - unfinished slow 
progressive track

See a pattern here? Nothing ever finished...

:: r ::

From sfraves-return-116911-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Nov 06 03:14:54 2004

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  The Failure of the American Experiment

--=====================_31008688==.REL
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_31008688==.ALT"

--=====================_31008688==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


<http://www.kuro5hin.org/story/2004/11/3/163714/809>The Failure of the 
American Experiment (<http://www.kuro5hin.org/section/op-ed>Op-Ed)
1d92756.jpg

By <http://www.kuro5hin.org/user/Baldrson>Baldrson
Fri Nov 5th, 2004 at 06:55:25 PM EST
<http://www.kuro5hin.org/?op=search&topic=politics>
1d92760.jpg

1d92756.jpg


A lot of Bush haters are United States citizens. Many feel they must now 
leave their country and renounce their citizenship, and feel trapped that 
they can't. Many Bush supporters are taking glee in encouraging them to do 
so, knowing full well many have no options for emigration. The problem is 
both "liberals" and "conservatives" have forgotten the United States is 
about much more than "democracy". It is about a laboratory of the States 
within which migration and eminent domain support the pursuit of happiness 
by providing a mutual defense system for peoples experimenting with their 
own widely varying belief systems.


1d92756.jpg
  In the wake of candidate Kerry's concession of defeat to Bush, many 
United States citizens believe they must migrate out of the United States, 
if not renounce their citizenships. The Senate is now even more dominated 
by Republicans. In 11 States, propositions to ban gay marriage were on the 
ballot, and in all 11 States gay marriage was banned. Many liberals are 
rightly concerned that the central government is going to turn against them 
and impose upon them uniform laws, applicable to all States, that are 
hostile to their pursuit of happiness.

Now is the time for liberals to reflect on the association between liberal 
policies and the centralization of powers that began in the Civil War. Is 
there a limit to the degree to which central government should uniformly 
govern all States? Should the United Nations ultimately take on the role of 
legislating uniform rules for all countries?

Usually, the answer to these questions are disturbingly totalitarian when 
coming from supposedly "liberal" people. Their success in getting central 
governments to support their views has shielded them from the structural 
problems with such centralization. However, now that both plebiscites (in 
the form of ballot propositions) and the highest voter turnout in US 
history has shown "democracy" can turn against liberal policies -- liberals 
can reflect and become enlightened as to the real nature of what has been 
called The American Experiment.

The Civil War, while a victory of self-determination of individual slaves, 
was a disaster for self-determination of groups of like mind -- "religion" 
as intended by the First Amendment. The federal government took on a role 
that was feared by the founders -- the arbitrer of differing beliefs among 
peoples rather than facilitating the pursuit of happiness by peoples of 
differing beliefs.

This failure of the intent of the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of 
religion is coming home to roost against the liberal way of life. There is 
increasing danger that uniform Federal statutes will impose fundamentalist 
Christian ideology uniformly across all States. The gambit of using the 
federal government to impose liberal policies has worked for decades but 
the simple mathematics of reproduction is that white liberals have trouble 
reproducing and cannot easily recruit new liberals from white families that 
have reproduced under Federal imposition of liberal policies.

Demography is destiny.

Now it is true that within a few decades it may be the case that the higher 
reproduction rates of other ethnicities, prone to vote Democratic, will 
outstrip the fecundity of fundamentalist Christian whites -- but this too 
could backfire. Hispanics are the fastest growing ethnic group and they are 
largely Catholic. Despite the fact that they continue to vote Democratic, 
not only might they never fully convert to liberal politics -- there is a 
very real chance they may succeed in shifting the Democratic party toward 
the right on issues such as abortion and homosexuality. Liberals have to 
ask themselves whether this deal with the devil of central power is worth 
the dangers to liberal ideology.

There must be a libertarian State, as many wish New Hampshire to become.

There must be a fundamentalist Christian state, as many wish South Carolina 
(the State with the highest per capita African American population) to become.

There must be a <http://www.bartleby.com/61/50/P0045000.html>panmixia 
state, as New York is becoming.

There must be ethnostates, as 
<http://vdare.com/misc/macdonald_041027_immigration.htm>Europe, 
<http://clusty.com/search?query=jewish+ethnicity>Israel and the 
<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1555914985>Amerindian reservations 
could still support.

There must be an east-west hybrid state as parts of Hawaii are becoming 
(with some islands reserved for indigenous Hawaiians).

There must be a "politically correct" state as California has become.

There must be a frontier for 
<http://www.pbs.org/weta/thewest/people/s_z/smith.htm>misfits, 
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burt_Rutan>adventurers and downright 
<http://clusty.com/search?v%3asources=webplus&query=transhumanism&>dangerous 
experiments -- as the <http://www.geocities.com/jim_bowery/ecoag.html>ocean 
deserts and <http://members.aol.com/oscarcombs/spacsetl.htm>space could be 
if interference with claims were prevented.

And even these aren't enough.

The problem is that all of these things represent true diversity which is 
the enemy of those who, in their profoundly destructive hypocrisy, equate 
"diversity" with intimate integration of diverse people within governments 
that cannot limit their interference in people's pursuit of happiness.

The fundamental conflict is between democracy as dispute processing and 
migration as dispute processing. Migration is superior, so long as eminent 
domain compensation applies, for the simple reason that it allows self 
determination for all value systems -- not just value systems that can 
produce the most invasive voters world wide.

The practicalities of eminent domain displacement are always problematic, 
but people do survive and the system does enhance the general welfare. More 
problematic than eminent domain itself is the general issue of natural 
habitat destruction due to humans. Human diversity should be valued but so 
should general biodiversity. How this tradeoff should work is beyond the 
scope of this essay, but suffice to say that human population, with the 
assistance of technology, should increasingly migrate to environments of 
less natural biodiversity. Humans should be subject to the eminence of the 
natural domain, so to speak, as they become more adept at life support 
technology and can increasingly migrate to otherwise lifeless environments.

As for me, even if much greater limits were placed on federal power, I 
expect I would renounce my United States citizenship and either (if Europe 
could support ethnostates by fending off the demographic shift to Islam and 
other migration-induced panmixia) repatriate to one of the North Sea states 
of Europe or invest my remaining years in opening up one of the frontier 
states. This would be my pursuit of happiness.

Can you pursue happiness without, like Christian or Islamic theocrats, 
imposing your value system on others?

Full discussion: 
<http://www.kuro5hin.org/story/2004/11/3/163714/809>http://www.kuro5hin.org/story/2004/11/3/163714/809



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_31008688==.ALT

coming from supposedly &quot;liberal&quot; people. Their success in

real nature of what has been called The American Experiment. <br><br>

government took on a role that was feared by the founders -- the arbitrer

of religion is coming home to roost against the liberal way of life.

fundamentalist Christian ideology uniformly across all States. The gambit

decades but the simple mathematics of reproduction is that white liberals

Now it is true that within a few decades it may be the case that the
higher reproduction rates of other ethnicities, prone to vote Democratic,
will outstrip the fecundity of fundamentalist Christian whites -- but
this too could backfire. Hispanics are the fastest growing ethnic group

And even these aren't enough. <br><br>
The problem is that all of these things represent <i>true</i> diversity which is the enemy of those who, in their profoundly destructive hypocrisy, equate &quot;diversity&quot; with intimate integration of diverse people within governments that cannot limit their interference in people's pursuit of happiness. <br><br>
The fundamental conflict is between democracy as dispute processing and migration as dispute processing. Migration is superior, so long as eminent domain compensation applies, for the simple reason that it allows self determination for <i>all</i> value systems -- not just value systems that can produce the most invasive voters world wide. <br><br>
The practicalities of eminent domain displacement are always problematic, but people do survive and the system does enhance the general welfare. More problematic than eminent domain itself is the general issue of natural habitat destruction due to humans. Human diversity should be valued but so should general biodiversity. How this tradeoff should work is beyond the scope of this essay, but suffice to say that human population, with the assistance of technology, should increasingly migrate to environments of less natural biodiversity. Humans should be subject to the eminence of the natural domain, so to speak, as they become more adept at life support technology and can increasingly migrate to otherwise lifeless environments. <br><br>
As for me, even if much greater limits were placed on federal power, I expect I would renounce my United States citizenship and either (if Europe could support ethnostates by fending off the demographic shift to Islam and other migration-induced panmixia) repatriate to one of the North Sea states of Europe or invest my remaining years in opening up one of the frontier states. This would be my pursuit of happiness. <br><br>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr new map of us

I already said time and again that this is not a evangelical Christian
Reconstructionist/Dominionist takeover. Evagelical Christians are only
30% of the US population.

It's about the neocon's ability to manipulate average Christian voters.

Cathloics (account for 20% of US population) do not believe being gay
is a choice and a God-given condition that can't be changed.

30% of all Catholics and mainline Protestants believe gays should be
able to marry. in line with US populist opinion (about 30% of all
Americans think gays should be able to get married). Most of Catholics
and mainline Protestants do not believe that church and religion
should be a part of politics and legal system, the fear they have
about gay marriage is one about traditions, not religion. Most of
these mainstream, progressive Christians also believe that gay
partners should have equal benefits as married couples

I agree that the Democrats are losing touch with the working class,
and so are the neocons.

> First, let's make a distinction between neocons and true conservatives.
>=20
> I don't think the neocons, represented by Bush and his administration, ar=
e
> traditional conservatives.  Right now, I'd much prefer an old-line
> conservative in office.  Traditional conservatives believed in the Bill o=
f
> Rights and the constitution and are against the Patriot Act.  Traditional
> conservatives believe in small government, not the creation of a global
> imperial presence. Traditional conservatives believe in fiscal
> responsibility, not massive spending while cutting taxes.
>=20

y
> the Republic and create an imperial power.  The old Romans
> asked Caesar to rule as a monarch;  so did neocon Republicans.
>=20

>=20

> Republican Party will be complete: it will become the imperial party,
> albeit not without dissent from traditional small government conservative=
s."
>=20

> created fear of the Jews, to win the election.  I was raised in middle
> America and I should know better.  Ohio, West Virginia, and Western
> Pennsylvania for example used to be bastions of the Democratic party --
> when the Democratic party represented labor and the values of the working
> class.

e
> battered old cars if they are lucky to own one, not high performance Germ=

> haven't graduated high school).  Do they hate gays and want to take away

Subject: [sfraves] Re: guns

	The comparison wasn't between gay marriage and receiving a bullet 
wound; it was between gay marriage and gun ownership. Now sex may be a 
natural part of marriage, but getting shot is not a natural part of 
owning a gun. In fact, many people own guns in order to *decrease* 
their chances of getting shot or otherwise becoming a victim of violent 
crime.

	Based on the crime rates, their choice appears to be working. The over 
30 states that have passed laws allowing concealed carrying of handguns 
have seen annual reductions in the rates of murder, rape, and robbery 
since passing those laws (see 
http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/493636.html ).

	But for anyone who opposes gun rights and believes that gun ownership 
does not reduce crime, I've seen a suggestion for an easy way to 
personally stand up and advertise your beliefs: Put a sticker or sign 
on the door of your home with a picture of a gun and a slash through 
it, along with the words "GUN-FREE HOUSEHOLD."

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>

From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: guns

Let's pretend this is Jeopardy for a minute.

Here's the answer:
It's one of the most population-dense areas on the planet; a city with 
a permanent population of twelve million people, a daytime population 
of fifteen million, and the center of a metropolitan area that easily 
tops twenty million.  Yet, in this city, you can pick the roughest of 
the rough neighborhoods, and walk down the street at any time of day or 
night with so little worry about the safety of your person or 
belongings, that the thought will probably never enter your mind.

+++Game show music plays for 30 seconds+++

Here's the question:
What is Tokyo?


Now, have a look at the hoops you have to go through to own a gun in 
Japan, even a rinky-dink little air pistol:

http://yarchive.net/gun/politics/japan_gun.html

It makes the UK's (for example) gun control laws look like a cake-walk 
in comparison, and our own, even in a place like San Francisco, 
positively neolithic.  Yet the violent crime rate in Japan is one of 
the lowest in the world.  Now, not being a statistician, I'm not going 
to try to claim that the ONLY reason Japan is so safe is the lack of 
availability of guns.  But the example, especially that of Tokyo itself 
(Large, densely packed,  cities being generally the areas of highest 
crime (violent, property, white collar, or otherwise) in ANY country), 
certainly disproves those silly notions that gun control increases 
crime or that an armed populace reduces it.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: guns

ok, im sorry, but that is bullshit.  

the bottom line: guns are designed to shoot bullets
into things.  

whether or not every gun owner intends to inflict
bodily harm on someone, guns are now, and always have
been designed to shoot things, and largely those things
are living creatures... 

in statistical research, one of the first things you
learn is that statistics can be manipulated very easily
to support the wishes of the researchers... 

and second, you learn about things called confounding
variables... there are so many other things that can
have a result on your findings... the golden rule of
statistical research: correlation does not equal
causation...

or to dumb it down, just because there have been laws
that allow for ownership of a concealed weapon does not
mean it *caused* the decrease in in crime. implying so
is irresponsible and playing to the ignorance and
stupidity of average voter. 

love and hugs and kisses,
tina

http://moonchyld1.livejournal.com

> ok, im sorry, but that is bullshit.
>
> the bottom line: guns are designed to shoot bullets
> into things.
>
> whether or not every gun owner intends to inflict
> bodily harm on someone, guns are now, and always have
> been designed to shoot things, and largely those things
> are living creatures...
>
> in statistical research, one of the first things you
> learn is that statistics can be manipulated very easily
> to support the wishes of the researchers...
>
> and second, you learn about things called confounding
> variables... there are so many other things that can
> have a result on your findings... the golden rule of
> statistical research: correlation does not equal
> causation...
>
> or to dumb it down, just because there have been laws
> that allow for ownership of a concealed weapon does not
> mean it *caused* the decrease in in crime. implying so
> is irresponsible and playing to the ignorance and
> stupidity of average voter.

Macadio, I'm not giving you lip service...I'm telling
I've never heard you. Just because you've played big
crews doesn't justify you getting booked at our
"small" events. I don't book people I haven't
heard...sorry if that sounds like lip service. I've
played Skills, F-8, Coolworld, and "small" events and
honestly I wouldn't expect anyone to book me because
of that...especially if they haven't heard or don't
like my music.

Also Van, most people will book on the merits alone
too...no problem there, but just because we choose to
do it a different way doesn't make it wrong. If we
didn't have people come to our events, we wouldn't be
around...so whether you like the formula or not, it
works. Inexpensive and full of good djs (your opinion
will most likely differ).

Best wishes and good luck on the label stuff Chris

Sascha
