On Thu, 4 Nov 2004, Chris Jackson wrote:

> Date: Thu, 4 Nov 2004 16:28:09 -0800 (PST)
> From: Chris Jackson <resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Never Die-Bold...
>=20
> VERY interesting piece.  My heart tells me something
> is VERY wrong....like someone stole my candy dammit!
>
> c h r i s
>
> ---------------------
>
> Never Say Die-bold: So You Don=92t Think the Bush
> Campaign Stole This Election? Think Again
>
> By Jackson Thoreau
> opEdNews.com
>
> If you=92re looking for one word to sum up the way the
> Bush-Cheney campaign stole another election Tuesday
> besides obvious ones like =93cheated,=94 try this one:
> Diebold.
>
> An election judge where I voted Tuesday in a heavily
> Democratic precinct in Maryland knows what that means
> and wasn=92t adverse to sharing his opinion of the
> Republican-owned company. As I was about to vote with
> the electronic system, I asked this judge if they had
> a way to check people=92s votes through a paper backup.
>
>
> The official said no, and then in a low voice so no
> one else would hear, added, =93And that really makes us
> nervous, with Diebold as the owner of that system.=94
>
>
> Goodbye, hanging chads. Hello, computer fraud that
> leaves no trace, no chads hanging.
>
> Diebold Inc. of North Canton, Ohio, supplied scores of
> machines and counted millions of votes Tuesday, while
> reportedly discarding many votes for Democrat John
> Kerry, according to British investigative reporter
> Gregory Palast. Walden O=92Dell, chief executive of
> Diebold and a top fundraiser for the Bush campaign,
> wrote in a fund-raising letter last year that he was
> =93committed to helping Ohio deliver its electoral votes
> to the president next year.=94
>
>
> That he did.
>
>
> Software errors involving the system can change
> results, computer scientists say. Since the majority
> of touch screens in the United States do not produce
> paper records, the machines could alter ballots
> without anyone noticing.
>
> =93What has most concerned scientists are problems that
> are not observable, so the fact that no major problems
> were observed says nothing about the system,=94 David
> Jefferson, a computer scientist at Lawrence Livermore
> National Laboratory in California, told the Associated
> Press. =93The fact that we had a relatively smooth
> election yesterday does not change at all the
> vulnerability these systems have to fraud or bugs.=94
>
> Some 8.2 percent of touch-screen votes in senatorial
> elections between 1998 and 2000 were lost, according
> to an MIT/CalTech study. That was more than any other
> system except lever machines, which lost 9.5 percent
> of votes.
>
> Bev Harris, author of Black Box Voting and the
> BlackBoxVoting.com web site, has documented numerous
> cases of electronic disasters. One occurred in Volusia
> County, Fla., in 2000 in which county election
> officials hand recounted more than 184,000 paper
> ballots used to feed the computerized system, after
> the central ballot-counting computer showed a
> Socialist Party candidate receiving more than 9,000
> votes and Al Gore getting minus 19,000. Another 4,000
> votes were received for Bush that should not have been
> there.
>
> Election officials eventually tallied Gore beating
> Bush by 97,063 votes to 82,214. But the wrong numbers
> had already been sent to the media, which were used by
> FOX and other networks to erroneously call the
> election for Bush and swing the public relations part
> of the recount battle in his favor.
>
> On Tuesday, Election Protection, a program of People
> for the American Way, had more than 15,000 calls to
> its hotline about ballot problems, voter intimidation
> and other
> situations.
>
>
> The Institute for Public Accuracy also outlined
> various problems. Susan Truitt, co-founder of the
> Citizens Alliance for Secure Elections, was quoted on
> its site saying that seven counties in Ohio had
> electronic voting machines without paper trails, and
> scientific exit polls showed Kerry with the lead. But
> verifying votes was impossible, she said.
>
> =93A recount without a paper trail is meaningless; you
> just get a regurgitation of the data,=94 Truitt said. =93A
> poll worker told me [Wednesday] morning that there
> were no tapes of the results posted on some machines;
> on other machines the posted count was zero, which
> obviously shouldn=92t be the case.=94
>
> Other problems include Ohio=92s version of Katherine
> Harris
>
> There were many other problems in Ohio. Like in
> Florida, the Ohio secretary of state, Ken Blackwell,
> made decisions on what could be counted and other
> important matters even as he shilled for Bush as a
> co-chair of his campaign. This raised serious
> conflict-of-interest concerns, said Ohio state Senator
> Teresa Fedor.
>
> =93There is a pattern of voter suppression; that=92s why I
> called for Blackwell=92s resignation more than a month
> ago,=94 she said. =93Blackwell, while claiming to run an
> unbiased elections process, was also the co-chair of
> the Bush-Cheney campaign in Ohio. Additionally, he was
> the spokesperson for the anti-business, anti-family
> constitutional
> amendment =91Issue 1,=92 and a failed initiative to repeal
> a crucial sales-tax revenue source for the state.
> Blackwell learned his moves from the Katherine Harris
> playbook of Florida 2000, and we won=92t stand for it.=94
>
>
> The Ohio tally also included a version of the Florida
> butterfly ballot, said Bob Fitrakis, an attorney with
> Election Protection. The absentee ballots were
> misleading in Franklin County,=94 he said. =93Kerry was
> the third line down, but you had to punch number four
> to vote for him. Bush was getting both his votes as
> well as Kerry=92s.=94
>
>
> There were also far fewer machines in the inner-city
> districts than in the suburbs, Fitrakis said. =93I
> documented at least a dozen people leaving because the
> lines were so long in African-American areas,=94 he
> said. =93Blackwell did a great deal of suppressing
> before the election - like attempting to refuse to
> process voter registration forms.=94
>
> I heard a report that one Ohio voter had to wait in
> line 15 hours to vote. In one of the busiest precincts
> in Columbus, Blackwell only supplied it with three
> voting
> machines. How many people gave up and did not vote
> there?
>
> Dirty tricks by Republicans on the rise
>
> A few days before the 2004 election, the Washington
> Post published an article detailing increasing dirty
> tricks, mostly by Republicans.
>
> In Lake County, Ohio, some people received a memo on
> bogus Board of Elections letterhead informing voters
> who registered through Democratic and NACCP drives
> that they could not vote.
>
> In Leon County, students at Florida State and Florida
> A&M universities who signed petitions to legalize
> medical marijuana or impose stiffer penalties for
> child molesters unknowingly had their party
> registration switched to Republican and their
> addresses
> changed. The latter would affect their ability to vote
> since they would not be registered at the proper site.
> The media traced the source to a group hired by the
> Florida Republican Party.
>
> In Allegheny County, Pa., fliers on a bogus county
> letterhead were handed out and mailed, saying that
> =93due to immense voter turnout expected on Tuesday,=94
> the election had been extended. Republicans should
> vote Tuesday, while Democrats should vote on Wednesday
> =96 the wrong day.
>
>
> In some Milwaukee black neighborhoods, a flier warned
> people that they could not vote in that election if
> they had already voted in another election that year.
> =93If you
> violate any of these laws, you can get ten years in
> prison and your children will get taken away from
> you,=94 the flier said.
>
> In Charleston County, S.C., a fake letter supposedly
> from the NAACP threatens
> voters who have outstanding parking tickets or have
> failed to pay child support with arrest. A similar
> flier was distributed in Baltimore in 2002.
>
> Such tricks are not new. There are famous examples
> like the 1971 break-in of Democratic National
> Committee headquarters by Nixon. There are also many
> lesser known examples. In 2002, Ron Kirk, a former
> Dallas mayor who ran as a Democrat for U.S. Senate,
> reported a bogus automated phone message dialed to
> voters in Austin and other cities. The message asked
> voters to support Kirk because he supported same-sex
> marriages and gay adoptions. Kirk said he didn=92t
> support either issue and blamed more Republican
> pre-election dirty tricks. His Republican opponent,
> John Cornyn, denied being behind the false phone bank.
>
>
> U.S. has a long history of rigged elections
>
> The U.S., of course, is no stranger to rigged
> elections, even well before Tuesday=92s and the one in
> 2000. A famous case was the controversial way that the
> late President Lyndon B. Johnson won a U.S. Senate
> seat in 1948 in Texas on his way to the White House
> that reportedly involved votes from dead people. What
> some overlook in this case was how LBJ had lost an
> election in a similar disputed fashion seven years
> before.
>
> Another lesser known case involved the 1984 landslide
> presidential election of the late Republican Ronald
> Reagan. In Dallas, where both Bush and Cheney lived at
> one time, there were 217 ballots cast in a precinct
> that had zero registered voters. That would not affect
> the election, but it demonstrates that fraud has
> existed for a long time.
>
> As early as 1986, Michael Shamos, a Pennsylvania
> computer scientist, testified during a Texas hearing
> that the computer hardware and software used to
> tabulate voters=92 ballots could easily be manipulated.
>
> =93Computers can be manipulated remotely, by wire or
> radio, or by direct physical input,=94 Shamos said. =93The
> memories on which these computers operate can easily
> fit into a shirt pocket and can be substituted in
> seconds. The software can be set to await the receipt
> of a special card, whose presence will cause all the
> election counters to be altered. This card could be
> dropped into the ballot box by any confederate. The
> possibilities for this type of tampering are endless,
> and virtually no detection is possible once tabulation
> has been completed....Even if the software is not
> altered, there is no reason to believe that it is
> correct. Many tests performed on such programs have
> revealed faulty logic and wildly incorrect results.=94
>
> Suzan Kesim, then-vice president of a security
> consulting firm in South Bend, Ind., also testified in
> 1986 that =93many of the computer auditing procedures
> used by the banking industry that have been tried and
> true could easily be modified or used as they are for
> auditing elections....Fraud possibilities include
> =91hidden programs=92.=94
>
> Texas even had its own voter purge almost two decades
> before Florida attempted to strike some 60,000 voters
> from the rolls with false accusations of felony
> convictions. In 1982, lists were provided to Texas
> election officials that made mostly false accusations
> of felony convictions against voters. The accused
> included public officials who successfully sued for
> slander. The state also hired armed officers at
> minority voter precincts and posted signs warning
> voters against casting illegal ballots. Charles
> Knutson pointed out in a Democrats.com report that the
> Texas purge probably involved Bush mastermind Karl
> Rove, who worked for then-Texas Republican Gov. Bill
> Clements in 1982.
>
> Another odd case involved a West Texas county where
> the system=92s optical scanners misread ballots and at
> first reported landslide wins for two Republican
> commissioners in 2002. But the next day, after alert
> poll workers became suspicious of the wide margins of
> supposed victory, they discovered a defective computer
> chip in the scanner system. After two hand recounts
> and another count with a replacement scanner chip,
> officials announced that Democrats Jerry House and
> Chloanne Lindsey actually won by wide margins.
>
> =93It was hard to believe that that type of mistake had
> happened,=94 Robbie Floyd, one of the Republicans who
> lost, said in one press report.
>
> So could Kerry have been ripped off by a defective
> computer chip in Ohio and Florida, where scientific
> exit polls indicated Kerry wins? We will never know
> since, unlike the Texas machines in 2002, the Diebold
> machines in Ohio and Florida have no paper trail.
>
> How convenient.
>
> Popular vote fixed?
>
> With all the former and current Republicans supporting
> Kerry =96 even a long-time Texas Republican friend of
> mine voted for a Democrat for the first time for
> president on Tuesday =96 it=92s hard to believe that Bush
> got about 3.5 million more votes than Kerry and 8
> million more than he received in 2000.
>
> There can=92t be that many new devil worshippers or
> Christian fundamentalists.
>
> A larger turnout =96 Tuesday=92s 60 percent turnout was
> the largest since 1968 =96 has favored Democrats in the
> past. But about 6 million of those votes have not been
> counted.
>
> Some said that exit polls were accurate in states that
> had paper trails, but not in ones without the paper
> trails for e-voting.
>
> Even though Kerry conceded, groups like the
> International Labor Communications Association refused
> to follow suit. The group is waging a campaign to
> count all the votes in Ohio.
>
> Kerry=92s concession was really strange and
> disappointing. Would Howard Dean have conceded so fast
> to Bush? Gore fought Bush harder than Kerry. I don=92t
> get it since Kerry even had Bruce Springsteen play =93No
> Retreat, No Surrender=94 at a campaign appearance and
> used that song during other events. John Edwards also
> pledged to make sure votes were counted. Then they
> surrendered without putting up a fight in the overtime
> phase. That was most disappointing, more so than
> Gore=92s concession in 2000.
>
> Did Skull and Bones members blackmail Kerry into
> conceding without a real fight?
>
>
> Perhaps Kerry simply foresaw the inevitable result,
> but he still could have seen the counting of
> provisional ballots through to the end. It would have
> raised some more awareness about the problems with
> Diebold and possibility of vote tampering. It would
> have shown Bush-Cheney that Democrats weren=92t backing
> down, especially with so many questions about vote
> reliability and reports of Republican voter
> suppression and dirty tricks.
>
> But Kerry called for unity with the Evil Empire. Why
> is it that Democrats are always trying to call for
> unity and compromise with Republicanazis? As Carolyn
> Kay with MakeThemAccountable.com said, we have to
> completely remake the Democratic Party. We have to
> learn from right wingers to =93take a licking and come
> back kicking. It is absolutely essential that as soon
> as possible we pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off,
> and start working to take over the Democratic Party.
> It has lost its moorings, and because of that it is
> losing elections, over and over and over again.=94
>
> Sure, the deck was stacked against Kerry. Perhaps the
> last week of bad news for Bush, the Washington
> Redskins loss, the exit polls, and other omens that
> seemed to spell a Kerry victory were mere ploys by
> Rove to make his side work harder and our side slack
> off a bit.
>
> One thing I know: We have to keep fighting these
> cheating thieves, not try to make peace with them. And
> I hope many people on our side won=92t move away =96
> though I realize moving out of the country is the
> ultimate protest and I understand that choice. We all
> have to figure out what is the best path to take for
> ourselves.
>
> As for me, I=92m staying in the belly of the beast, in
> the shadow of the Evil Empire, to continue to sucker
> punch it in its bloated, bullshit-filled gut. Starting
> now, just as many conservatives boycotted France for
> its correct stance against the Iraqi invasion, I=92m
> boycotting the state of Texas, where I lived for 40
> years before moving to friendlier and more progressive
> confines last year. Bush got his political start in
> Texas, where the Republicanazis imposed a
> redistricting scheme that made that far-right state
> even more Republican. Every statewide official is a
> Republican there. The Texas Republican Party platform
> reads like a nazi playbook, even calling for getting
> out of the UN, abolishing numerous federal agencies,
> making homosexuality a crime and teaching the Bible in
> public schools.
>
> Enough is enough. Fuck Texas and the horses that Bush
> and Cheney rode in on.
>
> And fuck Diebold, too.
>
> As for you, Sen. Kerry, I appreciate your hard work,
> your intelligence, your dedication to this campaign,
> although I was disappointed by your finish. But, with
> all due respect, you know where you can stick your
> call for unity=85..
>
> Jackson Thoreau is a Washington, D.C.-area
> journalist/writer. The latest book to which he
> contributed, Big Bush Lies, was published by RiverWood
> Books of Ashland, Ore., and is available at bookstores
> across the country. He can be contacted at
> jacksonthor@yahoo.com or jacksonthor@juno.com.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: guns

At 11:13 AM 11/6/04 -0800, John B wrote:

>Now, have a look at the hoops you have to go through to own a gun in 
>Japan, even a rinky-dink little air pistol:
>
>http://yarchive.net/gun/politics/japan_gun.html
>
>It makes the UK's (for example) gun control laws look like a cake-walk in 
>comparison, and our own, even in a place like San Francisco, positively 
>neolithic.  Yet the violent crime rate in Japan is one of the lowest in 
>the world.  Now, not being a statistician, I'm not going to try to claim 
>that the ONLY reason Japan is so safe is the lack of availability of 
>guns.  But the example, especially that of Tokyo itself (Large, densely 
>packed,  cities being generally the areas of highest crime (violent, 
>property, white collar, or otherwise) in ANY country), certainly disproves 
>those silly notions that gun control increases crime or that an armed 
>populace reduces it.

so you're saying social / cultural factors make a difference?  heavens 
forbid, no!  (libertarians don't get that because they don't
understand psychology).   Canada has lots of guns, more than America (?) 
and their level of violence is lower (but they're nicer;
as we all know, Americans tend to be loud, noisy, self-absorbed, 
excessively self-individualistic, and are immersed in a culture
that glorifies violence, so guns or no guns, I think America would have a 
high level of violent crime relative to the rest of the
civilized world no matter what)

doug

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr new map of us

Whew... a lot to touch on here, sorry this took so long!

quoth Starchild:
> On Thursday, November 4, 2004, at 08:52  PM, shawn allen wrote:
> >OK, I was exaggerating a bit. But it's clear that the religious right
> >had a huge impact in this religion, and Christian fundamentalists
> >are, well, fundamentally incapable of being presuaded that something
> >is more "moral" if it doesn't say so in the Bible.
> 
> Or what they've been *taught* that the Bible says. What the Bible
> *actually* says is often a bit different.

+1. :)

> Now when you say "the conservative-leaning media establishment," I'm
> sorry, but that's just mistaken.

To be fair, I didn't mean the media establishment as a whole was
conservative-leaning--I was referring to the portion of the overall
media establishment that happens to be more conservative.

> Even many leftists will admit that most of the mainstream media in the
> U.S. lean to the left when compared to the beliefs of the U.S. public
> as a whole. This is starting to change with the emergence of outlets
> like Fox News on the right to balance CNN and CBS on the left however,
> and it's coming as a serious shock to many people who have been long
> accustomed to getting their news with a liberal bias and seeing it as
> normal.

I still don't see the liberal bias. I don't necessarily want a media
that agrees with me, but I do expect them to report facts and come to
logical conclusions based on them. That's probably too much to expect
because the mainstream media has always failed to do so, but the past 4
years have shown a reckless disregard for objectivity. Fox News is
gaining in popularity, and the other big networks have picked up on
their style. Sinclair Broadcasting is another example of media
partisanship that is completely unrivaled on the left. What's sad is
that the left has had to create their own media outlets JUST to refute
the distortions of the right. There's no over-arching message for them
to convey except that Republicans are more evil than Democrats.

> >I think we've had this discussion before, so I'm going to avoid it.
> >Needless to say I totally disagree, and I think it's disingenuous to
> >equate gay rights with gun ownership. One grants people the legal
> >rights to share property, have children, and take care of one
> >anothers' legal affairs; the other permits people the right to own
> >and use lethal weapons. I have to admit though, I've given a lot of
> >thought to buying a gun recently.
> 
> The similarity comes in the fact that both sides -- mostly liberal
> gays and mostly conservative gun owners -- feel threatened by people
> of a different cultural background making their own choices in life
> which are not harming others.

Except their fear is totally unwarranted. They're afraid people will
take away their guns completely, while the reality is that a great deal
of reasonable people think they just shouldn't be able to own assault
weapons.

> On the bright side, we now have a group to bridge this cultural
> divide. The motto of the Pink Pistols (see http://www.PinkPistols.org
> ) is "armed gays don't get bashed."

Funny. What's sad is that these people seem just as unreasonable about
gun control as anyone else:

"Some politicians think that the Second Amendment is obsolete. Some
politicians think that the Second Amendment is for duck hunters and
competitive shooters. But one presidential candidate knows who the
Second Amendment is for: Everyone, especially those who, disarmed, face
victimization."

Yes, there are some people who want to ban handguns altogether. I
respectfully disagree with them. I just don't want anyone to be able to
carry fully automatic weapons with gigantic magazines, and most
lawmakers agree with me.

> >So, if these people are *so* adamant about their right to own a gun
> >because it says they can in the Constitution, why do they feel the
> >need to amend the document to accomodate their religious beliefs?
> 
> Because they hypocritically uphold the Bill of Rights when it suits
> them and ignore it when it doesn't, just as do many on the left.

I assume you're talking about the 2nd Amendment, so I'll let that slide.

> >I really don't think guns are as important to the fundamentalists as,
> >so the saying goes, "god and gays".
> 
> To the fundamentalists no, but to conservatives on the whole, I think
> perhaps yes. Bill Clinton publicly blamed gun owners for the
> Democrats' loss of Congress in 1994.

Rightly so. Clinton was moderate on many issues, so the right needed an
issue around which to rally their constituency. Hence the animosity
toward the Brady Bill, and the irrational fear that Democrats were going
to storm through people's doors and take away their guns. It turns out
the law did actually prevent the sale of hundreds of thousands of guns
to convicted felons. I see that as the successful application of totally
reasonable gun control legislation.

> >And if they don't see government or corporations standing up for
> >them, why the FUCK would they vote for Bush? Again, I think it's
> >because religion trumps everything for these people.
> 
> I think the biggest reason people voted for Bush is because they saw
> him as standing up to terrorism, and Kerry as weaker on that issue. If
> Kerry had talked tough against "Islamic fascism" and the Osama bin
> Ladens and Saddam Husseins of the world while repudiating his vote for
> the Patriot Act and slamming Bush for "letting terrorists take away
> our freedom" by violating civil liberties in the U.S., I think we
> could have seen a different election result.

I totally agree. I was soft on Kerry from the beginning, and I think we
could have had a much more honest election with Dean or Kucinich as the
candidate. I doubt that either of them would have been any more viable
in the midwest or the south though...

> >We'll see how happy they are when an industry unregulated fouls up
> >the environment so much that even their precious small towns and
> >unmolested countryside become so poisoned that they can no longer
> >live there.
> 
> Right now the main threat to people living in the boondocks is not
> unregulated industry. The main things negatively impacting people's
> ability to live in these areas are environmental regulations and the
> government acquisition of more and more wilderness land.

Key phrase: "right now".

> Have you ever heard of the Shovel Brigade? You could call it the
> conservative counterpart to Burning Man -- thousands of people
> descending on the wilderness near a tiny Nevada town, not to party,
> but to manually labor with shovels to reopen a road that the
> government tried to close (see
> http://www.worldnetdaily.com/news/article.asp?ARTICLE_ID=18045 ). If
> you get your news exclusively from left-leaning establishment media,
> this is one of those stories you probably didn't read about...

Nope, and frankly it doesn't seem like that big of a deal to me. The
government closed the road at the behest of a trout farmer because
development was killing his crops, and he claimed protection under the
Endangered Species Act. Timber companies and residents wanted the road
open for their own reasons, so they went out and dug it up themselves.
Score one against the socialist trout farmers!

> >I learned how to shoot a .22 in summer camp, does that count? :)
> 
> If bringing it a government school would get you expelled, which it
> probably would, then it ought to count for something.

Wait, so do you think kids should be able to carry guns?

> >Erm, not very stupid. Think about it: you're elected President at the
> >onset of a recession. Hundreds of thousands drop below the poverty line
> >during your first term. Millions lose their healthcare. Salaries of
> >everyone except the biggest earners fail to keep up with inflation.
> 
> Ah yes, inflation... that little consequence of the fact that
> government keeps printing more money which isn't backed by gold or
> anything else of real value.

I would argue that divorcing the dollar from the gold standard *helps*
government fight inflation by countering market meltdowns. But that's a
completely tangential discussion...

> Here's a chart on the effects of the Bush tax cuts from Citizens for
> Tax Justice (if it doesn't show up on the listserve, you can see it at
> http://www.ctj.org/pdf/allbushcut.pdf ), the same group that provided
> the numbers you cite above, which paints a rather different picture:

The last page shows exactly what I was talking about. The top 1% of
taxpayers received 25% of the cut, and the lowest 20% received 10%. So
if there were 100 taxpayers, and the tax cut doled out $1000 in total,
the poorest 20 would receive $5 apiece, while the single richest person
would get $250.

We have what the President would call a "fundamental difference of
opinion." We're the richest nation in the world, yet as individuals we
pay the second *least* in taxes as a percentage of GDP. 40% of the
nation's wealth is controlled by 2% of its citizens. With respect to
taxation as it relates to income, we have the most regressive tax policy
on earth; the poor and middle class have the highest tax burden. Both
the payroll and per-unit taxes like those on property affect the middle
and lower classes a great deal more than the upper class. And for what
it's worth, I agree: we should abolish the sales tax. It is a
fundamentally regressive tax that hurts the people who make the least
the most.

I think that people should have to pay to live in a country that affords
them such wealth. In fact, it's in their interest: better roads help
people get to work more quickly. Better healthcare keeps them from
having to take sick days. Labor regulations prevent them from being
injured (or killed) on the job. Nearly everything that their tax dollars
fund increases the likelihood that they'll have a more healthy,
intelligent, and able workforce to do the jobs that need to be done. But
our ridiculously complex tax system has produced so many loopholes that
many very wealthy people pay no taxes whatsoever, leaving people like
you and me to fund many programs that don't affect us at all.

To make matters worse, Bush's irresponsible tax cuts haven't put a
single dollar back in most people's pockets. Less federal tax revenue
starves states and municipalities for funding, so local property, sales,
and parcel taxes increase. The rising cost of healthcare *alone* has
offset any cut that middle and lower class taxpayers hoped to receive.
And don't even get me started on the corporate welfare this
administration has enacted in the form of subsidies, corporate tax
breaks, pork-barrell giveaways, etc.

> The chart shows that while the top 1% of earners get back a relatively
> large percent of their taxes under the cuts, most of the top 20% of
> earners don't do that well, getting an average of only 7% back
> compared to 10% and 12% for the bottom two categories of earners. The
> note above says that those in the higher income brackets will see
> greater reductions in their tax bills if the cuts do not expire as
> scheduled, but it's certainly not as lopsided as you suggest by
> looking only at dollar amounts and not percentages of what a person
> actually paid in the first place.

Let me explain why I did that: there's a fundamental economic concept
called the "utility of the dollar", which refers to the usefulness of a
single dollar as it relates to overall income. For people that make less
than $20,000 per year, $98 is much less useful than $85,000 given to
somebody who makes more than $518,000 per year. Granted, a good deal of
that tax cut at the very top went to people that make MUCH more than
half a million per year. But the fact remains that the people that
needed a tax cut the most received the least of it.

Trickle-down economics doesn't work. Corporate America proved it wrong
by socking away all their money in offshore bank accounts and the stock
market, which remains inaccessible to the lower and middle classes
because it's impossible to invest responsibly without paying lots of
money to brokers and professional investors. To make matters worse,
people that do get duped into investing their earned income in 401(k)s
and other schemes are essentially betting against themselves.

Say I invest $1000 in a fictional company called Foo Corp. The more
people that do the same, the more incentive Foo Corp.'s board has to
provide returns on the investment by increasing revenue. Unfortunately,
the most common methods of increasing revenue are cutting jobs (or
moving them overseas) and benefits. Executives that can make these tough
decisions on behalf of the board (the shareholders' representatives) are
rewarded substantially. (Today executive pay is 400 times more than that
of production workers, up from 42 times in 1982.) So Foo Corp. saves
$500 million by cutting jobs and employing call centers in India, gives
the CEO $100 million, and pays concessionary dividends to the
stockholders.

Meanwhile, I get a $300 tax cut and earn a whopping 10% return on my
investment, or $100. But my taxes increase because my state needs
additional funds for unemployment benefits, homeless relief, and
training workers for the "new economy". Eventually my (fictional)
employer wises up and decides that they don't need meticulate
open-source web developers like me when they can pay a group of Russians
half as much for a slapped-together ASP application. I take my money out
of Foo Corp. to pay the rent, but that doesn't affect them because they
have many other, more wealthy investors. I can whine about losing my job
all I want, but at the end of the day I'm fucked because my skills
aren't usefull in an corporate culture that prefers cheap, quick
solutions to quality and maintainability. To add insult to injury, I
have no redress whatsoever because I have no influence in the market
(e.g., money to invest).

This is, obviously, a hypothetical (if not somewhat hyperbolic) example.
But it's exactly what I see happening on a grand scale in this country,
and it makes me very sad that people defend tax cuts for the wealthy by
simply stating that they should be able to keep their money. It's not
their money: when I buy something on the open market, I expect that
money to be recycled into my local economy and aid society as a whole.
Instead I see every dollar that I spend or pay in taxes going to people
that already have tons and tons of money. There's no justice in that.

> >>The reality is that the wealthiest 20% of Americans pay like 80% of
> >>the income taxes, so of course any across-the-board cut in income
> >>taxes is going to "favor the wealthy."
> >
> >Actually, the CBO reports that the wealthiest 20% pay about 64% of
> >federal taxes.
> 
> OK, let's say for the sake of argument it's 64%. That's still over
> half the money being stolen from 1/5 of the people. And it's not
> necessarily the wealthiest 1/5, just the 1/5 who earn the most. There
> is a difference. Many wealthy people may have relatively little
> income, while some poor people may have a high income but a lot of
> expenses.  Others with high incomes may be reinvesting all their
> profits into growing their businesses and creating jobs.

Recent numbers indicate that yes, they're creating jobs. But those jobs
pay less:

"But 57 percent of the group who had lost full-time jobs and found new
full-time work reported that they were now earning less than what they
earned in their old jobs. Indeed, about one-third of those with smaller
paychecks were being paid at least 20 percent less."

<http://money.cnn.com/2004/07/30/news/economy/displaced_workers/>

Sure, they're growing business. But on a large scale most people are
making less, while the very wealthy continue to make much more.

> I say instead of predatorily taking more from the people who earn the
> most, who may or may not be rich, let's adopt some of the other
> policies I suggested to help those on the bottom, like eliminating
> taxes on start-up businesses.

I'm all for that, but as I've said before I think that needs to be
balanced with making income taxes more progressive.

> >>That's why they always criticize, but never come up with their own
> >>alternative plans that would substantially cut taxes *without*
> >>"favoring the wealthy."
> >
> >It seems pretty simple to me: make the tax brackets more progressive.
> 
> To make it even harder to cut taxes without "favoring the wealthy?"
> That's a stroke of genius!

Um, no. You make the tax brackets more progressive by cutting taxes for
the lowest wage earners. A progressive tax *cut* is regressive because
it gives the least money to the bottom brackets.

> >Cut taxes for the lowest wage earners, leave the middle untouched,
> >and increase taxes on the wealthiest.
> 
> If you cut taxes on the lowest wage earners, the middle and top
> earners will already be paying a greater percentage of the tax burden
> even if you don't increase their taxes.

Exactly. I would gladly pay more in taxes if I knew that my money was
being used effectively to lift people out of the lower class. It's in
everyone's best interest to eliminate the lower class altogether,
because that leaves more money for programs (or tax cuts, if you prefer)
that help everyone. Of course, if you're agaist welfare to begin with
I'm probably not making a very strong argument. :)

> >So where does all that revenue go?
> 
> The idea that every tax cut must be "paid for" is a media myth that
> comes from a failure to understand the concept of the Laffer Curve:
> When tax rates are higher, more people avoid paying taxes because the
> incentive to do so is greater, while lower tax rates result in more
> compliance. Thus it is often possible to reduce tax rates and actually
> *increase* the amount of revenue being taken in by government. Not
> that government actually needs the money (see below).

The Laffer Curve predicts that people will simply *work* less as their
tax rates increase--not that people who make gobs of money will evade
taxation because they're greedy. IMNSHO, this is a cultural issue that
needs to be addressed in this country. People need to decide whether or
not living in a country that allows such a ridiculous accumulation of
wealth is worth paying more in taxes so that the rest of us can get by.

> >How is the government supposed to maintain social services, fund
> >education and medical research, keep the military trained, or keep
> >the roads paved? Oh yeah, that's right: privatize everything.
> 
> Social services? Show me one that government is doing a good job
> providing. The traditional tough-love of the Salvation Army, private
> abortion clinics and health clinics, church soup kitchens, etc., are
> much more effective.

That's because THEY'RE FUNDED. I would dare say that every important
government-assisted program in this country is consistently underfunded,
most obviously education. Of course private schools are more successful:
parents pay a good deal of money to get their kids out of the public
system, and if everyone could just agree to pay more for education we
wouldn't need private schools to pick up the slack. It's criminal how
poorly teachers are paid in this country, and that we're being forced to
cut arts and after-school programs because states and cities are starved
for funding.

Again, this comes down to a fundamental difference of opinion. I think
the private sector is incapable of providing essential services, and
that the only way to help people effectively is to use tax dollars to
fund programs with their interests held in higher regard than the
pursuit of profit. And while I unfortunately don't have any examples of
how this could work domestically, Naomi Klein's recent article in
Harper's about the Iraqi reconstruction serves as a dire warning for
flawed privatization schemes:

<http://www.informationclearinghouse.info/article6930.htm>

The lesson of this failure is that private corporations cannot be held
accountable without government intervention. Market forces alone aren't
strong enough to make the private sector submit to the public's wishes
when all the wealth is concentrated in the hands of very few people.

> Homeschooled kids and kids in non-government schools are getting a
> better education than kids in government schools. Government school
> teachers agree -- they send their own kids to non-government schools
> at a higher rate than the general population.

I attended 6 public schools and one private during my grade school
education. Some were good (Connecticut, Nebraska), some bad (Georgia,
Florida). The private school in Georgia was clearly the best, and I'd be
hard-pressed to disagree with you that our public school system is in
serious trouble. But I really think that we could make it better if
everyone just agreed to fully fund their childrens' education. The
problem is, not everyone can afford to send their children to private
schools. With privatization you'd merely be forced to choose between two
private schools based entirely on how much they cost. I don't think
that's a choice any parent should have to make.

> The military is way over-funded. The U.S. government has a bigger 
> military budget than something like the next 10 top-spending countries 
> combined.

I wholeheartedly agree.

> Pharmaceutical companies were told, "Poor people in other countries
> can't afford your medicine. Sell it to them cheaper." Because most of
> their drug sales were in the U.S., they were still able to cover the
> millions of dollars it costs to develop a new drug due to government
> regulations by selling full-priced drugs here, they complied. But then
> people started saying, "Drugs are cheaper overseas! Companies are
> price-gouging! Americans should be able to buy prescription drugs in
> Canada!"

Bzzt. Drugs are less expensive overseas primarily because they aren't
protected by copyrights and patents, and partially because other
governments are allowed to negotiate prices on a larger scale than HMOs
and insurance companies in the US. Drugs aren't cheaper in Canada
because Candadians can't afford the market price; they're cheaper
because their single-payer system is able to buy drugs in bulk.

> Medical research is largely funded by drug sales. What do you think is
> going to happen to medical research if companies are prevented from
> recouping the costs of that research by making a high profit on the
> small percentage of drugs that are successfully brought to market?

A good deal of medical research is actually funded by the government
already, and performed in government-funded educational institutions.
Perhaps if drug companies decided to spend more on R&D than they do on
marketing, they wouldn't need to gouge us. The top seven drug companies
in the US have higher profit margins than any other industry in the
world. There's simply no way you can claim that they're starved for
research dollars or prohibited by regulation from making money. Of
course, there's no incentive for them to change the way they spend their
money if the "market" (inhibited in part by laws that prevent bulk
purchasing) has allowed them to rake in that kind of cash.

> Government jobs are stable, I'll give you that. Compared to private 
> enterprise, it's difficult to fire anybody in civil service, no matter 
> how badly they're fucking up. But I take it that your main point is 
> that you don't want to eliminate too many taxes and regulations even 
> when doing so would directly benefit poor people, because your top 
> priority is keeping big government.

If big government is the only way to ensure that people are treated
fairly and humanely, yes. *That's* my priority. I think the weakness of
Libertarianism is the rabid obsession with shrinking government,
regardless of the deleterious effects it has on society as a whole.

> How you expect to maintain a perpetually huge and powerful government
> without eventually getting a police state I have no idea, but that is
> one of the paradoxes of liberal ideology.

Not really. I think it would be easy to balance personal freedom with
sensible governmental control that defends people from corporations, but
vitriol from both sides makes it seemingly impossible to find a middle
ground. A single-payer healthcare system does not produce a "police
state". Laws that prevent individuals and corporations alike from
polluting the environment do not produce a "police state". Regulations
that prevent industry from subjecting people to harsh working conditions
does not produce a "police state". Conversely, I would argue that
dissolving government and leaving people to fend for themselves would
necessitate a police state: anarchistic free market imbalance could
eventually lead to literal class warfare, and if the government takes
the side of corporations in that battle (as they consistently have under
Bush, and would under a Libertarian government), we're screwed.

> >Give corporations control over everything that
> >people rely on, eliminate stable government jobs, and let the market
> >dictate what society needs. Great plan!
> 
> Making it easier and less expensive to do business would result in 
> more entrepreneurship and more competition. More competition means 
> *less* corporate control, not more. The opposite of competition is 
> monopoly; the more competition you have in an economy, the fewer 
> monopolies, and vice versa. Only when a company enjoys a monopoly can 
> it effectively exercise control. So contrary to your idea that a free 
> market would mean more corporate control, the reality is nearly the 
> opposite.

Sorry, but reality is on my side. Numerous prominent de-regulation
schemes brought about recently have resulted in less choice and more
corporate control. The FCC's loosening of regulations has given
ClearChannel and other dominant media companies a near stranglehold on
both the national radio market *and* music event bookings. 75% of what
we watch on TV is controlled by just 5 media conglomerates. California's
energy de-regulation allowed Enron to manipulate the market by reducing
supply at the time demand was highest. Today we found out that the FDA
may have been negligent in monitoring the safety of Vioxx, an
anti-inflammatory that's been found to increase the risk of heart attack
and stroke. So don't tell me that removing regulations ("making it
easier and less expensive to do business") is going to give me more
choice, or encourage competition.

The free market loves monopolies; after all, it's a sure-fire way to
make gobs and gobs of money. Build up your business, buy out your
competitors, saturate the population with advertising and you're golden.
And with the media owned and operated by the same corporations hawking
goods and services to their audiences, there's no way for small
businesses to compete.

I'll be the first "liberal" to concede that a great deal of regulation
written into law is totally unnecessary, beauracratic, procedural
nonesense. But that doesn't mean that regulation is fundamentally
flawed. It simply means the lawmakers have spent too much time bickering
over minutiae and been unable to focus on producing laws that actually
defend people from industry.

> >It's fashionable to claim that medical malpractice is solely
> >responsible for the rising costs of healthcare, but that only
> >accounts for 1% of the increase.
> 
> Of course medical malpractice isn't "solely" responsible for rising
> health care costs -- in a complex economy, where is one factor ever
> "solely" responsible for increasing prices in an entire industry? But
> realizing that the rising cost of insurance is a big factor in
> expensive health care isn't just "fashionable" -- it's accurate.
> According to a 2002 Department of Health and Human Services report,

Hey, isn't that the department headed by Tommy Thompson, who just weeks
ago visited swing states to quell fears of dwindling flu vaccine supply?
;)

> As a matter of fact Libertarians have criticized the Medicare "reform"
> bill (see http://www.lp.org/press/archive.php?function=view&record=649
> among others).  It's not even a reform -- it's a new welfare pork plan
> for seniors to have the government pay for their prescription drugs,
> further putting Medicare into the red. By the time most of us on this
> list are retirement age, the system will be long past bankrupt, and
> we'll be left to pay off the debt.

I totally agree (except, of course, with the notion that it's wrong for
the government to aid seniors in the purchase of prescription drugs). If
the government would just allow Medicare to negotiate lower prices by
buying in bulk on a national scale, those drugs would be a LOT cheaper.

> Social Security was set up as a voluntary program during the
> Depression for certain categories of working-class people without
> employer retirement plans to save for their retirement. It was not
> meant to be a mandatory socialist wealth-redistribution scheme, but
> that is what it has turned into.

You know what, I'm all for Social Security reform; I'm just not sure
that privatization is the solution.

> (source: http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm#Private )

For what it's worth, "Just Facts" shows quite a slant toward exposing
hipocrisy on the left. For instance, the section on China foreign policy
fails to detail the CIA's support for opium drug lords in Burma while
they waged covert war on the People's Liberation Army. The section on
"Racial Issues" fails to mention a single incidence of Republican
racism, rampant at the height of the Civil Rights movement. I can't
trust this site as an objective source when it's clearly driven by
partisan ideology.

> Regulations *preventing* U.S. industry from taking advantage of
> trading partners? Ha! That's the rare exception, not the rule. Most
> trade regulations are designed to protect domestic industry at the
> expense of both overseas trade partners and of domestic consumers who
> have to pay higher prices due to the lack of competition.

Sorry, that came out wrong. I'm opposed to defensive trade regulations.
I was merely pointing out that de-regulation in general allows industry
to take advantage of anyone--be it US citizens or the countries with
which we trade goods and services.

> Let's get something straight: Money belongs to the people who earn it,
> not to the government. When government takes your money and then gives
> some of it back to you, or you find out that the cost of regulations
> you have to obey is going down by 1% this year (instead of up by the
> usual 5%), that's not a "giveaway," it's a partial return of stolen 
> property.

Again, this is a fundamental disagreement. I believe that paying taxes
is something you have to do if you want to take part in American life.
No, it's not written into the Constitution. But it's something that
people have come to except because they understand that their tax
dollars fund everything from the construction of the roads they drive on
to the inspection of the food they eat. Our system isn't perfect. But I
refuse to accept the notion that people should be allowed to hoard their
money and still take advantage of all the services that the rest of the
population's taxes pay for.

> When government subsidizes corporations -- which it does frequently
> under both Republicans and Democrats, as evidenced by the fact that
> corporate welfare recipients give heavily to both parties (see
> http://www.opensecrets.org/industries/mems.asp ) -- that *is* a
> giveaway, and it's wrong. But let's not confuse the two concepts.

No arguments here...

> Before criticizing things like the EPA's easing of regulations on
> mercury, there are important questions that need to be asked. For
> instance, how much real danger is there from mercury in tuna fish? How
> many unborn babies have actually been poisoned? Is it proven, or is it
> a media scare story like crack babies?

Why would the FDA want to scare people? If the danger is unproven, then
you have a point. So prove it false. It just seems strange to me that
the FDA would purposefully release a warning about mercury levels in
fish at the same time that the EPA was easing regulations on mercury
pollution. Hey, maybe if we didn't have either agency we'd be a lot
better off!</sarcasm>

> Should the government force industry to spend $100 million (random
> hypothetical number) to make tuna 100% mercury-free, if the same
> expenditure, channeled into worker salaries, lower prices, and
> shareholder returns, could have marginally improved the standard of
> living of all the tuna industry workers, tuna buyers, and people whose
> pension plans include stock in fisheries or tuna-packing companies?

Of course they should--within reason. Even people with ties to the tuna
industry can't escape the (potential) dangers of mercury poisoning.

> Is this regulation worth costing many people that little bit of extra
> income that might have enabled some of the thousands or millions of
> people affected to afford to move to safer neighborhoods, to afford
> better health care, better day care, to upgrade to a newer, safer,
> less polluting car, to be able to afford to eat lunch somewhere
> healthier than McDonalds, etc.?

That's not my decision to make, and that's WHY there's an FDA. We need
these agencies to study the dangers and determine whether or not the
combined cost of putting regulations in place, industry implementing
them, and their enforcement, are greater than the cost of allowing
indusry to harm people. Without these agencies (or with these agencies
headed up by former industry lobbyists) we're left to fend for
ourselves, and I think that's wrong.

> The problem with the knee-jerk "let's regulate!" attitude is that it
> rarely takes any kind of real economic cost-benefit analysis into
> account.

WTF? Regulation isn't a "knee-jerk" attitude. It's a rational response
to the negative affects of industry on society.

> Regulators typically look at the immediate, intended effects of their
> legislation, often based on faulty or incomplete science or data,
> while failing to look at the more subtle and unintended consequences
> of their feel-good policies.

Then, as I've suggested is the case with the Bush Administration, the
regulators aren't doing their job. That doesn't mean regulation is
inherently wrong.

> >I will do no such thing. NPR is the most objective news source I know
> >of. Michael Krasny dedicated an hour of Forum last month to national
> >third-party candidates, including Badnarik.
> 
> I like NPR, but if you take an honest look at their programming,
> you'll admit they lean to the left. They're not partisans like Rush
> Limbaugh or Michael Moore, but I think there is a slight slant there. 

Sorry, I really don't see it. Forum is completely balanced when the
guests don't flake--in fact, I've found myself screaming at the radio
sometimes because I thought they were giving too much time to
Republicans. Talk of The Nation regularly welcomes partisans from both
sides. Terry Gross is admittedly leftist, but she doesn't allow that to
get in the way of her interviews with people like William Kristol,
chairman of the PNAC and editor of the Weekly Standard.

> And although Michael Krasny has generally been good about giving
> airtime to political alternatives -- which as a taxpayer-funded news
> source NPR damned well ought to be -- he also moderated a recent
> Jewish Community Center debate in SF between supporters of Bush and
> Kerry which excluded alternative party candidates.

Aw boo-hoo. What does that have to do with NPR?

> >Rush Limbaugh, on the other hand, doesn't deserve to be on the air.
> >He's a hateful, angry man that parrots the Republican party's talking
> >points and distorts the facts to suit his ideological slant. He's
> >just a cog in the right-wing attack machine, and I wouldn't waste my
> >time listening to a word he says if I were you.
> 
> If you were talking about Michael Savage, I would agree with you.  But
> Rush, despite his noted hypocrisy on the drug issue and a number of
> other positions that I strongly disagree with, has a lot of good
> insights on politics, economics, and society. I don't find him hateful
> or angry; he is generally good-humored, and polite to his callers. He
> also gets points with me for choosing Walter Williams as his usual
> substitute host -- Williams is a black man who is more libertarian
> than conservative.

I've tried listening to Rush. What I've heard is dishonest and
mean-spirited, and listening to that kind of program is not worth my
time.

> >>If you buy the Chronicle during the week, subscribe to the Washington
> >>Times national weekly edition for weekends. Don't just read Time or
> >>Newsweek magazines -- read Reason or Liberty. If your own news intake
> >>is ideologically balanced, you'll have a better perspective on what's
> >>going on with the rest of the country.
> >
> >I don't want ideological balance, I want objectivity.
> 
> Would you trust my opinion on what constitutes objectivity? How about
> Rush Limbaugh's opinion? No? Then I hope you won't mind if I choose
> ideological diversity in the news over your version of objectivity.
> Those who want to make up their own minds based on hearing a wide
> variety of viewpoints are advised to do the same.

I hear plenty of different viewpoints on NPR. I simply choose not to
spend my time with biased news sources that twist the facts.

> >I'd rather know the truth than try to figure it out by listening to
> >talking heads on either side try to skew an argument in their favor.
> >That's what I hate about the national news media: it's more about
> >letting both sides duke it out than getting to the facts of an issue.
> 
> Well, we're the equivalent of talking heads here on SFRaves trying 
> to skew an argument in our favor <grin>.

I disagree. It may appear so because nobody else gets involved in these
discussions, but the big difference is that this is an open forum.
There's nothing like this in the mass media.

> But I hope that my presentation has at least been somewhat fact-based
> and informative, if admittedly partisan from a libertarian perspective
> (which I trust you find more palatable than a conservative
> perspective).

I certainly do. :)

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <E91A3BDF-3027-11D9-926B-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>
Message-Id: <24B10CA2-3050-11D9-A5A6-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: guns

	It is true that Japan has both strict gun control and a low rate of 
violent crime. However this does not mean that there is a causal 
relationship between the two facts:

"More than gun control, more than the lack of criminal procedure 
safeguards, more than the authority of the police, it is the pervasive 
social controls of Japan that best explain the low crime rate. Other 
nations, such as the former Soviet Union, have had severe gun control, 
less criminal justice safeguards, and more unconstrained police forces 
than Japan. But the Soviets' crime rate was high and Japan's minuscule 
because Japan has the socially-accepted and internalised restraints on 
individual behaviour which the Soviets lack. While social controls fell 
and crime rose everywhere in the English-speaking world in the 1960s, 
social controls remained and crime fell in Japan."

(Source: http://www.guncite.com/journals/dkjgc.html )

	There is also the fact that while there are few violent crimes against 
others in Japan, there is a very high suicide rate. In fact there may 
even be a connection between these two circumstances. The essay above 
also includes the following:

"While the Japanese gun suicide rate is one-fiftieth of America's, the 
overall suicide rate is nearly twice as high as America's. Teenage 
suicide is 30 per cent more frequent in Japan than America. Every day 
in Japan, two Japanese under 20 years old kill themselves.

"Japan also suffers from double or multiple suicides, shinju. Parents 
bent on suicide take their children with them, at the rate of one per 
day, in oyako-shinju. In fact, 17 per cent of all Japanese officially 
defined as homicide victims are children killed by suicidal parents. 
One reason that the official Japanese homicide rate is so low is that 
if a Japanese woman slits her children's throats and then kills 
herself, police statistics sometimes record it as a family suicide, 
rather than a sensational murder. Thus, Japan's tight family 
structures, which keep the overall crime rate low, are not unalloyed 
blessings.

"Of the many reasons suggested by researchers for the high Japanese 
suicide rate, one of the most startling is weapons control. Japanese 
scholars Mamon Iga and Kichinosuke Tatai argue that one reason Japan 
has a suicide problem is that people have little sympathy for suicide 
victims. Iga and Tatai suggest that the lack of sympathy (and hence the 
lack of social will to deal with a high suicide rate) is based the 
Japanese' feelings of insecurity and consequent lack of empathy. They 
trace the lack of empathy to a 'dread of power'. That dread is caused 
in part by the awareness that a person cannot count on others for help 
against violence or against authority. In addition, say Iga and Tatai, 
the dread of power stems from the people being forbidden to possess 
swords or firearms for self-defense.

"Stated another way, firearms prohibition is part of a culture that 
subordinates the individual to society. When the individual finds 
himself not fitting into social expectations, self-destruction may 
often seem appropriate, since in a conflict between the individual and 
society, society is, by definition, always right. It is interesting to 
note that the overall violent death rates (counting both murders and 
suicides) in many of the developed countries are approximately the 
same. America has a high murder rate, but a relatively low suicide 
rate. Japan and Switzerland have very low murder rates, but suicide 
rates twice the American level. Seymour Martin Lipset notes the high 
suicide rates in Japan and western European countries and speculates 
that 'psychopaths there turn it on themselves'."

	So maybe in Japan, potential criminals are killing themselves instead 
of others. Isn't that a good thing? Not really. People who commit 
suicide tend to be social misfits and nonconformists. Although in a 
different society they might be more likely to become criminals, they 
might also be more likely to become ravers or members of the 
counterculture.

	My own ex-wife is Japanese. Although she had already been studying in 
the U.S. when I met her, I introduced her to the rave scene, Burning 
Man, drugs, etc. [I know, bad me...  8)  ] Anyway, after getting a full 
taste of American freedom, she came to find Japan so oppressive by 
comparison that she says she never wants to live there again, even 
though the rest of her family still does.

	Getting back to the original topic, the fact that Tokyo is the safest 
big city in the world cannot be attributed to disarming people -- it is 
much more complicated than that. If gun control laws were the 
explanation, then we would see similar laws reducing violent crime in 
the other places that have them, like the United States. But as 
documented in the article linked in my previous message, gun control 
laws have generally had exactly the opposite effect -- they have 
*increased* violent crime.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>


On Saturday, November 6, 2004, at 11:13  AM, John B wrote:

> Let's pretend this is Jeopardy for a minute.
>
> Here's the answer:
> It's one of the most population-dense areas on the planet; a city with 
> a permanent population of twelve million people, a daytime population 
> of fifteen million, and the center of a metropolitan area that easily 
> tops twenty million.  Yet, in this city, you can pick the roughest of 
> the rough neighborhoods, and walk down the street at any time of day 
> or night with so little worry about the safety of your person or 
> belongings, that the thought will probably never enter your mind.
>
> +++Game show music plays for 30 seconds+++
>
> Here's the question:
> What is Tokyo?
>
>
> Now, have a look at the hoops you have to go through to own a gun in 
> Japan, even a rinky-dink little air pistol:
>
> http://yarchive.net/gun/politics/japan_gun.html
>
> It makes the UK's (for example) gun control laws look like a cake-walk 
> in comparison, and our own, even in a place like San Francisco, 
> positively neolithic.  Yet the violent crime rate in Japan is one of 
> the lowest in the world.  Now, not being a statistician, I'm not going 
> to try to claim that the ONLY reason Japan is so safe is the lack of 
> availability of guns.  But the example, especially that of Tokyo 
> itself (Large, densely packed,  cities being generally the areas of 
> highest crime (violent, property, white collar, or otherwise) in ANY 
> country), certainly disproves those silly notions that gun control 
> increases crime or that an armed populace reduces it.
>

On 6 November 2004, shawn allen wrote:

> To be fair, I didn't mean the media establishment as a whole was
> conservative-leaning--I was referring to the portion of the overall
> media establishment that happens to be more conservative.

>From what I've read and seen, it would seem that the majority of media
outlets is likely in the liberal realm.  But the reason that I argue
that the media is overall a conservative influence is the REACH that the
various conservative outlets have vs. the reach that the liberal outlets
have.  i.e. Fox news (aka. Faux News) is now the #1 tv news network.
And ABC, CBS, and NBC don't necessarily have a truly conservative bias
as they do a corporate bias.  And don't even think about viewing radio.
;)

>
> > Even many leftists will admit that most of the mainstream media in the
> > U.S. lean to the left when compared to the beliefs of the U.S. public
> > as a whole. This is starting to change with the emergence of outlets

Nope!!  As a matter of count, maybe, but that doesn't mean anything.  An
EXTENSIVE study was done at Stanford recently (finished maybe 3 or 4
months ago) and I believe that what I mentioned above is what they
found.  I haven't seen full empirical data from it yet, but the process
seemed valid (using think-tank citings in weighing the extent of being
liberal or conservative.)  I asked whether they factored the subscriber
base in or not, or whether they counted an outlet that reached 10 people
the same as one that reached 10 million.  I haven't heard back (someone
at the station was part of the research team.)

> > like Fox News on the right to balance CNN and CBS on the left however,
> > and it's coming as a serious shock to many people who have been long
> > accustomed to getting their news with a liberal bias and seeing it as
> > normal.
>
> I still don't see the liberal bias. I don't necessarily want a media
> that agrees with me, but I do expect them to report facts and come to
> logical conclusions based on them. That's probably too much to expect
> because the mainstream media has always failed to do so, but the past 4
> years have shown a reckless disregard for objectivity. Fox News is

Just like Jon Stewart pointed out.  It seems that these folks are too
concerned about getting invited to the dinner parties (and not rocking
the boat to get excluded) rather than being actual journalists!  (Bow
tie boy in the Crossfire Jon Stewart interview even mentioned dinner
parties.)

> gaining in popularity, and the other big networks have picked up on
> their style. Sinclair Broadcasting is another example of media
> partisanship that is completely unrivaled on the left. What's sad is
> that the left has had to create their own media outlets JUST to refute
> the distortions of the right. There's no over-arching message for them
> to convey except that Republicans are more evil than Democrats.
>

[snip]

> > Ah yes, inflation... that little consequence of the fact that
> > government keeps printing more money which isn't backed by gold or
> > anything else of real value.
>

> government fight inflation by countering market meltdowns. But that's a
> completely tangential discussion...

It might be wise to take a look at what's going on elsewhere in the
world regarding reserves.  Russia may be trying to pull a Reagan back on
us.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Evidence Mounts That The Vote Was Hacked!!!!!!

--=====================_37201202==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Published on Saturday, November 6, 2004 by CommonDreams.org
Evidence Mounts That The Vote Was Hacked
by Thom Hartmann


When I spoke with Jeff Fisher this morning (Saturday, November 06, 2004), 
the Democratic candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives from 
Florida's 16th District said he was waiting for the FBI to show up. Fisher 
has evidence, he says, not only that the Florida election was hacked, but 
of who hacked it and how. And not just this year, he said, but that these 
same people had previously hacked the Democratic primary race in 2002 so 
that Jeb Bush would not have to run against Janet Reno, who presented a 
real threat to Jeb, but instead against Bill McBride, who Jeb beat.

"It was practice for a national effort," Fisher told me.

And some believe evidence is accumulating that the national effort happened 
on November 2, 2004.

The State of Florida, for example, publishes a county-by-county record of 
votes cast and people registered to vote by party affiliation. Net denizen 
Kathy Dopp compiled the official state information into a table, available 
at http://ustogether.org/Florida_Election.htm, and noticed something startling.

MORE:  http://www.commondreams.org/views04/1106-30.htm




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

                     The SFRaves Calendar
  Upcoming Parties and Events in the San Francisco Bay Area

Saturday, November 6, 2004 ** POP w/ Jeff Samuel (DJ) **


SATURDAY NOVEMBER 6TH 2004 POP at Rx Gallery - Every First Saturday


SPECTRAL RECORD RELEASE PARTY - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -=
=20
- - - -

BROKER/DEALER [LIVE] - SAN FRANCISCO, CA

Equipped with an array of samplers, sequencers and vintage synthesizers,=20
San Francisco wunderkinds Broker/Dealer make catchy minimal electronic=20
music equally suited for the den or the dancefloor. Simultaneously=20
channeling the aquatic dub of Berlin's Chain Reaction label and the=20
genre-defining minimal techno of the Kompakt imprint, on their debut=20
full-length, Initial Public Offering, B/D recalls German electronic=20
artists like Mike Ink, not to mention Metro Area's innovative=20
electro-disco.

After cooling off from last years full-length record on Asphodel,=20
Broker/Dealer comes back with something a bit more for the dance floor on=
=20
their new 12" single on Ghostly's Spectral label. The duo will perform a=20
special live set in honor of the release along with celebrating the=20
Dealer's 30th birthday!


JEFF SAMUEL [DJ] - SEATTLE, WA

Jeff Samuel's foray into electronic music began in 1995 when he first=20
witnessed a DJ set by Detroit's Claude Young in Columbus, Ohio.  He was=20
then introduced to that city's ele_mental collective, an inspiring core of=
=20
artists which included Ohio artists Titonton Duvante, the Archetype and=20
Todd Sines among others.  Through their concept-oriented events which=20
showcased the finer points of electronic music, he became enthralled and=20
began to DJ in 1996.  Soon after, he purchased his first synth and drum=20
machine.

While attending college in 1997, Jeff began exploring the possibilities of=
=20
software-based music production where he saw greater possibilities for=20
creativity and workflow.  He encountered much scrutiny for attempting to=20
make techno using only a computer.  Nevertheless, by 1998 he had started=20
to create his own completed tracks using an early version of Fruityloops=20
(now FL Studio).  Music from his first demo was signed to the German label=
=20
Lo-fi Stereo.  The "Bidooba" single was released in 1999 and featured a=20
remix from Kompakt's Michael Mayer.  Other tracks from the same demo found=
=20
their way to minimal techno pioneer Daniel Bell, who released them on his=
=20
7th City label in 2001.

Jeff pushed into the new millennium continuing his DJ career, releasing=20
more music and completing his college degree in Audio Production=20
simultaneously.  2002 proved to be a significant year which saw his=20
'Digital Self' Tektite EP remixed by Ricardo Villalobos, his abstract=20
material released by UK label Emoticon, and the beginning of a long=20
relationship with Cologne-based Trapez Recordings.  He also left Ohio for=
=20
the western port city of Seattle, where he pursued a career as a Sound=20
Designer in the videogame industry.

Today, Jeff Samuel is a sought-after remixer with a heavy DJ and=20
production schedule who still finds the time to make SFX for videogames.=20
His records are played by a diverse range of the world's most talented=20
DJ's including: Richie Hawtin, Sven Vath, Ricardo Villalobos, Francois K,=
=20
Steve Bug, Akufen, Craig Richards, Mazi, Claude Young, Timo Maas, Josh=20
Wink, Electric Indigo, Michael Mayer and John Tejada.  He is also=20
currently the only American DJ represented by the elusive Kompakt=20
organization.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Rx Gallery 132 Eddy=20
Street @ Mason Street San Francisco, CA 94102 http://www.rxgallery.com/ -=
=20
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - FREE before 10pm - $7=20

Friday, November 12, 2004 ** DIRTY w/ The Autobots **

The Autobots in their first ever west coast appearance. With a special=20

free cd's, vinyl, stickers and more.....


The Autobots (Broke/Skuff/TCR/Passenger/Botchit) - UK

The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez.Before the start of the=20
Autobots project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom=
=20
has produced over 40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been=
=20
promoting dance events since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly=
=20
new to the breaks scene, they have had releases on almost every major=20
breaks label, they've toured all around the world, and their tracks can be=
=20
found in the boxes of a lot of the biggest names in the business. Don't=20
miss them on their first ever west coast appearance.

Friday, November 12, 2004 ** Lee Coombs - Breakfast of Champions **

In the history of SF underground parties, there is one party that has=20
become the after party to start all parties.  In the spirit of keeping=20
things fresh, fun and original, the Breakfast of Champions party was born.=
=20
It traditionally starts at 6AM, the first day of the year, with the intent=
=20
on keeping the party going for those that didn't want to stop.  A bus full=
=20
of Space Cowboys collected those filing out of the parties across San=20
Francisco, and brought them to BOC.  After a few New Years passing, the=20
party is proudly maintained by everyone who walks through the doors.

Of course this party would not be mentionable if it wasn't for the DJs=20
that have graced the decks.  Along with all the Space Cowboys DJs, we have=
=20
hosted several local & international superstars who saved their best for=20
last and played amazing sets at 9AM.  One of these DJs is Lee Coombs, from=
=20
the Fingerlickin' UK family.  His uniquely tuned styles of acid tinged,=20
bass driven breakbeats, have been the soundtrack to many a Space Cowboy=20
party.  He joined us in '02 & '04.  He proudly returns to San Francisco to=
=20
promote the 11/16/04 release of his new album entitled 'Breakfast of=20
Champions.'

We need say no more.  We're tickled pink.  And ready to rock.  Please join=
=20
us for a night with new music, old friends, at one of the undeniably best=
=20
sounding clubs in the city.

LEE COOMBS - Breakfast of Champions US Album Release party hosted by the=20
Space Cowboys & 1015 Folsom WITH ADDITIONAL PERFORMANCES BY:  Kid Beyond=20
(live beatboxing), Felix the Dog (Groundscore), Adam Ohana (Get Freaky),=20
Benchun (False Profit) and the Space Cowboy DJ crew: Brad Robinson, The=20
Geometrist, 8ball, Kapt'n Kirk, Mancub, rrrus, & Smoove Visuals by James=20
Green & pixnstones

Friday November 12, 2004 | 10PM - 6AM 1015 Folsom, SF | 21+ w/Id | free b4=
=20
10:30 - $20 after

midnight, $10 after
