Saturday, November 13, 2004 ** Loveworks presents: FUTUREDISCO **

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Loveworks presents ~Q FUTUREDISCO ~Q ~V 11.13.04

Loveworks, the spark that has grown into an intense seven year inferno=20
combining house music, art, and cutting edge atmospherics continues it~Rs=
=20
series of monthly audiosocial experiments by immersing you in ~Q=20
FUTUREDISCO ~Q on Saturday November 13th ~R04 at their homebase~W the 111=
=20
Minna Gallery in San Francisco~Rs SOMA District.  This special event will=
=20
be homage to the roots of house music; disco in it~Rs past and present=20
forms.  In the early part of the evening, the Classics Caf=E9 will focus on=
=20
classic underground disco and the main floor will feature the sounds of=20
mutant disco, twisted disco and disco house later in the night.=20
Loveworks is proud to announce it~Rs first guest appearance by acclaimed=20
DJ and producer, DJ MFR of TRANSPORT RECORDINGS who will be lending his=20
smooth, pumping house style to the Loveworks dancefloor. Also supporting=20
MFR is Loveworks resident dj MATT VALENZ who will be harnessing the=20
rhythmic power of disco and aiming it straight at the crowd !  At the door=
=20
you will encounter a kindler, gentler guardian named TAMER who will once=20
again be serving up outfit and giving out smiles as well as guest services=
=20
by the newest member of the door team, MATT WALKER.  Your hosts for the=20
evening are NORI CASTILLO and DIANNA JACOBS who were instrumental in the=20
creation of the legendary TOONTOWN parties as well as CAREFREE DANCING,=20
the original house party at 177 Townsend.  Promoboy JIM WILLIAMS will also=
=20
be on hand to help ease you into the groove of the party !  Don~Rt forget=
=20
to join us early as the Classics Caf=E9 presents a very special event with=
=20
MEDIUM RARE MUSIC as they host a customer appreciation party for their=20
loyal patrons.  The Loveworks Classics Caf=E9 is an early evening deep dive=
=20
into the finer aspects of classic house, disco, funk, and soul that truly=
=20
kicks things off properly at 8pm and gets you ready for the serious body=20
rocking that comes later in the night.  This special evening of the Cafe=20
will feature the luscious disco rhythms of the amazing MARCELINO and a=20
special, legendary disco set by MEDIUM RARE~Rs own RON HOFFMAN.

BIO: DJ MFR DJ M.F.R. resides in San Francisco, California, U.S.A. His=20
musical history began at the early age of 18 when he began to djing in=20
Rome.  M.F.R's musical influences range from reggae, hip-hop and soul, to=
=20
classic rock and jazz. In 1990 he connected strongly with the soothing=20
sounds of soulful house music. Soon after, he began DJ'ing to express and=
=20
share his selection of deep, soothing soulful house music with others.=20
Moving to San Francisco in 1995, he immediately started playing in local=20
clubs. In recent years he has begun writing and experimenting with=20
electronic music.  In 1997 Marco together with Miguel "Migs" and Bruno=20
Ybarra started Transport Recordings, an independent label today well=20
established in the underground scene.  Currently he can be found in the=20
studio writing music ranging from deep house vocal songs and dubs, to=20
funky late night disco tracks and smooth down tempo jams A flavor for all=
=20
the dance floors.  In the recent years DJ MFR together with San Francisco=
=20
based producer Vincent Kwok started a production called "NEW MONDO". The=20
first two releases are now out on San Francisco label Eight Fifteen=20
Recordings. He can also be found spinning regularly at all of San=20
Francisco night clubs, such as: BACKFLIP "Mary's Body and Soul",=20
"Gravity", "Wet" 1015 FOLSOM "Release", "Heavy Rotation", RUBY SKYE "DRY",=
=20
"Discover", "Square" , SKYLARK "Sundays" 550 BARNAVALD "Stompy", UP&DOWN=20
CLUB, THE TOP, THE BLIND TIGER "Clique", "Electrolush", THE IRON "Opus",=20
BASE "Here&Now","Pure", THE GALAXY "Fame", "5150", MANHATTAN LOUNGE=20
"Scuba" , 111 Minna "Oxygen", "Atmosphere", DNA lounge "Family Funktion"=20
any many other..  DJ MFR has traveled the world headlining events in=20
cities such as Vancouver, Rome, Florence, LA, Seattle, Miami, Nashville=20
etc.... MFR also just released his hot new mix CD, WEST COAST EXCURSIONS=20
on Transport: http://www.transportrecordings.com/ . Check out a sample of=
=20
his sound online at: http://www.djcode.net/mfr.asp ( click on the MP3 Mix=
=20
button ! )

Loveworks Resident DJ Bio: MATT VALENZ In a world overtaken by automation=
=20
and technology, soul can be a hard thing to come by.  For someone lucky=20
enough to be raised on the sounds of Earth Wind & Fire, Kool and the Gang,=
=20
Diana Ross, and Tower of Power, being soulful comes as second nature. At=20
17 he was turned onto vinyl and was soon playing Miami bass, freestyle,=20
and primitive house at small underground parties in the central California=
=20
area, then moved on to start a career in the music business when he=20
relocated to San Francisco at age 21.  He continued his drive to learn=20
every aspect of the industry, and returned a few years ago from a two year=
=20
stay in England where he was the booking manager for dy-na-mix agency, the=
=20
best agency for underground music in Europe. Now, back in that city, he is=
=20
resident at ~Q Loveworks Dancing ~Q, a mobile house music phenomenon=20
focusing on vibe, music, and art.  past guests such as Doc Martin, Joi=20
Cardwell, J. Sinister, DJ Diz, and international guests like the UK's=20
Eddie Richards, A Man Called Adam, and Terry Francis have also helped to=20
establish the party as a premier place for true house music, funk, soul,=20
and classics in the bay area.  He continues to play at the some of San=20
Francisco's best parties and is currently assembling a personal studio.

Loveworks Resident DJ Bio: DAVID HARNESS In 1990, David began DJ'ing in=20
his hometown of Monterey, California, at the After Dark. As his popularity=
=20
grew past the boundaries of Monterey, he was invited to establish a=20
residency at Tilt, and Sound Factory, in San Francisco. In 1992, as=20
David's popularity continued to grow he, along with DJ, Ruben Mancias and=
=20
promoter Joseph Solis opened a hip and popular club, Lift, at Club Dv8.=20
David joined Bay Area legendary DJ, Pete Avila and host Foxxee Brown on=20
'Your Mama's House', on the Bay Area's popular radio station KMEL FM.=20
Being the only "true" house mix show on any Northern California radio=20
station, DJ's David Harness, Pete Avila and host Foxxee Brown have played=
=20
a key role in furthering House Music in the Bay Area. Also during that=20
year, David established a residency at San Francisco's legendary Club=20
Universe. David Harness has quickly become one of the most well known and=
=20
popular DJ's in the San Francisco Bay Area club scene. David's popularity=
=20
continued to soar, taking him around the world; and the opportunity to=20
play with New York's Legendary DJ's, Frankie Knuckles, Tony Humphries,=20
Little Louie Vega, Tedd Patterson, Dave Morales, London's Ricky Morrison,=
=20
Danny Teneglia, Marques Wyatt- to name a few. He has appeared in articles=
=20
and interviews in Billboard Magazine, Paper Magazine, Surface, XLR8R, Urb,=
=20
Streetsounds, Sweater, HX, Next and the Bay Guardian.

Bio: LOVEWORKS Add a large helping of deep underground house music with a=
=20
side of funk, a heap of disco, and a hint of techno, and you have the most=
=20
nutritious dancefloor experience available in San Francisco. Initially=20
conceived by Dianna Jacobs and Nori Castillo of Toontown / Carefree fame=20
in the summer of '96, Loveworks was envisioned as a refuge from the=20
monotony of local clubs and superficial music, and has become one of the=20
bay area's most well known nights out, while somehow remaining one it's=20
best kept secrets.  It exists to unite people of any race, social status=20
or sexuality together in a comfortable and friendly club environment with=
=20
music as the focal point, and in addition to it's monthly parties at the=20
Minna Gallery, Loveworks also teams up with other like minded parties=20
around the city and has been featured at clubs and parties such as Liquid,=
=20
the Top, Electric, and the Endup.  Besides late night dancing, Loveworks=20
has also been involved in events for Wired Magazine, Apple Computer, Sony=
=20
Digital, Construct Internet Design, and a host of others. Loveworks also=20
had the honor of winning the SF Bay Guardian~Rs ~Q BEST HOUSE CLUB ~Q in=20
1999.

Bio: 111 MINNA GALLERY 111 Minna Gallery is a dynamic ~Qcontemporary art=20
salon~R that provides an arena for multi-dimensional artistic expression=20
in a community atmosphere. The goal of the ~Qgallery-as salon~R concept is=
=20
to nurture and support a communal gathering of artists and a collaboration=
=20
between diverse art forms. This goal is achieved through six-week=20
rotations of visual art exhibitions curated by the staff combined with a=20
variety of music and film events. ~QMinna~R is not only the name of the=20
street on which the gallery is found but also translates from Japanese as=
=20
"everybody," an all-inclusive term that symbolizes the embracing=20
environment of the space. The gallery, which also offers two bars, is=20
crafted in an eclectic, contemporary design with ample furniture inviting=
=20
guests to leisurely relax and enjoy conversation among friends. The=20
combination of art, music, film, dance and conversation found at 111 Minna=
=20
Gallery creates a unique gathering place for a multi-sensory experience.

( contact: Nori for information and guest list questions / 866 841 9139=20
ext 2016 / loveworksdancing@onebox.com.  Check the website at=20
www.loveworksdancing.com )

Saturday, November 20, 2004 ** Mind Control **

***Mind Control***

~SA celebration to the life and love of Chris Vierra; the west coast=20
breakbeat monster?br> December 10, 1976 - July 14, 2004

San Francisco, California 8pm til 4am, 2 rooms 18+, 2 full bars for the=20
21+ Admission $10 100 % of the proceeds will be donated to Chris~Rs family

transformations by ill behavior

your hosts for the evening;

BREAKS

FACTORe 20k Freaks / Afterdark / Supercharged UK

The U.S. ascension of FACTORe is often attributed to his custom blend of=20
impeccable studio skills, charismatic performances on the decks, and the=20
business savvy that has made his record label, 20k freaks the first true=20
transatlantic label to offer duel pressings and releases in both the U.S.=
=20
and the U.K. simultaneously. His collaborative efforts with the Autobotz,=
=20
Aquasky vs Masterblaster, Backdraft,Breakfasterz, Deep Impact, and Panic=20
Room account for just a taste of his over 60 releases to date. Being tied=
=20
to crews like Supercharged UK, Breaks Poll~Rs pick for .1 breakbeat label=
=20
in ?3, and his tracks charted by the likes of Krafty Kuts, Skool of=20
Thought, Monk, Icey, and Aquasky vs Masterblaster; FACTORe has undoubtedly=
=20
captured the pulse of today~Rs brokenbeat and served it back to us on a=20
vinyl plate.

for the links you posted as well, Karina.

	Just when you thought the election was safely over... the=20
post-election fingernail-biting overtime may only be just beginning.

	It's hard to keep my cynicism intact when reality keeps =
outpacing it.=20
Even though I should know better, it still amazes me that the=20
authorities let elections in this country be run in such a half-assed,=20=

jury-rigged, error-filled, Banana Republic -- and I don't mean the=20
clothing company -- manner, year after year!

	I'm starting to think the best solution would be to have teams =
of=20
volunteers hand-count the votes, at the polling places so as to remove=20=

any possibility of funny things happening on the way to the elections=20
office, with multiple people physically signing off on each ballot. And=20=

that the counting process should be broadcast live on local public=20
access TV from start to finish. Even if it took two weeks to get the=20
results, at least we'd be able to trust them.

	Elections -- too important to be left to government??   8)

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>

> Published on Saturday, November 6, 2004 by CommonDreams.org
> Evidence Mounts That The Vote Was Hacked
> by Thom Hartmann
>
>
> When I spoke with Jeff Fisher this morning (Saturday, November 06,=20
> 2004), the Democratic candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives=20=

> from Florida's 16th District said he was waiting for the FBI to show=20=

> up. Fisher has evidence, he says, not only that the Florida election=20=

> was hacked, but of who hacked it and how. And not just this year, he=20=

> said, but that these same people had previously hacked the Democratic=20=

> primary race in 2002 so that Jeb Bush would not have to run against=20
> Janet Reno, who presented a real threat to Jeb, but instead against=20
> Bill McBride, who Jeb beat.
>
> "It was practice for a national effort," Fisher told me.
>
> And some believe evidence is accumulating that the national effort=20
> happened on November 2, 2004.
>
> The State of Florida, for example, publishes a county-by-county record=20=

> of votes cast and people registered to vote by party affiliation. Net=20=

> denizen Kathy Dopp compiled the official state information into a=20
> table, available at http://ustogether.org/Florida_Election.htm, and=20
> noticed something startling.

Subject: [sfraves] Adam Freeland rejects raving Bush girls

Taken from :: THE DIVISION UNDERGROUND NEWSLETTER
:: GLOBAL NEWS ::

Adam Freeland rejects raving Bush girls

Outspoken British breaks star Adam Freeland found himself performing for
George W's notoriously fun-loving daughters Jenna and Barb at a US rave last
week and was horrified when he realized who they were.
"I was in Chicago playing a We Want Your Vote gig last Thursday night and
the promoter had told me that the Bush daughters might be there and I'd been
like 'yeah, whatever', said Adam.

"Then about an hour into my set I dropped 'We Want Your Soul', the vibe
picked up and a few new heads came onto the floor from the adjacent VIP
room, including one pissed up (drunk-slang Ed) girl who was jumping around,
pulling hard on a fag (cigarette), who was obviously a party girl," he
recalled.


"Then I saw her face and I got this weird deep sickly churning in my
stomach; she looked exactly like George W and I realized 'fuck', it is her;
George W's daughter going nuts to We Want Your Soul, miming the words," said
Adam.

"I felt like I'd seen the antichrist (not that I'm a Christian) but it was
fucking odd and strange and her sister was there with her too, though she
wasn't afflicted with looking like him," he continued. "If Bush dressed up
as a girl, he'd be his daughter. Poor fucking girl."


"I thought maybe I should go find her chat her up or something (it didn't
look like it'd be that tough), try to get her into bed just so I could
infiltrate her mind, infiltrate her family, change the world, or even just
tell my mates I'd shagged a Bush," Adam added.

"But I didn't," he laughed.

http://www.bushwatch.com/hold1.htm ('In St.-Tropez, Jenna partied with Sean
"P. Diddy" Combs. In New York, the twins sent one of their Secret Service
agents over to procure an introduction to rocker Chris Cornell, the front
man for the band Audioslave. The girls were not averse to showing up at
places where controlled substances were enjoyed . . .')

http://www.thefirsttwins.com/countdown.html ('This was the Countdown to the
wondrous legal beer drinking age of 21. The Twins both successfully turned
21 on November 25, 2002. Now, this can be a count up from ground Zero: the
day the twins turned 21. What will happen? Only time can tell . . !')

http://www.wewantyoursoul.com ('You can receive a guaranteed CASH SUM for
life, in exchange for an agreement that entitles WWYS® the rights to your
soul from now until all eternity. Find out the current value of your soul -
click here now for a free, no obligation quotation . . .')

>

George W's daughter going nuts to We Want Your Soul, miming the words," said
Adam.

"I felt like I'd seen the antichrist (not that I'm a Christian) but it was
fucking odd and strange and her sister was there with her too, though she
wasn't afflicted with looking like him," he continued. "If Bush dressed up
as a girl, he'd be his daughter. Poor fucking girl."


"I thought maybe I should go find her chat her up or something (it didn't
look like it'd be that tough), try to get her into bed just so I could
infiltrate her mind, infiltrate her family, change the world, or even just
tell my mates I'd shagged a Bush," Adam added.

"But I didn't," he laughed.

http://www.bushwatch.com/hold1.htm ('In St.-Tropez, Jenna partied with Sean
"P. Diddy" Combs. In New York, the twins sent one of their Secret Service
agents over to procure an introduction to rocker Chris Cornell, the front
man for the band Audioslave. The girls were not averse to showing up at
places where controlled substances were enjoyed . . .')

http://www.thefirsttwins.com/countdown.html ('This was the Countdown to the
wondrous legal beer drinking age of 21. The Twins both successfully turned
21 on November 25, 2002. Now, this can be a count up from ground Zero: the
day the twins turned 21. What will happen? Only time can tell . . !')

http://www.wewantyoursoul.com ('You can receive a guaranteed CASH SUM for
life, in exchange for an agreement that entitles WWYS=AE the rights to your
soul from now until all eternity. Find out the current value of your soul -
click here now for a free, no obligation quotation . . .')

-------------------------------1099941465--

In a message dated 11/7/2004 11:53:27 PM Pacific Standard Time, 
amadu78@hotmail.com writes:
Taken from :: THE DIVISION UNDERGROUND NEWSLETTER
:: GLOBAL NEWS ::

Adam Freeland rejects raving Bush girls

Outspoken British breaks star Adam Freeland found himself performing for
George W's notoriously fun-loving daughters Jenna and Barb at a US rave last
week and was horrified when he realized who they were.
"I was in Chicago playing a We Want Your Vote gig last Thursday night and
the promoter had told me that the Bush daughters might be there and I'd been
like 'yeah, whatever', said Adam.

"Then about an hour into my set I dropped 'We Want Your Soul', the vibe
picked up and a few new heads came onto the floor from the adjacent VIP
room, including one pissed up (drunk-slang Ed) girl who was jumping around,
pulling hard on a fag (cigarette), who was obviously a party girl," he
recalled.


"Then I saw her face and I got this weird deep sickly churning in my
stomach; she looked exactly like George W and I realized 'fuck', it is her;
George W's daughter going nuts to We Want Your Soul, miming the words," said
Adam.

"I felt like I'd seen the antichrist (not that I'm a Christian) but it was
fucking odd and strange and her sister was there with her too, though she
wasn't afflicted with looking like him," he continued. "If Bush dressed up
as a girl, he'd be his daughter. Poor fucking girl."


"I thought maybe I should go find her chat her up or something (it didn't
look like it'd be that tough), try to get her into bed just so I could
infiltrate her mind, infiltrate her family, change the world, or even just
tell my mates I'd shagged a Bush," Adam added.

"But I didn't," he laughed.

http://www.bushwatch.com/hold1.htm ('In St.-Tropez, Jenna partied with Sean
"P. Diddy" Combs. In New York, the twins sent one of their Secret Service
agents over to procure an introduction to rocker Chris Cornell, the front
man for the band Audioslave. The girls were not averse to showing up at
places where controlled substances were enjoyed . . .')

http://www.thefirsttwins.com/countdown.html ('This was the Countdown to the
wondrous legal beer drinking age of 21. The Twins both successfully turned
21 on November 25, 2002. Now, this can be a count up from ground Zero: the
day the twins turned 21. What will happen? Only time can tell . . !')

http://www.wewantyoursoul.com ('You can receive a guaranteed CASH SUM for
life, in exchange for an agreement that entitles WWYS® the rights to your
soul from now until all eternity. Find out the current value of your soul -
click here now for a free, no obligation quotation . . .')

Subject: [sfraves] short review of jeff samuel at pop on friday...

I hadn't heard Jeff Samuel before this event, but was
looking forward to it.  hell, i look forward to
anything minimal techno-y.  anyway, he was pretty
good, good track selection, had a bumping dance floor,
though i think he played tracks out too long and
wasn't the most skilled mixer (no trainwrecks, but not
the smoothest transitions.)  but, decent bumpin'
minimal housy-techno, which had me bouncing until i
was just too tired.  

got to the party for the end of broker dealer's live
set.  they were good, better than the last time i saw
them.  they had a decent dance floor as well.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] short review of jeff samuel at pop on friday...

quoth Gavin Varitech:
> Does he have any mixes anywhere?

To be fair, Jeff Samuel is first and foremost a kick-ass producer, so I
think it's a bit unfair to judge him by his DJ skills. That said, I was
*really* impressed with his set on Saturday. Rarely do I hear artists
that DJ that well, and it made me that much more a fan of someone whose
records I buy on sight anyway :)

But FWIW, he has one link to a set of his in Osaka a couple of months
ago on his own site:

<http://jeffsamuel.com/>

Broker/Dealer also rocked it. If you missed out, you'll have another
chance to hear Ryan and Ryan play next Tuesday (11/16) at Hugger-Mugger.
BSP forthcoming...

Toodles,

this kind of view and at this price ($610 incl. utilities).  The view is to
die for, and we have a big outside deck to help us enjoy it!  (pictures at
the link below)

The roommates: Danny Picard, Katelyn Brod, and me, Beth Klem!
We're almost as cool as the view... well, at least the other two are :)
Everyone is really chill and easy to get along.  Danny and Katelyn work
nights, I work 9-5, so it's generally fairly quiet around here, though we do
throw big parties from time to time (with adv. notice, always).  Because of
the varied work schedules, we don't hang out as much as we'd like to, but we
get along famously and enjoy hanging out when we get a chance.

We would love to find another roommate who ends up feeling like family,
because that makes the house so much more pleasant to be in.  Note: we just
don't do drama.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  EMERGENCY CALL TO ACTION!

--=====================_13176346==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

EMERGENCY CALL TO ACTION!
VOTERGATE!!!

Are you anguished and enraged by the outcome of the Nov 2 election?  Are 
you following the growing mass of evidence of possible fraud and outright 
theft?  Lost votes, missing ballots, black-box machines with no paper 
trail, a clear pattern of intimidation of voters based on racial profiling, 
do you suspect a scandal bigger than Watergate and far more meaningful than 
Monica is being suppressed?

Was the 2004 election stolen?  Take action to defend democracy and demand 
an investigation into electoral fraud!

We can stay home and grumble and swear at the T.V. as Bush claims a 
mandate.  We can go to work as usual, and pretend nothing is wrong.  Or we 
can come out and take action.  Join us to protest the continuing 
disenfranchisement of African-American, Latino and student voters, to 
demand a suspension of the electoral college vote until there is a full and 
impartial investigation of all the irregularities, and to defend democracy.

Wednesday, November 10,
Noon
San Francisco Federal Building,
450 Golden Gate, plaza side,

Rally and nonviolent civil disobedience.

--We demand a thorough, impartial, and immediate investigation into 
electoral fraud, racially based suppression of voters, and a full count of 
all provisional and absentee ballots and 'spoiled' votes.
--We demand that the December 13 electoral college vote be suspended, if 
necessary, until these questions are resolved.  The legitimacy of our 
government is compromised when the integrity of our electoral system is in 
question,

Free and fair elections are the basis of a democratic government. When the 
integrity of the electoral system is in question, the government loses its 
legitimacy. No recount could be as destabilizing as the widespread 
suspicion that the Republicans have stolen a second election.

Here are just a few of the serious concerns that have arisen:

--Around the world, exit polls are used to verify that elections are free 
from fraud. Here in the US, polls in precincts using computer voting 
machines with no paper trail were consistently at odds with the reported 
outcome, while polls in precincts using paper ballots matched the outcome.
--In Ohio, adequate numbers of voting machines were not provided in African 
American and student neighborhoods, causing voters hours of waiting time at 
the polls.
--1,074 instances of voter intimidation were reported to the Election 
Protection Coalition.
--In Franklin County, Ohio, voting machines gave George Bush 3,893 votes in 
one precinct alone, far more than the number of registered voters. In 
Craven County, North Carolina, a software error gave Bush 11,283 extra 
votes,  In Broward County, Florida, voting machines were discovered to be 
counting backwards.
--In Ohio, the number of provisional ballots may be far higher than 
Secretary of State Blackwell claims.  Absentee and 'spoiled' ballots have 
not been counted­African American and Latino voters are far more likely to 
have their ballots discarded.
--Purging of supposed 'felons' in Florida and Colorado disproportionately 
targets communities of color and may violate the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
--The Diebold machines and central computer processors were never tested to 
assure that they could not be hacked by outsiders.
--And much, much more!

It's not too late!  The Watergate Scandal brought Nixon down long after he 
took office.  We can counter the false perception of Bush's 'mandate', push 
the mainstream media into covering these serious issues, maybe even put 
some spine into the Democrats, stand in alliance with youth and communities 
of color, and protect the integrity of our vote.  Fighting for fair 
elections is vital­for the present and the future!

Reclaim the Commons
Democracy Defense Committee
www.beyondvoting.org <http://www.beyondvoting.org/>

For more information on election fraud, see:
www.blackboxvoting.org <http://www.blackboxvoting.org/>
<http://www.tompaine.com/articles/kerry_won_.php>http://www.tompaine.com/articles/kerry_won_.php
www.gregpalast.com <http://www.gregpalast.com/>
www.democracyunderground.com <http://www.democracyunderground.com/>
<http://www.truthout.org/docs_04/110804A.shtml>http://www.truthout.org/docs_04/110804A.shtml
This is the announcement list for Direct Action to Stop the War (DASW).  To 
remove yourself from this list, send an email to 
directaction-unsubscribe@lists.riseup.net.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] nrr:  a use for your throw away vinyl

**Shudders**

http://kids.discovery.com/fansites/tradingspaceskids/crafts/season3/craft02.html?ct=9799.1328693843

Record Bowls


You must have your parent's permission to do this craft. Never turn on the
oven or stove without your parent's permission. Set the timer so you don't
forget about the records in the oven ... you don't want to clean this up
if you forget and leave the records in for too long.

Materials:

Oven-safe bowl
Old record
Oven mitts
Oven timer
Oven


Step by Step

Step 1

Ask a parent to preheat the oven to about 200-250 degrees.
Choose the bowl you are going to use. Flip the bowl so it is bottom up.
Lay the record on the bowl. When the record heats up, it will begin to
mold to the shape of the bowl.
Step 2

Set your timer for 5 minutes and place the bowls with the records in the
oven.
Step 3

When the timer rings, check on the record. If it looks like it's melted,
turn off the oven. Ask a parent to put on the oven mitts and remove the
bowls. If it's not yet to your liking, set the timer for another 3
minutes. Do not keep the record in the oven for more than 10 minutes.
Remember to turn off the oven when you are done.
Step 4

If you have two of the same-shaped bowls, you can press the bowl down on
top of the other to bring a better shape to the record.
Let your new record bowl cool for about 10 minutes.
Step 5

Use your new record bowls for anything! Just remember they can't hold water.

Subject: [sfraves] jeff responds. was: short review of jeff samuel at pop on 
     friday... [sfraves] 


jeff asked me to forward this message for him.

---------------------------- Original Message ----------------------------
From:    "Jeff Samuel" <me@jeffsamuel.com>

Hi There,

I received a forward of this review so I thought I'd make a short response.

When I approached the decks the master fader on the mixer was all the way
up to 10 with the level completely red, the channel levels equally hot,
and the Mackie monitor to my right blown out.  This left me with the tiny
monitor to my left that was already clipping.  Given the fact that this
was an art gallery with no 'sound guy', I couldn't really have turned the
levels down and turned the house sound up.  So, I had to wing it.  I was
often spending too much time trying to hear myself to do much technical
wizardry of any kind.  But hey, you can't win em all.

I appreciate the response in my defense, but I actually consider myself a
DJ first and producer second as I've got twice the experience in the
former than I do in the latter.  You absolutely should judge me by my DJ
skills BUT under proper conditions.

In any case, I thank you for coming and dancing despite the weak laws in
CA! As previously mentioned, you can check my site for a partial mix
(actually the first 45 mins of a 3-hr set) that may suit you better.

All the best,

Jeff Samuel
http://jeffsamuel.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr:  a use for your throw away vinyl

i think i have a perfecto record that i'd love to try this
with!

--- "Jonas R." <djjonas@sf-vibe.com> wrote:

> **Shudders**
> 
>
http://kids.discovery.com/fansites/tradingspaceskids/crafts/season3/craft02.html?ct=9799.1328693843
> 
> Record Bowls
> 
> 
> You must have your parent's permission to do this craft.
> Never turn on the
> oven or stove without your parent's permission. Set the timer
> so you don't
> forget about the records in the oven ... you don't want to
> clean this up
> if you forget and leave the records in for too long.
> 
> Materials:
> 
> Oven-safe bowl
> Old record
> Oven mitts
> Oven timer
> Oven
> 
> 
> Step by Step
> 
> Step 1
> 
> Ask a parent to preheat the oven to about 200-250 degrees.
> Choose the bowl you are going to use. Flip the bowl so it is
> bottom up.
> Lay the record on the bowl. When the record heats up, it will
> begin to
> mold to the shape of the bowl.
> Step 2
> 
> Set your timer for 5 minutes and place the bowls with the
> records in the
> oven.
> Step 3
> 
> When the timer rings, check on the record. If it looks like
> it's melted,
> turn off the oven. Ask a parent to put on the oven mitts and
> remove the
> bowls. If it's not yet to your liking, set the timer for
> another 3
> minutes. Do not keep the record in the oven for more than 10
> minutes.
> Remember to turn off the oven when you are done.
> Step 4
> 
> If you have two of the same-shaped bowls, you can press the
> bowl down on
> top of the other to bring a better shape to the record.
> Let your new record bowl cool for about 10 minutes.
> Step 5
> 
> Use your new record bowls for anything! Just remember they
> can't hold water.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>
---------------------------------------------------------------------

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>Adam Freeland rejects raving Bush girls

>Outspoken British breaks star Adam Freeland found himself performing for
>George W's notoriously fun-loving daughters Jenna and Barb at a US rave=
 last
>week and was horrified when he realized who they were.
>"I was in Chicago playing a We Want Your Vote gig last Thursday night and
>the promoter had told me that the Bush daughters might be there and I'd=
 been
>like 'yeah, whatever', said Adam.
>
>"Then about an hour into my set I dropped 'We Want Your Soul', the vibe
>picked up and a few new heads came onto the floor from the adjacent VIP
>room, including one pissed up (drunk-slang Ed) girl who was jumping around,
>pulling hard on a fag (cigarette), who was obviously a party girl," he
>recalled.
>
>
>"Then I saw her face and I got this weird deep sickly churning in my
>stomach; she looked exactly like George W and I realized 'fuck', it is her;
>George W's daughter going nuts to We Want Your Soul, miming the words,"=
 said
>Adam.
>
>"I felt like I'd seen the antichrist (not that I'm a Christian) but it was
>fucking odd and strange and her sister was there with her too, though she
>wasn't afflicted with looking like him," he continued. "If Bush dressed up
>as a girl, he'd be his daughter. Poor fucking girl."
>
>
>"I thought maybe I should go find her chat her up or something (it didn't
>look like it'd be that tough), try to get her into bed just so I could
>infiltrate her mind, infiltrate her family, change the world, or even just
>tell my mates I'd shagged a Bush," Adam added.
>
>"But I didn't," he laughed.
>

Drum and Bass Tuesdays in Downtown Oakland

Yeah, you heard me. D&B in the 510, huge upstairs club with HUGE, HUGE 
sound. You have never heard bass like this. The club has a large wooden 
dance floor, pool table, stage and a patio so you can drink and smoke at 
the same time. Easy parking, 2 blocks from BART (last train to SF leaves 
at 12:48am), and no neighbors to bitch about how fucking loud we are!

$2 Drafts
$3 Margaritas

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  DIRTY w/ Autobots - Breaks and DnB - Nov 12th

Evil Breaks presents: DIRTY
Friday November 12th, 2004
Jelly's (295 China Basin Wy @ pier 50)
9pm - 3am
$7 before 11pm / $10 after


The Autobots in their first ever west coast appearance. With a special 
outside DnB
room hosted by the Subscience crew with live fire dancers, free cd's, vinyl,
stickers and more.....


The Autobots (Broke/Skuff/TCR/Passenger/Botchit) - UK

The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez. Before the start of the 
Autobots
project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom has 
produced over
40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been promoting dance 
events
since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly new to the breaks scene, 
they
have had releases on almost every major breaks label, they've toured all 
around the
world, and their tracks can be found in the boxes of quite a few of the 
biggest
names in the business. Don't miss them on their first ever west coast 
appearance.


Evil Breaks room:

Ripple (Subscience)
B-Smarter (www.Sparxx.us/Equalize Ent/Virus Breaks) - Seattle, WA
Aaron Jae vs Athena (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks/the Nubotz)
Bam vs Influence (Evil Breaks/in Tha Mix)

Subscience DnB room:

Method One (Method-One.com)
Arson (Urban Drums/www.594Apparel.net)
The Hitmen (Subscience)
Doubleday (Swatchdog Recordings)


Located at Jellys (295 China Basin Wy) this event will be going strong from 
9pm - 3am.
$7 before 11pm and $10 after that.

more info: www.EvilBreaks.com


And just as a little incentive to all you breaks lovers out there, Evil 
Breaks has
agreed to do a special 2 for $10 deal to anyone registered on SFBreaks.org .
SFBreaks.org will be sending out an email a week before the show to get 
people on
the special list.  The list is limited only to the first 30 pairs, so make 
sure you
are signed up and ready.

causes me to tremble for the safety of my country. . . . corporations
have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places will follow,
and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong its reign by
working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is aggregated
in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-- U.S. President Abraham Lincoln, Nov. 21, 1864
(letter to Col. William F. Elkins)

yeah, hearing about the technical problems makes me
much more forgiving and want to take back my
criticism.  (i saw his response on 313 late in the day
yesterday, as well.)  now i'm a little irritable that
there's top-notch techno folks (matthew dear,
christian bloch, etc.) playing at a club without a
sound person (or at least no sound person that night.)
 i'm going to be going to Rx gallery a lot, because
they've got folks playing there i want to see, but
that sucks.  i kind of miss techno stuff at club 6 (i
must be desperate), but i do think that Rx has
slightly better sound than club 6, at least when it's
not turned up all the way like telefon tel aviv 
did last week (and over half the dance floor cleared.)
 

anyway, i'm wishing i lived in portland this week -
deadbeat AND crackhaus are playing there on friday. 
if i'd only known earlier, i could'a gotten a cheap
flight.  as it is i'm still considering going, but
maybe that's just nuts.  Deadbeat is incredible
though.  ¿Porque no están pinchando en San Francisco?

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: UpLift at SubLounge this Thur.

Hey there,
I'm hoping folks remember that UpLift is going on again this Thursday.
Looks to be a meld of progressive stuff as well as some breaks thrown in
to make it properly sweaty (mmmmm, sweaty.)  Come console me about the
election last week, or ask Osteen what he thinks of the whole thing. :)
Or, better yet, congratulate me about the recent successes!!! :)


Lineup for the evening:

DJ/Producer Steve Osteen (www.tussinspace.com) (8p - 9:15p) (bug him to
play some originals!!)

DJ Will Spencer (ProgressionSF) (fresh off a gig with Paul van Dyk!) :)
(10:30p - 11:45p)

with Residents:

fLOORCRAfT (Hosstribe, Aurasf) (9:15p - 10:30p)

and me, J.C. (Epiphany, KZSU, Netamp, Aurasf) (11:45p - close)


Also an Art Show by: UpLift's Resident Artist Chris Fabbri and his
special guests

This month's Art Show will include:

Paper Collages by Chris Fabbri
(http://groups.msn.com/ChrisFabbriArtistPoetHomePage)
Glitter Paintings/Blinky Art by Dee Dee Russell
(http://www.deedeetv.com/)
Abstractions by Florence Gray
Industrial Landscape Paintings of Oakland and SF by Jill Mclennan
(http://groups.msn.com/jillm)
Florida's Nostalgic Train Photos by Ron McAfee
(http://www.artareas.com/ArtAreas/home.nsf/ArtistExhibit/Ron+McAfee)
Digital Images & Paintings by Shu

No cover, and drink specials all night.

Sublounge: 628 20th Street @ 3rd Street, San Francisco, CA


-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

Subject: [sfraves] Mixmaster is right!!!

Of course you guys probably all already know this, but it's a nifty
lil interview with a nice lil demo of mixmaster mikes skills.  This
guy is insane!!!  Got to stand right behind him at last years
Cyberfest.  Looking right over his shoulder and seeing him live and in
action, i still couldn't believe what i was seeing.  I dont know how
the hell he keeps that needle in that groove so well with all that
scratching.  If you look in his lil falsh movie demo there on the page
you'll see him do this trick where he picks the record up at a 45
degree angle and is still scratching with it.  what the fuck is up
with that?  how the hell does he do it.  he truely is a vinyl genius
paving the way for the future of turntablism.

http://www.g4techtv.com/screensavers/features/50179/Two_Minutes_with_Mixmaster_Mike.html
-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"

From: Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
Reply-To: Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] What Kerry should have said...

"My fellow Americans, the people of this nation have spoken, and 
spoken with a clear voice. So I am here to offer my concession.   I
concede that I overestimated the intelligence of the American  people.
 Though the people disagree  with the President on almost every issue,
you saw fit to vote for him.

I never saw that coming.

That's really special. And I mean "special" in the sense that we use
it to describe those kids who ride the short school bus and find ways 
to injure themselves while eating pudding with rubber spoons. That 
kind of special.   I concede that I misjudged the power of hate.
That's pretty powerful  stuff, and I didn't see it.

So let me take a moment to congratulate the President's strategists:

 Putting the gay marriage amendments on the ballot in various swing
states like Ohio... well,  that was just genius. Genius.  > It got
people, a certain kind of people, to the polls. The  unprecedented
number of folks who showed up and cited "moral values" as their
biggest issue, those people changed history. The folks who consider
same sex marriage a more important issue than war, or  terrorism, or
the economy...

Who'd have thought the election would belong to them? Well, Karl Rove
did. Gotta give it up to him for that. Credit where it's due. I
concede that I put too much faith in America's youth With 8 out of 10
of you opposing the President, with your friends and classmates dying
daily in a war you disapprove of, with your future being  mortgaged to
pay for rich old peoples' tax breaks, you somehow managed to sit on
your asses and watch the Cartoon Network while aging homophobic
hillbillies carried the day. You voted with the exact same anemic
percentage that  you did in 2000. You suck.

Seriously, y'do.

There are some who would say that I sound bitter, that now is the time
for healing, to bring the nation together. Let me tell you a little
story.  Last night, I watched the returns come in with  some friends.
As the night progressed, people began to talk half-seriously about
secession, a red state / blue state split. The reasoning was this: We
in blue states produce the vast majority of the wealth in this country
and pay the most taxes, and you in the red states receive the majority
of the money from those taxes while complaining about 'em. We in the
blue states are the only ones who've been attacked by foreign
terrorists, yet you in the red states are gung ho to fight a war in
our name. We in the blue states produce the  entertainment that you
consume so greedily each day, while you in the  red states show open
disdain for us and our values. Blue state civilians are the actual
victims and targets of the war on terror,  while red state civilians
are the ones standing behind us and yelling  "Oh, yeah!? Bring it on!"

More than 40% of you Bush voters still believe that Saddam Hussein had
 something to do with 9/11. I'm impressed by that, truly I am. Your
sons and daughters who might die in this war know it's not true, the
people in the urban centers  where al Qaeda wants to attack know it's
not true, but those of you who are at practically no risk believe this
easy lie because you can.  As part of my concession speech, let me say
that I really envy that  luxury. I concede that.

Healing? We, the people at risk from terrorists, the people who
subsidize you, the people who speak in glowing and respectful terms 
about the heartland of America while that heartland insults and 
excoriates us... we wanted some healing. We spoke loud and clear. And
you refused to give it to us, largely because of your high moral
values. You knew better:  America doesn't need its  allies, doesn't
need to share the burden, doesn't need to unite the  world, doesn't
need to provide for its future. Hell no. Not when it's got a human
shield of pointy-headed, atheistic, unconfrontational breadwinners who
are willing to pay the bills and play nice in the vain hope of winning
a vote that we can never have. Because we're "morally inferior," I
suppose, we are supposed to respect your values while you insult ours.
And the big joke here is that for 20 years, we've done just that. 
It's not a "ha-ha" funny joke, I realize, but it's a joke all the
same.

As well as conceding the election today, I am also announcing my
candidacy for president in 2008.  And I make this pledge to you today:
THIS time, next time, there will  be no pandering. This time I will
run with all the open and joking  contempt for my opponents that our
President demonstrated towards the cradle of liberty, the Ivy League
intellectuals, the "media elite,"   and the "white-wine sippers." This
time I will not pretend that the  simple folk of America know just as
much as the people who devote  their lives to serving and studying the
nation and the world. They don't.

So that's why I'm asking for your vote in 2008, America. I'm talking
to you, you ignorant, slack-jawed yokels, you bible-thumping, inbred 
drones, you redneck, racist, chest-thumping, perennially duped
grade-school grads. Vote for me, because I know better, and I truly 
believe that I can help your smug, sorry asses.

Thank you, and may God, if he does in fact exist, bless each and every
one of you."

Anonymous

-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mixmaster is right!!!

Really?  That's crazy, I saw Swamp play once up in Seattle (back in
like 97 or maybe 98), and i was watching him scratch and right at the
end of his set he went to take the record off the platter and it
snapped in half and he just kept on scratchin and scratchin....it was
kinda cool, cept for a couple of times the needle came off the the
record and would land on the scratch mat underneath and make a nasty
ass scratching sound which didnt sound too good.  And when he was done
he took the record off and threw it into the crowd.  One of the
promoters for the party had told me after words during tear down that
he was just trying to pull the record off the platter and it snagged
on the nipple and broke thr record and he got really mad and that's
why he just kept scratching with the broken record.  So i wonder if it
was really accidental and he got mad, and since developed this broken
record technique from that instance, or if he really meant to break
the record and scratch with it.  Either way it was freakin intense,
and i'm glad i got to witness it.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mobile Clubbing

> but more importantly, the BASS.

AMEN BROTHA TIP!!!!!

> and a well-tuned system is a beautiful thing,

As we the members of SWAT Sound know...sometimes it's not all in the
reflexes, it's all in the tuning (and processing gear).  Even a small
sound system tuned just right can sound awesome.  Too many people
think that riding your system to near and sometimes all the way to
clipping is the way to go...hell's no, it's not about how much your
pushing but how you use what you're pushing.

-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"It's all in the reflexes"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Red Bull & You!!

I was doing some research on 5-htp and smart drugs when I found this site
that includes taurine as an ingredient in their formula.  I remember a
discussion a few months ago about taurine's popular urban legend as bull
urine and the resulting dialogue that it was not, but thought I would
revisit the topic for those not in attendance.

Looks like a little redbull everyday could be good for you.. minus the
caffeine :0

Ranger

--------------

Source sight: http://www.neuro-fx.com

TAURINE 

This is a nerve and muscle regulating, amino acid that helps regulate
electrical impulses in the brain, and heart. It aids muscle building through
cell volumizing and regulates heartbeat. Taurine protects central nervous
system and brain cells by helping to maintain cell membrane stability. In
the brain taurine is a key agent in preventing neuron over-activity. Taurine
is a component of bile acids, which are necessary for the body to absorb
fat-soluble vitamins. It is found in meat, fish, eggs and dairy products.
Although it is a "non-essential" amino acid, taurine deficiency may occur in
vegans who eat no dairy products.

Taurine helps strengthen the heart and other muscles through cell
volumizing.

Taurine has cell protecting antioxidant and cell membrane stabilization
properties.

Taurine has been used to treat epilepsy, because of its nerve regulating
property and ability to inhibit neural overactivity

5-HTP (5-hydroxytryptophan)

5-HTP is the immediate precursor to serotonin and it has been compared in
double-blind studies of depression sufferers to many of the popular SSRI's
(selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) such as Prozac, Paxil, Luvox and
Zoloft. It has shown comparable results to these drugs with few and milder
side effects. 

Our inclusion of this product in our system is due to the increased
production, and re-uptake of serotonin that we experienced while taking
Piracetam alone and with Acetlycholine precursors. While this effect is not
included in most of the research done on Nootropics like Piracetam it has
been noted by our in house research team members. We included 5-HTP in our
system and as a result, all of the associated problems of low serotonin
levels stopped immediately. Everyone felt better in our test group, and we
find that we have a much better product than competing products that do not
include this important discovery. Increased serotonin levels make one feel
much more in control and calm which helps to take away any edge from the
stimulating ingredients that we include in the system.

ALCAR Acetyl-L-Carnitine

This is an amazing nutrient that works synergistically as an Acetyl group
donor with DMAE to form the important memory neurotransmitter Acetylcholine.
There have been previous clinical trials showing that this nutrient actually
can improve memory and cognitive functioning in patients experiencing
dementia. In a recent study, patients with Alzheimer's disease undergoing
standard drug therapy were also given acetyl-L carnitine (ALCAR) at 2 grams
a day. It was found that those patients treated with the addition of ALCAR
had an improved level of responsiveness. It appears that acetyl-L carnitine
is a key nutrient for energy production at the cellular level. 

By enhancing membrane stability, energy production, and neurotransmission,
ALCAR helps to improve mental function. In addition, it may also have
anti-inflammatory effects that reduce free radical generation. ALCAR has
also demonstrated the ability to bind cortisol and increase nerve growth
factor production within the hippocampal region of the brain, and may
explain its positive effects on neuron function.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What are the elements of a good flyer design?

1. Necessary information (time, date, location,
artists, crew, etc.) is on the flyer and easy to find.
2. Innovative design that doesn't look like every
other flyer out there.
3. It is legible to people in an altered condition.

Peace,

Peter

>BABY ANNE!
>
>Where is the sweet, shy BABY ANNE we used to know and love? Always wicked
>on the turntables, our reigning funky breaks Bass Queen used to pose
>demurely in publicity shots wearing something like a long sleeve turtleneck
>sweater or a baby blue velour hoodie, looking soulful. But on the cover of
>her new mix-CD âMIXTRESSâ (Zone Records/System Recordings) our Baby is 
>in
>black leather bondage gear, including handcuffs! Yikes!
>
>Baby Anne (real name Marianne Broadaway), born in Panama City, Florida,
>moved with her family to Orlando when she was four. The oldest of five
>kids, she was very shy in school, but did well in sports, ballet and tap,
>and cheerleading. She began raving in 1990 when she was 18. âI really 
>liked
>the music. A lot of my guy friends bought records and were learning how to
>DJ and I would ask them to play certain songs. They saw I was interested so
>they included me and I picked it up. I started spinning when I was 19, but
>there were no other girls so a lot of them didnât want me to, but one or
>two stuck up for me.â
>
>In 1992, DJ Icey (Americaâs funky breaks King, whom she met before she
>started DJing) let her play at a couple of his parties. âI donât really
>know why other than it was funny or cute or whatever. It was just for fun
>in the beginning and then it kind of took off. Even when I started getting
>paid to DJ, I still only saw it as a hobby and self-entertainment and I
>would only play stuff I would want to hear if I was on the dance floor with
>my friends. I was never trying to prove anything or impress anyone.â
>
>Her guy friends used to call her âJig-o-wattâ because she danced a lot, 
>but
>Icey thought that wasnât an appropriate DJ name because you couldnât 
>tell
>she was a girl, so âhe started calling me Baby Anne as a nickname for
>Marianne. I fought it at first but it ended up sticking.â
>
>Thinking she needed to start a real career, Baby Anne quit DJing for
>awhile. She enrolled in community college and worked as a bartender for a
>year, but wasnât very happy. One night at work when a guest DJ was 
>playing,
>âOut of nowhere I said, What am I doing? Iâm going to start DJing 
>again,
>and ever since Iâve been doing it full-time.â

>followed by âBass Queen In The Mix 2â (2000) and âDark Side of the 
>Boomâ
>(2001), on Pandisc; then âIâm About to Breakâ (2002) and âMixed 
>Live: Club
>Ra, Las Vegasâ (2003), on Moonshine.  Both girls and guys have told Baby
>Anne that she has inspired them to start DJing or producing.
>
>For the record, Music Monthly first spoke with Baby Anne in DC on January
>2003, but the interviewer misplaced the tape, which luckily resurfaced in
>time for her latest release. Music Monthly reached Baby Anne recently for
>updates. Following is a composite of both interviews.
>
>Music Monthly:  Where did your âMixtressâ idea come from?
>
>Baby Anne:  I was trying to think of a title and came up with 
>âMixtress.â
>The image came later when I was thinking about what to do for the cover.
>Then I started on the song and it followed suit. Halfway through it I was
>looking for a vocal sample and when I found the one I used, the 
>âMixtressâ
>theme came back into play.
>
>MM:  Where did the sexy vocal sample come from?
>
>BA:  Just a sample CD. I donât even remember. Itâs definitely not me,
>though!
>
>MM:  Where did you get those clothes and where was your photo shoot? And
>who are those masked men?
>
>BA:  I donât normally own clothes like the ones on the cover. I [took] a
>shopping trip to my local exotic dancer store. It was fun. Then I flew to
>New York to work with a good photographer. He picked the mystery men. I
>canât give away their identities!
>
>MM: Is there a correlation between the âMixtressâ concept and the sound 
>of
>the mix?
>
>BA: I donât think the style of this CD is much different from my others.
>The sound has progressed with the breakbeat scene. Iâve always liked high
>energy breaks. This CD might be a little more intense, but I would have to
>credit the great songs on it that I might not have been able to find in the
>past.
>
>MM:  Does your new image coincide with a new way of viewing yourself?
>
>BA:  No, the whole thing was just for fun. I was trying to think of
>something different that didnât look like every other mix-CD and I got
>lucky. Thereâs nothing different about me. Iâm sure I will not repeat 
>this
>theme. Iâm sure if I hadnât thought of it, someone else would have
>eventually.
>
>MM:  Are you still into yoga?
>
>BA:  I am. I love it. I feel really good afterwards. I try to encourage
>everyone to try it.
>
>MM:  What pets do you have now? You used to have a ferret.
>
>BA:  My two dogs, Moopu and Scrappy, and my psycho cat.
>
>MM:  Whatâs in your CD player now?
>
>BA: [2003] I donât listen to breaks or any kind of dance music when Iâm 
>not
>working because I donât want to get burned out on it. I listen to â80s
>music, â70s rock and roll, and grunge. [Iâm a] big Nirvana fan. âYou 
>Know
>Youâre Rightâ - I love that song - made me miss Kurt Cobain.
>[2004] âShake your Buddah, Vol. 1â World Beats. No, Iâm not a 
>Buddhist.

>
>MM: What are your thoughts on the state of the rave scene and the anti-rave
>legislation?
>
>BA: I think there are always going to be politicians against the rave
>scene, using it as a political issue to go against. I donât play many 
>raves
>anymore, mostly night clubs. I think itâs for a number of reasons,
>partially because of that, partially because of our economy, most places
>are hurting. Another reason is that in some areas there were too many
>promoters who over-saturated their market, kind of over did it. Kids 
>didnât
>want to pay 25 bucks every week to go to a party. Iâm optimistic.
>Everything has its highs and lows. Weâre at a low right now so thereâs
>nowhere to go but up. But there are places I go where things are great.
>
>MM:  Advice for aspiring DJs?
>
>BA:  Iâd probably say the same thing that I would have said to one of my
>younger brothers or sisters when they each considered DJing. Only do it if
>it makes you happy, not because you want to be a DJ because it wonât get
>you very far. But if music is what you love, then you can take it as far as
>you want.
>
>MM:  Where were you on 9/11?
>
>BA:  It was strange. Since I work at night I would normally sleep in until
>11 or 12. I usually have my ringer off but for some reason I had it on and
>my brother called at 9 am  and said, Two planes just crashed into the World
>Trade Center and I just wanted to make sure you were at home. So I got up
>and watched the whole thing on TV. I felt so bad for all those people. It
>still gets to me. I think it reinforced what Iâve always thought, that a
>lot of people go through life just working and getting by. I try to make
>myself happy and experience everything I can, within reason.
>
>MM:  What are your current personal goals?
>
>BA:  Iâve recently gone through some personal changes that have 
>influenced
>me to change my point of view on life. My priorities include eliminating
>negativity from my life. That includes unhealthy relationships, ways of
>thinking, stress. I want to make the most of my life and help my friends
>and family as much as I can to do the same.
>
>MM:  What are you contributing to society?
>
>BA:  (cringes) Nothing? (laughs) I feel like Iâm an entertainer and 
>thatâs
>the end of it. People go out and want to have a good time and I hope that
>they do, but as far as me making a difference, I donât think this is the
>place. Other things bother me, like animal cruelty and homeless people, and
>if I was going to contribute something Iâd advocate for something like
>that. But I am an entertainer and I donât think itâs that big of a 
>deal.
>
>MM:  Okay, but when you play and you connect, what do you feel?
>
>BA:  Fun! I got into this because I love to dance and really love music and
>now Iâm on the other end of it. I want people to have fun. I donât want
>them getting messed up and sitting on the floor. Maybe itâs because Iâm 
>the
>older sister and I have to watch out for my younger siblings, but I want
>people to get up and dance and have a good time. When I have a song I
>really like and play it, I get chills and throw my hands up and scream with
>the crowd. We get excited.
>
>AARON MYERS IN FLIGHT
>
>When LTJ BUKEM was forced to cancel his October 6 gig at FIVE:DNBSESSIONS,
>Baltimoreâs AARON MYERS was bumped from opener to headliner, in honor of
>his imminent relocation to San Diego. It was a fine night at Five, BOBBY
>JAE (District Soul, DCDNB, Upfront) opening with his trademark soulfulness,
>AARON MYERS giving the crowd a mighty rinsing out, and LOCKS closing with
>mellow energy.
>
>Myers went West for many reasons but âmainly because I just needed a 
>venue
>change.â Though heâs DJed in the Baltimore/DC area since 1995, most of 
>his
>bookings were outside the area from London to Los Angeles, so he felt moved
>to go somewhere more receptive to his sound. âThis style of music really
>fits well into the [San Diego] scene.â
>
>Myers drove cross-country in two days, stopping in Amarillo, Texas for a
>radio show. Music Monthly reached Myers at his new home âby the bay and
>about 5 minutes from the beach.â
>
>Music Monthly:  Thought you were a downtempo drum ânâ bass DJ, but you
>played a fairly hard set at FIVE?
>
>Aaron Myers:  I think people see me as a âdowntempoâ dnb DJ because I 
>run
>an atmospheric dnb label, TestFlight Recordings. Most people associate
>atmospheric dnb with LTJ Bukemâs Good Looking label which tends to focus 
>on
>chill sounds. The truth is I have always played energetic, which is why I
>have found myself getting away from the âatmosphericâ title and lean
>towards calling it âprogressiveâ - dnb that is actually progressing. 
>Most
>of what we hear today is stale, in my opinion, and my main element is
>playing and releasing tunes that are forward thinking and pushing
>boundaries.
>
>MM:  What were your big tracks of the night?
>
>AM:  âHallwaysâ by MRN was definitely one of the highlights. It usually 
>is
>whenever I play it. I ended up rewinding it, which is a rarity for me since
>I hate rewinds. They take away from a set, in my opinion. MRN is definitely
>one to watch out for. I also premiered Blameâs new tune âAmethystâ 
>which
>will be coming out on TestFlight in the next few months.
>
>Got some really good reactions out of some of the ICR tunes, another artist
>I am finding myself playing more and more of. Most of my set consisted of
>tracks from my label, EHLâs Warm Communications and ASCâs Covert 
>Operations
>labels, so seeing a good reaction from the crowd made every tune equally
>big, knowing people were feeling what we have been pushing so hard over the
>past few years.
>
>MM:  How does your move affect TestFlight?
>
>AM:  I think, if anything, it will help. In order to get notice, people
>have to listen, and thatâs exactly what we get out here.
>
>MM:  What does TestFlight have coming up?
>
>AM:  October saw the release of our first CD, ACSâs second album and 
>first
>for TestFlight, âOpen Spaces,â which has been getting some great 
>reviews.
>It features 12 tracks of drum ânâ bass and downtempo, and features 
>tracks
>by Jadis who previously worked with Orion on his releases for TeeBeeâs
>Subtitles Label (available at retail stores, record shops, iTunes). There
>are also two vinyl releases put out this past year, ASC âTenth Zone
>Eastâ/âMind Control,â which is a rather hard piece to find these days 
>due
>to our old distributor, Vinyl Dist., going under. I donât even have a 
>copy
>for myself. The other release was Orion âTestimonyâ/âMemento,â 
>which we
>were able to save and is available through techgroove.co.uk.
>
>On the CD end I have two projects lined up that I am really excited about.
>First is âAaron Myers Presents: Altitude Volume Oneâ featuring 
>exclusive
>tracks by Blame, MRN, Electrosoul System, ICR, Furianga, Method One and a
>remix by Marcus Intalex, among others. That should hit the shelves late
>2004, early 2005. I have another artist album lined up with Russiaâs
>Electrosoul System doing his first full-length LP, another artist heading
>for big places with releases lined up for Good Looking, Cov-ops, Phutro and
>DeFunked. Beyond that I have plans, none that I am ready to announce yet,
>but big things are on the horizon.
>
>MM:  Miss anything about Baltimore/DC?
>
>AM:  I definitely miss my friends and family. The weirdest thing is the
>seasons changing â it doesnât happen out here. But I wonât have to 
>worry
>about snow!
>
>MM:  Last words?
>
>AM:  Get out there and check this stuff out. There is more to dnb than loud
>predictable basslines, so many new artists doing great things. I hope to be
>able to create a forum for them to be heard. Buy your copy of âOpen 
>Spacesâ
>and thereâs much more to come. As long as people are listening, Iâll 
>still
>be making noise!
>
>CHECK IT
>
>Lovers of dance will appreciate DANCES OF ECSTASY, a documentary by
>Australian filmmakers Michelle Mahrer and Nicole Ma, that travels around
>the world to places where they found people achieving altered-state
>experiences through dancing, from Whirling Dervishes of Turkey, Orisha
>Priestesses in Nigeria and Brazil, shaman healers in the Kalahari and
>Korea, a Gabrielle Roth dance workshop in New York City, and the Rainbow
>Serpent Festival rave in an Australian forest. The film celebrates the
>universal experience of joy through movement to music with a cornucopia of
>images of dance rituals and interviews, and a broad spectrum of rhythmic
>music of diverse cultures. Enthralling.
>
>Sweet and ethereal, âTHE BEST OF DELERIUMâ (Nettwerk) conjures sensual
>candle-lit baths with rose petals, or thoughtful walks through ancient
>forests. Dreamy, romantic vocals by spell-casting artists including Sarah
>McLachlan, Aude, Zoe Johnston (Bent, Faithless), Kristy Thirsk and Leigh
>Nash grace Canadian Bill Leeb and Rhys Fulberâs luxuriant Gothic
>soundscapes, sometimes haunted by choruses evoking Gregorian chants. The
>album includes their hit singles âSilence,â âInnocente (Falling in 
>Love),â
>âUnderwater, âAfter Allâ and âTruly,â and new tracks âParisâ 
>and âYou and
>I.â
>
>BUZZLIFE gets busy at three venues this month, including nights with BAD
>BOY BILL, CONCORD DAWN, DJ IRENE, GROOVERIDER, DJ SS, at CUBIK; UNKLE
>featuring JAMES LAVALLE + RICHARD FILE, and SANDER KLEINENBERG at FIVE; and
>bringing back TURKEY FEVER with SCOTT HENRY + FEELGOOD Thanksgiving night.
>
>ULTRAWORLD is back at the newly expanded SONAR now boasting a Concert Hall
>in addition to its Club and Lounge, with CHRISTOPHER LAWRENCE, MICHAEL
>OWEN, AK1200, DJ C, MCKAIN, MAZ (Chicago) and PATRICK TURNER. Look out  for
>PENDULUM, SUV W/MC L NATURAL, DB, BOBBY JAE, DJ DESTAR, ANDY C + MC GQ,
>ACTUAL FACT, LUKE FAIR and ADAM T. RUSH the rest of the month.
>
>Speaking of Los Angeles-based CHRISTOPHER LAWRENCE, #7 in DJ Magazineâs
>2004 Top 100 DJs poll, his new CD âUn-Hooked: The Hook Sessionsâ 
>(System
>Recordings, out November 15) reprises some of the finest moments of his
>producing career with seminal Scottish DJ/producer Chris Cowieâs Hook
>Recordings label (whose catalog, supported by Sasha, John Digweed, Paul
>Oakenfold and Paul van Dyk, included Taylor, Sandra Collins X-Cabs, Joshua
>Ryan, Fred Numf, and Transa). How nice to have this compilation of CLâs
>classic Hook tunes âNavigator,â âCruise Control,â âFilmerâ and 
>âShredder,â
>and seven others showcasing his range from peak hour anthems to darker,
>more pensive chillout moods.
>
>Belated congratulations to DJ LOVEGROVE aka LG CONCANNON (SONIC SOUL),
>BALTIMORE Magazineâs BEST DJ OF 2003!  Sweet!
>
>Woot for the refreshing DIY grassroots energy of The World Renowned Doctor
>Me
>llifluid B. Stuffedâs FLYINâ CIRCUS. On October 23, BAGGADONUTS, JOE
>KOPASEK AND DANIELLA DOWNS, STATLER AND WALDORF, ELEKTROKIND, JON GORDYN,
>SOULAR, and KID AMIGA and friends cavorted âsomewhereâ happily.
>
>mary ishimoto morris

Subject: Re: [sfraves] baby anne/aaron myers & misc.

ya i agree, i dont really care for her, dont think she's really all
that.  besides i hate that lame ass florida (Icey) breaks sound.  It's
totally so lame and boring.  i will admit there is a track or 2 by
Icey that i like, but they're a lil old.  But that whole sound is
lame.  I hate it when record stores classify it as Funky breaks...they
aint funky, not even close.  And every track sounds just like the
track before it, the same bassline, the same "ravey" synth
sound...totally lame.  That sound turned me off of breaks for a long
time, because anytime i'd go to see a breakbeat DJ they'd be playing
that crap.  But that was up in Portland and Seattle and they didnt
really know any better i guess.  I'm much happier here, with the
breaks i hear.  dont really hear the florida sound down here too much,
cept for Madame Mercury, and well i dont like her either so i avoid
her every chance i get.

-- 
Chester Copperpot
