>>>>there were no other girls so a lot of them didnât want me to, but one 
>>>>or
>>>>two stuck up for me.â?
>>>>
>>>>In 1992, DJ Icey (Americaâs funky breaks King, whom she met before she
>>>>started DJing) let her play at a couple of his parties. âI donât 
>>>>really
>>>>know why other than it was funny or cute or whatever. It was just for 
>>>>fun
>>>>in the beginning and then it kind of took off. Even when I started 
>>>>getting
>>>>paid to DJ, I still only saw it as a hobby and self-entertainment and I
>>>>would only play stuff I would want to hear if I was on the dance floor 
>>>>with
>>>>my friends. I was never trying to prove anything or impress anyone.â?
>>>>
>>>>Her guy friends used to call her âJig-o-wattâ? because she danced a 
>>>>lot, but
>>>>Icey thought that wasnât an appropriate DJ name because you couldnât 
>>>>tell
>>>>she was a girl, so âhe started calling me Baby Anne as a nickname for
>>>>Marianne. I fought it at first but it ended up sticking.â?
>>>>
>>>>Thinking she needed to start a real career, Baby Anne quit DJing for
>>>>awhile. She enrolled in community college and worked as a bartender for 
>>>>a
>>>>year, but wasnât very happy. One night at work when a guest DJ was 
>>>>playing,
>>>>âOut of nowhere I said, What am I doing? Iâm going to start DJing 
>>>>again,
>>>>and ever since Iâve been doing it full-time.â?
>>>>
>>>>When Icey started producing, he said to her, âCome in and make a 
>>>>song.â? She
>>>>said okay  and came out of the studio with her first single 
>>>>âAbercrombieâ?
>>>>(1995).
>>>>
>>>>Baby Anneâs discography also includes other releases on Iceyâs Zone 
>>>>imprint
>>>>such as âTrippinâ On Da Bass,â? âFreaks Groove,â? âBass 
>>>>Queen,â? âProbeâ? and
>>>>âPulse,â? and  âBody Movinââ? on Pandisc, âBeatâ? on 
>>>>Phattraxx, and âFuryâ? on
>>>>Moonshine. In 1999 she released her first mix-CD âBass Queen In The 
>>>>Mix,â?
>>>>followed by âBass Queen In The Mix 2â? (2000) and âDark Side of the 
>>>>Boomâ?
>>>>(2001), on Pandisc; then âIâm About to Breakâ? (2002) and âMixed 
>>>>Live: Club
>>>>Ra, Las Vegasâ? (2003), on Moonshine.  Both girls and guys have told 
>>>>Baby
>>>>Anne that she has inspired them to start DJing or producing.
>>>>
>>>>For the record, Music Monthly first spoke with Baby Anne in DC on 
>>>>January
>>>>2003, but the interviewer misplaced the tape, which luckily resurfaced 
>>>>in
>>>>time for her latest release. Music Monthly reached Baby Anne recently 
>>>>for
>>>>updates. Following is a composite of both interviews.
>>>>
>>>>Music Monthly:  Where did your âMixtressâ? idea come from?
>>>>
>>>>Baby Anne:  I was trying to think of a title and came up with 
>>>>âMixtress.â?
>>>>The image came later when I was thinking about what to do for the cover.
>>>>Then I started on the song and it followed suit. Halfway through it I 
>>>>was
>>>>looking for a vocal sample and when I found the one I used, the 
>>>>âMixtressâ?
>>>>theme came back into play.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Where did the sexy vocal sample come from?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  Just a sample CD. I donât even remember. Itâs definitely not 
>>>>me,
>>>>though!
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Where did you get those clothes and where was your photo shoot? And
>>>>who are those masked men?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  I donât normally own clothes like the ones on the cover. I [took] 
>>>>a
>>>>shopping trip to my local exotic dancer store. It was fun. Then I flew 
>>>>to
>>>>New York to work with a good photographer. He picked the mystery men. I
>>>>canât give away their identities!
>>>>
>>>>MM: Is there a correlation between the âMixtressâ? concept and the 
>>>>sound of
>>>>the mix?
>>>>
>>>>BA: I donât think the style of this CD is much different from my 
>>>>others.
>>>>The sound has progressed with the breakbeat scene. Iâve always liked 
>>>>high
>>>>energy breaks. This CD might be a little more intense, but I would have 
>>>>to
>>>>credit the great songs on it that I might not have been able to find in 
>>>>the
>>>>past.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Does your new image coincide with a new way of viewing yourself?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  No, the whole thing was just for fun. I was trying to think of
>>>>something different that didnât look like every other mix-CD and I got
>>>>lucky. Thereâs nothing different about me. Iâm sure I will not 
>>>>repeat this
>>>>theme. Iâm sure if I hadnât thought of it, someone else would have
>>>>eventually.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Are you still into yoga?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  I am. I love it. I feel really good afterwards. I try to encourage
>>>>everyone to try it.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  What pets do you have now? You used to have a ferret.
>>>>
>>>>BA:  My two dogs, Moopu and Scrappy, and my psycho cat.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Whatâs in your CD player now?
>>>>
>>>>BA: [2003] I donât listen to breaks or any kind of dance music when 
>>>>Iâm not
>>>>working because I donât want to get burned out on it. I listen to 
>>>>â80s
>>>>music, â70s rock and roll, and grunge. [Iâm a] big Nirvana fan. 
>>>>âYou Know
>>>>Youâre Rightâ? - I love that song - made me miss Kurt Cobain.
>>>>[2004] âShake your Buddah, Vol. 1â? World Beats. No, Iâm not a 
>>>>Buddhist.
>>>>(smile)
>>>>
>>>>MM: What are your thoughts on the state of the rave scene and the 
>>>>anti-rave
>>>>legislation?
>>>>
>>>>BA: I think there are always going to be politicians against the rave
>>>>scene, using it as a political issue to go against. I donât play many 
>>>>raves
>>>>anymore, mostly night clubs. I think itâs for a number of reasons,
>>>>partially because of that, partially because of our economy, most places
>>>>are hurting. Another reason is that in some areas there were too many
>>>>promoters who over-saturated their market, kind of over did it. Kids 
>>>>didnât
>>>>want to pay 25 bucks every week to go to a party. Iâm optimistic.
>>>>Everything has its highs and lows. Weâre at a low right now so 
>>>>thereâs
>>>>nowhere to go but up. But there are places I go where things are great.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Advice for aspiring DJs?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  Iâd probably say the same thing that I would have said to one of 
>>>>my
>>>>younger brothers or sisters when they each considered DJing. Only do it 
>>>>if
>>>>it makes you happy, not because you want to be a DJ because it wonât 
>>>>get
>>>>you very far. But if music is what you love, then you can take it as far 
>>>>as
>>>>you want.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Where were you on 9/11?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  It was strange. Since I work at night I would normally sleep in 
>>>>until
>>>>11 or 12. I usually have my ringer off but for some reason I had it on 
>>>>and
>>>>my brother called at 9 am  and said, Two planes just crashed into the 
>>>>World
>>>>Trade Center and I just wanted to make sure you were at home. So I got 
>>>>up
>>>>and watched the whole thing on TV. I felt so bad for all those people. 
>>>>It
>>>>still gets to me. I think it reinforced what Iâve always thought, that 
>>>>a
>>>>lot of people go through life just working and getting by. I try to make
>>>>myself happy and experience everything I can, within reason.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  What are your current personal goals?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  Iâve recently gone through some personal changes that have 
>>>>influenced
>>>>me to change my point of view on life. My priorities include eliminating
>>>>negativity from my life. That includes unhealthy relationships, ways of
>>>>thinking, stress. I want to make the most of my life and help my friends
>>>>and family as much as I can to do the same.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  What are you contributing to society?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  (cringes) Nothing? (laughs) I feel like Iâm an entertainer and 
>>>>thatâs
>>>>the end of it. People go out and want to have a good time and I hope 
>>>>that
>>>>they do, but as far as me making a difference, I donât think this is 
>>>>the
>>>>place. Other things bother me, like animal cruelty and homeless people, 
>>>>and
>>>>if I was going to contribute something Iâd advocate for something like
>>>>that. But I am an entertainer and I donât think itâs that big of a 
>>>>deal.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Okay, but when you play and you connect, what do you feel?
>>>>
>>>>BA:  Fun! I got into this because I love to dance and really love music 
>>>>and
>>>>now Iâm on the other end of it. I want people to have fun. I donât 
>>>>want
>>>>them getting messed up and sitting on the floor. Maybe itâs because 
>>>>Iâm the
>>>>older sister and I have to watch out for my younger siblings, but I want
>>>>people to get up and dance and have a good time. When I have a song I
>>>>really like and play it, I get chills and throw my hands up and scream 
>>>>with
>>>>the crowd. We get excited.
>>>>
>>>>AARON MYERS IN FLIGHT
>>>>
>>>>When LTJ BUKEM was forced to cancel his October 6 gig at 
>>>>FIVE:DNBSESSIONS,
>>>>Baltimoreâs AARON MYERS was bumped from opener to headliner, in honor 
>>>>of
>>>>his imminent relocation to San Diego. It was a fine night at Five, BOBBY
>>>>JAE (District Soul, DCDNB, Upfront) opening with his trademark 
>>>>soulfulness,
>>>>AARON MYERS giving the crowd a mighty rinsing out, and LOCKS closing 
>>>>with
>>>>mellow energy.
>>>>
>>>>Myers went West for many reasons but âmainly because I just needed a 
>>>>venue
>>>>change.â? Though heâs DJed in the Baltimore/DC area since 1995, most 
>>>>of his
>>>>bookings were outside the area from London to Los Angeles, so he felt 
>>>>moved
>>>>to go somewhere more receptive to his sound. âThis style of music 
>>>>really
>>>>fits well into the [San Diego] scene.â?
>>>>
>>>>Myers drove cross-country in two days, stopping in Amarillo, Texas for a
>>>>radio show. Music Monthly reached Myers at his new home âby the bay 
>>>>and
>>>>about 5 minutes from the beach.â?
>>>>
>>>>Music Monthly:  Thought you were a downtempo drum ânâ bass DJ, but 
>>>>you
>>>>played a fairly hard set at FIVE?
>>>>
>>>>Aaron Myers:  I think people see me as a âdowntempoâ? dnb DJ because 
>>>>I run
>>>>an atmospheric dnb label, TestFlight Recordings. Most people associate
>>>>atmospheric dnb with LTJ Bukemâs Good Looking label which tends to 
>>>>focus on
>>>>chill sounds. The truth is I have always played energetic, which is why 
>>>>I
>>>>have found myself getting away from the âatmosphericâ? title and lean
>>>>towards calling it âprogressiveâ? - dnb that is actually progressing. 
>>>>Most
>>>>of what we hear today is stale, in my opinion, and my main element is
>>>>playing and releasing tunes that are forward thinking and pushing
>>>>boundaries.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  What were your big tracks of the night?
>>>>
>>>>AM:  âHallwaysâ? by MRN was definitely one of the highlights. It 
>>>>usually is
>>>>whenever I play it. I ended up rewinding it, which is a rarity for me 
>>>>since
>>>>I hate rewinds. They take away from a set, in my opinion. MRN is 
>>>>definitely
>>>>one to watch out for. I also premiered Blameâs new tune âAmethystâ? 
>>>>which
>>>>will be coming out on TestFlight in the next few months.
>>>>
>>>>Got some really good reactions out of some of the ICR tunes, another 
>>>>artist
>>>>I am finding myself playing more and more of. Most of my set consisted 
>>>>of
>>>>tracks from my label, EHLâs Warm Communications and ASCâs Covert 
>>>>Operations
>>>>labels, so seeing a good reaction from the crowd made every tune equally
>>>>big, knowing people were feeling what we have been pushing so hard over 
>>>>the
>>>>past few years.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  How does your move affect TestFlight?
>>>>
>>>>AM:  I think, if anything, it will help. In order to get notice, people
>>>>have to listen, and thatâs exactly what we get out here.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  What does TestFlight have coming up?
>>>>
>>>>AM:  October saw the release of our first CD, ACSâs second album and 
>>>>first
>>>>for TestFlight, âOpen Spaces,â? which has been getting some great 
>>>>reviews.
>>>>It features 12 tracks of drum ânâ bass and downtempo, and features 
>>>>tracks
>>>>by Jadis who previously worked with Orion on his releases for TeeBeeâs
>>>>Subtitles Label (available at retail stores, record shops, iTunes). 
>>>>There
>>>>are also two vinyl releases put out this past year, ASC âTenth Zone
>>>>Eastâ?/â?Mind Control,â? which is a rather hard piece to find these 
>>>>days due
>>>>to our old distributor, Vinyl Dist., going under. I donât even have a 
>>>>copy
>>>>for myself. The other release was Orion âTestimonyâ?/â?Memento,â? 
>>>>which we
>>>>were able to save and is available through techgroove.co.uk.
>>>>
>>>>On the CD end I have two projects lined up that I am really excited 
>>>>about.
>>>>First is âAaron Myers Presents: Altitude Volume Oneâ? featuring 
>>>>exclusive
>>>>tracks by Blame, MRN, Electrosoul System, ICR, Furianga, Method One and 
>>>>a
>>>>remix by Marcus Intalex, among others. That should hit the shelves late
>>>>2004, early 2005. I have another artist album lined up with Russiaâs
>>>>Electrosoul System doing his first full-length LP, another artist 
>>>>heading
>>>>for big places with releases lined up for Good Looking, Cov-ops, Phutro 
>>>>and
>>>>DeFunked. Beyond that I have plans, none that I am ready to announce 
>>>>yet,
>>>>but big things are on the horizon.
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Miss anything about Baltimore/DC?
>>>>
>>>>AM:  I definitely miss my friends and family. The weirdest thing is the
>>>>seasons changing â it doesnât happen out here. But I wonât have to 
>>>>worry
>>>>about snow!
>>>>
>>>>MM:  Last words?
>>>>
>>>>AM:  Get out there and check this stuff out. There is more to dnb than 
>>>>loud
>>>>predictable basslines, so many new artists doing great things. I hope to 
>>>>be
>>>>able to create a forum for them to be heard. Buy your copy of âOpen 
>>>>Spacesâ?
>>>>and thereâs much more to come. As long as people are listening, Iâll 
>>>>still
>>>>be making noise!
>>>>
>>>>CHECK IT
>>>>
>>>>Lovers of dance will appreciate DANCES OF ECSTASY, a documentary by
>>>>Australian filmmakers Michelle Mahrer and Nicole Ma, that travels around
>>>>the world to places where they found people achieving altered-state
>>>>experiences through dancing, from Whirling Dervishes of Turkey, Orisha
>>>>Priestesses in Nigeria and Brazil, shaman healers in the Kalahari and
>>>>Korea, a Gabrielle Roth dance workshop in New York City, and the Rainbow
>>>>Serpent Festival rave in an Australian forest. The film celebrates the
>>>>universal experience of joy through movement to music with a cornucopia 
>>>>of
>>>>images of dance rituals and interviews, and a broad spectrum of rhythmic
>>>>music of diverse cultures. Enthralling.
>>>>
>>>>Sweet and ethereal, âTHE BEST OF DELERIUMâ? (Nettwerk) conjures 
>>>>sensual
>>>>candle-lit baths with rose petals, or thoughtful walks through ancient
>>>>forests. Dreamy, romantic vocals by spell-casting artists including 
>>>>Sarah
>>>>McLachlan, Aude, Zoe Johnston (Bent, Faithless), Kristy Thirsk and Leigh
>>>>Nash grace Canadian Bill Leeb and Rhys Fulberâs luxuriant Gothic
>>>>soundscapes, sometimes haunted by choruses evoking Gregorian chants. The
>>>>album includes their hit singles âSilence,â? âInnocente (Falling in 
>>>>Love),â?
>>>>âUnderwater, âAfter Allâ? and âTruly,â? and new tracks 
>>>>âParisâ? and âYou and
>>>>I.â?
>>>>
>>>>BUZZLIFE gets busy at three venues this month, including nights with BAD
>>>>BOY BILL, CONCORD DAWN, DJ IRENE, GROOVERIDER, DJ SS, at CUBIK; UNKLE
>>>>featuring JAMES LAVALLE + RICHARD FILE, and SANDER KLEINENBERG at FIVE; 
>>>>and
>>>>bringing back TURKEY FEVER with SCOTT HENRY + FEELGOOD Thanksgiving 
>>>>night.
>>>>
>>>>ULTRAWORLD is back at the newly expanded SONAR now boasting a Concert 
>>>>Hall
>>>>in addition to its Club and Lounge, with CHRISTOPHER LAWRENCE, MICHAEL
>>>>OWEN, AK1200, DJ C, MCKAIN, MAZ (Chicago) and PATRICK TURNER. Look out  
>>>>for
>>>>PENDULUM, SUV W/MC L NATURAL, DB, BOBBY JAE, DJ DESTAR, ANDY C + MC GQ,
>>>>ACTUAL FACT, LUKE FAIR and ADAM T. RUSH the rest of the month.
>>>>
>>>>Speaking of Los Angeles-based CHRISTOPHER LAWRENCE, #7 in DJ 
>>>>Magazineâs
>>>>2004 Top 100 DJs poll, his new CD âUn-Hooked: The Hook Sessionsâ? 
>>>>(System
>>>>Recordings, out November 15) reprises some of the finest moments of his

>>>>Recordings label (whose catalog, supported by Sasha, John Digweed, Paul
>>>>Oakenfold and Paul van Dyk, included Taylor, Sandra Collins X-Cabs, 
>>>>Joshua
>>>>Ryan, Fred Numf, and Transa). How nice to have this compilation of 
>>>>CLâs
>>>>classic Hook tunes âNavigator,â? âCruise Control,â? âFilmerâ? 
>>>>and âShredder,â?
>>>>and seven others showcasing his range from peak hour anthems to darker,
>>>>more pensive chillout moods.

> > >BABY ANNE!
> > >

>wicked
> > >on the turntables, our reigning funky breaks Bass Queen used to pose

> > >
> > >Baby Anne (real name Marianne Broadaway), born in Panama City, Florida,
> > >moved with her family to Orlando when she was four. The oldest of five
> > >kids, she was very shy in school, but did well in sports, ballet and 
>tap,
> > >and cheerleading. She began raving in 1990 when she was 18. âI really
> > >liked

> >song.â
> > >She
> > >said okay and came out of the studio with her first single
> > >âAbercrombieâ
> > >(1995).
> > >
> > >Baby Anneâs discography also includes other releases on Iceyâs Zone
> > >imprint
> > >such as âTrippinâ On Da Bass,â âFreaks Groove,â âBass

> > >âProbeâ and
> > >âPulse,â and âBody Movinââ on Pandisc, âBeatâ on 
>Phattraxx,
> > >and âFuryâ on
> > >Moonshine. In 1999 she released her first mix-CD âBass Queen In The
> > >Mix,â
> > >followed by âBass Queen In The Mix 2â (2000) and âDark Side of 
>the
> > >Boomâ
> > >(2001), on Pandisc; then âIâm About to Breakâ (2002) and âMixed
> > >Live: Club
> > >Ra, Las Vegasâ (2003), on Moonshine. Both girls and guys have told 
>Baby
> > >Anne that she has inspired them to start DJing or producing.
> > >
> > >For the record, Music Monthly first spoke with Baby Anne in DC on 
>January
> > >2003, but the interviewer misplaced the tape, which luckily resurfaced 
>in
> > >time for her latest release. Music Monthly reached Baby Anne recently 
>for
> > >updates. Following is a composite of both interviews.
> > >
> > >Music Monthly: Where did your âMixtressâ idea come from?
> > >
> > >Baby Anne: I was trying to think of a title and came up with
> > >âMixtress.â
> > >The image came later when I was thinking about what to do for the 
>cover.
> > >Then I started on the song and it followed suit. Halfway through it I 
>was
> > >looking for a vocal sample and when I found the one I used, the
> > >âMixtressâ
> > >theme came back into play.
> > >
> > >MM: Where did the sexy vocal sample come from?
> > >
> > >BA: Just a sample CD. I donât even remember. Itâs definitely not 
>me,
> > >though!
> > >
> > >MM: Where did you get those clothes and where was your photo shoot? And
> > >who are those masked men?
> > >
> > >BA: I donât normally own clothes like the ones on the cover. I [took] 
>a
> > >shopping trip to my local exotic dancer store. It was fun. Then I flew 
>to
> > >New York to work with a good photographer. He picked the mystery men. I
> > >canât give away their identities!
> > >
> > >MM: Is there a correlation between the âMixtressâ concept and the
> >sound
> > >of
> > >the mix?
> > >
> > >BA: I donât think the style of this CD is much different from my
> >others.
> > >The sound has progressed with the breakbeat scene. Iâve always liked
> >high
> > >energy breaks. This CD might be a little more intense, but I would have
> >to
> > >credit the great songs on it that I might not have been able to find in
> >the
> > >past.
> > >
> > >MM: Does your new image coincide with a new way of viewing yourself?
> > >
> > >BA: No, the whole thing was just for fun. I was trying to think of
> > >something different that didnât look like every other mix-CD and I 
>got
> > >lucky. Thereâs nothing different about me. Iâm sure I will not 
>repeat
> > >this
> > >theme. Iâm sure if I hadnât thought of it, someone else would have
> > >eventually.
> > >
> > >MM: Are you still into yoga?
> > >
> > >BA: I am. I love it. I feel really good afterwards. I try to encourage
> > >everyone to try it.
> > >
> > >MM: What pets do you have now? You used to have a ferret.
> > >
> > >BA: My two dogs, Moopu and Scrappy, and my psycho cat.
> > >
> > >MM: Whatâs in your CD player now?
> > >
> > >BA: [2003] I donât listen to breaks or any kind of dance music when
> >Iâm
> > >not
> > >working because I donât want to get burned out on it. I listen to
> >â80s
> > >music, â70s rock and roll, and grunge. [Iâm a] big Nirvana fan.
> >âYou
> > >Know
> > >Youâre Rightâ - I love that song - made me miss Kurt Cobain.
> > >[2004] âShake your Buddah, Vol. 1â World Beats. No, Iâm not a
> > >Buddhist.
> > >(smile)
> > >
> > >MM: What are your thoughts on the state of the rave scene and the
> >anti-rave
> > >legislation?
> > >
> > >BA: I think there are always going to be politicians against the rave
> > >scene, using it as a political issue to go against. I donât play many
> > >raves
> > >anymore, mostly night clubs. I think itâs for a number of reasons,
> > >partially because of that, partially because of our economy, most 
>places
> > >are hurting. Another reason is that in some areas there were too many
> > >promoters who over-saturated their market, kind of over did it. Kids
> > >didnât
> > >want to pay 25 bucks every week to go to a party. Iâm optimistic.
> > >Everything has its highs and lows. Weâre at a low right now so
> >thereâs
> > >nowhere to go but up. But there are places I go where things are great.
> > >
> > >MM: Advice for aspiring DJs?
> > >
> > >BA: Iâd probably say the same thing that I would have said to one of 
>my
> > >younger brothers or sisters when they each considered DJing. Only do it
> >if
> > >it makes you happy, not because you want to be a DJ because it wonât
> >get
> > >you very far. But if music is what you love, then you can take it as 
>far
> >as
> > >you want.
> > >
> > >MM: Where were you on 9/11?
> > >
> > >BA: It was strange. Since I work at night I would normally sleep in 
>until
> > >11 or 12. I usually have my ringer off but for some reason I had it on
> >and
> > >my brother called at 9 am and said, Two planes just crashed into the
> >World
> > >Trade Center and I just wanted to make sure you were at home. So I got 
>up
> > >and watched the whole thing on TV. I felt so bad for all those people. 
>It
> > >still gets to me. I think it reinforced what Iâve always thought, 
>that
> >a
> > >lot of people go through life just working and getting by. I try to 
>make
> > >myself happy and experience everything I can, within reason.
> > >
> > >MM: What are your current personal goals?
> > >
> > >BA: Iâve recently gone through some personal changes that have
> > >influenced
> > >me to change my point of view on life. My priorities include 
>eliminating
> > >negativity from my life. That includes unhealthy relationships, ways of
> > >thinking, stress. I want to make the most of my life and help my 
>friends
> > >and family as much as I can to do the same.
> > >
> > >MM: What are you contributing to society?
> > >
> > >BA: (cringes) Nothing? (laughs) I feel like Iâm an entertainer and
> > >thatâs
> > >the end of it. People go out and want to have a good time and I hope 
>that
> > >they do, but as far as me making a difference, I donât think this is
> >the
> > >place. Other things bother me, like animal cruelty and homeless people,
> >and
> > >if I was going to contribute something Iâd advocate for something 
>like
> > >that. But I am an entertainer and I donât think itâs that big of a
> > >deal.
> > >
> > >MM: Okay, but when you play and you connect, what do you feel?
> > >
> > >BA: Fun! I got into this because I love to dance and really love music
> >and
> > >now Iâm on the other end of it. I want people to have fun. I donât
> >want
> > >them getting messed up and sitting on the floor. Maybe itâs because
> >Iâm
> > >the
> > >older sister and I have to watch out for my younger siblings, but I 
>want
> > >people to get up and dance and have a good time. When I have a song I
> > >really like and play it, I get chills and throw my hands up and scream
> >with
> > >the crowd. We get excited.
> > >
> > >AARON MYERS IN FLIGHT
> > >
> > >When LTJ BUKEM was forced to cancel his October 6 gig at
> >FIVE:DNBSESSIONS,
> > >Baltimoreâs AARON MYERS was bumped from opener to headliner, in honor
> >of
> > >his imminent relocation to San Diego. It was a fine night at Five, 
>BOBBY
> > >JAE (District Soul, DCDNB, Upfront) opening with his trademark
> >soulfulness,
> > >AARON MYERS giving the crowd a mighty rinsing out, and LOCKS closing 
>with
> > >mellow energy.
> > >
> > >Myers went West for many reasons but âmainly because I just needed a
> > >venue
> > >change.â Though heâs DJed in the Baltimore/DC area since 1995, most
> >of
> > >his
> > >bookings were outside the area from London to Los Angeles, so he felt
> >moved
> > >to go somewhere more receptive to his sound. âThis style of music
> >really
> > >fits well into the [San Diego] scene.â
> > >
> > >Myers drove cross-country in two days, stopping in Amarillo, Texas for 
>a
> > >radio show. Music Monthly reached Myers at his new home âby the bay 
>and
> > >about 5 minutes from the beach.â
> > >
> > >Music Monthly: Thought you were a downtempo drum ânâ bass DJ, but 
>you
> > >played a fairly hard set at FIVE?
> > >
> > >Aaron Myers: I think people see me as a âdowntempoâ dnb DJ because 
>I
> > >run
> > >an atmospheric dnb label, TestFlight Recordings. Most people associate
> > >atmospheric dnb with LTJ Bukemâs Good Looking label which tends to
> >focus
> > >on
> > >chill sounds. The truth is I have always played energetic, which is why 
>I
> > >have found myself getting away from the âatmosphericâ title and 
>lean
> > >towards calling it âprogressiveâ - dnb that is actually 
>progressing.
> > >Most
> > >of what we hear today is stale, in my opinion, and my main element is
> > >playing and releasing tunes that are forward thinking and pushing
> > >boundaries.
> > >
> > >MM: What were your big tracks of the night?
> > >
> > >AM: âHallwaysâ by MRN was definitely one of the highlights. It
> >usually
> > >is
> > >whenever I play it. I ended up rewinding it, which is a rarity for me
> >since
> > >I hate rewinds. They take away from a set, in my opinion. MRN is
> >definitely
> > >one to watch out for. I also premiered Blameâs new tune 
>âAmethystâ
> > >which
> > >will be coming out on TestFlight in the next few months.
> > >
> > >Got some really good reactions out of some of the ICR tunes, another
> >artist
> > >I am finding myself playing more and more of. Most of my set consisted 
>of
> > >tracks from my label, EHLâs Warm Communications and ASCâs Covert
> > >Operations
> > >labels, so seeing a good reaction from the crowd made every tune 
>equally
> > >big, knowing people were feeling what we have been pushing so hard over
> >the
> > >past few years.
> > >
> > >MM: How does your move affect TestFlight?
> > >
> > >AM: I think, if anything, it will help. In order to get notice, people
> > >have to listen, and thatâs exactly what we get out here.
> > >
> > >MM: What does TestFlight have coming up?
> > >
> > >AM: October saw the release of our first CD, ACSâs second album and
> > >first
> > >for TestFlight, âOpen Spaces,â which has been getting some great
> > >reviews.
> > >It features 12 tracks of drum ânâ bass and downtempo, and features
> > >tracks
> > >by Jadis who previously worked with Orion on his releases for 
>TeeBeeâs
> > >Subtitles Label (available at retail stores, record shops, iTunes). 
>There
> > >are also two vinyl releases put out this past year, ASC âTenth Zone
> > >Eastâ/âMind Control,â which is a rather hard piece to find these
> >days
> > >due
> > >to our old distributor, Vinyl Dist., going under. I donât even have a
> > >copy
> > >for myself. The other release was Orion âTestimonyâ/âMemento,â
> > >which we
> > >were able to save and is available through techgroove.co.uk.
> > >
> > >On the CD end I have two projects lined up that I am really excited
> >about.
> > >First is âAaron Myers Presents: Altitude Volume Oneâ featuring
> > >exclusive
> > >tracks by Blame, MRN, Electrosoul System, ICR, Furianga, Method One and

> > >Electrosoul System doing his first full-length LP, another artist

> > >for big places with releases lined up for Good Looking, Cov-ops, Phutro
> >and
> > >DeFunked. Beyond that I have plans, none that I am ready to announce

> > >but big things are on the horizon.
> > >
> > >MM: Miss anything about Baltimore/DC?
> > >
> > >AM: I definitely miss my friends and family. The weirdest thing is the
> > >seasons changing â it doesnât happen out here. But I wonât have 
>to
> > >worry
> > >about snow!
> > >
> > >MM: Last words?
> > >
> > >AM: Get out there and check this stuff out. There is more to dnb than
> >loud
> > >predictable basslines, so many new artists doing great things. I hope 
>to
> >be
> > >able to create a forum for them to be heard. Buy your copy of âOpen
> > >Spacesâ
> > >and thereâs much more to come. As long as people are listening, 
>Iâll
> > >still
> > >be making noise!
> > >
> > >CHECK IT
> > >
> > >Lovers of dance will appreciate DANCES OF ECSTASY, a documentary by
> > >Australian filmmakers Michelle Mahrer and Nicole Ma, that travels 
>around
> > >the world to places where they found people achieving altered-state
> > >experiences through dancing, from Whirling Dervishes of Turkey, Orisha
> > >Priestesses in Nigeria and Brazil, shaman healers in the Kalahari and
> > >Korea, a Gabrielle Roth dance workshop in New York City, and the 
>Rainbow
> > >Serpent Festival rave in an Australian forest. The film celebrates the
> > >universal experience of joy through movement to music with a cornucopia
> >of
> > >images of dance rituals and interviews, and a broad spectrum of 
>rhythmic
> > >music of diverse cultures. Enthralling.
> > >
> > >Sweet and ethereal, âTHE BEST OF DELERIUMâ (Nettwerk) conjures
> >sensual
> > >candle-lit baths with rose petals, or thoughtful walks through ancient
> > >forests. Dreamy, romantic vocals by spell-casting artists including 
>Sarah
> > >McLachlan, Aude, Zoe Johnston (Bent, Faithless), Kristy Thirsk and 
>Leigh
> > >Nash grace Canadian Bill Leeb and Rhys Fulberâs luxuriant Gothic
> > >soundscapes, sometimes haunted by choruses evoking Gregorian chants. 
>The
> > >album includes their hit singles âSilence,â âInnocente (Falling 
>in
> > >Love),â

> > >bringing back TURKEY FEVER with SCOTT HENRY + FEELGOOD Thanksgiving

Subject: Re: [sfraves] baby anne/aaron myers & misc.

speaking of breaks...come check out The Autobots this friday!  i promise 
you, it'll be some next level breakbeat madness!


Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY

The Autobots (Broke/Skuff/TCR/Passenger/Botchit) - UK

The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez.Before the start of the 
Autobots project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom 
has produced over 40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been 
promoting dance events since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly 
new to the breaks scene, they have had releases on almost every major breaks 
label, they've toured all around the world, and their tracks can be found in 
the boxes of a lot of the biggest names in the business. Don't miss them on 
their first ever west coast appearance.

Check out the SFBreaks.org Interview:
http://sfbreaks.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=127

Download their newest mix:
http://www.theautobots.com/autobot%20mix%20july%2004_96k.mp3


Evil Breaks room:

Ripple (Subscience)
B-Smarter (www.Sparxx.us/Equalize Ent/Virus Breaks) - Seattle, WA
Aaron Jae vs Athena (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks/the Nubotz)
M.O.D. vs Influence (Evil Breaks/in Tha Mix)

Subscience DnB room:

Method One (Method-One.com)
Arson (Urban Drums/www.594Apparel.net)
The Hitmen (Subscience)
Doubleday (Swatchdog Recordings)


Located at Jellys (295 China Basin Wy) this event will be going strong from 
9pm - 3am.

$7 before 11pm and $10 after that.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  an ethical dilemma for latinos ( and all people for that matter )

	An idealogue? Having just looked at his background, Alberto Gonzalez 
looks like more of a social climber to me. Someone willing to be useful 
to those in power (in his case, Bush). Anyway there's nothing wrong 
with being an idealogue -- as long as the ideas you believe in are 
good. Michael Moore is an idealogue (not that the ideas he believes in 
are necessarily good, LOL!) As Barry Goldwater said, "extremism in 
defense of liberty is no vice, and moderation in pursuit of justice is 
no virtue."

	However I agree that Gonzalez's past actions don't make me enthused 
about the possibility of him becoming attorney general. His legal 
recommendations on Guantanamo and Iraq should be a red flag.

	Perhaps this nomination will serve as a note of caution to people 
playing the race card in the future -- it's always a two-edged sword. 
If some folks hadn't been so eager to lionize minorities and demonize 
white people in the past, there would be less danger of Gonzalez 
getting a pass just because he's a Latino now.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. - I'm still intending to reply to your last message on the earlier 
political thread Shawn, but damn it's a long mother, and I just haven't 
got around to it yet.   8)

>The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez.Before the start of the 
>Autobots project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom 
>has produced over 40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been 
>promoting dance events since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly 
>new to the breaks scene, they have had releases on almost every major 
>breaks label, they've toured all around the world, and their tracks can be 
>found in the boxes of a lot of the biggest names in the business. Don't 
>miss them on their first ever west coast appearance.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


Video of Tanks at anti-war protest in LA
Tanks on the streets of LA

http://la.indymedia.org/

LOS ANGELES, November 9, 2004 - At 7:50 PM two armored tanks showed up at 
an anti-war protest in front of the federal building in Westwood. The tanks 
circled the block twice, the second time parking themselves in the street 
and directly in front of the area where most of the protesters were 
gathered. Enraged, some of the people attempted to block the tanks, but 
police quickly cleared the street. The people continued to protest the 
presence of the tanks, but about ten minutes the tanks drove off. It is 
unclear as to why the tanks were deployed to this location. Uploaded here 
is video from the event.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  an ethical dilemma for latinos ( and all people for that matter )

quoth Starchild:
> An idealogue? Having just looked at his background, Alberto Gonzalez
> looks like more of a social climber to me. Someone willing to be
> useful to those in power (in his case, Bush).
>
> Anyway there's nothing wrong with being an idealogue -- as long as the
> ideas you believe in are good. Michael Moore is an idealogue (not that
> the ideas he believes in are necessarily good, LOL!)

OK, so I think we can both agree that either a) the ideas this guy
believes in are bad, or b) he has no ideology per se, but just issues
decisions and recommendations to further his own career. I'm not sure
which is worse, but either possibility would disqualify him for the AG
seat if I had any say in the matter.

> As Barry Goldwater said, "extremism in defense of liberty is no vice,
> and moderation in pursuit of justice is no virtue."

Great quote. Did he say anything about extremism in defense of justice?
;)

> However I agree that Gonzalez's past actions don't make me enthused

I couldn't agree more.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What are the elements of a good flyer design?

what everyone else has said so far along with:

visually- it should represent the mood/theme/flavor of
the party. ie- don't put fuzzy yellow bunnies dancing
in a purple sea of pink daisies under a pastel rainbow
proclaiming "lovie dovie jingle sprouts" for a minimal
techno party yer throwin in a sewer. ghetto-tek maybe.
leave that design fer the candies. ultimately, you
should be able to look at the flyer, close yer eyes
and imagine what the party's gonna be like (while
fryin balls, of course).

Subject: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What are the elements of a good flyer design?

the best parties i've ever been to have been word of
mouth (no flier) or minimal black ink hand bills. when
the fliers started getting more involved the parties
went down the tubes. at the end of the day no one
cares what the flier looked like. if a party is wicked
thats all that matters.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What are the elements of a good flyer design?

In addition to the others:

1)  Not littered all over the sidewalks in SOMA .  Very little says 
"Don't go to this party." more than seeing the flyer on the ground when 
I'm walking to work in the morning.

and

2)  Not pasted to the side of my car by the morning dew.  Not only is 
this one just as disrespectful as the above, it's also totally 
pointless.  Even when I *DO* want your flyer, I don't want one that's 
been reduced to a mass of pulpy goo by the moisture.  Note that using 
ultra-gloss-lacquered-100 
proof-super-mega-nonrecyclable-nonbiodegradable-plastic coated 
cardstock is not an acceptable solution to this problem.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What are the elements of a good

Ditto on 1) and 2):

It wasn't funny at the time...well I guess it was...

At Serenity, a SF Concourse party I was at in ~'99, I parked in front of
the space, and afterwards I had..no kidding...*500+* Cyberfest flyers on my car.

Completely covered the windshield, in every door jam, nook and cranny,
covering my license plates.. I was like an armored cyberfest
advertisement. I wanted to take a picture, but moreso wanted to get outta
there, so I didn't. (I think innocentchild got to see the destruction)

Funny thing was 5 months later on a trip to an Oregon campout, I pull over
and pop the hood to find 50+ *more* Cyberfest flyers that were
lodged into my engine compartment. Man they must've worked hard to do
that!

I was raped by rave-flyers, only now can I come forward to talk about it
;-)

-t

> speaking of breaks...come check out The Autobots
> this friday!  i promise 
> you, it'll be some next level breakbeat madness!
> 
> 
> Evil Breaks presents:
> DIRTY
> 
> The Autobots (Broke/Skuff/TCR/Passenger/Botchit) -
> UK
> 
> The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez.Before
> the start of the 
> Autobots project in 2002, they were both veterans of
> the dance scene, Tom 
> has produced over 40 drum and bass releases since
> 1992, while Jez has been 
> promoting dance events since the late 1980's. And
> although they are fairly 
> new to the breaks scene, they have had releases on
> almost every major breaks 
> label, they've toured all around the world, and
> their tracks can be found in 
> the boxes of a lot of the biggest names in the
> business. Don't miss them on 
> their first ever west coast appearance.
> 
> Check out the SFBreaks.org Interview:
> http://sfbreaks.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=127
> 
> Download their newest mix:
>
http://www.theautobots.com/autobot%20mix%20july%2004_96k.mp3
>

Subject: [sfraves] Flux 101: The massive FLUXuation on 6th street (Sat-Night)









So yeah, we just got 1 extra hour to sleep this fall. I know you need it,
but you can't have it this weekend. This month's installment of FLUX brings
you one EXTRA hour to turn it out!!!! Quite possibly the best lineup you've
seen for sometime.

For all of you that just don't know, here's the breakdown of the game plan.



The Stats~

Calamity Jane: Hands down one of the best breaks dj in SF opens the party up
in true progressive form, setting the pace for more to come.



Koroma: The highly book progressive dj, will bring life to the night tribal
dancer deep down inside of us and keep you bangin' to the beat of the drum!



Farmboy: Wipes that smile of your face! His progressive style, spotted with
break beats will have you stuck on the dance floor with one drink raised in
the air!!!



Gianni:  No stranger to the late night scene Gianni's will take control of
your body leaving you breathless, but wait. last night a Dj saved your
life!!



Massive FLUXuation!!! Free All Night @ Anu.

San Francisco's finest will give you an early dancing start & massive Dj
lineup.



Anu
43 6th @ Market

8pm-2am

Calamity Jane ~ Koroma ~ FarmBoy ~ Gianni

haha... well a couple years ago someone "released" a
sfr sex-chart, more related to the now defunct (as far
as i know) sfraves channel on IRC than to this list...

however there was quite an uprising and outrage when
this came out, probably because there were a lot of
accurate connections that people thought were secret...
there were also a lot of inaccurate accusations which
caused people to be angry as well...

according to the sex-chart tradition, a connection was
defined by any exchange of bodily fluids (ie kissing
was included) which imo made it highly inaccurate,
because jesus, if i had to chart every person i've
*kissed* it would have been a nightmare, doing so for
all those people, well, i dont know that it could be
completed ;)

anyways, the one you found was scott's response to the
drama, and is actually some kind of code that randomly
generates the location of peoples names in the chart... 

good times for sure :)

love and hugs and kisses,
tina

http://moonchyld1.livejournal.com

Subject: [sfraves] Whatchu Listenin To Willis???

Alright people I'm bored today, no ones here at work today so it's up
to you people to keep me entertained.

What are you listening to right now (in your cd player, car, iPod,
etc.)?  Who/What origianlly influenced you into that artist/song?

I'll start:

Nine Inch Nails - Down In It (actually i'm watching the video, but same diff)
It all started on a Boy Scout camping trip back in 1991-1992-ish, my
friend Bob Long had brought along a walkman and 1 tape, that tape was
NIN's Pretty Hate Machine, We listened to that tape on loop for 3
days, non-stop, cept for when we had to change the batteries.  The
song that really caught my attention was Sin, i had to hear that song
more, so when we got back home after that weekend I immediatly went to
the music store and bought the Pretty Hate Machine CD, and it's been
downhill ever since....hehehe, that started the plunge into the
industrial darkness.  Thank god for that weekend.
-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"It's all in the reflexes"

I've been jocking an El Juan cd that he gave me at the OtherWorld Halloween
party. I haven't enjoyed a D&B cd in AGES, so this is a nice change of pace
for me. Even prompted me to go buy some new D&B choonz....

Of course, El Juan is ten ZILLION times better live - but the cd does nicely
in a pinch.

What got me into him? The 1st underground party I went to out here, where I
believe I met Michael (le Breadstick fellow), Dina, Miki & a few other folks
for the 1st time. It was at some sort of art school/gallery type joint in
the city. He was spinning, and was quite good...had to wait until this year
to see him again. By the way - that just sucks, cuz he is a SICK dj and
deserves frequent bookings...

Yadda...

> friend Bob Long had brought along a walkman and 1
> tape, that tape was
> NIN's Pretty Hate Machine, We listened to that tape
> on loop for 3
> days, non-stop, cept for when we had to change the
> batteries.  The
> song that really caught my attention was Sin, i had
> to hear that song
> more, so when we got back home after that weekend I
> immediatly went to
> the music store and bought the Pretty Hate Machine
> CD, and it's been
> downhill ever since....hehehe, that started the
> plunge into the
> industrial darkness.  Thank god for that weekend.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] buy records online - i need them thar links again

That'd be me - king of shopping WAY too much online...

www.releaserecords.com

www.satelliterecords.com  (although I have horror stories about their shit
service)

www.planetXusa.com  (the worst customer service known to man - but good
selection)

www.dropshop.com

www.dmswax.com

www.streetwisemusic.com

www.vinyladdiction.co.uk

www.replayrecords.com

www.htfr.com

www.juno.co.uk

www.chaosexistance.com

www.gemm.com  (if you can't find it here, you can't fiund it right now -
check back weekly for updates!)

That oughtta do for now...

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] buy records online - i need them thar links again

i think i found what i was looking for although not as
good of a deal as a few months back. 

i started ordering from satellite when they first went
online. they used to be really bad but for giggles i
decided to order from them over the summer and the
have finally gotten their shit together. 

i talked to one of their guys. they set up their
online system so they integrate with suppliers. they
take your order, get the records from suppliers, then
ship. i have ordered probably 200 records from them
this summer and only had 2-3 that didn't ship. WAY
better than they used to be. i even rang then a couple
times to tell them that a record didn't show on my
invoice that i paid for and the included it with my
next order and waved shipping. i would give them a
thumbs up these days. at least since this summer till
today.

=)

matt

Date: Thu, 11 Nov 2004 12:58:51 -0800 (PST)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20041111125741.T37174@taz3.hyperreal.org>
SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RIP John Peel

No matter your genre....heads that know will miss John
Peel for the many years of dedicated enthusiasm as a
true pioneer of progressive music....

"He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to
punk, reggae and hip-hop, before they crossed over
into the mainstream. "

Legendary radio DJ John Peel dies


Veteran BBC broadcaster John Peel has died at the age
of 65, while on holiday in Peru.

Peel, whose radio career spanned 40 years, was on a
working holiday in the city of Cuzco with his wife
Sheila when he suffered a heart attack.

He was BBC Radio 1's longest-serving DJ and in recent
years had also presented Home Truths on Radio 4.

Radio 1 controller Andy Parfitt said Peel's
contribution to modern music and culture was
"immeasurable".

'Hugely missed'

He added: "John Peel was a broadcasting legend. I am
deeply saddened by his death as are all who work at
Radio 1. "John's influence has towered over the
development of popular music for nearly four decades.


HAVE YOUR SAY

John Peel stayed true to what mattered most in music
Pete, Nottingham, UK


"Hopeful bands all over the world sent their demo
tapes to John knowing that he really cared.

"His commitment and passion for new music only grew
stronger over the years. In fact, when I last saw him
he was engaged in a lively debate with his fellow DJs
over the state of new music today

"He will be hugely missed."

Mr Parfitt told Radio 1's Newsbeat that Peel had been
on a holiday of a lifetime when he died.

'Irreplaceable'

He added: "He had gone on holiday with Sheila to a
place where he had always wanted to go."


BBC director general Mark Thompson said: "We are all
very shocked and saddened by the news of John's death.


"He was one of the giants of radio and will be missed,
not just by everyone at the BBC, but by millions of
listeners of all ages."

Tony Blair's spokesman said the Prime Minister was
"genuinely saddened by the news".

He added: "His view is that he was a unique voice in
British broadcasting and used that voice to unearth
new talent and different subjects and make them
accessible to a much wider audience."

Radio 1 DJ Jo Whiley, who presented coverage of the
Glastonbury Festival with Peel, paid tribute to her
colleague and close friend.

She said: "John was simply one of my favourite men in
the whole world - as a music fan and presenter he was
simply an inspiration."

Mainstream music

Peel was born in Heswall, near Liverpool, and after
completing his military service in Britain in 1962,
went to the US where he began working for a radio
station in Dallas.

It was because of him I got to hear some of the most
obscure but influential music I ever heard
James Dean Bradfield, Manic Street Preachers

He joined Radio 1 at the launch in 1967, and
established himself with the late night programme Top
Gear.

He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to
punk, reggae and hip-hop, before they crossed over
into the mainstream.

Peel's programme built up a reputation around the
world, and in addition to his Radio 1 programme, he
could also be heard on the BBC's World Service.

James Dean Bradfield, lead singer of the Manic Street
Preachers, paid tribute to Peel.

He told BBC News Online: "It was because of him I got
to hear some of the most obscure but influential music
I ever heard.

"He was a lifeline to hearing music I would never have
heard otherwise. The service he provided was getting
to hear music that you couldn't buy in Cardiff. He was
a portal to a whole new world."

He always had his finger on the pulse of the music
industry
Michael Bradley, Undertones

Blur lead singer Damon Albarn said John Peel's
patronage was "one of the most significant things that
happened to us in our careers".

"The world is going to be a poorer place with his
sudden departure. I will miss him deeply," he added.

"I want to send my heartfelt sympathy to his lovely
family. John's memory will never be forgotten because
he had the spirit of music in him."

Favourite record

After announcing Peel's death on Radio 1, the station
played his favourite song, Teenage Kicks, by the
Undertones.

Michael Bradley, bass player for the Undertones, spoke
of his shock on learning of Peel's death.

He said: "He was a very funny, very warm man and we
will always be grateful for what he did for The
Undertones.

"Personally, I find it incredible what he did for the
band and we always got huge pride out of the fact that
he said Teenage Kicks was his favourite single.

"He always had his finger on the pulse of the music
industry and the fact that Radio 1 played the
Undertones, the White Stripes and the Strokes today
showed just how relevant he remained throughout his
career."

Story from BBC NEWS:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3955289.stm

-- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************

> "genuinely saddened by the news".
>
> He added: "His view is that he was a unique voice in
> British broadcasting and used that voice to unearth
> new talent and different subjects and make them
> accessible to a much wider audience."
>
> Radio 1 DJ Jo Whiley, who presented coverage of the
> Glastonbury Festival with Peel, paid tribute to her
> colleague and close friend.
>
> She said: "John was simply one of my favourite men in
> the whole world - as a music fan and presenter he was
> simply an inspiration."
>
> Mainstream music
>
> Peel was born in Heswall, near Liverpool, and after
> completing his military service in Britain in 1962,
> went to the US where he began working for a radio
> station in Dallas.
>
> It was because of him I got to hear some of the most
> obscure but influential music I ever heard
> James Dean Bradfield, Manic Street Preachers
>
> He joined Radio 1 at the launch in 1967, and
> established himself with the late night programme Top
> Gear.
>
> He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to
> punk, reggae and hip-hop, before they crossed over
> into the mainstream.
>
> Peel's programme built up a reputation around the
> world, and in addition to his Radio 1 programme, he
> could also be heard on the BBC's World Service.
>
> James Dean Bradfield, lead singer of the Manic Street
> Preachers, paid tribute to Peel.
>
> He told BBC News Online: "It was because of him I got
> to hear some of the most obscure but influential music
> I ever heard.
>
> "He was a lifeline to hearing music I would never have
> heard otherwise. The service he provided was getting
> to hear music that you couldn't buy in Cardiff. He was
> a portal to a whole new world."
>
> He always had his finger on the pulse of the music
> industry
> Michael Bradley, Undertones
>
> Blur lead singer Damon Albarn said John Peel's
> patronage was "one of the most significant things that
> happened to us in our careers".
>
> "The world is going to be a poorer place with his
> sudden departure. I will miss him deeply," he added.
>
> "I want to send my heartfelt sympathy to his lovely
> family. John's memory will never be forgotten because
> he had the spirit of music in him."
>
> Favourite record
>
> After announcing Peel's death on Radio 1, the station
> played his favourite song, Teenage Kicks, by the
> Undertones.
>
> Michael Bradley, bass player for the Undertones, spoke
> of his shock on learning of Peel's death.
>
> He said: "He was a very funny, very warm man and we
> will always be grateful for what he did for The
> Undertones.
>
> "Personally, I find it incredible what he did for the
> band and we always got huge pride out of the fact that
> he said Teenage Kicks was his favourite single.
>
> "He always had his finger on the pulse of the music
> industry and the fact that Radio 1 played the
> Undertones, the White Stripes and the Strokes today
> showed just how relevant he remained throughout his
> career."
>
> Story from BBC NEWS:
>
http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3955289.stm
>
> -- 
> **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
> **************************************************************
>
>

> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

>
>> No matter your genre....heads that know will miss John
>> Peel for the many years of dedicated enthusiasm as a
>> true pioneer of progressive music....
>>
>> "He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to
>> punk, reggae and hip-hop, before they crossed over
>> into the mainstream. "
>>
>> Legendary radio DJ John Peel dies
>>
>>
>> Veteran BBC broadcaster John Peel has died at the age
>> of 65, while on holiday in Peru.
>>
>> Peel, whose radio career spanned 40 years, was on a
>> working holiday in the city of Cuzco with his wife
>> Sheila when he suffered a heart attack.
>>
>> He was BBC Radio 1's longest-serving DJ and in recent
>> years had also presented Home Truths on Radio 4.
>>
>> Radio 1 controller Andy Parfitt said Peel's
>> contribution to modern music and culture was
>> "immeasurable".
>>
>> 'Hugely missed'
>>
>> He added: "John Peel was a broadcasting legend. I am
>> deeply saddened by his death as are all who work at
>> Radio 1. "John's influence has towered over the
>> development of popular music for nearly four decades.
>>
>>
>> HAVE YOUR SAY
>>
>> John Peel stayed true to what mattered most in music
>> Pete, Nottingham, UK
>>
>>
>> "Hopeful bands all over the world sent their demo
>> tapes to John knowing that he really cared.
>>
>> "His commitment and passion for new music only grew
>> stronger over the years. In fact, when I last saw him
>> he was engaged in a lively debate with his fellow DJs
>> over the state of new music today
>>
>> "He will be hugely missed."
>>
>> Mr Parfitt told Radio 1's Newsbeat that Peel had been
>> on a holiday of a lifetime when he died.
>>
>> 'Irreplaceable'
>>
>> He added: "He had gone on holiday with Sheila to a
>> place where he had always wanted to go."
>>
>>
>> BBC director general Mark Thompson said: "We are all
>> very shocked and saddened by the news of John's death.
>>
>>
>> "He was one of the giants of radio and will be missed,
>> not just by everyone at the BBC, but by millions of
>> listeners of all ages."
>>
>> Tony Blair's spokesman said the Prime Minister was
>> "genuinely saddened by the news".
>>
>> He added: "His view is that he was a unique voice in
>> British broadcasting and used that voice to unearth
>> new talent and different subjects and make them
>> accessible to a much wider audience."
>>
>> Radio 1 DJ Jo Whiley, who presented coverage of the
>> Glastonbury Festival with Peel, paid tribute to her
>> colleague and close friend.
>>
>> She said: "John was simply one of my favourite men in
>> the whole world - as a music fan and presenter he was
>> simply an inspiration."

--- Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Alright people I'm bored today, no ones here at work
> today so it's up
> to you people to keep me entertained.
> 
> What are you listening to right now (in your cd
> player, car, iPod,
> etc.)?  Who/What origianlly influenced you into that
> artist/song?
> 
> I'll start:
> 
> Nine Inch Nails - Down In It (actually i'm watching
> the video, but same diff)
> It all started on a Boy Scout camping trip back in
> 1991-1992-ish, my
> friend Bob Long had brought along a walkman and 1
> tape, that tape was
> NIN's Pretty Hate Machine, We listened to that tape
> on loop for 3
> days, non-stop, cept for when we had to change the
> batteries.  The
> song that really caught my attention was Sin, i had
> to hear that song
> more, so when we got back home after that weekend I
> immediatly went to
> the music store and bought the Pretty Hate Machine
> CD, and it's been
> downhill ever since....hehehe, that started the
> plunge into the
> industrial darkness.  Thank god for that weekend.
> -- 
> Chester Copperpot

> "Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"

Right now I have in the CD player:

Mobb Deep   - Hell on Earth


I like mobb deep cause they have a gritty true east coast sound. Real rappin 
and real hip-hop a lil "darker" then stuff by like J5 or Dialted peoples 
etc.. But still very good.

Jedi Mind Tricks - Visons of Gandhi

Now Jedi mind is hard gritty east coast stuff with lots of references to 
Allah, Jesus christ and all types of crazy ass samples very unique album and 
from listening to it you would think that these dudes were black. But in 
fact Vinnie paz is white or I-talian and so is Stoop there producer and 
couple other members of the crew. Very orginal works if you ask me all there 
albums I have are good. Violent by design and there newest one something of 
Blood is really good too.

X-Mailer: Web Mail 5.6.4-0

Subject: [sfraves] nrr... Investigate the Election Results

{sorry if this was posted already.. but Hello 2Day.. we
gotta do something =)}

Questions are swirling around whether the election was
conducted honestly or 
not.  We need to know -- was it or wasn't it?

If people were wrongly prevented from voting, or if
legitimate votes were 
mis-counted or not counted at all, we need to know so
the wrongdoers can be 
held accountable, and so we can prevent this from
happening again.

Members of Congress are demanding an investigation to
answer this question.  
The decision on whether or not there will be an
investigation could come as 
soon as Monday.  Join us in supporting the call for one
now, at:

 http://www.moveon.org/investigatethevote/

Then please invite your friends and colleagues to sign,
as well.  We need to 
show Congress that hundreds of thousands of Americans
are serious about 
protecting the integrity of the vote.

We're all hearing the stories and wondering what's true
and what isn't.  But 
at least two cases of serious problems are accepted
beyond doubt:

* In Broward County, Florida, electronic voting
machines counted
 backwards: as more people voted, the official vote
count went down. [1]

* In one Columbus, Ohio suburb, election officials have
acknowledged
 that electronic voting machines credited Bush with
winning 4,258
 votes, even though only 638 people voted there. [2]

These are just cases where we know something went
wrong.  There were also 
lots of reports of people being denied ballots on
Election Day.  So far, 
these reports remain anecdotal, but they must be
compiled and examined.  And 
the Internet is abuzz with theories about why the
official counts were so 
different from the exit polls.

Do you have a story?  Were you prevented from voting? 
Tell us, at:

 http://www.moveon.org/investigatethevote/

Six prominent members of Congress have called for an
investigation.  
Representatives Conyers (D-MI), Holt (D-NJ), Nadler
(D-NY), Scott (D-VA), 
Watt (D-NC) and Wexler (D-FL), have demanded that the
U.S. General 
Accounting Office:

 immediately undertake an investigation of the efficacy
of voting
 machines and new technologies used in the 2004
election, how
 election officials responded to difficulties they
encountered,
 and what we can do in the future to improve our
election systems
 and administration. [3]

We've got to support their call by asking our own
Representatives and 
Senators to join them.

If you have a personal story of disenfranchisement,
tell us.  These members 
of Congress have agreed to include our stories and
comments in their call 
for an investigation.  Please sign now -- we'll deliver
our compiled 
statements to them on Friday.

Even if you don't have a personal story, your signature
on our petition will 
still help build support for an investigation.

To keep our faith in democracy, we need to know the
facts.  Your signing 
this petition, and sharing your story if you have one,
will help.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

--Carrie, Joan, Lee, Marika, Noah, Peter, Rosalyn, and
Wes
 The MoveOn.org Team
 November 11, 2004

Footnotes:

1. Broward Machines Count Backward, Palm Beach Post,
November 5, 2004

2. Glitch Gave Bush Extra Votes in Ohio, AP carried on
CNN, November 5, 2004

3. Letters from members of Congress to David Walker,
Comptroller General of 
the United States, demanding an investigation of the
election: November 5th, 
2004 & November 8th, 2004

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] baby anne/aaron myers & misc.

Can't vouch for her dj skills, don't like the Icey style breaks (gag), but I 
will say that it appears she got lucky. Right time to start. Right place, 
with the right friends. It's all about networking and who you know. DJ 
skills, I've seen people with horrible skills getting booked big because 
they know people. What I read in this article is that she knew Icey and he 
totally pushed her up and without that it's hard to say if she'd be where 
she is now. Lucky girl...

> BABY ANNE!
>
> Where is the sweet, shy BABY ANNE we used to know and love? Always wicked
> on the turntables, our reigning funky breaks Bass Queen used to pose
> demurely in publicity shots wearing something like a long sleeve 
> turtleneck
> sweater or a baby blue velour hoodie, looking soulful. But on the cover of
> her new mix-CD âMIXTRESSâ (Zone Records/System Recordings) our Baby is in
> black leather bondage gear, including handcuffs! Yikes!
>
> Baby Anne (real name Marianne Broadaway), born in Panama City, Florida,
> moved with her family to Orlando when she was four. The oldest of five
> kids, she was very shy in school, but did well in sports, ballet and tap,
> and cheerleading. She began raving in 1990 when she was 18. âI really 
> liked
> the music. A lot of my guy friends bought records and were learning how to
> DJ and I would ask them to play certain songs. They saw I was interested 
> so
> they included me and I picked it up. I started spinning when I was 19, but
> there were no other girls so a lot of them didnât want me to, but one or
> two stuck up for me.â
>
> In 1992, DJ Icey (Americaâs funky breaks King, whom she met before she
> started DJing) let her play at a couple of his parties. âI donât really
> know why other than it was funny or cute or whatever. It was just for fun
> in the beginning and then it kind of took off. Even when I started getting
> paid to DJ, I still only saw it as a hobby and self-entertainment and I
> would only play stuff I would want to hear if I was on the dance floor 
> with
> my friends. I was never trying to prove anything or impress anyone.â
>
> Her guy friends used to call her âJig-o-wattâ because she danced a lot, 
> but
> Icey thought that wasnât an appropriate DJ name because you couldnât tell
> she was a girl, so âhe started calling me Baby Anne as a nickname for
> Marianne. I fought it at first but it ended up sticking.â
>
> Thinking she needed to start a real career, Baby Anne quit DJing for
> awhile. She enrolled in community college and worked as a bartender for a
> year, but wasnât very happy. One night at work when a guest DJ was 
> playing,
> âOut of nowhere I said, What am I doing? Iâm going to start DJing again,
> and ever since Iâve been doing it full-time.â
>
> When Icey started producing, he said to her, âCome in and make a song.â 
> She
> said okay  and came out of the studio with her first single âAbercrombieâ
> (1995).
>
> Baby Anneâs discography also includes other releases on Iceyâs Zone 
> imprint
> such as âTrippinâ On Da Bass,â âFreaks Groove,â âBass Queen,â âProbeâ and
> âPulse,â and  âBody Movinââ on Pandisc, âBeatâ on Phattraxx, and âFuryâ on
> Moonshine. In 1999 she released her first mix-CD âBass Queen In The Mix,â
> followed by âBass Queen In The Mix 2â (2000) and âDark Side of the Boomâ
> (2001), on Pandisc; then âIâm About to Breakâ (2002) and âMixed Live: Club
> Ra, Las Vegasâ (2003), on Moonshine.  Both girls and guys have told Baby
> Anne that she has inspired them to start DJing or producing.
>
> For the record, Music Monthly first spoke with Baby Anne in DC on January
> 2003, but the interviewer misplaced the tape, which luckily resurfaced in
> time for her latest release. Music Monthly reached Baby Anne recently for
> updates. Following is a composite of both interviews.
>

>
> Baby Anne:  I was trying to think of a title and came up with âMixtress.â
> The image came later when I was thinking about what to do for the cover.
> Then I started on the song and it followed suit. Halfway through it I was
> looking for a vocal sample and when I found the one I used, the âMixtressâ
> theme came back into play.
>
> MM:  Where did the sexy vocal sample come from?
>
> BA:  Just a sample CD. I donât even remember. Itâs definitely not me,
> though!
>
> MM:  Where did you get those clothes and where was your photo shoot? And
> who are those masked men?
>
> BA:  I donât normally own clothes like the ones on the cover. I [took] a
> shopping trip to my local exotic dancer store. It was fun. Then I flew to
> New York to work with a good photographer. He picked the mystery men. I
> canât give away their identities!
>
> MM: Is there a correlation between the âMixtressâ concept and the sound of
> the mix?
>
> BA: I donât think the style of this CD is much different from my others.
> The sound has progressed with the breakbeat scene. Iâve always liked high
> energy breaks. This CD might be a little more intense, but I would have to
> credit the great songs on it that I might not have been able to find in 
> the
> past.
>
> MM:  Does your new image coincide with a new way of viewing yourself?
>

> lucky. Thereâs nothing different about me. Iâm sure I will not repeat this
> theme. Iâm sure if I hadnât thought of it, someone else would have
> eventually.
>
> MM:  Are you still into yoga?
>
> BA:  I am. I love it. I feel really good afterwards. I try to encourage
> everyone to try it.
>
> MM:  What pets do you have now? You used to have a ferret.
>
> BA:  My two dogs, Moopu and Scrappy, and my psycho cat.
>
> MM:  Whatâs in your CD player now?

> MM: What are your thoughts on the state of the rave scene and the 
> anti-rave
> legislation?
>
> BA: I think there are always going to be politicians against the rave
> scene, using it as a political issue to go against. I donât play many 
> raves

> partially because of that, partially because of our economy, most places
> are hurting. Another reason is that in some areas there were too many
> promoters who over-saturated their market, kind of over did it. Kids didnât
> want to pay 25 bucks every week to go to a party. Iâm optimistic.
> Everything has its highs and lows. Weâre at a low right now so thereâs
> nowhere to go but up. But there are places I go where things are great.
>

>
> BA:  Iâd probably say the same thing that I would have said to one of my

> you very far. But if music is what you love, then you can take it as far 
> as
> you want.
>
> MM:  Where were you on 9/11?
>
> BA:  It was strange. Since I work at night I would normally sleep in until
> 11 or 12. I usually have my ringer off but for some reason I had it on and
> my brother called at 9 am  and said, Two planes just crashed into the 
> World
> Trade Center and I just wanted to make sure you were at home. So I got up
> and watched the whole thing on TV. I felt so bad for all those people. It
> still gets to me. I think it reinforced what Iâve always thought, that a
> lot of people go through life just working and getting by. I try to make
> myself happy and experience everything I can, within reason.
>
> MM:  What are your current personal goals?
>
> BA:  Iâve recently gone through some personal changes that have influenced
> me to change my point of view on life. My priorities include eliminating
> negativity from my life. That includes unhealthy relationships, ways of
> thinking, stress. I want to make the most of my life and help my friends
> and family as much as I can to do the same.
>
> MM:  What are you contributing to society?
>
> BA:  (cringes) Nothing? (laughs) I feel like Iâm an entertainer and thatâs
> the end of it. People go out and want to have a good time and I hope that
> they do, but as far as me making a difference, I donât think this is the
> place. Other things bother me, like animal cruelty and homeless people, 
> and
> if I was going to contribute something Iâd advocate for something like

>
> MM:  Okay, but when you play and you connect, what do you feel?
>
> BA:  Fun! I got into this because I love to dance and really love music 
> and
> now Iâm on the other end of it. I want people to have fun. I donât want
> them getting messed up and sitting on the floor. Maybe itâs because Iâm 
> the

> really like and play it, I get chills and throw my hands up and scream 
> with
> the crowd. We get excited.
>
> AARON MYERS IN FLIGHT
>
> When LTJ BUKEM was forced to cancel his October 6 gig at FIVE:DNBSESSIONS,
> Baltimoreâs AARON MYERS was bumped from opener to headliner, in honor of
> his imminent relocation to San Diego. It was a fine night at Five, BOBBY
> JAE (District Soul, DCDNB, Upfront) opening with his trademark 
> soulfulness,
> AARON MYERS giving the crowd a mighty rinsing out, and LOCKS closing with
> mellow energy.
>
> Myers went West for many reasons but âmainly because I just needed a venue
> change.â Though heâs DJed in the Baltimore/DC area since 1995, most of his
> bookings were outside the area from London to Los Angeles, so he felt 
> moved
> to go somewhere more receptive to his sound. âThis style of music really
> fits well into the [San Diego] scene.â
>
> Myers drove cross-country in two days, stopping in Amarillo, Texas for a
> radio show. Music Monthly reached Myers at his new home âby the bay and
> about 5 minutes from the beach.â
>
> Music Monthly:  Thought you were a downtempo drum ânâ bass DJ, but you
> played a fairly hard set at FIVE?
>
> Aaron Myers:  I think people see me as a âdowntempoâ dnb DJ because I run
> an atmospheric dnb label, TestFlight Recordings. Most people associate
> atmospheric dnb with LTJ Bukemâs Good Looking label which tends to focus 
> on
> chill sounds. The truth is I have always played energetic, which is why I
> have found myself getting away from the âatmosphericâ title and lean
> towards calling it âprogressiveâ - dnb that is actually progressing. Most
> of what we hear today is stale, in my opinion, and my main element is
> playing and releasing tunes that are forward thinking and pushing
> boundaries.
>
> MM:  What were your big tracks of the night?
>
> AM:  âHallwaysâ by MRN was definitely one of the highlights. It usually is
> whenever I play it. I ended up rewinding it, which is a rarity for me 
> since
> I hate rewinds. They take away from a set, in my opinion. MRN is 
> definitely
> one to watch out for. I also premiered Blameâs new tune âAmethystâ which
> will be coming out on TestFlight in the next few months.
>
> Got some really good reactions out of some of the ICR tunes, another 
> artist

> tracks from my label, EHLâs Warm Communications and ASCâs Covert 
> Operations
> labels, so seeing a good reaction from the crowd made every tune equally

> past few years.
>

>

>
> CHECK IT
>
> Lovers of dance will appreciate DANCES OF ECSTASY, a documentary by
> Australian filmmakers Michelle Mahrer and Nicole Ma, that travels around
> the world to places where they found people achieving altered-state
> experiences through dancing, from Whirling Dervishes of Turkey, Orisha
> Priestesses in Nigeria and Brazil, shaman healers in the Kalahari and
> Korea, a Gabrielle Roth dance workshop in New York City, and the Rainbow
> Serpent Festival rave in an Australian forest. The film celebrates the
> universal experience of joy through movement to music with a cornucopia of
> images of dance rituals and interviews, and a broad spectrum of rhythmic
> music of diverse cultures. Enthralling.
>
> Sweet and ethereal, âTHE BEST OF DELERIUMâ (Nettwerk) conjures sensual
> candle-lit baths with rose petals, or thoughtful walks through ancient
> forests. Dreamy, romantic vocals by spell-casting artists including Sarah
> McLachlan, Aude, Zoe Johnston (Bent, Faithless), Kristy Thirsk and Leigh
> Nash grace Canadian Bill Leeb and Rhys Fulberâs luxuriant Gothic
> soundscapes, sometimes haunted by choruses evoking Gregorian chants. The
