>
>> No matter your genre....heads that know will miss John
>> Peel for the many years of dedicated enthusiasm as a
>> true pioneer of progressive music....
>>
>> "He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to
>> punk, reggae and hip-hop, before they crossed over
>> into the mainstream. "
>>
>> Legendary radio DJ John Peel dies
>>
>>
>> Veteran BBC broadcaster John Peel has died at the age
>> of 65, while on holiday in Peru.
>>
>> Peel, whose radio career spanned 40 years, was on a
>> working holiday in the city of Cuzco with his wife
>> Sheila when he suffered a heart attack.
>>
>> He was BBC Radio 1's longest-serving DJ and in recent
>> years had also presented Home Truths on Radio 4.
>>
>> Radio 1 controller Andy Parfitt said Peel's
>> contribution to modern music and culture was
>> "immeasurable".
>>
>> 'Hugely missed'
>>
>> He added: "John Peel was a broadcasting legend. I am
>> deeply saddened by his death as are all who work at
>> Radio 1. "John's influence has towered over the
>> development of popular music for nearly four decades.
>>
>>
>> HAVE YOUR SAY
>>
>> John Peel stayed true to what mattered most in music
>> Pete, Nottingham, UK
>>
>>
>> "Hopeful bands all over the world sent their demo
>> tapes to John knowing that he really cared.
>>
>> "His commitment and passion for new music only grew
>> stronger over the years. In fact, when I last saw him
>> he was engaged in a lively debate with his fellow DJs
>> over the state of new music today
>>
>> "He will be hugely missed."
>>
>> Mr Parfitt told Radio 1's Newsbeat that Peel had been
>> on a holiday of a lifetime when he died.
>>
>> 'Irreplaceable'
>>
>> He added: "He had gone on holiday with Sheila to a
>> place where he had always wanted to go."
>>
>>
>> BBC director general Mark Thompson said: "We are all
>> very shocked and saddened by the news of John's death.
>>
>>
>> "He was one of the giants of radio and will be missed,
>> not just by everyone at the BBC, but by millions of
>> listeners of all ages."
>>
>> Tony Blair's spokesman said the Prime Minister was
>> "genuinely saddened by the news".
>>
>> He added: "His view is that he was a unique voice in
>> British broadcasting and used that voice to unearth
>> new talent and different subjects and make them
>> accessible to a much wider audience."
>>
>> Radio 1 DJ Jo Whiley, who presented coverage of the
>> Glastonbury Festival with Peel, paid tribute to her
>> colleague and close friend.
>>
>> She said: "John was simply one of my favourite men in
>> the whole world - as a music fan and presenter he was
>> simply an inspiration."
>>
>> Mainstream music
>>
>> Peel was born in Heswall, near Liverpool, and after
>> completing his military service in Britain in 1962,
>> went to the US where he began working for a radio
>> station in Dallas.
>>
>> It was because of him I got to hear some of the most
>> obscure but influential music I ever heard
>> James Dean Bradfield, Manic Street Preachers
>>
>> He joined Radio 1 at the launch in 1967, and
>> established himself with the late night programme Top
>> Gear.
>>
>> He became one of the first DJs to give exposure to
>> punk, reggae and hip-hop, before they crossed over
>> into the mainstream.
>>
>> Peel's programme built up a reputation around the
>> world, and in addition to his Radio 1 programme, he
>> could also be heard on the BBC's World Service.
>>
>> James Dean Bradfield, lead singer of the Manic Street
>> Preachers, paid tribute to Peel.
>>
>> He told BBC News Online: "It was because of him I got
>> to hear some of the most obscure but influential music
>> I ever heard.
>>
>> "He was a lifeline to hearing music I would never have
>> heard otherwise. The service he provided was getting
>> to hear music that you couldn't buy in Cardiff. He was
>> a portal to a whole new world."
>>
>> He always had his finger on the pulse of the music
>> industry
>> Michael Bradley, Undertones
>>
>> Blur lead singer Damon Albarn said John Peel's
>> patronage was "one of the most significant things that
>> happened to us in our careers".
>>
>> "The world is going to be a poorer place with his
>> sudden departure. I will miss him deeply," he added.
>>
>> "I want to send my heartfelt sympathy to his lovely
>> family. John's memory will never be forgotten because
>> he had the spirit of music in him."
>>
>> Favourite record
>>
>> After announcing Peel's death on Radio 1, the station
>> played his favourite song, Teenage Kicks, by the
>> Undertones.
>>
>> Michael Bradley, bass player for the Undertones, spoke
>> of his shock on learning of Peel's death.
>>
>> He said: "He was a very funny, very warm man and we
>> will always be grateful for what he did for The
>> Undertones.
>>
>> "Personally, I find it incredible what he did for the
>> band and we always got huge pride out of the fact that
>> he said Teenage Kicks was his favourite single.
>>
>> "He always had his finger on the pulse of the music
>> industry and the fact that Radio 1 played the
>> Undertones, the White Stripes and the Strokes today
>> showed just how relevant he remained throughout his
>> career."
>>

i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

	sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <34b1664704111108321465ee08@mail.gmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Whatchu Listenin To Willis???

quoth Chester Copperpot:
> Alright people I'm bored today, no ones here at work today so it's up
> to you people to keep me entertained.
> 
> What are you listening to right now (in your cd player, car, iPod,
> etc.)?  Who/What origianlly influenced you into that artist/song?

On my iPod: various DJ mixes by John Tejada, Brian Ffar, Maetrik, Richie
Hawtin, Trent Roche, and live sets by Lucien N. Luciano and Claro
Intelecto.

On the stereo: Crunch Time by Misc., and stuff from this year's Beta
Lounge record club: DJ Zeph, Bigga Bush, and Branden Harper. If I'm in a
chill mood, nothing does me better than Talkie Walkie by Air. And
Bjork's Medulla is still growing on me, slowly but surely.

On the decks (I'm lucky enough to work at home, so I can listen to
records all day long): the new Ricardo Villalobs 3x12" on Perlon
(MASSIVE!) and Dominick Eulberg's Flora & Fauna LP on Traum
Schallplatten.

In the car, an oldie but extremely goodie: Dead Cities by Future Sound
of London. For me, it's the best of both worlds as far as FSOL are
concerned: the electronic aesthetic of Accelerator and the lush, organic
textures of Lifeforms, with each track tied together by an intangible
sonic thread. "Antique Toy" is my favorite on this album, primarily
because it makes such interesting use of classic Roland drum machines. I
love the image that it conjures, of somebody wandering through the
basement of an abandoned building thousands of years in the future and
coming across this battered old plastic box. Somehow he gets it working
again, but the patterns stutter and pause, and the emptiness of the
place allows its sounds to reverberate endlessly. The track works on so
many levels: it's a thematic device for the album; it's a prediction of
how the technology of today will be perceived by future generations (if
not the artists' perception of 10-year-old drum machines); it's probably
even a subtle stab at vintage gear fetishists.

How did I get into FSOL? Well, I was first exposed to "Papau New
Guineau" by the soundtrack to that horrible '92 animated film Cool
World (also featuring Ministry, Thrill Kill Kult and Moby). But I didn't
really pursue that lead, and I eventually stumbled upon Accelerator when
it was re-pressed with the fancy graphics a few years later. "Papau New
Guineau" is still probably my favorite song of all time.

Toodles,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

> In the car, an oldie but extremely goodie: Dead Cities by Future Sound
> of London. For me, it's the best of both worlds as far as FSOL are
> concerned: the electronic aesthetic of Accelerator and the lush, organic
> textures of Lifeforms, with each track tied together by an intangible
> sonic thread. "Antique Toy" is my favorite on this album, primarily
> because it makes such interesting use of classic Roland drum machines. I
> love the image that it conjures, of somebody wandering through the
> basement of an abandoned building thousands of years in the future and
> coming across this battered old plastic box. Somehow he gets it working
> again, but the patterns stutter and pause, and the emptiness of the
> place allows its sounds to reverberate endlessly. The track works on so
> many levels: it's a thematic device for the album; it's a prediction of
> how the technology of today will be perceived by future generations (if
> not the artists' perception of 10-year-old drum machines); it's probably
> even a subtle stab at vintage gear fetishists.
> 
> How did I get into FSOL? Well, I was first exposed to "Papau New
> Guineau" by the soundtrack to that horrible '92 animated film Cool
> World (also featuring Ministry, Thrill Kill Kult and Moby). But I didn't
> really pursue that lead, and I eventually stumbled upon Accelerator when
> it was re-pressed with the fancy graphics a few years later. "Papau New
> Guineau" is still probably my favorite song of all time.
> 
> Toodles,
> --
> shawn allen
>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>   phone://+1.415.577.3961
>   http://alterior.net
>   aim://shawnpallen

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Whatchu Listenin To Willis???

What's really cool is it's on the Cool World soundtrack from the time when 
it came out. That was a major motion picture release and it had early rave 
music on it! Actually that whole soundtrack is a pretty cool retrospective 
and I still have my copy from back when I saw the movie. Hybrid's remix of 
Papua New Guinea is really cool and probably my favorite. I see it as 
minimally touched and as a cleaned up version using modern gear.

> ----- Original Message ----- From: "Mary Morris" =
<morrism@washpost.com>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

> Subject: [sfraves] baby anne/aaron myers & misc.

>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> (pre-edited version of a column that appears in the dc area)  (if you=20=

>> write
>> and your local music paper doesn't cover edm - ask if *you* can do=20
>> it! : )
>>
>> BABY ANNE!
>>
>> Where is the sweet, shy BABY ANNE we used to know and love? Always=20
>> wicked
>> on the turntables, our reigning funky breaks Bass Queen used to pose
>> demurely in publicity shots wearing something like a long sleeve=20
>> turtleneck
>> sweater or a baby blue velour hoodie, looking soulful. But on the=20
>> cover of
>> her new mix-CD =93MIXTRESS=94 (Zone Records/System Recordings) our =
Baby=20
>> is in
>> black leather bondage gear, including handcuffs! Yikes!
>>
>> Baby Anne (real name Marianne Broadaway), born in Panama City,=20
>> Florida,
>> moved with her family to Orlando when she was four. The oldest of =
five
>> kids, she was very shy in school, but did well in sports, ballet and=20=

>> tap,
>> and cheerleading. She began raving in 1990 when she was 18. =93I =
really=20
>> liked
>> the music. A lot of my guy friends bought records and were learning=20=

>> how to
>> DJ and I would ask them to play certain songs. They saw I was=20
>> interested so
>> they included me and I picked it up. I started spinning when I was=20
>> 19, but
>> there were no other girls so a lot of them didn=92t want me to, but =
one=20
>> or
>> two stuck up for me.=94
>>
>> In 1992, DJ Icey (America=92s funky breaks King, whom she met before =
she
>> started DJing) let her play at a couple of his parties. =93I don=92t=20=

>> really
>> know why other than it was funny or cute or whatever. It was just for=20=

>> fun
>> in the beginning and then it kind of took off. Even when I started=20
>> getting
>> paid to DJ, I still only saw it as a hobby and self-entertainment and=20=

>> I
>> would only play stuff I would want to hear if I was on the dance=20
>> floor with
>> my friends. I was never trying to prove anything or impress anyone.=94
>>
>> Her guy friends used to call her =93Jig-o-watt=94 because she danced =
a=20
>> lot, but
>> Icey thought that wasn=92t an appropriate DJ name because you =
couldn=92t=20
>> tell
>> she was a girl, so =93he started calling me Baby Anne as a nickname =
for
>> Marianne. I fought it at first but it ended up sticking.=94
>>
>> Thinking she needed to start a real career, Baby Anne quit DJing for
>> awhile. She enrolled in community college and worked as a bartender=20=

>> for a
>> year, but wasn=92t very happy. One night at work when a guest DJ was=20=

>> playing,
>> =93Out of nowhere I said, What am I doing? I=92m going to start DJing=20=

>> again,
>> and ever since I=92ve been doing it full-time.=94
>>
>> When Icey started producing, he said to her, =93Come in and make a=20
>> song.=94 She
>> said okay  and came out of the studio with her first single=20
>> =93Abercrombie=94
>> (1995).
>>
>> Baby Anne=92s discography also includes other releases on Icey=92s =
Zone=20
>> imprint
>> such as =93Trippin=92 On Da Bass,=94 =93Freaks Groove,=94 =93Bass =
Queen,=94 =93Probe=94=20
>> and
>> =93Pulse,=94 and  =93Body Movin=92=94 on Pandisc, =93Beat=94 on =
Phattraxx, and=20
>> =93Fury=94 on
>> Moonshine. In 1999 she released her first mix-CD =93Bass Queen In The=20=

>> Mix,=94
>> followed by =93Bass Queen In The Mix 2=94 (2000) and =93Dark Side of =
the=20
>> Boom=94
>> (2001), on Pandisc; then =93I=92m About to Break=94 (2002) and =93Mixed=
 Live:=20
>> Club
>> Ra, Las Vegas=94 (2003), on Moonshine.  Both girls and guys have told=20=

>> Baby
>> Anne that she has inspired them to start DJing or producing.
>>
>> For the record, Music Monthly first spoke with Baby Anne in DC on=20
>> January
>> 2003, but the interviewer misplaced the tape, which luckily=20
>> resurfaced in
>> time for her latest release. Music Monthly reached Baby Anne recently=20=

>> for
>> updates. Following is a composite of both interviews.
>>
>> Music Monthly:  Where did your =93Mixtress=94 idea come from?
>>
>> Baby Anne:  I was trying to think of a title and came up with=20
>> =93Mixtress.=94
>> The image came later when I was thinking about what to do for the=20
>> cover.
>> Then I started on the song and it followed suit. Halfway through it I=20=

>> was
>> looking for a vocal sample and when I found the one I used, the=20
>> =93Mixtress=94
>> theme came back into play.
>>
>> MM:  Where did the sexy vocal sample come from?
>>
>> BA:  Just a sample CD. I don=92t even remember. It=92s definitely not =
me,
>> though!
>>
>> MM:  Where did you get those clothes and where was your photo shoot?=20=

>> And
>> who are those masked men?
>>
>> BA:  I don=92t normally own clothes like the ones on the cover. I=20
>> [took] a
>> shopping trip to my local exotic dancer store. It was fun. Then I=20
>> flew to
>> New York to work with a good photographer. He picked the mystery men.=20=

>> I
>> can=92t give away their identities!
>>
>> MM: Is there a correlation between the =93Mixtress=94 concept and the=20=

>> sound of
>> the mix?
>>
>> BA: I don=92t think the style of this CD is much different from my=20
>> others.
>> The sound has progressed with the breakbeat scene. I=92ve always =
liked=20
>> high
>> energy breaks. This CD might be a little more intense, but I would=20
>> have to
>> credit the great songs on it that I might not have been able to find=20=

>> in the
>> past.
>>
>> MM:  Does your new image coincide with a new way of viewing yourself?
>>
>> BA:  No, the whole thing was just for fun. I was trying to think of
>> something different that didn=92t look like every other mix-CD and I =
got
>> lucky. There=92s nothing different about me. I=92m sure I will not =
repeat=20
>> this
>> theme. I=92m sure if I hadn=92t thought of it, someone else would =
have
>> eventually.
>>
>> MM:  Are you still into yoga?
>>
>> BA:  I am. I love it. I feel really good afterwards. I try to=20
>> encourage
>> everyone to try it.
>>
>> MM:  What pets do you have now? You used to have a ferret.
>>
>> BA:  My two dogs, Moopu and Scrappy, and my psycho cat.
>>
>> MM:  What=92s in your CD player now?
>>
>> BA: [2003] I don=92t listen to breaks or any kind of dance music when=20=

>> I=92m not
>> working because I don=92t want to get burned out on it. I listen to =
=9180s
>> music, =9170s rock and roll, and grunge. [I=92m a] big Nirvana fan. =
=93You=20
>> Know
>> You=92re Right=94 - I love that song - made me miss Kurt Cobain.
>> [2004] =93Shake your Buddah, Vol. 1=94 World Beats. No, I=92m not a=20=

>> Buddhist.
>> (smile)
>>
>> MM: What are your thoughts on the state of the rave scene and the=20
>> anti-rave
>> legislation?
>>
>> BA: I think there are always going to be politicians against the rave
>> scene, using it as a political issue to go against. I don=92t play =
many=20
>> raves
>> anymore, mostly night clubs. I think it=92s for a number of reasons,
>> partially because of that, partially because of our economy, most=20
>> places
>> are hurting. Another reason is that in some areas there were too many
>> promoters who over-saturated their market, kind of over did it. Kids=20=

>> didn=92t
>> want to pay 25 bucks every week to go to a party. I=92m optimistic.
>> Everything has its highs and lows. We=92re at a low right now so =
there=92s
>> nowhere to go but up. But there are places I go where things are=20
>> great.
>>
>> MM:  Advice for aspiring DJs?
>>
>> BA:  I=92d probably say the same thing that I would have said to one =
of=20
>> my
>> younger brothers or sisters when they each considered DJing. Only do=20=

>> it if
>> it makes you happy, not because you want to be a DJ because it won=92t=20=

>> get
>> you very far. But if music is what you love, then you can take it as=20=

>> far as
>> you want.
>>
>> MM:  Where were you on 9/11?
>>
>> BA:  It was strange. Since I work at night I would normally sleep in=20=

>> until
>> 11 or 12. I usually have my ringer off but for some reason I had it=20=

>> on and
>> my brother called at 9 am  and said, Two planes just crashed into the=20=

>> World
>> Trade Center and I just wanted to make sure you were at home. So I=20
>> got up
>> and watched the whole thing on TV. I felt so bad for all those=20
>> people. It
>> still gets to me. I think it reinforced what I=92ve always thought,=20=

>> that a
>> lot of people go through life just working and getting by. I try to=20=

>> make
>> myself happy and experience everything I can, within reason.
>>
>> MM:  What are your current personal goals?
>>
>> BA:  I=92ve recently gone through some personal changes that have=20
>> influenced
>> me to change my point of view on life. My priorities include=20
>> eliminating
>> negativity from my life. That includes unhealthy relationships, ways=20=

>> of
>> thinking, stress. I want to make the most of my life and help my=20
>> friends
>> and family as much as I can to do the same.
>>
>> MM:  What are you contributing to society?
>>
>> BA:  (cringes) Nothing? (laughs) I feel like I=92m an entertainer and=20=

>> that=92s
>> the end of it. People go out and want to have a good time and I hope=20=

>> that
>> they do, but as far as me making a difference, I don=92t think this =
is=20
>> the
>> place. Other things bother me, like animal cruelty and homeless=20
>> people, and
>> if I was going to contribute something I=92d advocate for something =
like
>> that. But I am an entertainer and I don=92t think it=92s that big of =
a=20
>> deal.
>>
>> MM:  Okay, but when you play and you connect, what do you feel?
>>
>> BA:  Fun! I got into this because I love to dance and really love=20
>> music and
>> now I=92m on the other end of it. I want people to have fun. I don=92t=20=

>> want
>> them getting messed up and sitting on the floor. Maybe it=92s because=20=

>> I=92m the
>> older sister and I have to watch out for my younger siblings, but I=20=

>> want
>> people to get up and dance and have a good time. When I have a song I
>> really like and play it, I get chills and throw my hands up and=20
>> scream with
>> the crowd. We get excited.
>>
>> AARON MYERS IN FLIGHT
>>
>> When LTJ BUKEM was forced to cancel his October 6 gig at=20
>> FIVE:DNBSESSIONS,
>> Baltimore=92s AARON MYERS was bumped from opener to headliner, in =
honor=20
>> of
>> his imminent relocation to San Diego. It was a fine night at Five,=20
>> BOBBY
>> JAE (District Soul, DCDNB, Upfront) opening with his trademark=20
>> soulfulness,
>> AARON MYERS giving the crowd a mighty rinsing out, and LOCKS closing=20=

>> with
>> mellow energy.
>>
>> Myers went West for many reasons but =93mainly because I just needed =
a=20
>> venue
>> change.=94 Though he=92s DJed in the Baltimore/DC area since 1995, =
most=20
>> of his
>> bookings were outside the area from London to Los Angeles, so he felt=20=

>> moved
>> to go somewhere more receptive to his sound. =93This style of music=20=

>> really
>> fits well into the [San Diego] scene.=94
>>
>> Myers drove cross-country in two days, stopping in Amarillo, Texas=20
>> for a
>> radio show. Music Monthly reached Myers at his new home =93by the bay=20=

>> and
>> about 5 minutes from the beach.=94
>>
>> Music Monthly:  Thought you were a downtempo drum =92n=92 bass DJ, =
but you
>> played a fairly hard set at FIVE?
>>
>> Aaron Myers:  I think people see me as a =93downtempo=94 dnb DJ =
because I=20
>> run
>> an atmospheric dnb label, TestFlight Recordings. Most people =
associate
>> atmospheric dnb with LTJ Bukem=92s Good Looking label which tends to=20=

>> focus on
>> chill sounds. The truth is I have always played energetic, which is=20=

>> why I
>> have found myself getting away from the =93atmospheric=94 title and =
lean
>> towards calling it =93progressive=94 - dnb that is actually =
progressing.=20
>> Most
>> of what we hear today is stale, in my opinion, and my main element is
>> playing and releasing tunes that are forward thinking and pushing
>> boundaries.
>>
>> MM:  What were your big tracks of the night?
>>
>> AM:  =93Hallways=94 by MRN was definitely one of the highlights. It=20=

>> usually is
>> whenever I play it. I ended up rewinding it, which is a rarity for me=20=

>> since
>> I hate rewinds. They take away from a set, in my opinion. MRN is=20
>> definitely
>> one to watch out for. I also premiered Blame=92s new tune =93Amethyst=94=
=20
>> which
>> will be coming out on TestFlight in the next few months.
>>
>> Got some really good reactions out of some of the ICR tunes, another=20=

>> artist
>> I am finding myself playing more and more of. Most of my set=20
>> consisted of
>> tracks from my label, EHL=92s Warm Communications and ASC=92s Covert=20=

>> Operations
>> labels, so seeing a good reaction from the crowd made every tune=20
>> equally
>> big, knowing people were feeling what we have been pushing so hard=20
>> over the
>> past few years.
>>
>> MM:  How does your move affect TestFlight?
>>
>> AM:  I think, if anything, it will help. In order to get notice,=20
>> people
>> have to listen, and that=92s exactly what we get out here.
>>
>> MM:  What does TestFlight have coming up?
>>
>> AM:  October saw the release of our first CD, ACS=92s second album =
and=20
>> first
>> for TestFlight, =93Open Spaces,=94 which has been getting some great=20=

>> reviews.
>> It features 12 tracks of drum =91n=92 bass and downtempo, and =
features=20
>> tracks
>> by Jadis who previously worked with Orion on his releases for =
TeeBee=92s
>> Subtitles Label (available at retail stores, record shops, iTunes).=20=

>> There
>> are also two vinyl releases put out this past year, ASC =93Tenth Zone
>> East=94/=94Mind Control,=94 which is a rather hard piece to find =
these days=20
>> due
>> to our old distributor, Vinyl Dist., going under. I don=92t even have =
a=20
>> copy
>> for myself. The other release was Orion =93Testimony=94/=94Memento,=94 =
which=20
>> we
>> were able to save and is available through techgroove.co.uk.
>>
>> On the CD end I have two projects lined up that I am really excited=20=

>> about.
>> First is =93Aaron Myers Presents: Altitude Volume One=94 featuring=20
>> exclusive
>> tracks by Blame, MRN, Electrosoul System, ICR, Furianga, Method One=20=

>> and a
>> remix by Marcus Intalex, among others. That should hit the shelves=20
>> late
>> 2004, early 2005. I have another artist album lined up with Russia=92s
>> Electrosoul System doing his first full-length LP, another artist=20
>> heading
>> for big places with releases lined up for Good Looking, Cov-ops,=20
>> Phutro and
>> DeFunked. Beyond that I have plans, none that I am ready to announce=20=

>> yet,
>> but big things are on the horizon.
>>
>> MM:  Miss anything about Baltimore/DC?
>>
>> AM:  I definitely miss my friends and family. The weirdest thing is=20=

>> the
>> seasons changing =96 it doesn=92t happen out here. But I won=92t have =
to=20
>> worry
>> about snow!
>>
>> MM:  Last words?
>>
>> AM:  Get out there and check this stuff out. There is more to dnb=20
>> than loud
>> predictable basslines, so many new artists doing great things. I hope=20=

>> to be
>> able to create a forum for them to be heard. Buy your copy of =93Open =
=20
>> Spaces=94
>> and there=92s much more to come. As long as people are listening, =
I=92ll=20
>> still
>> be making noise!
>>
>> CHECK IT
>>
>> Lovers of dance will appreciate DANCES OF ECSTASY, a documentary by
>> Australian filmmakers Michelle Mahrer and Nicole Ma, that travels=20
>> around
>> the world to places where they found people achieving altered-state
>> experiences through dancing, from Whirling Dervishes of Turkey, =
Orisha
>> Priestesses in Nigeria and Brazil, shaman healers in the Kalahari and
>> Korea, a Gabrielle Roth dance workshop in New York City, and the=20
>> Rainbow
>> Serpent Festival rave in an Australian forest. The film celebrates =
the
>> universal experience of joy through movement to music with a=20
>> cornucopia of
>> images of dance rituals and interviews, and a broad spectrum of=20
>> rhythmic
>> music of diverse cultures. Enthralling.
>>
>> Sweet and ethereal, =93THE BEST OF DELERIUM=94 (Nettwerk) conjures =
sensual
>> candle-lit baths with rose petals, or thoughtful walks through =
ancient
>> forests. Dreamy, romantic vocals by spell-casting artists including=20=

>> Sarah
>> McLachlan, Aude, Zoe Johnston (Bent, Faithless), Kristy Thirsk and=20
>> Leigh
>> Nash grace Canadian Bill Leeb and Rhys Fulber=92s luxuriant Gothic
>> soundscapes, sometimes haunted by choruses evoking Gregorian chants.=20=

>> The
>> album includes their hit singles =93Silence,=94 =93Innocente (Falling =
in=20
>> Love),=94
>> =93Underwater, =93After All=94 and =93Truly,=94 and new tracks =
=93Paris=94 and =93You=20
>> and
>> I.=94
>>
>> BUZZLIFE gets busy at three venues this month, including nights with=20=

>> BAD
>> BOY BILL, CONCORD DAWN, DJ IRENE, GROOVERIDER, DJ SS, at CUBIK; UNKLE
>> featuring JAMES LAVALLE + RICHARD FILE, and SANDER KLEINENBERG at=20
>> FIVE; and
>> bringing back TURKEY FEVER with SCOTT HENRY + FEELGOOD Thanksgiving=20=

>> night.
>>
>> ULTRAWORLD is back at the newly expanded SONAR now boasting a Concert=20=

>> Hall
>> in addition to its Club and Lounge, with CHRISTOPHER LAWRENCE, =
MICHAEL
>> OWEN, AK1200, DJ C, MCKAIN, MAZ (Chicago) and PATRICK TURNER. Look=20
>> out for
>> PENDULUM, SUV W/MC L NATURAL, DB, BOBBY JAE, DJ DESTAR, ANDY C + MC=20=

>> GQ,
>> ACTUAL FACT, LUKE FAIR and ADAM T. RUSH the rest of the month.
>>
>> Speaking of Los Angeles-based CHRISTOPHER LAWRENCE, #7 in DJ=20
>> Magazine=92s
>> 2004 Top 100 DJs poll, his new CD =93Un-Hooked: The Hook Sessions=94=20=

>> (System
>> Recordings, out November 15) reprises some of the finest moments of=20=

>> his
>> producing career with seminal Scottish DJ/producer Chris Cowie=92s =
Hook
>> Recordings label (whose catalog, supported by Sasha, John Digweed,=20
>> Paul
>> Oakenfold and Paul van Dyk, included Taylor, Sandra Collins X-Cabs,=20=

>> Joshua
>> Ryan, Fred Numf, and Transa). How nice to have this compilation of=20
>> CL=92s
>> classic Hook tunes =93Navigator,=94 =93Cruise Control,=94 =93Filmer=94 =
and=20
>> =93Shredder,=94
>> and seven others showcasing his range from peak hour anthems to=20
>> darker,
>> more pensive chillout moods.

I got a bit snap happy with the camera and didn't edit
anything. The beach Sierra and me are on is the south
beach on Donner Lake. Note how bloddy low the lake is.
Beautiful time of year to hike around there. No
campers. We saw 3-4 people out there. 

Enjoy 

Matt

> > On Thu, 11 Nov 2004 15:29:30 -0800, shawn allen
> <shawn@alterior.net> 
> > wrote:
> >> quoth Chester Copperpot:
> >> > Alright people I'm bored today, no ones here at
> work today so it's up
> >> > to you people to keep me entertained.
> >> >
> >> > What are you listening to right now (in your cd
> player, car, iPod,
> >> > etc.)?  Who/What origianlly influenced you into
> that artist/song?
> >>
> >> On my iPod: various DJ mixes by John Tejada,
> Brian Ffar, Maetrik, Richie
> >> Hawtin, Trent Roche, and live sets by Lucien N.
> Luciano and Claro
> >> Intelecto.
> >>
> >> On the stereo: Crunch Time by Misc., and stuff
> from this year's Beta
> >> Lounge record club: DJ Zeph, Bigga Bush, and
> Branden Harper. If I'm in a
> >> chill mood, nothing does me better than Talkie
> Walkie by Air. And
> >> Bjork's Medulla is still growing on me, slowly
> but surely.
> >>
> >> On the decks (I'm lucky enough to work at home,
> so I can listen to
> >> records all day long): the new Ricardo Villalobs
> 3x12" on Perlon
> >> (MASSIVE!) and Dominick Eulberg's Flora & Fauna
> LP on Traum
> >> Schallplatten.
> >>
> >> In the car, an oldie but extremely goodie: Dead
> Cities by Future Sound
> >> of London. For me, it's the best of both worlds
> as far as FSOL are
> >> concerned: the electronic aesthetic of
> Accelerator and the lush, organic
> >> textures of Lifeforms, with each track tied
> together by an intangible
> >> sonic thread. "Antique Toy" is my favorite on
> this album, primarily
> >> because it makes such interesting use of classic
> Roland drum machines. I
> >> love the image that it conjures, of somebody
> wandering through the
> >> basement of an abandoned building thousands of
> years in the future and
> >> coming across this battered old plastic box.
> Somehow he gets it working
> >> again, but the patterns stutter and pause, and
> the emptiness of the
> >> place allows its sounds to reverberate endlessly.
> The track works on so
> >> many levels: it's a thematic device for the
> album; it's a prediction of
> >> how the technology of today will be perceived by
> future generations (if
> >> not the artists' perception of 10-year-old drum
> machines); it's probably
> >> even a subtle stab at vintage gear fetishists.
> >>
> >> How did I get into FSOL? Well, I was first
> exposed to "Papau New
> >> Guineau" by the soundtrack to that horrible '92
> animated film Cool
> >> World (also featuring Ministry, Thrill Kill Kult
> and Moby). But I didn't
> >> really pursue that lead, and I eventually
> stumbled upon Accelerator when
> >> it was re-pressed with the fancy graphics a few
> years later. "Papau New
> >> Guineau" is still probably my favorite song of
> all time.
> >>
> >> Toodles,
> >> --
> >> shawn allen
> >>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
> >>   phone://+1.415.577.3961
> >>   http://alterior.net
> >>   aim://shawnpallen
> >

Subject: [sfraves] Thought for Today

--=====================_18877163==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



An elder Cherokee Native American was teaching his grandchildren about 
life.  He
said to them, "A fight is going on inside me...It is a terrible fight, and 
it is
between two wolves.  One wolf represents fear, anger, envy, sorrow, regret,
greed, arrogance, self-pity, guilt, resentment, inferiority, lies, pride and
superiority.  The other wolf stands for joy, peace, love, hope, sharing,
serenity, humility, kindness, benevolence, friendship, empathy, generosity,
truth, compassion, and faith.  This same fight is going on inside of you and
every other person too."

They thought about it for a minute and then one child asked his grandfather,
"Which wolf will win?"  The old Cherokee simply replied..."The one I feed."





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_18877163==.ALT--

From sfraves-return-117123-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Nov 12 00:17:39 2004

Received: (qmail 6326 invoked from network); 12 Nov 2004 00:17:36 -0000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <OFB1904A8E.D6D6727E-ON85256F4A.000034B8-85256F4A.00026A0C@washpost.com>
From: Mary Morris <morrism@washpost.com>
Date: Thu, 11 Nov 2004 19:17:22 -0500
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] baby anne/aaron myers & misc.






isn't it great how diverse we are?  :)

i think it's interesting how prominent djs elicit such a wide range of
responses to their work.

and of course in this scene that means the whole spectrum from love to
hate, lol.  ;)

or maybe that's true in any scene.

my husband, who is a huge fan of the late great jazz drummer buddy rich,
says rich's career was plagued by people who tore him down, while in the
opinions of lots of fans rich was one of the greatest drummers who ever
lived, so maybe our scene is not so different.

if baby anne was lucky, i don't begrudge her that.  a lot of being
successful in the entertainment business *is* luck.  that's just the way it
is.  but it's not all luck.  if she can't draw a crowd or rock a house,
luck won't keep getting her bookings.  i've met some pretty hardcore baby
anne fans.  if she makes them happy, good for her.  :)

i am not a huge breaks fan myself, florida or otherwise, but i like
"mixtress."  it's fun.

please do like whatever you do like.  :)

respectfully,
mary :)



< I really like what Ishkur's Guide to Electronic Music has to say about
Icey's "Florida Breaks:" style.  I agree there 100%....  Can't stand
the shit.

As a matter of fact, I think that's what turned me off so hard to raves
back when I got dragged to a few in Florida.  Breaks, breaks, and more
fucking breaks; and big clusters of people standing around nearly-empty
sections of the dance floor while one tweaker moron fakes a seizure.
Thanks, but I'll take the largest sea of San Francisco F8-worshipping
e-tards you can find over that scene, any day of the week.


cya,
john >

On Nov 11, 2004, at 2:21 PM, innocentchild wrote:

> Can't vouch for her dj skills, don't like the Icey style breaks (gag),
> but I will say that it appears she got lucky. Right time to start.
> Right place, with the right friends. It's all about networking and who
> you know. DJ skills, I've seen people with horrible skills getting
> booked big because they know people. What I read in this article is
> that she knew Icey and he totally pushed her up and without that it's
> hard to say if she'd be where she is now. Lucky girl...
>
> :: r ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Free hosting for mixes?

It depends what you want to do.  Do you want streaming
or just downloading?  Beware of hidden limits either
way.  And I don't know anyone that's supporting
streaming that is totally free.

There are a number of web hosting companies that now
throw in streaming for free.  So if you need a website
or can switch providers you can get streaming for
free.

My former company Live365.com charges now charges
$9.95 per month for streaming audio broadcasting. :(

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [bsp/nrr] Free hosting for mixes?

http://www.google.com/search?sourceid=navclient&ie=UTF-8&q=%22free+mp3+hosting%22

came up with something.   I don't know of any totally free sites that work well though.  all i hear is complaints most of them, but 
what do you get for free right ?

If you don't find what you're looking for and decide you want to get your own domain/site/piece-o-teh-Interweb and be the master of 
your own destiny, as a small local consulting/hosting company (http://5angle.com), I provide hosting for a few local dj's and other 
sfr folks.  hit me up off list if you're interested.  i can't compete with CheaperThanGODCanProvideWebHosting.   but if you're 
looking for quite competitively priced local service where there *is* a person at the other end of the phone call (*some* people 
think that's worth something :) hit me up off list.


drunk dialing your hosting provider's cell phone at 3am is grate !

-=dave

ps- i added the BSP/NRR tagline since i don't appreciate people promoting non-music stuff to the list either.  but he asked so i 
couldn't resist :)

> i fell in love with it then.  I like to bust it out every once in a
> while when i play a breaks set, it's a good chill opening track and

> Chester Copperpot

> "Goonies never say die!"
> "Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
> "It's all in the reflexes"

> On Thu, 11 Nov 2004 15:29:30 -0800, shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
wrote:
> > quoth Chester Copperpot:
> > > Alright people I'm bored today, no ones here at work today so it's up
> > > to you people to keep me entertained.
> > >
> > > What are you listening to right now (in your cd player, car, iPod,
> > > etc.)?  Who/What origianlly influenced you into that artist/song?
> >
> > On my iPod: various DJ mixes by John Tejada, Brian Ffar, Maetrik, Richie
> > Hawtin, Trent Roche, and live sets by Lucien N. Luciano and Claro
> > Intelecto.
> >
> > On the stereo: Crunch Time by Misc., and stuff from this year's Beta
> > Lounge record club: DJ Zeph, Bigga Bush, and Branden Harper. If I'm in a
> > chill mood, nothing does me better than Talkie Walkie by Air. And
> > Bjork's Medulla is still growing on me, slowly but surely.
> >
> > On the decks (I'm lucky enough to work at home, so I can listen to
> > records all day long): the new Ricardo Villalobs 3x12" on Perlon
> > (MASSIVE!) and Dominick Eulberg's Flora & Fauna LP on Traum
> > Schallplatten.
> >
> > In the car, an oldie but extremely goodie: Dead Cities by Future Sound
> > of London. For me, it's the best of both worlds as far as FSOL are
> > concerned: the electronic aesthetic of Accelerator and the lush, organic
> > textures of Lifeforms, with each track tied together by an intangible
> > sonic thread. "Antique Toy" is my favorite on this album, primarily
> > because it makes such interesting use of classic Roland drum machines. I
> > love the image that it conjures, of somebody wandering through the
> > basement of an abandoned building thousands of years in the future and
> > coming across this battered old plastic box. Somehow he gets it working
> > again, but the patterns stutter and pause, and the emptiness of the
> > place allows its sounds to reverberate endlessly. The track works on so
> > many levels: it's a thematic device for the album; it's a prediction of
> > how the technology of today will be perceived by future generations (if
> > not the artists' perception of 10-year-old drum machines); it's probably
> > even a subtle stab at vintage gear fetishists.
> >
> > How did I get into FSOL? Well, I was first exposed to "Papau New
> > Guineau" by the soundtrack to that horrible '92 animated film Cool
> > World (also featuring Ministry, Thrill Kill Kult and Moby). But I didn't
> > really pursue that lead, and I eventually stumbled upon Accelerator when
> > it was re-pressed with the fancy graphics a few years later. "Papau New
> > Guineau" is still probably my favorite song of all time.
> >
> > Toodles,
> > --
> > shawn allen
> >   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
> >   phone://+1.415.577.3961
> >   http://alterior.net
> >   aim://shawnpallen
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: New track (UlvCM) & Live Mix @ Defcon XII

Well,

For those folks who like a little techno in their lives I have posted a new 
track to the virtual catalog of EGR Records:
http://egr.egregious.net/egrv-01/
It came about last week while I was at ICMC as a short live performance.

I also got around to getting most of my live mix from Defcon XII posted as 
well.. It was a short set with some tech difficulties such as the rig being 
ghetto and a needle going out, but hey... I kind of like live sets that 
aren't pulled off in a perfect environment...   as I have plenty that 
are... live and studio.. :)

For more DJ comps.. I have 9 mostly techno oriented ones here:
http://www.egregious.net/comps/

and some tracks and media stuff here:
http://www.egregious.net/media/

Cheers,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:

> 
> 
> An elder Cherokee Native American was teaching his
> grandchildren about 
> life.  He
> said to them, "A fight is going on inside me...It is
> a terrible fight, and 
> it is
> between two wolves.  One wolf represents fear,
> anger, envy, sorrow, regret,
> greed, arrogance, self-pity, guilt, resentment,
> inferiority, lies, pride and
> superiority.  The other wolf stands for joy, peace,
> love, hope, sharing,
> serenity, humility, kindness, benevolence,
> friendship, empathy, generosity,
> truth, compassion, and faith.  This same fight is
> going on inside of you and
> every other person too."
> 
> They thought about it for a minute and then one
> child asked his grandfather,
> "Which wolf will win?"  The old Cherokee simply
> replied..."The one I feed."
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101: 
>
http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> 
> "The government, which was designed for the people,
> has got into the hands 
> of the bosses and their employers, the special
> interests.  An invisible 
> empire has been set up above the forms of
> democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
> 
> "There are times when you have to obey a call which
> is the highest of all, 
> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such
> obedience may cost many a 
> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends,
> from family, from the 
> state to which you may belong, from all that you
> have held as dear as life 
> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>    Gandhi
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic
> organization are ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that
> will gradually become 
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] TONIGHT!  get dirty with The Autobots!  Breaks and DnB!

fyi, we've got a gigantamous canopy and several heaters to keep the outdoor 
DnB area dry and warm for you folks!  i picked up Jez of the Autobots last 
night from SFO and we met up with B-Smarter from Seattle.  these guys are 
dope and i can promise you only the banginest beats tonight!

good vibes.  good people.  good beats.  it'sssss....tasty!  see you there!

Evil Breaks presents: DIRTY
Friday November 12th, 2004
Jelly's (295 China Basin Wy @ pier 50)
9pm - 3am
$7 before 11pm / $10 after


The Autobots in their first ever west coast appearance. With a special 
outside DnB
room hosted by the Subscience crew with live fire dancers, free cd's, vinyl,
stickers and more.....


The Autobots (Broke/Skuff/TCR/Passenger/Botchit) - UK

The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez. Before the start of the 
Autobots
project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom has 
produced over
40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been promoting dance 
events
since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly new to the breaks scene, 
they
have had releases on almost every major breaks label, they've toured all 
around the
world, and their tracks can be found in the boxes of quite a few of the 
biggest
names in the business. Don't miss them on their first ever west coast 
appearance.


Evil Breaks room:

Ripple (Subscience)
B-Smarter (www.Sparxx.us/Equalize Ent/Virus Breaks) - Seattle, WA
Aaron Jae vs Athena (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks/the Nubotz)
Bam vs Influence (Evil Breaks/in Tha Mix)

Subscience DnB room:

Method One (Method-One.com)
Arson (Urban Drums/www.594Apparel.net)
The Hitmen (Subscience)
Doubleday (Swatchdog Recordings)


Located at Jellys (295 China Basin Wy) this event will be going strong from 
9pm - 3am.
$7 before 11pm and $10 after that.

more info: www.EvilBreaks.com

	In Ohio, pressure has already resulted in Republican Secretary =
of =20
State Ken Blackwell announcing a conference on election law to =20
recommend changes in election procedure to the legislature. But he is =20=

trying to shut out alternative parties, and what about getting the =20
truth about what happened in *this* election, such as Michael =20
Badnarik's name being blacked out by election workers in one Ohio =20
precinct (see letter from Ohio Libertarian Party executive director =20
below), not to mention the possibility that the vote was hacked on a =20
national level? The letter below includes Blackwell's phone number and =20=

email address. Let's add our voices to the public feedback he is =20
getting.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>



Badnarik Challenges Election Results
Blackwell Announces Conference

=A0=A0=A0=A0 We have just received wonderful news, and I want to share =
it
with you as soon as possible.

=A0=A0=A0=A0 Multiple citizen activist groups have joined together to
protest the management of this year's election.=A0 Just yesterday,
Michael Badnarik and David Cobb issued a challenge to the Ohio
Secretary of State Ken Blackwell.=A0 This challenge was headline news
on Ohio public radio and the Columbus Dispatch.=A0
See this link:=A0

http://www.dispatch.com/news-story.php?story=3Ddispatch/2004/11/12/=20
20041112-B1-00.html&rfr=3Dnwsl

=A0=A0=A0=A0 No one thinks this will change the outcome of the election, =
but
we are, instead, focusing on the inherent unfairness of our current
election laws in Ohio. We have received scattered reports of
intimidation, fraud, and official counting errors.=A0 In one precinct,
Michael Badnarik's name was actually blacked out by election
workers.=A0 Many voters stood in lines for hours.

=A0=A0=A0=A0 We are demanding change.=A0 We want votes to be counted =
promptly
and fairly in a transparent and easily accountable system.=A0 We want
to end the restriction of only allowing Democrats and Republicans to
work the polls (independents cannot be poll workers in Ohio).=A0 We
demand that the Libertarian Party be recognized for what it truly
is, a political party.=A0 We demand equal and fair ballot access
requirements for all political parties and independents.

=A0=A0=A0=A0 If you are an Ohio Voter, we encourage you to attend the =
public
meetings which has been called for this weekend: Saturday November
13, 1-4 PM New Faith Baptist Church, 955 Oak Street, Columbus, Ohio =20
43205 and
Monday November 15, 6-9 PM, Auditorium (Meeting Room A), Courthouse,
373 S. High St. Columbus, OH

=A0=A0=A0=A0 Under this tremendous pressure from citizen activists,
Secretary of State Ken Blackwell has announced a Post-Election
Conference on Election Law to recommend necessary changes to the
legislature.=A0 This conference is scheduled for January.=A0

=A0=A0=A0=A0 We urgently need your help to continue the pressure.=A0 His =
phone
number is: 614-466-2585 and his email is: election@sos.state.oh.us

=A0=A0=A0=A0 We are asking that you politely, yet firmly, demand that =
the
Libertarian Party be given a seat at Ken Blackwell's Post-Election
Conference.=A0 If you can help us by making a financial contribution,
the funds will be well spent.=A0 This is our contribution link:=A0
http://www.lpo.org/Contribute/LPOGoals.shtml

=A0=A0=A0=A0 With your help, we will continue to fight for all our =
rights.

In Liberty,
Robert Butler
Executive Director
Libertarian Party of Ohio

> 
> The Autobots are Huddersfield based Tom & Jez. Before the start of the 
> Autobots
> project in 2002, they were both veterans of the dance scene, Tom has 
> produced over
> 40 drum and bass releases since 1992, while Jez has been promoting 
> dance events since the late 1980's. And although they are fairly new 
> to the breaks scene, they have had releases on almost every major 
> breaks label, they've toured all around the world, and their tracks 
> can be found in the boxes of quite a few of the biggest names in the 
> business. Don't miss them on their first ever west coast appearance.

1/100,000,000.  Statewide vs. national.

fraud did occur.  If evidence does arise, someone gets charged with a fellony. 
Perhaps voting reform will become a priority so that everyone's vote, for any
candidate, does indeed count.

Sorry eveyone I have been in the field all day and
havn't been able to email. I just got home and had
another call from Jeff Fisher. 

Basically he said that the DNC got ahold of him and
didn't know about the voting irregularity numbers. He
spoke with Al Sharpin and a few other high end peeps.
They assigned him a lawyer to help and put him in a
safe place to work this out. 

Jeff said to keep the phone call, faxes, emails, etc.
flooding in. I guess that's all we can do at this
point. If we can flood the politions with requests
then maybe this will actually work. I am expecting an
email or phone call again later this
afternoon/evening. I will forard an email if I get one
or just relay the phone call. 

PLEASE KEEP THE DEMAINDS GOING OUT!!!

Here is is web address with instructions on what to
do.

http://www.jefffisherforcongress.com/

=)

Matt

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr... Investigate the Election Results

Matt,

	I definitely agree about the untrustworthiness of the media, and the 
New York Times is more pro-government than most. Nevertheless, it's 
hard to dispute the conclusions of these two articles. After previously 
distributing allegations of vote fraud I received from Apollo on this 
list and other sources elsewhere, and being inclined to believe that 
Bush or his supporters stole the election, after reviewing further 
information I no longer believe that the evidence warrants such a 
conclusion.

	On the other hand, an investigation couldn't hurt. You can never have 
too much transparency in the voting process, and I know that there were 
lots of problems, even if the national vote wasn't hijacked for Bush. 
If you want to give more than lip service to such efforts, you can 
contribute here to help the Libertarian and Green parties' joint effort 
to force a recount in Ohio: https://badnarik.org/ (include "for Ohio 
recount" in the phone or email address line if you do not wish to make 
a general donation). Press release on recount project follows.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
November 11, 2004

POC:
Blair Bobier, Cobb Campaign -- 541.929.5755 or 414.364.1596
Stephen Gordon, Badnarik campaign 256-227-8360 or
communications@badnarik.org


PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES TO DEMAND OHIO RECOUNT

David Cobb and Michael Badnarik, the 2004 Green and Libertarian
presidential candidates, today announced their joint intent to secure
a recount of presidential ballots cast in Ohio.

"Due to widespread reports of irregularities in Ohio's voting
  process, we are compelled to demand a recount of the Ohio
  presidential vote," the two candidates said in a joint statement.
  "Voting is at the heart of the American political process and its
  integrity must be preserved. When Americans stand in line for hours
to exercise their right to vote, they need to know that their votes
will be counted fairly and accurately. We are acting to protect the
rights of the people of Ohio, and the rights of all Americans. Public
trust in the democratic process is at stake."

The candidates also demanded that Ohio Secretary of State Kenneth
Blackwell, a Republican who chaired the Ohio Bush campaign, recuse
himself from the recount process.

Ohio's election proceedings were marred by numerous press and
independent reports of voter intimidation, mis-marked and discarded
ballots, problems with electronic voting machines and
disenfranchisement -- apparently by design -- of African-American
voters. A number of citizen and voting rights organizations will hold
hearings this Saturday in Columbus, Ohio to give an airing to, and
investigate, these claims.  The hearings will be held from 1-4 p.m.
at the New Faith Baptist Church, 955 Oak Street. Voters, poll
workers, journalists and voting experts are invited to testify. A
second hearing will be held on Monday at a location to be announced,
from 6-9 p.m.

The Badnarik and Cobb campaigns are in the process of raising the
required fee, estimated at $110,000, for securing a complete recount.
The campaigns are accepting contributions through their web sites.
The Badnarik-Campagna website is http://www.badnarik.org. The
Cobb-LaMarche website is http://www.votecobb.org.

Throughout this election cycle, the Cobb and Badnarik campaigns have
worked together in a spirit of cooperation and civility rarely found
in electoral politics. The campaigns jointly participated in and/or
sponsored a series of independent debates, and the two candidates
were arrested together in St. Louis protesting their exclusion from
the restricted, two-party corporate-sponsored "debates." Now, as the
election results remain in question, Michael Badnarik and David Cobb
are proud to once again act together on behalf of the rights and
interests of the American people in reaching the truth.

-30-
385 words


References:

For an article detailing a dozen ways in which the Ohio vote was
potentially manipulated, see
http://www.freepress.org/departments/display/19/2004/810

To see an investigative report which asserts that the Ohio vote was
improperly decided, see
http://www.tompaine.com/articles/kerry_won.php

For a firsthand account of apparent manipulation of third party
  votes, see
  http://knappster.blogspot.com/2004/11/right-before-our-eyes.html

Subject: [sfraves] Sample the Future:  Rip, mix, burn. Swap till you drop.

--=====================_1480809==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Sample the Future

      Rip, mix, burn. Swap till you drop. The music cops
      can't do a thing - it's 100 percent legal, licensed
      by the bands. The Wired CD, copyrighted for the
      21st century.

By Thomas Goetz


By nature, musicians are thieves. Nicking a bit of this
song and a lick from that one, shaping their style on
the riffs of those who came before, musicians are
experts in the art of acquisition. Woody Guthrie knew
this; he pinched melodies from Leadbelly - and let
anybody pinch him in return. The Sex Pistols knew this;
they shamelessly lifted from the New York Dolls and ABBA
(yes, ABBA) and set off a teenage riot. And James Brown
knows this; he accrued a large debt to Little Richard -
only to become the most sampled man in showbiz, with
thousands of his grunts and bridges and beats pilfered
by lesser men.

But what some call theft, others call sharing. Thanks to
sharing, there are genre-bending artists like Beck and
Prince, the mash-up legacy of Jay Z's Black Album, and
the sublime delight of Walter Murphy's "A Fifth of
Beethoven."

More: <http://wired.com/wired/archive/12.11/sample.html>




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_1480809==.ALT--

break beats will have you stuck on the dance floor with one drink raised in

http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story2
<http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story2&u=/ap/20041114/ap_on_en_mu/obi
t_odb> &u=/ap/20041114/ap_on_en_mu/obit_odb

 

Rapper O.D.B. Collapses, Dies in Studio 





30 minutes ago

 

By NEKESA MUMBI MOODY, AP Music Writer 

NEW YORK - The rap artist O.D.B., whose utterly unique rhymes, wild
lifestyle and incessant legal troubles made him one of the most vivid
characters in hip-hop, collapsed and died inside a recording studio
Saturday. He was 35. 



 <http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/041114/482/ny11611140227>
Photo
 <http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/041114/482/ny11611140227>
AP Photo 

 

 

O.D.B. had complained of chest pains before collapsing at the Manhattan
studio, and was dead by the time paramedics arrived, said Gabe Tesoriero, a
spokesman for O.D.B.'s record label, Roc-a-Fella. 

The cause of death was not immediately clear, but O.D.B. had recently
finished a prison sentence for drug possession and escaping a rehab clinic.
He would have turned 36 on Monday. 

O.D.B. - also known as Ol' Dirty Bastard, Dirt McGirt, Big Baby Jesus or his
legal name of Russell Jones - was a founding member of the seminal rap group
the Wu-Tang Clan in the early 1990s. With his unorthodox delivery -
alternately slurred, hyper and nonsensical - O.D.B. stood out even in the
nine-man Clan, which featured such future stars as Method Man, RZA and
Ghostface Killah. 

The Wu-Tang blueprint was for each member to pursue solo projects, and
O.D.B.'s were among the best. He released hit singles such as "Shimmy Shimmy
Ya" and "Got Your Money," and appeared on remixes with artists like Mariah
Carey. 

"There's nobody like him in the game," RZA told The Associated Press in an
April interview, when asked if O.D.B. could resume his career after prison.
"He's got a lot of problems he's got to iron out, of course, but as far as a
one-of-a-kind person, a one-of-a-kind artist, he's one of a generation, one
of a lifetime. He's a very rare commodity." 

But as his fame increased, so did his erratic behavior, and fans came to
expect the unexpected from O.D.B. 

When MTV News followed him around at the height of his popularity, he took
the camera crew and several of his kids (he was said to have more than a
dozen, by numerous mothers) to the welfare office - in a limousine - to get
an allotment of food stamps. 

And he received them. 

In February 1998, he crashed the stage at the Grammy Awards and hijacked a
microphone from singer Shawn Colvin (news
<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/celeb/*http:/news.search.yahoo.com/search/
news?fr=news-storylinks&p=%22Shawn%20Colvin%22&c=&n=20&yn=c&c=news&cs=nw> )
as she accepted an award, apparently upset over losing the best rap album
Grammy to P. Diddy (then known as Puff Daddy (news
<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http:/news.search.yahoo.com/search
/news?fr=news-storylinks&p=%22Puff%20Daddy%22&c=&n=20&yn=c&c=news&cs=nw>  -
web
<http://us.rd.yahoo.com/DailyNews/manual/*http:/search.yahoo.com/search?fr=w
eb-storylinks&p=Puff%20Daddy>  sites)). He complained that he spent a lot of
money for new clothes because he thought he was going to win. The rapper
later apologized. 

Over the years, he was wounded in shootings and arrested on a veritable
laundry list of charges, including menacing security officers, illegally
possessing body armor, driving with a suspended license, shoplifting and
threatening a former girlfriend. 

In 2000, after escaping a court-ordered stint in a California rehabilitation
center, authorities searched for him for a month. He was finally arrested in
Philadelphia - three days after performing in a New York City concert with
his Wu-Tang clique. 

He was sentenced in 2001 to two to four years in prison for drug possession,
plus two concurrent years for escaping from the clinic. He was released in
2003 and immediately signed with Roc-a-Fella. 

He heralded his return with a news conference alongside singer Carey - pop
fans may know him best for his memorable cameo on her hit "Fantasy,"
featuring rhymes like "me and Mariah, go back like babies with pacifiers." 

Tesoriero said O.D.B. had been working on his comeback album for more than a
year and was almost finished. 

"Russell inspired all of us with his spirit, wit, and tremendous heart,"
Roc-A-Fella founder Damon Dash said in a statement. "The world has lost a
great talent, but we mourn the loss of our friend." 

His mother, Cherry Jones, said she received the news of her son's death in a
phone call, which she called "every mother's worst dream." 


 

 

"To the public he was known as Old Dirty Bastard, but to me he was known as
Rusty. The kindest most generous soul on earth," her statement said.
"Russell was more than a rapper, he was a loving father, brother, uncle, and
most of all, son." 

(Corrects Wu-Tang to 9 members, sted 8, in 4th graf. INSERTS 1 graf after
5th pvs, 'The Wu-Tang...,' to RAISE RZA quote from end of story. SUBS 7th
graf pvs, 'When MTV...,' to ADD he arrived at welfare office in a limo.
INSERTS 1 graf after 10th pvs, 'Over the years...,' to ADD that he once
performed a concert while sought by authorities. Note contents of rapper's
name throughout. Should stand.)

generation, one
of a lifetime. He's a very rare commodity.&quot; =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p style=3D'line-height:15.0pt'><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>But as his fame
increased, so did his erratic behavior, and fans came to expect the =
unexpected
from O.D.B. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p style=3D'line-height:15.0pt'><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =

crashed the stage at the Grammy Awards and hijacked a microphone from =

had been working on his comeback album for more than a year and was =
almost
finished. <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p style=3D'line-height:15.0pt'><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>&quot;Russell =
inspired
all of us with his spirit, wit, and tremendous heart,&quot; Roc-A-Fella =
founder
Damon Dash said in a statement. &quot;The world has lost a great talent, =
but we
mourn the loss of our friend.&quot; <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p style=3D'line-height:15.0pt'><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>His mother, =
Cherry
Jones, said she received the news of her son's death in a phone call, =
which she
called &quot;every mother's worst dream.&quot; =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<table class=3DMsoNormalTable border=3D0 cellspacing=3D0 cellpadding=3D0 =

  <td width=3D"99%" valign=3Dtop style=3D'width:99.0%;padding:0in 0in =

  <p class=3DMsoNormal =

  </td>
  <td width=3D10 valign=3Dtop style=3D'width:.1in;padding:0in 0in 0in =

  <p class=3DMsoNormal =

  face=3DArial><span =

t></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style=3D'line-height:15.0pt'><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:black'>&quot;To the =
public he
was known as Old Dirty Bastard, but to me he was known as Rusty. The =
kindest
most generous soul on earth,&quot; her statement said. &quot;Russell was =
more
than a rapper, he was a loving father, brother, uncle, and most of all,
son.&quot; <o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p style=3D'line-height:15.0pt'><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack =
face=3DArial><span

Wu-Tang to 9
members, sted 8, in 4th graf. INSERTS 1 graf after 5th pvs, 'The =
Wu-Tang...,'
to RAISE RZA quote from end of story. SUBS 7th graf pvs, 'When MTV...,' =
to ADD
he arrived at welfare office in a limo. INSERTS 1 graf after 10th pvs, =
'Over
the years...,' to ADD that he once performed a concert while sought by
authorities. Note contents of rapper's name throughout. Should stand.) =
<o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

I don't want to pee in your punch bowl, but its was
Joe Biden, a Democrat, that authored and sponsored the
RAVE act.  

"Senator Joseph Biden (D-DE, sponsor) and Senator
Charles Grassley (R-IA, co-sponsor) introduced the
RAVE Act on June 18, 2002  (Biden's intro, Grassley's
intro).  Later, Senators Orrin Hatch (R-UT), Joseph
Lieberman (D-CT), and Strom Thurmond (R-SC) added
their names as co-sponsors. 

Senator Patrick Leahy and Senator Richard Durbin were
also co-sponsors, but withdrew their support and
removed their names as co-sponsors."

http://www.emdef.org/s2633/

Have fun and be safe,

The flower sermon:
Buddha=B4s disciples asked him to preach a sermon.=20
Instead of talking, he took a lotus blossom and held it out for them to=20
see.

For a long time no one said anything. Then Maha Kashyapa smiled :)

That was the beginning of Zen!

Last week, November 6, 2004 marked my 6th year of sending out the=20
calendar... Thank you for your continued support of SFRaves.org /=20
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf !!!

                      The SFRaves Calendar
   Upcoming Parties and Events in the San Francisco Bay Area

Saturday, November 13, 2004 ** Loveworks presents: FUTUREDISCO **

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Loveworks presents ~Q FUTUREDISCO ~Q ~V 11.13.04

Loveworks, the spark that has grown into an intense seven year inferno=20
combining house music, art, and cutting edge atmospherics continues it~Rs=
=20
series of monthly audiosocial experiments by immersing you in ~Q=20
FUTUREDISCO ~Q on Saturday November 13th ~R04 at their homebase~W the 111=
=20
Minna Gallery in San Francisco~Rs SOMA District.  This special event will=
=20
be homage to the roots of house music; disco in it~Rs past and present=20
forms.  In the early part of the evening, the Classics Caf=E9 will focus on=
=20
classic underground disco and the main floor will feature the sounds of=20
mutant disco, twisted disco and disco house later in the night.=20
Loveworks is proud to announce it~Rs first guest appearance by acclaimed=20
DJ and producer, DJ MFR of TRANSPORT RECORDINGS who will be lending his=20
smooth, pumping house style to the Loveworks dancefloor. Also supporting=20
MFR is Loveworks resident dj MATT VALENZ who will be harnessing the=20
rhythmic power of disco and aiming it straight at the crowd !  At the door=
=20
you will encounter a kindler, gentler guardian named TAMER who will once=20
again be serving up outfit and giving out smiles as well as guest services=
=20
by the newest member of the door team, MATT WALKER.  Your hosts for the=20
evening are NORI CASTILLO and DIANNA JACOBS who were instrumental in the=20
creation of the legendary TOONTOWN parties as well as CAREFREE DANCING,=20
the original house party at 177 Townsend.  Promoboy JIM WILLIAMS will also=
=20
be on hand to help ease you into the groove of the party !  Don~Rt forget=
=20
to join us early as the Classics Caf=E9 presents a very special event with=
=20
MEDIUM RARE MUSIC as they host a customer appreciation party for their=20
loyal patrons.  The Loveworks Classics Caf=E9 is an early evening deep dive=
=20
into the finer aspects of classic house, disco, funk, and soul that truly=
=20
kicks things off properly at 8pm and gets you ready for the serious body=20
rocking that comes later in the night.  This special evening of the Cafe=20
will feature the luscious disco rhythms of the amazing MARCELINO and a=20
special, legendary disco set by MEDIUM RARE~Rs own RON HOFFMAN.

BIO: DJ MFR DJ M.F.R. resides in San Francisco, California, U.S.A. His=20
musical history began at the early age of 18 when he began to djing in=20
Rome.  M.F.R's musical influences range from reggae, hip-hop and soul, to=
=20
classic rock and jazz. In 1990 he connected strongly with the soothing=20
sounds of soulful house music. Soon after, he began DJ'ing to express and=
=20
share his selection of deep, soothing soulful house music with others.=20
Moving to San Francisco in 1995, he immediately started playing in local=20
clubs. In recent years he has begun writing and experimenting with=20
electronic music.  In 1997 Marco together with Miguel "Migs" and Bruno=20
Ybarra started Transport Recordings, an independent label today well=20
established in the underground scene.  Currently he can be found in the=20
studio writing music ranging from deep house vocal songs and dubs, to=20
funky late night disco tracks and smooth down tempo jams A flavor for all=
=20
the dance floors.  In the recent years DJ MFR together with San Francisco=
=20
based producer Vincent Kwok started a production called "NEW MONDO". The=20
first two releases are now out on San Francisco label Eight Fifteen=20
Recordings. He can also be found spinning regularly at all of San=20
Francisco night clubs, such as: BACKFLIP "Mary's Body and Soul",=20
"Gravity", "Wet" 1015 FOLSOM "Release", "Heavy Rotation", RUBY SKYE "DRY",=
=20
"Discover", "Square" , SKYLARK "Sundays" 550 BARNAVALD "Stompy", UP&DOWN=20
CLUB, THE TOP, THE BLIND TIGER "Clique", "Electrolush", THE IRON "Opus",=20
BASE "Here&Now","Pure", THE GALAXY "Fame", "5150", MANHATTAN LOUNGE=20
"Scuba" , 111 Minna "Oxygen", "Atmosphere", DNA lounge "Family Funktion"=20
any many other..  DJ MFR has traveled the world headlining events in=20
cities such as Vancouver, Rome, Florence, LA, Seattle, Miami, Nashville=20
etc.... MFR also just released his hot new mix CD, WEST COAST EXCURSIONS=20
on Transport: http://www.transportrecordings.com/ . Check out a sample of=
=20
his sound online at: http://www.djcode.net/mfr.asp ( click on the MP3 Mix=
=20
button ! )

Loveworks Resident DJ Bio: MATT VALENZ In a world overtaken by automation=
=20
and technology, soul can be a hard thing to come by.  For someone lucky=20
enough to be raised on the sounds of Earth Wind & Fire, Kool and the Gang,=
=20
Diana Ross, and Tower of Power, being soulful comes as second nature. At=20
17 he was turned onto vinyl and was soon playing Miami bass, freestyle,=20
and primitive house at small underground parties in the central California=
=20
area, then moved on to start a career in the music business when he=20
relocated to San Francisco at age 21.  He continued his drive to learn=20
every aspect of the industry, and returned a few years ago from a two year=
=20
stay in England where he was the booking manager for dy-na-mix agency, the=
=20
best agency for underground music in Europe. Now, back in that city, he is=
=20
resident at ~Q Loveworks Dancing ~Q, a mobile house music phenomenon=20
focusing on vibe, music, and art.  past guests such as Doc Martin, Joi=20
Cardwell, J. Sinister, DJ Diz, and international guests like the UK's=20
Eddie Richards, A Man Called Adam, and Terry Francis have also helped to=20
establish the party as a premier place for true house music, funk, soul,=20
and classics in the bay area.  He continues to play at the some of San=20
Francisco's best parties and is currently assembling a personal studio.

Loveworks Resident DJ Bio: DAVID HARNESS In 1990, David began DJ'ing in=20
his hometown of Monterey, California, at the After Dark. As his popularity=
=20
grew past the boundaries of Monterey, he was invited to establish a=20
residency at Tilt, and Sound Factory, in San Francisco. In 1992, as=20
David's popularity continued to grow he, along with DJ, Ruben Mancias and=
=20
promoter Joseph Solis opened a hip and popular club, Lift, at Club Dv8.=20
David joined Bay Area legendary DJ, Pete Avila and host Foxxee Brown on=20
'Your Mama's House', on the Bay Area's popular radio station KMEL FM.=20
Being the only "true" house mix show on any Northern California radio=20
station, DJ's David Harness, Pete Avila and host Foxxee Brown have played=
=20
a key role in furthering House Music in the Bay Area. Also during that=20
year, David established a residency at San Francisco's legendary Club=20
Universe. David Harness has quickly become one of the most well known and=
=20
popular DJ's in the San Francisco Bay Area club scene. David's popularity=
=20
continued to soar, taking him around the world; and the opportunity to=20
play with New York's Legendary DJ's, Frankie Knuckles, Tony Humphries,=20
Little Louie Vega, Tedd Patterson, Dave Morales, London's Ricky Morrison,=
=20
Danny Teneglia, Marques Wyatt- to name a few. He has appeared in articles=
=20
and interviews in Billboard Magazine, Paper Magazine, Surface, XLR8R, Urb,=
=20
Streetsounds, Sweater, HX, Next and the Bay Guardian.


Bio: LOVEWORKS Add a large helping of deep underground house music with a=
=20
side of funk, a heap of disco, and a hint of techno, and you have the most=
=20
nutritious dancefloor experience available in San Francisco. Initially=20
conceived by Dianna Jacobs and Nori Castillo of Toontown / Carefree fame=20
in the summer of '96, Loveworks was envisioned as a refuge from the=20
monotony of local clubs and superficial music, and has become one of the=20
bay area's most well known nights out, while somehow remaining one it's=20
best kept secrets.  It exists to unite people of any race, social status=20
or sexuality together in a comfortable and friendly club environment with=
=20
music as the focal point, and in addition to it's monthly parties at the=20
Minna Gallery, Loveworks also teams up with other like minded parties=20
around the city and has been featured at clubs and parties such as Liquid,=
=20
the Top, Electric, and the Endup.  Besides late night dancing, Loveworks=20
has also been involved in events for Wired Magazine, Apple Computer, Sony=
=20
Digital, Construct Internet Design, and a host of others. Loveworks also=20
had the honor of winning the SF Bay Guardian~Rs ~Q BEST HOUSE CLUB ~Q in=20
1999.

Bio: 111 MINNA GALLERY 111 Minna Gallery is a dynamic ~Qcontemporary art=20
salon~R that provides an arena for multi-dimensional artistic expression=20
in a community atmosphere. The goal of the ~Qgallery-as salon~R concept is=
=20
to nurture and support a communal gathering of artists and a collaboration=
=20
between diverse art forms. This goal is achieved through six-week=20
rotations of visual art exhibitions curated by the staff combined with a=20
variety of music and film events. ~QMinna~R is not only the name of the=20
street on which the gallery is found but also translates from Japanese as=
=20
"everybody," an all-inclusive term that symbolizes the embracing=20
environment of the space. The gallery, which also offers two bars, is=20
crafted in an eclectic, contemporary design with ample furniture inviting=
=20
guests to leisurely relax and enjoy conversation among friends. The=20
combination of art, music, film, dance and conversation found at 111 Minna=
=20
Gallery creates a unique gathering place for a multi-sensory experience.

( contact: Nori for information and guest list questions / 866 841 9139=20
ext 2016 / loveworksdancing@onebox.com.  Check the website at=20
www.loveworksdancing.com )

Saturday, November 20, 2004 ** Mind Control **

***Mind Control*** A celebration to the life and love of Chris Vierra; the=
=20
west coast breakbeat monster?br> December 10, 1976 - July 14, 2004. San=20
Francisco, California 8pm til 4am, 2 rooms 18+, 2 full bars for the 21+=20
Admission $10 100 % of the proceeds will be donated to Chris~Rs family.=20
Sound by Summit Sessions and E.A.R. Lasers by UV99 Otherworldly=20
transformations by ill behavior. Your hosts for the evening;

BREAKS FACTORe 20k Freaks / Afterdark / Supercharged UK

The U.S. ascension of FACTORe is often attributed to his custom blend of=20
impeccable studio skills, charismatic performances on the decks, and the=20
business savvy that has made his record label, 20k freaks the first true=20
transatlantic label to offer duel pressings and releases in both the U.S.=
=20
and the U.K. simultaneously. His collaborative efforts with the Autobotz,=
=20
Aquasky vs Masterblaster, Backdraft,Breakfasterz, Deep Impact, and Panic=20
Room account for just a taste of his over 60 releases to date. Being tied=
=20
to crews like Supercharged UK, Breaks Poll~Rs pick for .1 breakbeat label=
=20
in ?3, and his tracks charted by the likes of Krafty Kuts, Skool of=20
Thought, Monk, Icey, and Aquasky vs Masterblaster; FACTORe has undoubtedly=
=20
captured the pulse of today~Rs brokenbeat and served it back to us on a=20
vinyl plate.

GREG J funky cactus recordings / sktratchmatics / kidbippy.com DJ CHAMP=20
wcg productions / djchamp.com ERIC RIGGSBEE breakthru sf / mirage kru=20
AARON JAE evil breaks / aaronjae.com / nubotz T.I.T.S aka TAMIM ill=20
behavior / back2back / t.n.t KRIME and PUNISHMENT kris kent vs justin f /=
=20
ill behavior DJ CHUCK stylus

HOUSE

/ terratraxx.com TORQUE 92.7 party TWINK electric funk / t.n.t GARRETT=20

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

Not only do we have LA County Prosecutor Marcia Clark, she of Susan
Wagner High School Class of '71, best known as the dropper of the OJ
Simpson ball, and Jeb Stuart Magruder, of Watergate fame, from there,
we also have Emilio Estevez and ugh, Christina Aguilera both being
born there, and, now, there's this.

It's a sad day.

These things usually come in threes, and with Arafat gone as well, I
was kind of surprised to hear that our beloved and esteemed Vice
President made it out of the hospital yesterday, guess it's just
another example of how some prayers are answered and some ain't.
