Subject: [sfraves] Lastnight: Anu, Cloudfactory, & Evil Breaks.... Wow... what a NIGHT!

OK... so like it was OK.. Wow.. LoL. such a fun night...

I went 2 the City 2 hook up w/ Delia.. got 2 Anu
early... met Farmboy!!!  Hella CoL Dude!  YAY.. Darren
(sp) showed up not 2 long after that... YAY... then
like Calamity Jane cmae in, dropped this really Awesome
chill, down tempo, oldie set!!  Ooooh my gosh man...
Pretty IN Pink!!! YAAAAAAY!!!

OK.. Koroma showed up w/ Mina... Hello 2Day... he took
me 2 dinner.. Thanks 4 the Mondo Grubs Koroma!!!  YAY!!
 oh oh oh.. alota people endedup showing up!!  It was
Dope!!!  But around like 9:45, we cut out 2 go 2 the
Scorpios shindig...

Gianni.. sorry I didn't stay 4 your set Dude... I still
owe U a hug homie!  We gotta hang out like mondo soon
man.. seriously!  I miss U G!

So we got 2 OW around like 10:30... man.. all i gotta
say was WOW.. it was fuckin' amazing being back w/ the
CF crew again.. I missed them sooooooo much!!!

Sets: Nico was fuckin Sick w/ techno set!!  I Loved him
rockin' out behind the decks!!!  Sabin was Dope... he
spun this like IDM turned Jungle set!!  It was So Dope
'cause i don't rememberhim spinning Jungle... OK.. Ki
was Dope!!  OH my gosh man.. his hair os GONE now..
Hello 2Day... he did a similiar set like Sabin... kinda
IDMish (I think) or maybe like micro housish turned
Jungle also...

I dunno.. there were alota DJs who I wasn't sure who
they wre who spun house, Gothy tunes, ummm... hmmmm...
that's all i really remember... but the music was
primo... there was a 2nd room w/ just chill music!!=20
NICE!!

It was fun.. it was Dope hangin' w/ Family!!  YAY!!

Evil Breaks.. although it was close by & Delia & I were
gonna walk there... we kinda didn't make it.. LoL..
next time.. i swear!

It was a good night though!!  I was really happy w/ how
things happened & people I saw!  YAY!!  Love U all!

Take Care
Peace=3D->O=A7bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Recording.org


http://www.recording.org

For those with an interest in recording, mixing, professional audio and 
production, here's a site with forums that cover topics such as:

Forums: http://www.recording.org/modules.php?name=Forums

pro audio equipment, recording studio electronics, hardware, gear used for 
recording music.

Recording Studio
micing, tracking, mixing & editing music, tips and techniques in the 
recording studio

Recording Studio
micing, tracking, mixing & editing music, tips and techniques in the 
recording studio

Audio Video Film
pre and post production tips and techniques. avid, final cut, adobe. voice 
overs, commercials, making movies, music video's and more.

Music Business
indie music, record deals, labels, getting signed, music contacts, 
publishing, marketing, etc.

Acoustics & Design
A rack full of great gear is useless if your studio and control room 
acoustics are inadequate. Get the real facts.

Vocal Booth
The art of recording the voice, proper use of the microphone and how to 
get the best out of vocal talent in production.

Pro Audio REVIEWS!
Recording gear reviews on preamps, compressors, EQ's Mic's, monitors and 
other pro audio equipment. See: RO Reviews for monthly articles.

DAW's & Computing
Setting up your (DAW) "digital audio workstation". tips and techniques.

Digital Audio Recording
Digital audio tracking, mixing, editing. daw plug-in , software and 
hardware. Direct recording and more...

Digital Audio Recording
Digital audio tracking, mixing, editing. daw plug-in , software and 
hardware. Direct recording and more...

 	Budget Gear
a place where we discuss low cost and down right cheap new or used 
recording hardware, budget gear that can still get the job done. preamps, 
compressors, eq's, mics, prossessors & more...

AUDIO PROJECTS
Indie musicians, streaming, critique etc.

 	Creating Music
Song Writing Construction: composing, arranging and producing.

Sound and Rhythm
In the studio with drums, percussion, keyboards and MIDI

Job Postings etc
music business only

La Paix,

Karina

Subject: [sfraves] RIP:   John Balance

--=====================_2969730==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


We are greatly saddened to have to you that at about 5.30 pm Saturday Nov 
13th, John Balance, was killed in an accident at home.

Under the influence of alcohol he fell from the first floor landing, 
hitting his head on the floor some 15ft below.

Peter/Sleazy who was in the front room heard the noise, came out 
investigate and found him unconscious, though still breathing.

Balance was rushed to hospital, where his condition deteriorated, and he 
died soon after, without ever regaining consciousness.

There is no suggestion that this event was in any way deliberate, in fact, 
anything other than a tragic accident.

Unusually, Balance had been cheerful during the day, and was looking 
forward to seeing Ian at the weekend, and working on new recordings this week.

* * *

Our awareness that physical death is not an end, but merely a transition to 
a whole different part of existence, a new adventure, should by now be 
clear to everyone.

Jhonn has simply crossed over the Threshold...

As Thomas Olson wrote this morning: "Listening to some Coil songs now, and 
they are all sounding to me now as if they were written for this moment...."

Nevertheless the parting will be hard for us all. Fortunately there is much 
to be done that will keep us busy in the next few difficult weeks.

When we have more details we will post them.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_2969730==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] mean part 2: the legacy nrr

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:

"did you see it yet?"
"see what?"
"the other mean part?"
"yes, i did. there's more too."
"really? where?"
"down there. just scroll down a little farther. do you
see it?"
"oh my god!!!!!!!!!! that was hell of mean! what about
the next one?"
"i don't know yet, i am bored."
"me too." :)

for those not in the know, john balance was one of the founding
members of throbbing gristle, and later: coil.  coil was one of

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:

> 
> We are greatly saddened to have to you that at about 5.30 pm
> Saturday Nov 
> 13th, John Balance, was killed in an accident at home.
> 
> Under the influence of alcohol he fell from the first floor
> landing, 
> hitting his head on the floor some 15ft below.
> 
> Peter/Sleazy who was in the front room heard the noise, came
> out 
> investigate and found him unconscious, though still
> breathing.
> 
> Balance was rushed to hospital, where his condition
> deteriorated, and he 
> died soon after, without ever regaining consciousness.
> 
> There is no suggestion that this event was in any way
> deliberate, in fact, 
> anything other than a tragic accident.
> 
> Unusually, Balance had been cheerful during the day, and was
> looking 
> forward to seeing Ian at the weekend, and working on new
> recordings this week.
> 
> * * *
> 
> Our awareness that physical death is not an end, but merely a
> transition to 
> a whole different part of existence, a new adventure, should
> by now be 
> clear to everyone.
> 
> Jhonn has simply crossed over the Threshold...
> 
> As Thomas Olson wrote this morning: "Listening to some Coil
> songs now, and 
> they are all sounding to me now as if they were written for
> this moment...."
> 
> Nevertheless the parting will be hard for us all. Fortunately
> there is much 
> to be done that will keep us busy in the next few difficult
> weeks.
> 
> When we have more details we will post them.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101: 
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> 
> "The government, which was designed for the people, has got
> into the hands 
> of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An
> invisible 
> empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
> 
> "There are times when you have to obey a call which is the
> highest of all, 
> i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may
> cost many a 
> bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from
> family, from the 
> state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as
> dear as life 
> itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
>    Gandhi
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are
> ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> gradually become 
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> 
> 
>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Electronic dub?

by "electronic dub", are you referring to stuff done by current
EDM artists?

there's quite a number of good compilations out there, notably
the stuff on the guidance label.  jack dangers and ben stokes
have done some real good stuff with their tino corp project:
check out the last two volumes of "tino's breaks" (#4 and 5).

groups like thievery corp, dzihan + kamien, kruder +
dorfmeister, boozoo bajou, etc have done dub remixes.

there was some stuff that bill laswell (of material) did called
"ambient dub" back in the mid 90s.  look up "divination" - i
know of two volumes.

there's also illbient dub:  check out "sub dub" for that...

that's all i can think of of the top of my head - i'm at work
right now.  email me back later, and i'll see what else i have
at home.

m

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0411151505510.4162-100000@gere.odin.pdx.edu>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: Electronic Dub

quoth Sean G:
> Hey there was some mention of 'electronic dub' on this list a minute
> ago ... and after a conversation with a chum of mine, I'm more
> intrigued. I've never heard this kind of music before? Someone
> mentioned 'Deadbeat'...

Deadbeat is one of the better known artists on Germany's ~scape label.
His latest LP, "Something Borrowed, Something Blue" is very
representative of the "electronic dub" sound. Pretty much everything
else on the label has some sort of dub influence.

> are there any other artists in this genre I should know about? Any
> places I can purchase (or download) this music to get a feel for it?

Other artists to look out for on ~scape are Burnt Friedman, Jan Jelinek
and Bus (Daniel Meteo and Tom Thiel). Meteo's own label, Meteosound,
recently released a various artists EP (on both 12" and CD) called
"Hitek" that has lots of great stuff on it, including a Monolake remix
of Apparat's "Steinholz" and a track by The Orb's Thomas Fehlmann.

Any discussion involving the words "electronic" and "dub" would be
incomplete without mention of Basic Channel, the German duo that put
Berlin dub on the map. They're at their dubbiest when they record as
Rhythm & Sound with reggae vocalists like Tikiman and Cornell Campbell.
They pressed 10" EPs with both a vocal and an instrumental which are
becoming increasingly rare, but they also recently released 12" and CD
compilations of the vocal and instrumental versions separately.

Other labels (and artists, in parens) to look out for include:

Zer0 G Sounds (Triton, GYS, Localfields)
Mosaic (Steve O'Sullivan, Bluetrain)
Background (Portable)
Contexterrior (Jay Haze, Ricardo Villalobos)
Atavisme (Pepe Bradock)
Force Tracks (Swayzak, Dub Taylor, Crane AK, MRI, Luomo)
Echochord (Mikkel Metal, DJ Daniel)
Mille Plateaux (the Clicks & Cuts compilations are amazing)

I've found a lot of this stuff at Amoeba in SF, but most of it I buy
online. Forced Exposure and Bent Crayon are both in the US, so the
turnaround is nice and quick, but you'll have better luck finding old
stuff at either Hard Wax in Berlin or Kompakt in Cologne. Unfortunately,
NONE of them have samples online. :(

<http://www.forcedexposure.com/>
<http://www.bentcrayon.com/>
<http://www.hardwax.com/>
<http://www.kompakt-net.de/>

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) H.L. Mencken's vision coming to pass?

	Someone just sent this timely quote from H.L. Mencken, one of the 
great journalists of the 20th century:

"As democracy is perfected, the office of president represents, more 
and more closely, the inner soul of the people.  On some great and 
glorious day the plain folks of the land will reach their heart's 
desire at last, and the White House will be adorned by a downright 
moron."

-H.L. Mencken (1880 - 1956)

	Mencken understood that the United States was set up as a republic, 
not a democracy, and clearly understood some of the problems with the 
latter form of government.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

explain my recent D&B record shopping spree - I had to buy that sorta stuff 
cuz I never hear it played out).

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Ode to an Ol' Dirty Bastard

--=====================_2972894==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Ode to an Ol' Dirty Bastard
He left behind a violent legacy and possibly a dozen children. But the 
Wu-Tang Clan rapper also helped forge an irresistible 
pan-Asian-ghetto-gangsta style.

- - - - - - - - - - - -
By Pete L'Official

SALON.COM (PAID SUB)

Nov. 16, 2004  |  Outrageous. Unpredictable. Deranged, possibly. 
Irresponsible, certainly. But I don't care what anybody says. Ol' Dirty 
Bastard was avant-garde as hell.

"Avant-garde" was originally a military term, referring to an advanced 
group forging an assault on the enemy ahead. And O.D.B., whose given name 
was Russell Tyrone Jones, and his fellow members of the Wu-Tang Clan were 
way ahead of the rest -- a radically unique collection of some of the most 
charismatic and creative rappers ever to rhyme two lines. Their 1993 album, 
"Enter the Wu-Tang: 36 Chambers," not only did more for Timberland boots 
and black ski masks than any corporate ad campaign ever could, but put East 
Coast rap firmly back on the map, a full year before Puff Daddy and Bad Boy 
Records wrested the mike away from the West Coast's Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg and 
Suge Knight's Death Row Records.

Wu-Tang artists RZA, GZA (Robert Diggs and Gary Grice, cousins to Jones), 
Method Man, Raekwon and Ghostface, among others, went on to have solo album 
success both critically and commercially, and the Wu were among the first 
groups to get involved in the licensed hip-hop fashion bonanza with their 
label, Wu-Wear.

But what made the Wu-Tang Clan -- named in honor of the Wu-Tang school of 
sword fighting featured in the kung fu flicks so idolized by the rap 
group's members -- truly brilliant was their vibrant, irresistible 
aesthetic. Hip-hop always had its thugs, even thugs who wrote rhymes 
employing complex verse structures. But thugs who spliced arcane 
mythologies with intricately constructed, Asian-gothic beats with kung fu 
movie audio samples were a new phenomenon. Their self-mythologizing and pop 
culture referencing (preceded by Run D.M.C.'s shelltoe Adidas/gold rope 
chain aesthetic) came long before Quentin Tarantino exploited his love of 
Asian "grindhouse" cinema in "Kill Bill," Vol. 1 and 2, which were, 
incidentally, scored by the RZA.

Wu-Tang hailed from Staten Island, and the tiny, oft-forgotten part of New 
York was transformed into Shaolin Island in their pan-Asian-ghetto-gangsta 
conception. Their radio-ready aesthetic evoked the nostalgia of Saturday 
afternoons spent embroiled in heady chop-socky dramas like "Five Deadly 
Venoms" or "Shaolin Temple II." And it gave these gifted personalities 
their own individual legends, built out of a hybridized Afro-Asian folklore.

O.D.B., who died of as yet undetermined causes in a recording studio in 
Manhattan on Saturday, was an integral part of that aesthetic. Even in a 
group that featured larger-than-life personas, like the now 
near-ubiquitous(ly high) Method Man, or the GZA's labyrinthine verse 
stylings, saying that O.D.B. managed to distinguish himself is a massive 
understatement. He was called Ol' Dirty Bastard because, as stated in an 
interlude on "36 Chambers," "There ain't no father to his style."

Ol' Dirty's gold-toothed, marble-mouthed, free-associative nonsense raps 
ran in topic from not-so-subtle threats ("Do you wanna get your teeth 
knocked the fuck out?") to wistful remembrances of lost love and its 
painful aftermath ("Burn me/ I get into shit/ I let it out like diarrhea/ 
got burned once/ but that was only gonohrrea"). He wrote rhymes for the 
ladies too. Almost always playful -- which was whenever he wasn't inviting 
muthafuckas to step to him on his "Brooklyn Zoo" turf -- O.D.B. famously 
rapped, "Me and Mariah/ go back like babies with pacifiers," in a duet with 
Mariah Carey from 1995's "Fantasy" (the remixed Tom Tom Club track). O.D.B. 
also saw his biggest hit come as a result of matching his gravelly tones 
with the sweet sounds of Kelis and a showy Neptunes beat on "Got Your 
Money," off of his 1999 album, "Nigga Please."

Raw energy loosed in lyrical form, O.D.B. had no qualms about singing -- 
well, murdering -- melodies in his songs, continuing in the fine tradition 
of notoriously off-key soloist and rap legend Biz Markie. It's a tradition 
that has survived to today with Kanye West, André 3000, Mos Def and 
Pharrell Williams offering pitch-unperfect, but heartfelt, recordings.

As a performer, he was our raging, amphetamined id whose "non-style" of 
sorts reminds me of a classic James Brown lyric: "I don't know karate, but 
I know c-razy." O.D.B. knew crazy. He was the personification of the phrase 
"I just don't give a fuck" long before Eminem had any claim to it, and 
O.D.B.'s trademark growl made it OK for rapper DMX to bark his way through 
his albums, selling millions of records with each successive "Ruff, Ruff."

But such reckless disregard for any accepted conventions, especially those 
having to do with the law, will usually get you into trouble whenever you 
do step over the line. And O.D.B. was a habitual line-stepper.

In 1994, O.D.B. took MTV News cameras into a limousine with him and several 
of his kids (he was said to have more than a dozen, by numerous mothers, 
though his wife of 13 years, Icelene Jones, claims he only has three -- 
with her), and drove to a welfare office to collect food stamps.

Arrested in 1997 for failing to pay nearly a year's worth of child support 
for three children he had with his wife, O.D.B.'s rap sheet would get only 
longer. He pleaded guilty to attempted assault on his wife in 1998, then 
two months later was shot in the back in what he claimed was a robbery of 
his Brooklyn home. Later that year he was arrested for shoplifting $50 
sneakers in Virginia Beach, Va., and was charged with making "terrorist 
threats" at the House of Blues in Los Angeles.

In a wonderful media moment of raw honesty and perhaps a little 
intoxication, O.D.B. attended the 1998 Grammys and, disappointed that 
Wu-Tang lost out to Puffy for best rap album, grabbed the microphone from a 
stunned Shawn Colvin and addressed the crowd. "Please calm down," he said. 
"I went and bought me an outfit today that cost me a lot of money, because 
I figured that Wu-Tang was gonna win. I don't know how you all see it, but 
when it comes to the children, Wu-Tang is for the children. We teach the 
children. Puffy is good, but Wu-Tang is the best. I want you all to know 
that this is O.D.B., and I love you all, peace." The day before he had 
rescued a 4-year-old girl from a car wreck in Brooklyn.

Always a pioneer, O.D.B. became the first person arrested under a new 
California law that prevented convicted felons from wearing bulletproof 
vests in 1999. His legal troubles, particularly that year and beyond, were 
many -- and certainly not to be glorified or glamorized -- but he did 
manage to carry off some of these with a certain amount of panache. In 
October 2000, O.D.B. chose to escape from custody while being transported 
to court from a Pasadena, Calif., rehab center, but true to his iconoclast 
form, he didn't keep a low profile like any ol' fugitive. He not only 
recorded part of an album with RZA, but also appeared onstage to perform 
with the rest of the Clan at New York's Hammerstein Ballroom in November 
2000. He was finally arrested in the parking lot of a McDonald's in 
Philadelphia two nights later by an officer who recognized him because her 
son was a fan. He was later sentenced to two years behind bars in upstate 
New York.

Upon his release, he immediately signed with Roc-A-Fella Records and began 
work on a new album, which was nearing completion at the time of his passing.

Say what you want to say about O.D.B. He certainly would have said whatever 
the fuck he wanted to say about you. Perhaps his is a case where person and 
persona were too tightly wrapped up within one another; one certainly fed 
off the other, for better or worse. A lot of his behavior was pretty 
indefensible, but the energy and eccentricity he brought to hip-hop will be 
missed -- and nearly impossible to replace -- as a result of his tragically 
young death. He would have been 36 years old Monday.

What more can say about O.D.B., Ol' Dirty, Osirus, Joe Bannanas [sic], Dirt 
Dog, Unique Ason, Dirt McGirt, or however the matchless Mr. Jones chooses 
to refer to himself in the afterlife. My personal favorite was Big Baby 
Jesus, a name that, to questions regarding its provenance, he explained, "I 
always been Jesus. I don't know what the big secret's been all these 
years." In fact, maybe it's better to let him speak for himself one last 
time, from the intro to his first solo album, in all his proudly ignoble glory:

"My name is Mr. Russell Jones. 'Scuse me for that one, I had to let that 
one loose. Tonight, you're gonna see something that you've never seen 
before. Something that nobody in the history of rap ever set they self to 
do. This fucking guy that I speak to you about is something crazy, he's 
something insane. He's the greatest performer ever since. Uh. James Brown. 
He's bad, and he's a cool guy, and you need to really get to know him. 
Ladies and gentlemen, from all houses to all towns. From the Moon, to 
Pluto, back down to Earth. Ladies and gentlemen, one more time, give it up, 
for the Ol' Dirty Doggie. I mean, the Ol'. Dirty. Bastard. I love that guy."

Me too.

- - - - - - - - - - - -



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ~*EXPANDER*~ Jan.22nd.2005 (*NEW VENUE*/ALL AGES/$5)(XTORT) *BSP*


Ok here is not your average response to an Xtort BSP post.

How bout you do this for one of your parties.

You get all the DJ's and people on this list that bitch about your parties 
to submit a demo. And create a list of columns for the various styles that 
the DJ's play and based on the submissions you give that list of DJ names 
for the various styles to this list to vote and or choose some of the best 
submissions for those paticular styles. And there ya go you have a 
completely **NEW** lineup for your next event. I think that would stop the 
bitching of those few on this list.


I think bashing Xtort is old now cause they are not going to change there 
ways they have a simple easy party method like skillz etc.. and it works. Im 
personally done with bashing them. But I do challenge them to do a party as 
I have suggested since they have a draw and rep. They can pull it of if they 
truly wanted too.

Macadio

Subject: [sfraves] RIAA heads up

HR4077 info:
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d108:h.r.04077:


Wired article:
http://www.wired.com/news/politics/0,1283,65704,00.html

WASHINGTON -- Several lobbying camps from different industries and
ideologies are joining forces to fight an overhaul of copyright law,
which they say would radically shift in favor of Hollywood and the
record companies and which Congress might try to push through during a
lame-duck session that begins this week.

The bill lumps together several pending copyright bills including
HR4077, the Piracy Deterrence and Education Act, which would
criminally punish a person who "infringes a copyright by ... offering
for distribution to the public by electronic means, with reckless
disregard of the risk of further infringement." Critics charge the
vague language could apply to a person who uses the popular Apple
iTunes music- sharing application.

The bill would also permit people to use technology to skip
objectionable content -- like a gory or sexually explicit scene -- in
films, a right that consumers already have. However, under the
proposed law, skipping any commercials or promotional announcements
would be prohibited. The proposed law also includes language from the
Pirate Act (S2237), which would permit the Justice Department to file
civil lawsuits against alleged copyright infringers.

[snip]

http://www.jcthedj.com
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and
causes me to tremble for the safety of my country. . . . corporations
have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places will follow,
and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong its reign by
working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is aggregated
in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-- U.S. President Abraham Lincoln, Nov. 21, 1864
(letter to Col. William F. Elkins)

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Message-ID: <BAY21-DAV2R25oMAmOF00015cf9@hotmail.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [nrr] Congress to Make Commercial Skipping Illegal (today)

------=_NextPart_000_00C0_01C4CBEA.7F73FC70
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

All:

The House has passed HR 2391, which is being considered by the Senate =
today (11/16).  Successful passage by the Senate will put this bill on =
the President's desk late this year or early next.

This bill makes it a violation of the Copyright Act to skip commercials =
using a technological means (hardware or software) -- and it makes it a =
violation to make the computer program that allows people to skip =
commercials.  You can get information on the bill here:

http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d108:h.r.02391:
http://www.publicknowledge.org/pdf/HR_2391.pdf

and you can read the Wired story on the bill here:

http://www.wired.com/news/politics/0,1283,65704,00.html

In section 212 there is an exemption IF:

(A) no fixed copy of the altered version of the motion picture is
created by such computer program or other technology; and

(B) no changes, deletions or additions are made by such computer program
or other technology to commercial advertisements, or to network or
station promotional announcements, that would otherwise be performed or
displayed before, during or after the performance of the motion
picture.';


But this seems quite abiguous and the original intent for this exemption =
is for skipping of motion picture scenes that may be deemed "obscene", =
especially when it comes to such "devices" such as home PVR systems that =
run on a computer.

My suggestion is call your Senators and Representatives and let them =
know that it is ridiculous to make it illegal for you to skip =
commercials (assuming you agree that it is).

You can reach your Senators and Representatives through the Capitol =
switchboard at (202) 224-3121 or (202) 225-3121.  Or you can email them =
by going to their web sites, which you can find through www.senate.gov =
or www.house.gov.

-=3Ddave
------=_NextPart_000_00C0_01C4CBEA.7F73FC70--

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ~*EXPANDER*~ Jan.22nd.2005 (*NEW VENUE*/ALL AGES/$5)(XTORT) *BSP*

Hey Macadio...I think that your suggestion rocks and
makes complete sense, but here's the gist of it. The
people that come to our shows ask for the lineups we
have. Of course it never hurts to throw in new
talented people, but to get rid of the core headliners
that we have would negatively affect our event. The
majority of the DJs that most of us would recommend
are ideal for an older 21+ crowd...that's going to be
problematic for our events. But we're always open so
if people take the intiative to get us the info, we'll
totally look into it.

Thanks

Sascha
XTORT: http://www.xtortproductions.cjb.net

techno is back

techno is not salvation

shazbot is ready

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP - Random Acts of Art - Wednesday Nov. 17th, 2004 @ Loft 11

	As far as art shows with a cover charge go, there's always Costco. 
They offer quite an amazing selection of art including the Campbell's 
Soup cans which inspired Andy Warhol -- now is your chance to go and 
see the real thing on the shelves for a low price in a large, bust-free 
warehouse space. They'll even loan you a classic American-style 
shopping cart (value over $100) in which to wheel around your artistic 
purchases.

	But my personal preference is Safeway. The art's slightly more on the 
high end, but they don't charge a cover, and they've already installed 
natural thunderstorm sound effects in the ambient produce section. The 
main sound system could use an upgrade and the MCs are weak as fuck, 
but perhaps this will change when they start getting real, in-store 
DJs. And get this -- they have a permit to go 24 hours.

	Perhaps someone will print this email out and take it to the Random 
Acts of Art show so that they can be aware of their competition.   8)

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>


On Tuesday, November 16, 2004, at 02:28  PM, Sean Casey wrote:

> I always think it's weird to pay cover at an art show where art is
> to be sold.

I like Xtort's parties. Sure there's a certain amount of similarity between 
one party and the next, but there are a lot of young party kids in Sac who like 
the DJs that Sascha23 books. The parties are not identical, though. It was 
cool seeing DJ Kuma from Japan not long ago, and at Xpander there will be DJ Jak 
from Portland. 

Apparently there are a lot of DJs who would like to get into the lineup ... 
but this is just one promoter all the way out in Sac ... There are tons of 
other promoters throwing other parties, and aren't there, like, dozens of 21+ 
clubs in SF you could be spinning at?  Why pick on Xtort? Maybe their parties seem 
more noticeable because they're promoted well in advance, they occur pretty 
frequently, and the flyers have a similar look.
I thought Macadio's idea for getting new DJs was a good one. If Sascha goes 
for it, I hope these DJs attract a good crowd. We might find out that the Sac 
kids do indeed like Breaks or some other style they're not hearing now. 



--part1_9a.19accf58.2ecbfcee_boundary--

SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Googlism: SFRaves

The funny thing about Googlism, is the algorithm they use to search pages 
returns results from Documents on web sites across the WWW:

Googlism is not affiliated with Google, but powered by Google Search 
Results.  In effect, all of these phrases are taken from pages on the web 
that were randomly indexed by Google's robot and spiders.

From: http://www.googlism.com/about.htm

Explanation of technologies:

Who  	The Googlism.com concept was conceived by Paul Cherry and 
creatively programmed by Chris Morton. Googlism.com is in no way 
affiliated, sponsored or in any way the property of, or responsibility of 
Google.com (Google Inc). However, we do use Google.com for creating our 
exciting and funny results. If you have any comments, suggestions or 
otherwise, please contact us at mailto:support@googlism.com Googlism.com 
is owned by an Australian company Domain Active, there we go, we saved you 
the hassle of doing a whois.

What 	Googlism was created as a fun tool to see what Google "thinks" of 
certain topics and people. Of course, the results are not really Google's 
opinion, they're yours, the web site owners of the world. Within the 
Google results are thousands of your thoughts and opinions about thousands 
of different topics, people, names, things and places, we simply search 
Google and let you know what website owners think about the name or topic 
you suggested.

When 	The Googlism idea was formulated in September 2002 and developed 
that month for a world wide release in early October 2002. Welcome to 
Googlism.com, what are your Googlisms? NEWS! Sometime early January 2004, 
Google.com adopted measures to prevent Googlism.com from querying the 
Google servers to find new Googlisms. We are not upset, due to the immense 
popularity of Googlism.com, we were requesting an average of 15,000 unique 
queries a day. We have just over 1.7 million unique Googlisms in total and 
since opening we served around 16 million total searches, or an average of 
35,000 searches per day.

Where 	Googlism.com has received links from thousands of webmasters and 
websites all around the world. We have had online reviews in PCMag.com, 
About.com, ZDNet.com, and many more. Print articles in worldwide magazines 
and newspapers, including one book that we know of. There are a couple of 
pages about Googlism in "Google Hacks - 100 Industrial-Strength Tips and 
Tricks" By Tara Calishain and Rael Dornfest.

<3 Karina

If you search Google for the exact phrase, "sfraves is pretty much the 
only resource for current dance music events in the bay area"

http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=sfraves+is+pretty+much+the+only+resource+for+current+dance+music+events&btnG=Google+Search

I didn't find a page with that exact result, so the search they use might 
include other pages from a larger index of web site collections, but 
interestingly enough, first hit / Result has this URL is indexed - The 
Best of Bay, 1999 Awards, which Hyperreal/SFRaves won an award for
"Best Local Online Rave Resource"

http://www.bestofthebay.com/1999/enter.html

Here's the exact URL on the page: 
http://www.bestofthebay.com/1999/enter.html#rave

Keep on smiling
  -- 
************************************************************** 
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so much
in despairing of life as in hoping for another life & in eluding
the implacable grandeur of this life. -- Albert Camus --
***************************************************************

> hmmm i wonder about that ... I like SF Raves but I think a lot more people
> rely on Bayraves. Certainly sfraves is not the ONLY resource.
>
> If I was about to leave for a party and wanted to find last minute
> information, I would go to Bayraves first. I wouldn't expect to find it on sfr -- maybe
> in the olden days but not now.
> i <3  sfr though

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP - Random Acts of Art - Wednesday Nov. 17th, 2004 @ Loft 11

The $5 door price is to help recoop the cost of the venue, pay for the
catering company which is offering hors d'ouvres, and also to help pay
the winery which is offering wine tasting.... all of which cost money.

the people throwing this event are not being showcased in the art show
and i was told are not even profiting from the sales that the artists
make.  they are trying to get publicity for some local artists while
at the same time trying to recoop some of the cost to throw the event.

if you think that $5 is too much, then don't go.  



my only involvement with this event is that a friend is throwing it -
i will not even be in attendance.  the only reason i sent this
information to this list is because i thought perhaps someone on here
might be interested in it.

the $$$, but Loft 11 is so transparent about it that it sickens me...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Blocked Websites

If you have a shell account somewhere outside your firewall, you can set
up a tunnel over ssh (assuming your company allows outbound ssh
connections). "Internet access" isn't very specific, I'm assuming you mean
"web access".

That's not true is it?  They'll still be able to see
the unusual traffic (even if they can't read it) which
they may or may not decide to investigate further. 
Depends on the company and why/what they are blocking.
 

I'd suggest that if you want to keep your job you
shouldn't attempt to circumvent their blocks.  Doing
so would clearly be legal grounds for termination and
you wouldn't even be eligible for unemployment.

Just my .02 of course.

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Run out and get Half-Life 2 now :)

Just to clarify...Halo 2 is awesome,but Half-Life 2 is
officially the *BEST* adventure/FPS in the industry.
It's use of scripted storytelling and putting "you" in
the role of Gordon Freeman is untouchable and well
worth the 5 year wait.

You need a PC to play and to get decent performance
and still have lots of fun...this is what you'll need.

System Requirements : Windows 98/ME/2000/XP, AMD 1.5
or Pentium III 1.6 Ghz or better, 256MB RAM, 64MB
DirectX 9.0 video card, 12X CDROM, DirectX 9.0
compatible sound card, Keyboard, Mouse

NOW GO GO GO and game...

Sascha 
XTORT: http://www.xtortproductions.cjb.net

 sfraves@hyperreal.org
To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <20041117172750.GC23823@atari.saturn5.com>
Message-Id: <6A084E5C-38FA-11D9-A835-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Run out and get Half-Life 2 now :)

	I don't know -- the new generation of video games somehow don't do it  
for me. Admittedly I haven't played many video games for a long time,  
but the ones I got the most out of were probably Ms. Pacman, Joust,  
Tetris, etc.

	Imagine a chess game. You see the pieces in front of you and move  
them. The game mechanics are simple and right there in front of you,  
with minimal bells and whistles. Now imagine a 3-D chess game where the  
figures on the board are life-size, and you're moving around among  
them. The board has become a landscape complete with terrain features,  
birds flying around, and so on. Every move, you see the pieces walking  
around, fighting each other in elaborate battles with cool moves and  
sound effects, etc. Now say you want to have a game of chess. Both have  
been around a while, although the second one keeps getting various  
upgrades to make it slightly more exciting or realistic, so most of the  
novelty factor is gone. Which version of the game do you choose to  
play? Not necessarily the second one. Sometimes all those extras are  
beside the point. I'm kind of curious to see Halo 2 from all the hype,  
but I don't know if it's really something I'll have an urge to own and  
play regularly.

	I also think there will always be the equivalent of "movies," no  
matter how far video game or virtual reality technology eventually  
progress. In a movie, the viewer is an omnipresent god. You get the  
best view of all the action, effortlessly. You see and hear everything  
important. You don't get stuck and spend twenty minutes trying to  
figure out how to jump between buildings. Even actors like to watch  
movies and go to the theater.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Cobalt Recording Artists Live in the mix. Click the link below the boxes to 
be directed to the online mixes techno section on spins and then give them a 
listen.  Unit 21 did a live pa for Gravy FM and these guys from russia do not 
mess around.  R. V. Aggelen is from the Netherlands click on his mix and you 
will be taken into his world of production skills that are garunteed to get you 
grooving on the dance floor where ever you maybe.
To see our artist's current releases log onto www.cobaltrecordings.net.  We 
also have tracks mp3 format available on www.trackitdown.net , and soon to also 
have tracks available on www.beatport.com . 

DJ Pisces This is Cobalt Recordings in the Mix 


Unit 21 Unit 21 - Live Pa @Gravy FM 

Unit 21 This is Cobalt Mix 

RV Aggelen RV Aggelen's Live set 


Click this link for access to the music and then look for the titles above in 
the boxes and click play. 
Free Online Music and DJ Mixes @ Spins.US - Spins - Electronic and dance 
music events calendar, Internet community and inform..

 

For the latest information on releases log onto : www.cobaltrecordings.net

      This Thursday 11/18 another HUGE celebrity & his friends @ LOFT11  =

    =20

      LOFT 11 has played host to some of today biggest and most =
controversial celebrities. Prince along with "Purple Rain" cast mates =
Morris Day and Jerome took over the entire second floor for his =
"Official After-Party." Most recently, one week before her SNL lip-sync =
controversy Ashley Simpson was here taking in the San Francisco "Ultra =
Lounge" scene. This Thursday will be no exception.=20

      This is a message to our "Loyal Customers" letting you know we =
have another surprise celebrity guest possibly a few of his friends will =
be hanging out too!!!=20

      *GUEST LIST IS VERY LIMITED
      *DRESS CODE WILL BE ENFORCED

confirmation for guest list privileges)=20

YOU!! =20

Message-ID: <20041119012532.39064.qmail@web53208.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 18 Nov 2004 17:25:32 -0800 (PST)
From: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr: NOC NOC'S!!!! :)

since it's so quiet on the list, i thought i'd post one of my
favorite geri dahl emails to the list.  this one's circa 2001,
march 28 to be exact...

;)
m

--- Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com> wrote:

> now of course, when i go out, i usually just say, "hi"
> to the people i usually say "hi" to...they don't know
> how 
> i talk to myself like YOU GUYS do. i don't know what
> to call this. hey, this is my review of the past...
> whatever, 
> i'm just classifying things because it works well with
> your brain i've read: 
> 
> "so, i'm having some sort of pear ale at Noc Noc's.
> the table in front of me is extra rock-rock. i'm
> sitting on a potentially dirty mat on the floor in my
> favorite and only french dress. Shit! Alright, i am
> not sitting comfortably at all.
> 
> Lover, Lover, Lover
> Lore
> Lover, Lover, Lover
> more and more and more....
> 
> do you crave me? will you bath me
> in your
> loving, simply....
> oh this music is
> divine.........(and then i drew a big black dot on the
> page, but i can't do that here)
> 
> there are tigers
> beyond the dream
> they're running and
> running and running
> from me.
> 
> i'm so sleepy and so hurt still. i'm looking for the
> child's hand and the stars and that which i know
> exists, but is still only visible to me through those
> hands...oh, here they are...pushing forth from my
> heart, and they spread on out like a wide arc....angel
> triumphant 
> can you hear the child sing? oh, should my vision be
> brought forth to this place, i should be wildly happy
> and 
> contagiously so...please breath with me, through me
> and hesitate not to be. and now my thoughts turn
> further to cigarettes 
> and wine and miracles...and how about another glass of
> that PEAR ale...how about a little chivalry for this
> sweet girl..oh my favorite lady died, and she used to
> call 
> me sweet girl...sweet girl...sweet girl....i miss my
> grandmother like crazy. i don't need no motivation, no
> suspicion, 
> no intrigue, no searches, no being taken for granted,
> no lies. this morning, i stared into a lipid pool of
> water 
> in my mind, and i cast a  spell for an answer to ALL,
> and without hardly an effort, the answers shall come
> to me tonight.
> Sunshine, i remember the glorious sunshine from the
> day...from today.
> (okay, then i drew some stuff that i can't put here
> and underneath it, it  says:
> 
> blues band
> 
> i'm not looking forward to going outside...which way
> will i go and why and singing to a little drum 'n'
> bass is 
> going to be fine and never ever being hurt, insulted,
> raped, lied to, or being forced to witness an act of
> cruelty is SOMETHING that is so, so fine to me..so
> fine...sing the song and speak the poetry..can't wait
> till emily comes home. i also can't wait for all of
> the kisses and the heartfelt apologies and for the
> never agains to be never agains, and with that, i will
> sing and sing and sing as a servant to all until the
> day i die." 
> 
> so anyway, that's it, and also, you might want to
> listen to Thievery Corporation, cuz they make some
> good downtempo 
> shiiiiiiiit, mutha (bleep, bleep, bleep, parental
> guidance suggested cause i said a naughty word)...yez,
> i am tired. ;)  


=====

 http://redstickman.homestead.com/redstickman.html

 MP3s are back online!  click on the above link.

From: s e r a p h i m <djseraphim@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: EATS TAPES (live!) at KISS KISS this friday

Friday, Nov. 19th
Kiss Kiss at The Hush Hush Lounge!

Special Guests
EATS TAPES (live techno/electro)


along with
Mochipet
Seraphim Delush
and Forest Green with a special bleepy techno set just for this night,
11/19. =)

10PM to 2AM
$5 cover, 21+

Kiss Kiss every Friday night
@ The Hush Hush Lounge
496 14th St. @ Guerrero
San Francisco

Eats Tapes (SFBayGuardian Review)
If you need music to pump you up for a night on the town, Eats Tapes is
the answer. Bandmates and lovebirds Gregory Zifcak and Marijke
Jorritsma bring the jams to a new level of awesomeness. Their
self-titled, 14-minute CD-R EP starts off with "Supreme Master," in
which the first thing a listener hears is this unbelievably catchy, raw
E.Q. blast. It's a cute riff that's dynamically layered with bass drum,
a weird industrial dripping and banging sound, bass guitar groove, and
an all-out drum-machine dance assault that could get Muqtada Al-Sadr
tapping his toes in jubilation. "Animal Minded" is reminiscent of a
night when someone has, unbeknownst to you, dosed your drink with
hallucinogens, so that you find yourself in an alley booty-shaking with
a homeless man around a fire burning in a 50-gallon barrel. And
"Knightress" brings you full circle: you're back inside the renegade
warehouse dance fest, getting in groove with the pounding bass drum,
the blips and bleeps of the shredded E.Q., and the cheeseball hand
claps, feeling the coda  a crescendo analogous to the grand finale of
a good fireworks show. This EP can take you there. It's self-released,
so e-mail nein_oh_nein@yahoo.com to buy a copy, or better yet, catch
the duo live. (Ben Valis)

 

=====
-- 
Sarah Delush . Seraphim : www.djseraphim.com
pain in the @$$.
Sister SF . Sister USA --> Event and crew co-ordinator : www.sistersf.com . www.sisterusa.com

Message-ID: <20041119142922.38017.qmail@web21526.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 19 Nov 2004 06:29:22 -0800 (PST)
From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Music and the Brain

"Music surrounds usand we wouldn't have it any other
way. An exhilarating orchestral crescendo can bring
tears to our eyes and send shivers down our spines.
Background swells add emotive punch to movies and TV
shows. Organists at ballgames bring us together,
cheering, to our feet. Parents croon soothingly to
infants.

And our fondness has deep roots: we have been making
music since the dawn of culture. More than 30,000
years ago early humans were already playing bone
flutes, percussive instruments and jaw harps--and all
known societies throughout the world have had music.
Indeed, our appreciation appears to be innate. Infants
as young as two months will turn toward consonant, or
pleasant, sounds and away from dissonant ones. And
when a symphony's denouement gives delicious chills,
the same kinds of pleasure centers of the brain light
up as they do when eating chocolate, having sex or
taking cocaine." 


http://sciam.com/print_version.cfm?articleID=0007D716-71A1-1179-AF8683414B7F0000

> --- Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com> wrote:

>> now of course, when i go out, i usually just say, "hi"
>> to the people i usually say "hi" to...they don't know
>> how 
>> i talk to myself like YOU GUYS do. i don't know what
>> to call this. hey, this is my review of the past...
>> whatever, 
>> i'm just classifying things because it works well with
>> your brain i've read: 
>> 
>> "so, i'm having some sort of pear ale at Noc Noc's.
>> the table in front of me is extra rock-rock. i'm
>> sitting on a potentially dirty mat on the floor in my
>> favorite and only french dress. Shit! Alright, i am
>> not sitting comfortably at all.
>> 
>> Lover, Lover, Lover
>> Lore
>> Lover, Lover, Lover
>> more and more and more....
>> 
>> do you crave me? will you bath me
>> in your
>> loving, simply....

>> beyond the dream
>> they're running and
>> running and running
>> from me.
>>

>> child's hand and the stars and that which i know
>> exists, but is still only visible to me through those
>> hands...oh, here they are...pushing forth from my
>> heart, and they spread on out like a wide arc....angel
>> triumphant 
>> can you hear the child sing? oh, should my vision be
>> brought forth to this place, i should be wildly happy
>> and 
>> contagiously so...please breath with me, through me
>> and hesitate not to be. and now my thoughts turn
>> further to cigarettes 
>> and wine and miracles...and how about another glass of
>> that PEAR ale...how about a little chivalry for this
>> sweet girl..oh my favorite lady died, and she used to
>> call 
>> me sweet girl...sweet girl...sweet girl....i miss my
>> grandmother like crazy. i don't need no motivation, no
>> suspicion, 
>> no intrigue, no searches, no being taken for granted,
>> no lies. this morning, i stared into a lipid pool of
>> water 
>> in my mind, and i cast a  spell for an answer to ALL,
>> and without hardly an effort, the answers shall come
>> to me tonight.
>> Sunshine, i remember the glorious sunshine from the
>> day...from today.

Message-Id: <6.1.2.0.2.20041119125839.02aa33d8@localhost>
X-Sender: apollo@localhost
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.1.2.0
Date: Fri, 19 Nov 2004 12:59:00 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_11092129==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Canada busy sending back Bush-dodgers.

--=====================_11092129==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

The following appeared in the Columbus Dispatch on 11/16/04 written by Joe
Blundo, a Dispatch columnist.

Canada busy sending back Bush-dodgers.

The flood of American liberals sneaking across the border into Canada has
intensified in the past week, sparking calls for increased patrols to stop
the illegal immigration.

  The re-election of President Bush is prompting the exodus among
left-leaning citizens who fear they'll soon be required to hunt, pray and
agree with Bill O'Reilly.

  Canadian border farmers say it's not uncommon to see dozens of sociology
professors, animal-rights activists and Unitarians crossing their fields at
night.

  "I went out to milk the cows the other day, and there was a Hollywood
producer huddled in the barn," said Manitoba farmer Red Greenfield, whose
acreage borders North Dakota.

  The producer was cold, exhausted and hungry.

  "He asked me if I could spare a latte and some free-range chicken. When I
said I didn't have any, he left. Didn't even get a chance to show him my
screenplay, eh?"

  In an effort to stop the illegal aliens, Greenfield erected higher fences,
but the liberals scaled them. So he tried installing speakers that blare
Rush Limbaugh across the fields.

  "Not real effective," he said. "The liberals still got through, and Rush
annoyed the cows so much they wouldn't give milk."

  Officials are particularly concerned about smugglers who meet liberals near
the Canadian border, pack them into Volvo station wagons, drive them across
the border and leave them to fend for themselves.

  "A lot of these people are not prepared for rugged conditions," an Ontario
border patrolman said. "I found one carload without a drop of drinking
water. They did have a nice little Napa Valley cabernet, though."

  When liberals are caught, they're sent back across the border, often
wailing loudly that they fear retribution from conservatives. Rumors have
been circulating about the Bush administration establishing re-education
camps in which liberals will be forced to drink domestic beer and watch
NASCAR.

  In the days since the election, liberals have turned to sometimes-ingenious
ways of crossing the border.  Some have taken to posing as senior citizens
on bus trips to buy cheap Canadian prescription drugs. After catching a
half-dozen young vegans disguised in powdered wigs, Canadian immigration
authorities began stopping buses and quizzing the supposed senior-citizen
passengers.

  "If they can't identify the accordion player on The Lawrence Welk Show, we
get suspicious about their age," an official said.

  Canadian citizens have complained that the illegal immigrants are creating
and organic-broccoli shortage and renting all the good Susan Sarandon
movies.

  "I feel sorry for American liberals, but the  Canadian economy just can't
support them," an Ottawa resident said. "How many art-history majors does
one country need?"

  In an effort to ease tensions between the United States and Canada, Vice
President Dick Cheney met with the Canadian ambassador and pledged that the
administration would take steps to reassure liberals, a source close to
Cheney said.

  "We're going to have some Peter, Paul & Mary concerts. And we might put
some endangered species on postage stamps. The president is determined to
reach out."





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_11092129==.ALT--

can't
> support them," an Ottawa resident said. "How many art-history majors does
> one country need?"
>
>   In an effort to ease tensions between the United States and Canada, Vice
> President Dick Cheney met with the Canadian ambassador and pledged that
the
> administration would take steps to reassure liberals, a source close to
> Cheney said.
>
>   "We're going to have some Peter, Paul & Mary concerts. And we might put
> some endangered species on postage stamps. The president is determined to
> reach out."

Yes, the times they are a changin'

Tuesday, November 16, 2004
By Tony Norman
Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

Back in the days when this was a free country, it was possible to sing an 
antiwar song like "Masters of War" without having to give the Secret 
Service a second thought.

But 41 years after Bob Dylan recorded his elegiac, acoustically spare 
meditation on the folly of war, the lyrics are still causing trouble with 
those H.L.Mencken referred to as the "booboisie."



http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/04321/412504.stm



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_17545519==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] nrr voter fraud update

here is the latest emailed to me from jeff fisher in
florida.----------

To Commissioner Aaronson and everyone I blind copied:
Please read this email and forward this to everyone
you know.
 
Mr. Aaronson is a County Commissioner in Palm Beach,
Florida. He is a Democrat who can be reached at (561)
355-2205 or you can email him at
BAARONSO@co.palm-beach.fl.us.
 
This to inform you all that the press has been
suppressing the news regarding the recount in New
Hampshire, Ohio and the efforts we are making leading
to the possible recount of Florida's certified votes.
Ask Mr. Aaronson to lead the charge in Palm Beach
County as he is famous for fighting for Democracy even
when the odds are stacked up against it or him.   Mr.
Aaronson is well respected and treated as a hero in
the Boca Raton area and he is very good friends with
Congressman Robert Wexler and State Senator Ron Klein.
 
Last night  my  website was hacked into and I can't
access it. The website
http://www.JeffFisherforCongress was altered three
times in the past 18 hours by those hackers. The
homepage is useless. Most of the links don't work. We
also have discovered that the ElectionFraud2004 yahoo
group through its moderator has been posting messages
to the net. However, since November 16, 2004 none of
those messages have reached the Internet after being
posted. ElectionFraud2004 acts like a town center for
people who want to post suspicious incidents and
information regarding this past General Election.
 
Update to this message: 1:30 p.m. November 20, 2004,
the yahoo group, Election Fraud 2004 posted messages
finally came through the Internet. Whomever had the
capability and technology to stop the messages from
going from the yahoo server to the net withheld it for
three plus days. That is how they can stop the news
from reaching the people in a timely fashion.
 
Update to this message: 3:30 p.m. November 20, 2004,
the website is up and running with the help of David
Toppings from Arizona. Thank you. America thanks Mr.
Toppings.
 
 
That is the act of a group of people who are trying to
suppress the truth. I can't prove who they are but let
the assumptions begin. I will find another way to get
the message out. I have just begun to fight for this
nation. If you know anything about the book DUNE, then
you will understand "the sleeper has awakened".
 
Jeff Fisher
561-889-2165
 
P.S. They have hacked into Bev Harris's computer
recently at Black Box Voting and several people that I
have been consulting with in the state of Washington,
North Carolina, New York, California and Minnesota. As
of today I am getting information that blog sites are
getting hacked into also.
 
Remember, the Watergate break-in was done by a few and
it took time for that to unfold. This time we have the
Internet and if "We the People" spread the word they
won't be able to stop all of us.
 

Email message from Wake Forest University:
Is the FBI investigation something that seems like it
will take a number of
months or could they potentially have some "official"
information prior to
the final nationwide certification of the election?
 
My answer to the person from Wake Forest University:
Regarding the FBI: The possibilities [before the
Electoral College meets] are still up in the air. The
reason for any hope lies with information that Russ
Baker from The Nation told us yesterday that he
thought it was important, but he didn't have the time
or resources to investigate. In addition, Eve Conant
of Newsweek has received copies of documents from the
"sender" that confirmed my earlier statements
regarding my meeting with the sender, when I saw some
of the documents regarding the 2000 and 2002 election.
  The information that Eve Conant received backs up
the senders" statement that it was going to happen in
multiple states during the 2004 General Election. The
information Russ Baker revealed to us on November 19,
2004 was that the sender gave him a copy of several
hundred names and corresponding social security
numbers that the sender claimed were used in the
2000 election to cast votes. Today, November 20, 2004
we learned that this appears to have happened in
Precinct 16 in Kansas City, Missouri during the 2004
General Election.

The U.S. ascension of FACTORe is often attributed to his custom blend of=20
impeccable studio skills, charismatic performances on the decks, and the=20
business savvy that has made his record label, 20k freaks the first true=20
transatlantic label to offer duel pressings and releases in both the U.S.=
=20
and the U.K. simultaneously. His collaborative efforts with the Autobotz,=
=20
Aquasky vs Masterblaster, Backdraft,Breakfasterz, Deep Impact, and Panic=20
Room account for just a taste of his over 60 releases to date. Being tied=

to crews like Supercharged UK, Breaks Poll~Rs pick for .1 breakbeat label=

in ?3, and his tracks charted by the likes of Krafty Kuts, Skool of=20
Thought, Monk, Icey, and Aquasky vs Masterblaster; FACTORe has undoubtedly=

captured the pulse of today~Rs brokenbeat and served it back to us on a=20
vinyl plate.

=20
**

      On Wednesday, November 24, 2004, from 10 PM - 8 AM, the Endup will=20
host a special Thanksgiving Eve celebration that will seek to explore the=
=20
many different meanings of the word "GRACE".

      For the fifth time at the Endup, Goddessmind Productions will present=
=20
an evening of music and visual imagery that seeks to convey the various=20
definitions of ~SGRACE~T- through the elegance and beauty of the=20
atmosphere, the symmetry and harmony of the music, the ease of motion of=20
the dancers, the receiving of a gift that is unearned, the mythological=20
goddesses that spread grace, charm, and beauty in human lives, and a=20
blessing given before Thanksgiving.

      Gracing us with the music for this event will be DJs: Ellen Ferrato,=
=20
M3, and the Baroness, as well as guitarist, Jay Bowman, performing live=20
with DJs Mike Starita and Michael Anthony. ~SGRACE~Twill also feature=20

are coming together to represent the uprising of the underground in the=20
Monterey Bay!

Alex Brimsmead, and Koa will be spinning all night long.  More DJ's TBA!

=20
in helping to heal the planet will be representing.

AAVS, Earthsave, GoVeg and Action for animals will be supporting everyone=
=20
and more are on the way!

Bring your drum to join the circle out on a heated patio!

beat all night!

sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Is 'Fair Use' in Peril?

--=====================_1520906==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Is 'Fair Use' in Peril?

The far-reaching Intellectual Property Protection Act would
deny consumers many of the freedoms they take for granted.

By Eric Hellweg

November 19, 2004, technologyreview.com

http://www.technologyreview.com/articles/04/11/wo_hellweg111904.asp?trk=nl


Do you like fast-forwarding through commercials on a
television program you've recorded? How much do you like it?
Enough to go to jail if you're caught doing it? If a new
copyright and intellectual property omnibus bill sitting on
Congress's desk passes, that may be the choice you'll face.

How can this be possible? Because language that makes fast-
forwarding through commercials illegal-no doubt inserted at
the behest of lobbyists for the advertising industry-was
inserted into a bill that would allow people to fast forward
past objectionable sections of a recorded movie (and I bet you
already thought that was OK). And that's but one, albeit
scary, scenario that may come to pass if the Intellectual
Property Protection Act is enacted into law. Deliberations on
this legislation will be one of the tasks for the lame-duck
Congress that commenced this week.

In a statement last month, Senator John McCain stated his
opposition to this bill, and specifically cited the anti-
commercial skipping feature: 'Americans have been recording TV
shows and fast-forwarding through commercials for 30 years,'
he said. 'Do we really expect to throw people in jail in 2004
for behavior they've been engaged in for more than a quarter
century?'

Included in the legislation are eight separate bills, five of
which have already passed one branch of Congress, one of which
was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee, and two of
which have merely been proposed. By lumping all the bills
together and pushing the package through both houses of
Congress, proponents hope to score an enormous victory for
Hollywood and some content industries.

Here's more of what's included: a provision that would make it
a felony to record a movie in a theater for future
distribution on a peer-to-peer network. IPPA would also
criminalize the currently legal act of using the sharing
capacity of iTunes, Apple's popular music software program;
the legislation equates that act with the indiscriminate file
sharing on popular peer-to-peer programs. Currently, with
iTunes, users can opt to share a playlist with others on their
network. IPPA doesn't differentiate this innocuous-and Apple
sanctioned-act from the promiscuous sharing that happens when
someone makes a music collection available to five million
strangers on Kazaa or Grokster.

Not surprisingly, the bill has become a focal point for very
vocal parties. In favor of the legislation are groups such as
the Recording Industry Association of America, the Motion
Picture Association of America, and various songwriter, actor,
and director organizations. 'We certainly support it,' says
Jonathan Lamy, spokesperson for the RIAA. 'It includes a
number of things to strengthen the hand of law enforcement to
combat piracy. Intellectual property theft is a national
security crime. It's appropriate that the fed dedicate
resources to deter and prosecute IP theft.'

Against the bill stand a number of technology lobbying groups
and public-interest organizations. '[IPPA] is a cobbled-
together package to which Congress has given inadequate
attention. It is another step in Hollywood and the recording
industry's campaign to exert more control over content,' says
Gigi Sohn, president of Public Knowledge, a Washington, DC-
based public interest group that aims to alert the public to
fair use and consumer rights infringements, and fight those
perceived infringements in Washington.

Anyone attuned to the machinations of Congress the last two
years likely has become numb to the often overblown rhetoric
on this issue. Both sides use hyperbole-usually in the form of
calling a piece of legislation the death of an industry or the
death of individual rights. The 1982 statement to a
congressional committee by Jack Valenti, then head of the
MPAA, that the VCR is to Hollywood what the Boston Strangler
was to a woman alone still stands as the ne plus ultra of
exaggerated claims. And civil libertarians haven't met an
affront that didn't equal a stake through the heart of
individual rights. But IPPA demands attention not just from
Hill watchers, but from regular individuals. In part because
IPPA is such a broad, encompassing bill that could affect
things as pedestrian as fast-forwarding a commercial, but also
because with Senator Orrin Hatch-a very Hollywood-friendly
pol-on his way out as the chair of the Senate Judiciary
Committee, to be replaced possibly by Arlen Specter, many in
the Hollywood community see this as an important, last chance
to get their demands made into law.

[Eric Hellweg is a technology writer based in Cambridge, MA.]

Copyright 2004 Technology Review, Inc. All rights

[For additional information about this legislation, see <
http://www.publicknowledge.org/issues/hr2391> -- moderator]




------------------------------



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"There are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, 
i.e. the voice of conscience even though such obedience may cost many a 
bitter tear, and even more, separation from friends, from family, from the 
state to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life 
itself. For this obedience is the law of our being."
   Gandhi

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WEP Cracking

Alternately, you could get an antenna for your wireless network
adapter and try and find an open network; a full-power 100 mW (dude,
that's BUMPIN for unlicensed microwave radio) adapter (might I
recommend the OriNOCO Gold :-p) would also be helpful cracking a WEP
key requires a little more effort than is sometimes believed.  Check
out http://www.oreillynet.com/cs/user/view/cs_msg/26023 for more info.
 When they say WEP is insecure, they mean from governments and large
corporations with vast resources at their behest; on a smaller scale,
it's a somewhat reasonable solution.  It just seems a bit silly to
spend more time and effort to do something illegal when you can use an
open AP risk free.

wardriving is grate!

Just my $.02,

jonathan

Subject: Re: [sfraves] WEP Cracking

get a live linux cd like PHLAK. simply pop it into your cdrom drive,
and you boot into linux (it doesn't touch anything on your system...
you simply have a full running copy of linux after a couple minutes of
booting), and you will have all the tools like ethereal and airsnort
ready to go. even if you are not a linux person, you should be able to
figue it out, at least after reading a couple tutorials somewhere.
doing wep cracking through windows is a pain.

2tall

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) The election was fixed (a long time ago) - over 98% of House members reelected again!

--Apple-Mail-2-496842664
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	format=flowed

	Amid the controversy over whether there was organized fraud in =
the=20
recent election, few people seem to notice that on a bigger scale, the=20=

fix was in a long time ago. And it has benefitted both Republican and=20
Democrat insiders at the expense of anyone who might challenge their=20
reign in office. When over 98% of House members win reelection FOUR=20
TIMES IN A ROW, it's obvious that the system is rigged to benefit=20
current officeholders. And unlike the possibility of a stolen=20
presidential election, we KNOW this is happening. It's being done right=20=

in plain view, all perfectly legal.

	So what can we do? Support term limits and vote against =
incumbents!=20
And don't support the Republican OR Democrat parties or their=20
candidates, because they're both responsible for this destruction of=20
democracy. It's not too late to fight back and help politicians "just=20
say no" to power addiction. Let's rotate their sorry asses out of=20
office and get some new talent in there. Vote Libertarian for a change=20=

-- http://www.lp.org.

Fight the power!
					<<< Starchild >>>


Once Again, Incumbents Are the Big Winners
Sunday, November  21, 2004

By Patrick Basham and John Samples

Election Day 2004 showed the power of incumbency in American politics.=20=

For the fourth time in row, incumbents in the House of Representatives=20=

won over 98 percent of their races.

And not only are they winning consistently, but they=92re doing so by=20
increasingly wider margins; incumbency now adds about 11 percent to the=20=

vote share of the average officeholder. The past three elections=20
constituted the least competitive elections (with one exception) since=20=

1946.

Some observers might argue that the overwhelming success of incumbents=20=

should not worry Americans. Voters, they say, are satisfied with their=20=

representatives. Perhaps that=92s true, but we suspect something else is=20=

at work: Incumbents have given themselves too many advantages in the=20
electoral game.

The congressional franking privilege allows incumbents to flood their=20
districts with mail that often is little more than taxpayer-funded=20
campaign literature. Large administrative and political staffs on=20
Capitol Hill and in district offices attend to the needs of voters, all=20=

the while stressing the qualities of their bosses.

Incumbents also receive taxpayer-subsidized travel, easy access to the=20=

media and, most recently, web sites to communicate with the electorate.=20=

And they have the power to deliver pork barrel spending to their=20
districts. The limits on all of those advantages are set by their=20
beneficiaries=97 the Congress members themselves.

Against those advantages, it is difficult for a challenger to oust an=20
incumbent without spending at least as much as, and probably more than,=20=

the incumbent. Only by spending large sums on television advertising,=20
direct mail solicitations and grassroots organization can a challenger=20=

develop the levels of name recognition, issue identification and voter=20=

mobilization to catch up with the years (and frequently decades) of=20
subsidized campaigning and pork barrel spending that so characterize an=20=

incumbent=92s term in office.

And the incumbents=92 advantages are growing.

Thirty years ago, in the wake of Watergate, Congress imposed=20
restrictions on campaign contributions. The more recent McCain-Feingold=20=

legislation has set that limit at $2,000 for a congressional candidate.=20=

Under the rhetorical guise of warding off unspecified corruption, an=20
incumbent is happy to cap contributions at $2,000 per contributor if=20
his challenger must operate under the same limit.

Certainly, an incumbent may detest the phone calls he has to make to=20
potential donors and the fundraising breakfasts, lunches and dinners he=20=

has to attend. But at night he sleeps well in the knowledge that his=20
challenger back home must do the same (more, if the challenger is=20
serious about winning) without, in most cases, a comparable network of=20=

contacts, donors and lobbyists whose longstanding collective investment=20=

in the incumbent=92s career ensures continuing financial commitment.

The difficulties of raising money have made it harder for challengers=20
to beat incumbents. They have also discouraged qualified, successful=20
people from putting themselves forward as candidates in the first=20
place, thereby reducing the quality of the pool of potential=20
challengers. So it should not surprise us that in this era of increased=20=

restrictions on campaign finance, there is also increasing electoral=20
success for incumbents.

Political gerrymandering has also helped incumbents. More and more=20
House districts have become safe for Democrats or Republicans thanks to=20=

redistricting by state legislatures. In nearly a third of this year=92s=20=

House races, the winning candidate (i.e., the incumbent) was either=20
unopposed or faced an opponent without campaign funds.

The public understands the electoral game is fixed. A Rasmussen poll=20
found 72 percent of Americans agreed with the statement that, =93In=20
American elections, members of Congress have unfair advantages over=20
people who want to run against them.=94

American elections do have competition between the political parties.=20
After all, the Democrats could win back the House and Senate in 2006.=20
What we lack is competition between insiders and outsiders. No one can=20=

seriously believe even 10 percent of incumbents will lose in 2006. This=20=

lack of competitive congressional elections is a direct consequence of=20=

public subsidy.

In the Federalist Papers, James Madison wrote that the House of=20
Representatives was a =93numerous and changeable body=94 that would most=20=

directly reflect the shifting popular will. These days, changes in the=20=

House are the rare exception rather than the democratic rule.=20
Representative democracy works best when voters have choices and=20
competition for office. Americans have too little of both now.

John Samples is director of the Center for Representative Democracy at=20=

the Cato Institute. Patrick Basham is a senior fellow in the Center.=20=

--Apple-Mail-2-496842664--
