Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Hugger-Mugger Tonight

Hey freaks,

Come tie one on and get your weekly dose of techno, house, electro, dub,
ghetto-tech, IDM, schaffelpunk, glitch rock, cyber polka, gloomcore,
hard waltz and acid pop. This week's guests:

The Fresh Blend (SODA)
<http://www.freshblend.com/>

Matt Laszuk has been DJing for well over a decade, and he's been a
staple at the Rx Gallery since day one. His influences include
industrial, classic hardcore, detroit techno, IDM and drum and bass.
Check his site for some great mixes!

Philip Sherburne (SODA, XLR8R)
<http://www.philipsherburne.com/>

Philip is a globally recognized writer and reviewer for XLR8R, and a
long list of other publications. He's an accomplished essayist, a
compulsive music collector with practically unrivaled access to cutting
edge shit, a skillful DJ, and an incredibly nice guy to boot.

(UPDATE: just heard from Philip that he's going to be running a little
late due to a family emergency. Fear not though, we'll try to get him
into the rotation before the night is through!)

w/residential support from: Shazbot + AndyW.

Hugger-Mugger takes place every fucking Tuesday!

Lit Lounge
6th @ Mission, SF
9-2am, 21+, free

w/residents: AndyW, Clairity, Forest Green, Li, Juan Segovia, and
Shazbot.

<http://tech-on.com/huggermugger.html>

Toodles,

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Lycos search engine promoting screensaver that fights spam

Well, its homepage is overloaded so I can see the details, but I check
an article on The Register.

http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/11/26/lycos_europe_spam_blitz/

Apparently the screensaver will only attempt to do a large # of  HTTP
requests (rather than ICMP or NBT type packets frequently associated
with DDoS attacks), it only aims to disrupt the servers, rather than
bringing them to a halt.

This is very borderline illegal stuff. What if the law changes in your
juridiction? What if good servers get targeted? (This thing use source
data from SpamCop, which is infamous for being overly aggressive and
its blocklist frequently block legitimate emails. See
http://jhoward.fastmail.fm/spamcop.html )  What about the other good
people who buy hosting space from the same webserver?

Worse yet.... What if the program itself gets exploited by someone
else and turns into  spambots or DDoSbots for other people?

What I see of this little app is a piece of feel-good software that
makes you feel like doing something good, but in reality does little
to achieve its goals and may cause a lot of collateral damages along
the way. It's like those "this poor 10-yr cancer patient gets $0.02
for every forward" chain mail.

What I think this is really about? Lycos trying to lurk you to install
their screensaver, so they can ***display their ads*** on your screen
when your computer is not active.

- Jeff



There are real solutions like Yahoo's DomainKeys, or we can all begin
to adopt digital signatures like PGP and S/MIME. The internet email
protocols are very insecure and outdated, that's why it gets
exploited. Spam is only one of its many problems.

- Jeff

On 30 November 2004, Jeffrey Chan wrote:

> Well, its homepage is overloaded so I can see the details, but I check
> an article on The Register.
>
> http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/11/26/lycos_europe_spam_blitz/
>
> Apparently the screensaver will only attempt to do a large # of  HTTP
> requests (rather than ICMP or NBT type packets frequently associated
> with DDoS attacks), it only aims to disrupt the servers, rather than
> bringing them to a halt.

I think the aim is simply to eat up bandwidth.  I believe it has some
built in throttling to avoid bringing the server to it's knees.

>
> This is very borderline illegal stuff. What if the law changes in your
> juridiction? What if good servers get targeted? (This thing use source
> data from SpamCop, which is infamous for being overly aggressive and
> its blocklist frequently block legitimate emails. See
> http://jhoward.fastmail.fm/spamcop.html )  What about the other good
> people who buy hosting space from the same webserver?

What about a low-tech way to do even more damage from your pc than if
you were using the program: go to the "victim's" website, prop a little
something with weight on the F5 key and head out to grab a bite to
eat.... :)

>
> Worse yet.... What if the program itself gets exploited by someone
> else and turns into  spambots or DDoSbots for other people?
>
> What I see of this little app is a piece of feel-good software that
> makes you feel like doing something good, but in reality does little
> to achieve its goals and may cause a lot of collateral damages along
> the way. It's like those "this poor 10-yr cancer patient gets $0.02
> for every forward" chain mail.
>
> What I think this is really about? Lycos trying to lurk you to install
> their screensaver, so they can ***display their ads*** on your screen
> when your computer is not active.

Well, I don't believe I've seend ads (yet.)  And if the targeting aspect
is less severe than you make it out to be, I have no problem with it.

>
> - Jeff
